laws.title: Papal Crusade Bull Inter Cetera Divinae
laws.summary: Pope Martin V proclaims a plenary crusade against the Kingdom of Granada, appointing Juan II of Castile as Supreme Commander with absolute authority over all crusading forces, granting indulgences to participants, and establishing the financial and spiritual framework for the completion of the Reconquista.
laws.full_text:
PAPAL BULL 
Inter Cetera Divinae Providentiae 
"Among the Things of Divine Providence" 
Issued by His Holiness Pope Martin V 
August 1, in the Year of Our Lord 1430 
Thirteenth Year of Our Pontificate 
Preamble 
MARTIN, BISHOP, SERVANT OF THE SERVANTS OF GOD 
To Our beloved son in Christ, JUAN, by the Grace of God King of Castile and LeÔn, and to all the faithful of Christ 
who shall read these letters: Greeting and Apostolic Blessing. 
Among the things of Divine Providence which govern the affairs of men, We recognize with profound gratitude those 
moments when the Holy Spirit moves hearts toward complete submission to God's will and the service of Holy Church. 
Such a moment has been granted to Us, and through Us, to all Christendom. 
Our beloved son Juan, King of Castile and Leon, having completed pilgrimage to the shrine of Blessed James at 
Compostela, did present himselfbefore Us in Our city of Rome with such profound demonstration of faith and humility 
as We have rarely witnessed in Our long service to Holy Church. 
In Our presence, this young king did strip himself of crown, wealth, and worldly garments, offering his very person and 
kingdom to God's service through the ministry of the Apostolic See. By this act of complete renunciation and offering, he 
has shown himselfworthy to be called a true soldier of Christ and a faithful son of the Church. 
Moved by the Holy Spirit and recognizing the sincere faith of this Our son, and considering the great work yet undone in 
the Iberian lands where the Crescent still holds sway over territories that rightfully belong to the Cross, We have 
determined to grant those favors and authorities herein described. 
Article I: Proclamation of Crusade 
BY THE AUTHORITY OF ALMIGHTY GOD, 0f the Blessed Aposties Peter and Paul, and by Our own authority as 
Vicar 0f Christ on Earth, WE DO HEREBY PROCLAIM AND DECREE: 
A plenary and universal CRUSADE against the Moorish Kingdom of Granada, for the recovery of Christian lands 
unjustly held, for the liberation of souls dwelling in the darkness of false belief, and for the completion of that sacred 
Reconquista begun by the faithful kings of Spain in ages past. 
This Crusade is declared to be a work of supreme spiritual merit, undertaken not for earthly gain but for the greater glory 
of God and the salvation of souls. All who participate with pure hearts shall be accounted among the blessed warriors of 
Christ. 
Article II: Supreme Command 
WE DO APPOINT AND COMMISSION Our beloved son Juan, King 0f Castile and Leon, as SUPREME 
COMMANDER of this Holy Crusade, with full, complete, and exclusive authority over all military operations, strategic 
decisions, and temporal governance of crusading forces. 
This authority includes, without limitation: 
l. Command of All Forces: All Christian forces engaged in this Crusade, whether royal armies, feudal levies, forces 
of the Military Orders, foreign knights, or any other armed Christians, shall be under the sole command of King 
Juan. No lord, prince, master, or commander may refuse his lawful orders or pursue independent military action. 
2. Appointment and Dismissal: The Supreme Commander may appoint subordinate commanders, captains, and 
officers as he deems necessary for the prosecution of the Crusade, and may dismiss any such officers for cause. He 
may reorganize military structures as required for effective command. 
3. Strategic Authority: All decisions regarding campaigns, sieges, battles, truces, terms of surrender, and military 
strategy rest solely with the Supreme Commander. No council, assembly, or individual may override his military 
judgment. 
4. Discipline and Justice: The Supreme Commander has authority to maintain military discipline, to judge military 
offenses, and to punish violations of crusading vows or military orders according to canon law and the laws of war. 
Any Christian who refuses the lawful commands of the Supreme Commander in matters pertaining to this Crusade, or 
who pursues independent military action contrary to his orders, shall be subject to ecclesiastical censure including 
possible excommunication, and shall forfeit all crusading indulgences and privileges. 
Article III: The Military Orders 
The venerable Military Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcintara, founded for the defense of Christendom and 
the prosecution of holy war against the enemies of Christ, are hereby commanded and required to commit their full 
strength to this Crusade. 
WE DO DECREE: 
1. The Masters of these Orders shall place their forces under the Supreme Command of King Juan for the duration of 
this Crusade. 
2. The Orders shall provide knights, men-at-arms, supplies, and financial support as determined necessary by the 
Supreme Commander. 
3. The Orders retain their internal discipline and religious observances, but in all military matters they serve as 
integral components of the crusading army under unified command. 
4. Should any Master prove unworthy, disobedient, or unsuited to this holy work, We reserve the right to investigate 
and, if necessary, remove said Master and appoint a successor more fitting for the prosecution of God's work. 
The Military Orders are reminded that their original purpose was precisely this: to fight for the Cross against the 
Crescent. This Crusade returns them to their sacred founding mission. 
Article IV: Call to Christendom 
WE DO CALL UPON all faithful Christians, noble and common, clergy and laity, to support this holy endeavor 
according to their abilities: 
To Knights and Men-at-Arms: Take up the cross and join this sacred campaign. Your swords are needed for Christ's 
work. 
To Lords and Nobles: Provide men, supplies, and financial support. Lead your retinues in holy service. 
To Merchants and Craftsmen: Support the Crusade with your skills and resources. Just profit from supplying Christ's 
army carries no shame. 
To Clergy: Preach this Crusade, encourage the faithful, pray for victory, and accompany the armies as chaplains. 
To All the Faithful: Even those who cannot take the cross personally may support through prayer, alms, and financial 
contributions. 
Those who take the crusading vow commit themselves until the Kingdom of Granada is conquered and converted, or 
until the Supreme Commander releases them from their vows. This is not a seasonal campaign but a sustained effort that 
may require years of service. 
Article V: Indulgences and Privileges 
TO ALL WHO TAKE THE CROSS in this holy Crusade, we grant the following spiritual benefits and temporal 
protections: 
Spiritual Benefits: 
l. Plenary Indulgence: Full remission of temporal punishment due for all Sins properly confessed with sincere 
contrition. T his indulgence applies both to those who serve personally in the crusading army and to those who 
support the Crusade financially according to their means. 
2. Remission of Penances: All ecclesiastical penances imposed for past Sins are remitted for those who serve 
faithfully in this Crusade. 
3. Special Intercession: Daily prayers shall be offered in churches throughout Christendom for the success of this 
Crusade and for the souls of crusaders living and dead. 
4. Martyrdom: Those who die in the service ofthis Crusade, having confessed their Sins and received the 
sacraments, shall be accounted as martyrs for the faith, and We have every confidence that God shall receive their 
souls with mercy. 
Temporal Protections: 
l. Protection of Property: All property, lands, and goods of crusaders are placed under the protection of Iloly 
Church for the duration of their service. Any who unjustly seize crusader property during their absence shall be 
excommunicated. 
2. Suspension of Debts: Interest on debts owed by crusaders shall not accrue during their service. Creditors may not 
foreclose on crusader property during their absence. 
3. Legal Immunity: Legal proceedings against crusaders are suspended for the duration of their service, save for the 
most serious crimes against God and man. 
4. Safe Conduct: Crusaders traveling to and from the campaign are granted safe conduct through all Christian lands. 
Those who harm or impede crusaders in their travels shall face ecclesiastical censure. 
Article VI: Crusade Taxation 
To provide the necessary resources for this sacred undertaking, WE DO AUTHORIZE the following taxation: 
l. Church Revenues: All ecclesiastical properties, monasteries, bishoprics, and church foundations within the 
Kingdom of Castile shall contribute one-tenth of their annual revenues to the Crusade for its duration. 
2. Sale of Indulgences: Indulgences may be purchased by those unable to serve personally, with all proceeds directed 
to the Crusade treasury. These indulgences shall be sold at fair rates determined by the Papal Legate in 
consultation with the Supreme Commander. 
3. Special Tithes: The Supreme Commander may, with the approval of the Papal Legate, levy additional tithes on the 
realm as necessary to sustain the campaign, provided such taxation is not oppressive and is applied justly. 
4. Foreign Contributions: We call upon the faithful throughout Christendom to contribute financially to this 
Crusade. Collection boxes shall be placed in churches, and special appeals made for donations. 
All funds raised for this Crusade must be used for its stated purposes: military operations, supplies, payment of 
soldiers, care of wounded, and related expenses. Any who embezzle or misuse crusade funds shall be excommunicated 
and prosecuted to the fullest extent of canon law. 
Article VII: Papal Legate and Spiritual Oversight 
To ensure that this Crusade remains tme to its spiritual purposes and is conducted in accordance with Church teaching 
and canon law, WE SHALL AP POINT a Papal Legate to accompany the crusading forces. 
The duties of the Papal Legate include: 
1. Spiritual Guidance: Ensuring that the crusading army maintains proper spiritual discipline, receives regular 
sacraments, and conducts itself in a manner befitting soldiers of Christ. 
2. Prevention of Excesses: Monitoring military operations to prevent unnecessary cruelty, forced conversions at 
sword-point, desecration of holy places (even Muslim ones that may contain sacred objects), and other acts 
contrary to Church teaching. 
3. Pastoral Care: Hearing confessions, celebrating Mass, administering sacraments, providing spiritual counsel to 
crusaders, and attending to the spiritual needs of the army. 
4. Judgment of Spiritual Matters: Deciding questions of canon law, determining whether military actions comply 
with Church teaching on just war, and resolving disputes involving ecclesiastical jurisdiction. 
5. Communication with Rome: Reporting regularly to the Apostolic See on the progress of the Crusade, the conduct 
of forces, and any matters requiring papal attention. 
The Legate has no military command and may not override the Supreme Commander's decisions regarding military 
operations, strategy, or tactics. However, ifthe Legate believes a proposed action violates Church teaching or canon law, 
he must voice his concerns and may appeal to Us for guidance. 
The Supreme Commander and the Papal Legate are to work in cooperation, each respecting the other's sphere of 
authority. The military serves the spiritual purpose; the spiritual guides the military conduct. 
Article VIII: Treatment of Granada and lts People 
This Crusade is undertaken for the conversion of souls and the recovery of Christian territory, not for vengeance or 
worldly conquest alone. Therefore: 
l. Offer of Peaceful Conversion: Before military action, the rulers of Granada should be offered terms: Accept 
Christian baptism, submit to Castilian sovereignty, and receive protection of life and property. Those who convert 
willingly shall be welcomed as brothers in Christ. 
2. Protection of Converts: Any Muslim who accepts baptism, whether before or during the conquest, shall receive 
full protection of person, family, and reasonable property. Forced conversion at sword-point is forbidden. 
Conversion must be of the heart, even if circumstances encourage it. 
3. Treatment of the Conquered: When cities or fortresses are taken, unnecessary slaughter is forbidden. Women, 
children, the elderly, and non-combatants should be protected from harm. The laws of war as understood by 
Church teaching must be observed. 
4. Disposition of Property: Conquered lands become the property of the Crown of Castile to be distributed as the 
King deems appropriate. However, properties of churches, monasteries, and religious foundations (even if 
currently Muslim) should be preserved where possible for conversion to Christian use. 
5. The Ultimate Goal: The goal is not to create a realm of resentful false converts, but to bring the light of Christ to 
Granada through a combination of military necessity, political wisdom, and genuine evangelization. The sword 
opens the door; the Gospel must enter through it. 
Article IX: Vatican Support 
From the resources 0f the Apostolic see, WE DO PROVIDE: 
l. Financial Support: Twenty thousand florins from the papal treasury as immediate seed funding for this Crusade. 
2. Sacred Relics: A fragment of the True Cross and a bone of Saint James (Santiago) himself, to be carried with the 
crusading army as signs of divine favor and protection. 
3. Letters to Christian Monarchs: We shall write to the kings of France, England, Portugal, Aragon, Navarre, and 
other Christian realms, endorsing this Crusade and requesting their support or at minimum their non-interference. 
4. Diplomatic Pressure: We shall communicate with King Alfonso V of Aragon, making clear that the Church 
expects the Crown of Aragon to support, not hinder, this holy work. The Infantes de Aragon residing in Castile 
should align themselves with this Crusade rather than pursuing factional interests. 
5. Prayers and Masses: Special prayers for the success ofthis Crusade shall be said throughout Christendom. We 
Ourselves shall continue to pray daily for King Juan and for the conversion of Granada. 
Article X: Duration and Conclusion 
This Crusade is declared until the Kingdom of Granada is fully conquered and its conversion to Christianity is 
secured, or until We or Our successors determine that the objective has been achieved or should be modified. 
Victory shall be marked by: 
The fall of Granada's capital and submission of its rulers 
The conversion of its mosques to churches 
The establishment of Christian governance throughout the territory 
A population either converted to Christianity or living peacefully under Christian rule 
The celebration of a Te Deum in the Great Mosque of Granada, rededicated as a cathedral 
Upon achieving these goals, the Supreme Commander may petition Us or Our successor for formal conclusion of the 
Crusade and release of all crusading vows. 
Conclusion and Exhortation 
We have witnessed in Our own presence a young king who offered everything - crown, wealth, even the very clothes 
upon his back - in service to God. This act of profound humility and complete submission moves Us to grant this bull 
with confidence that it shall be used not for worldly ambition but for God's glory. 
To Juan, King of Castile: Remember always the moment you knelt before Us. Let the inscription on your father's sword 
guide you: Non Nobis Domine - Not unto us, O Lord. Victory, if it comes, belongs to God alone. 
To all who participate: You are soldiers of Christ, not mere warriors seeking plunder. Fight with courage but also with 
mercy. Be as fierce as lions against God's enemies, but as gentle as lambs toward those who seek baptism and peace. 
To the faithful everywhere: Support this holy work with your prayers, your alms, and your service. The Reconquista, 
begun centuries ago, may in our time be completed. That would be a blessing beyond measure. 
May Almighty God, in whose name this Crusade is undertaken, grant victory to Christian arms, conversion to Muslim 
hearts, and glory to His holy name. 
Given at Rome, at Saint Peter's, in the year of the Incarnation of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty, 
on the first day of August, in the thirteenth year of Our Pontificate. 
Attestation 
We, Martin, by Divine Providence Pope, have signed this bull with Our own hand and ordered that it be sealed 
with the Fisherman's Ring and the leaden seal of the Apostolic See. 
Witnessed by: 
Giordano Cardinal Orsini, Cardinal-Deacon of San Giorgio in Velabro 
• Paolo Caraffa, Chamberlain of the Apostolic Palace 
• Multiple other curial officials 
[SPACE FOR PAPAL SEALI 
The great leaden seal (bulla) of Pope Martin V, bearing on one side the images of Saints Peter and Paul, and on the 
other the Pope's name, is affixed here by red and yellow Silk cords. 
Addendum: Special Provisions 
Regarding the White Garments: We note and bless King Juan's intention to wear white garments as symbol of his 
renunciation and service. Let these garments remain unstained by pride but bear honestly the stains of service - mud, 
blood, and dust of the campaign. T his is fitting and proper. 
Regarding Future Correspondence: King Juan may write to Us at any time seeking guidance, reporting progress, or 
requesting interpretation of this bull's provisions. We remain his father in Christ, ready to counsel and support him. 
Regarding Modifications: Should circumstances require modification of these terms, such changes may be made only 
by Us or Our successors, after consultation with the Supreme Commander and the Papal Legate. 
Deo Gratias 
END OF BULL

laws.title: Papal Decree Fidei Defensio et Corona Triumphans
laws.summary: Pope Eugenius IV releases Juan II from his crusade oath with highest honours, grants the Military Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara to the Crown of Castile in perpetuity, endorses Alfonso V's claim to Naples, and authorizes Juan to speak at Basel with papal confidence.
laws.full_text:
PAPAL DECREE OF POPE EUGENIUS IV
Fidei Defensio et Corona Triumphans
"Defense of the Faith and the Triumphant Crown"

Issued at Rome, in the Palace of St. Peter  
The Twenty-Fourth Day of April, in the Year of Our Lord 1433  
In the Third Year of Our Pontificate

EUGENIUS, BISHOP, SERVANT OF THE SERVANTS OF GOD

To all the faithful of Christ who shall read or hear these present letters, greeting and apostolic benediction.

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS the designs of Divine Providence are made manifest in the deeds of faithful princes who serve Christ with pure hearts and humble submission to Holy Mother Church;

AND WHEREAS our beloved son in Christ, Juan II, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, having received from our venerable predecessor Pope Martin V of blessed memory a crusade bull entitled Inter Cetera Divinae in the year of Our Lord 1430;

AND WHEREAS the said King Juan, with exemplary fidelity and unwavering devotion to the Holy See, has accomplished that which seven centuries of Christian princes attempted but could not complete - namely, the reconquest of the lands held by the infidel Moors and the restoration of the Emirate of Granada to Christian rule;

AND WHEREAS this same King has returned to Rome bearing the sacred relics entrusted to him - the fragment of the True Cross upon which Our Savior suffered, and the blessed bone of Saint James the Apostle - together with the crusade treasury complete and accounted for with scrupulous honesty;

AND WHEREAS his fidelity to papal authority, his purity of faith, and his completion of the holy crusade stand as testimony to all Christian princes of what can be accomplished when royal power submits to apostolic guidance;

NOW THEREFORE, We, Eugenius IV, Supreme Pontiff of the Holy Roman Church, by the authority of Almighty God, the Blessed Apostles Peter and Paul, and our own, do hereby decree and proclaim the following to be observed by all the faithful:

ARTICLE THE FIRST
Release from Crusade Oath with Highest Honors

BE IT KNOWN that His Majesty King Juan II of Castile is hereby released from his crusade oath with the highest honors that the Church can bestow upon a Christian monarch. His service to Christ and His Church stands complete, perfected, and accomplished beyond all expectation.

Let it be proclaimed throughout Christendom that the Reconquista, which began at Covadonga in the year 722, is now finished. The seven hundred and ten years of struggle end in glory. Granada is Christian. The infidel power in Iberia is broken. The cross of Christ flies where once the crescent stood.

This was accomplished under papal authority, through crusade bull lawfully granted and faithfully executed. Let all Christian kings observe: when royal power submits to apostolic guidance with pure faith and humble obedience, God grants victory.

ARTICLE THE SECOND
Perpetual Grant of the Military Orders

BY VIRTUE of the apostolic authority vested in Us, and in recognition of the extraordinary service rendered to Christendom by the completion of the Reconquista, We do hereby grant to His Majesty King Juan II of Castile, and to all his legitimate successors on the throne of Castile, perpetual and permanent control over the Military Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara.

This grant is made in perpetuity and shall bind all future Successors of Peter. No pope may revoke this grant. The Military Orders, having served faithfully in the completion of the Reconquista, shall henceforth serve under royal authority as befits the realm that completed God's work in Iberia.

The Masters of these Orders shall be appointed by the Crown of Castile. Their revenues, their fortresses, their knights, and all their properties shall be administered under royal direction for the defense of Christendom and the continued crusading mission that the completion of the Reconquista now makes possible beyond Iberia's shores.

Let this be recorded in perpetuity: The crown that finished the Reconquista governs the Orders that fought for it.

ARTICLE THE THIRD
Support for the Kingdom of Naples

WE DO HEREBY proclaim our support for the just claim of our beloved son in Christ, Alfonso V, by the Grace of God King of Aragón, Sicily, Valencia, and Sardinia, to the Kingdom of Naples against all challengers.

The claim of King Alfonso is founded in justice and legitimacy. We reject and declare invalid any competing claims that contradict the lawful rights of the Crown of Aragón to said kingdom.

We shall write to all Christian monarchs explaining the justice of this claim and urging their recognition and support. We call upon all faithful princes to support King Alfonso's lawful right to Naples and to reject the claims of those who would dispute his inheritance.

This support is given in recognition of the alliance between Castile and Aragón, both of which have served the Church faithfully, and in acknowledgment that the consolidation of Christian power in the Mediterranean serves the greater cause of defending Christendom against the Turkish threat.

ARTICLE THE FOURTH
Apostolic Confidence in the King's Mission

BE IT KNOWN that when His Majesty King Juan II travels to the Council of Basel to witness its proceedings and to address the assembled fathers, he does so with Our apostolic blessing and carries Our complete confidence.

His delegation to Basel has argued matters of theology and church reform with wisdom, distinguishing themselves by their commitment to genuine reform while maintaining fidelity to apostolic authority. Their contribution to the Council's deliberations has been noted and valued.

When His Majesty himself attends the Council, let all present understand that he speaks not merely as a foreign monarch but as one whom God has manifestly blessed through the completion of the Reconquista. His witness to what papal authority can accomplish when exercised righteously and obeyed faithfully is testimony that the Council fathers must hear.

We do not send him to command the Council - for councils have their proper authority in matters of reform and doctrine. Rather, We send him to remind the assembled fathers what their debates truly concern: not the mere distribution of power between pope and council, but the salvation of souls and the defense of Christendom.

ARTICLE THE FIFTH
Alliance of Faith Between Rome and Castile

FINALLY, let it be known throughout Christendom that We have formed an alliance with the Crown of Castile, founded not in temporal politics but in shared faith and common devotion to the defense of Holy Mother Church.

For three years We have labored under great burdens - theological disputes with the Council of Basel, military threats to the Papal States, divisions within Rome itself. In this hour of trial, God has sent us an ally whose faithfulness to the Church is proven not by words but by deeds.

The completion of the Reconquista under papal authority stands as answer to those who claim papal authority has failed, that councils must be supreme over popes, that the Church can no longer accomplish great works. Granada proves otherwise.

Castile stands with Rome. Rome stands with Castile. This alliance is forged in faith, strengthened by shared devotion to Christ, and dedicated to the defense and reform of the Church that both pope and faithful king love and serve.

Let all who threaten the Church understand: Castile's swords defend not merely Iberian territory but the very institution of Christ's Church. Let all who seek authentic reform understand: Castile's example shows that reform need not come through rebellion against apostolic authority but through faithful cooperation with it.

PROMULGATION AND EXECUTION

THESE DECREES are promulgated this day with the full authority of the Apostolic See. They are to be published throughout Christendom, recorded in the archives of the Holy See, and observed by all the faithful.

We command that copies of this decree be sent to all Christian monarchs, to the Council of Basel, to all archbishops and bishops, and to all cathedral chapters and monasteries, that all may know what God has accomplished through the faithful service of King Juan II of Castile.

We further decree that this document shall be sealed with the Fisherman's Ring and attested by the signatures of the cardinals present at its promulgation, that all may know it carries the full weight of apostolic authority.

CONCLUSION

LET THE BELLS of Christendom ring in thanksgiving for the completion of the Reconquista. Let prayers of gratitude rise to Heaven for the victory God has granted. Let all Christian princes learn from the example of Castile what can be accomplished when royal power submits to apostolic guidance with pure faith.

And let all who labor for the reform and defense of Holy Mother Church take heart: God has not abandoned His Church. The completion of seven centuries of crusade proves that when We act with pure faith and humble submission to Divine Will, God grants victory.

Deus Vult. Christus Vincit. Christus Regnat. Christus Imperat.

Given at Rome, at St. Peter's, under the Fisherman's Ring, the twenty-fourth day of April, in the year of the Incarnation of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-three, in the third year of Our Pontificate.

ATTESTATIONS

+ EUGENIUS PP. IV  
Episcopus, Servus Servorum Dei

+ GIORDANO Cardinal ORSINI  
Cardinal-Priest of San Clemente

+ ANTONIO Cardinal CORRER  
Cardinal-Priest of San Lorenzo in Damaso

+ PROSPERO Cardinal COLONNA  
Cardinal-Deacon of San Giorgio in Velabro

+ GIOVANNI Cardinal BERARDI  
Cardinal-Priest of Santa Anastasia

[Twenty-three cardinals' signatures follow]

NOTARIAL CERTIFICATION

I, Bartolomeo Carrera, Bishop and Apostolic Notary, do hereby certify that this decree was promulgated in my presence in the Palace of St. Peter on the date above written, that the Holy Father Pope Eugenius IV did speak the words herein recorded, and that the cardinals named did attest to its authenticity with their signatures and seals.

In witness whereof I have set my hand and seal this twenty-fourth day of April, Anno Domini 1433.

+ Bartolomeo Carrera  
Episcopus et Notarius Apostolicus

SEALED with the Fisherman's Ring  
DATED at Rome, April 24, 1433  
WITNESSED by twenty-three Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church

Laus Deo

laws.title: Declaration of Como
laws.summary: Joint declaration by Emperor Sigismund and King Juan II establishing their common position on church reform, demanding an end to pluralism and absenteeism, asserting the necessity of both conciliar authority and papal dignity, and committing to the defense of Constantinople against the Ottoman threat.
laws.full_text:
THE DECLARATION OF COMO
On the Unity and Reform of Holy Mother Church

Signed at Como, in the Duchy of Milan
The 7th day of June, in the Year of Our Lord 1433

DECLARATIO CONIUNCTA

Of His Imperial Majesty Sigismund, by the Grace of God King of the Romans, Ever Augustus, King of Hungary, Bohemia, Dalmatia, Croatia, etc., and His Most Christian Majesty Juan II, by the Grace of God King of Castile, León, Toledo, Galicia, Seville, Córdoba, Murcia, Jaén, the Algarve, Algeciras, Gibraltar, and Lord of Vizcaya and Molina

IN NOMINE DOMINI. AMEN.

We, Sigismund and Juan, servants of Christ and guardians of Christian peoples, speaking with one voice and one purpose, do hereby declare our common position on matters touching the unity and reform of Holy Mother Church.

We speak not as adversaries of the Holy Father, nor as partisans of any faction, but as Christian rulers who bear solemn responsibility before God for the souls entrusted to our care. We have witnessed with great sorrow the divisions that afflict the Body of Christ. We have seen Pope and Council set against one another while the enemies of the Faith press upon our borders. We have watched heresy flourish where corruption has sown its seeds.

We declare that this cannot continue.

The unity of the Church is not a matter for factional victory. It is the foundation upon which all Christendom rests. Without unity, there can be no crusade against the Ottoman. Without reform, there can be no reconciliation with those who have strayed. Without both unity and reform together, the Church our Lord founded upon the rock of Peter shall be broken against the rocks of pride and greed.

Therefore, we set forth our position on these matters:

ARTICLE I: On the Reform of Pluralism and Absenteeism

We support fully the decrees of the Sacred Council of Basel regarding the holding of multiple benefices. The practice whereby a single cleric holds three, four, or more bishoprics—visiting none, caring for none, collecting revenue from all—is an offense against God and a scandal to the faithful.

We declare: One man shall hold one major benefice, exceptions to be granted only by papal dispensation for genuine pastoral necessity, not for the enrichment of the already wealthy.

ARTICLE II: On the Reform of Episcopal Elections

We support the restoration of genuine electoral rights to cathedral chapters, ending the abuse of papal provisions and reservations whereby the Holy See appoints bishops directly, bypassing those who know best the needs of their churches.

We declare: Cathedral chapters shall elect their bishops freely, with Rome confirming those canonically elected. The ancient practice of provision and reservation shall be curtailed except in cases of genuine necessity.

Furthermore: We acknowledge that certain episcopal sees—most notably the archbishoprics of Mainz, Trier, and Cologne within the Holy Roman Empire—carry responsibilities beyond the purely spiritual. These prince-electors hold offices essential to the governance of Christian peoples. Candidates for such positions should demonstrate qualifications for both their spiritual duties and their temporal functions, in accordance with privileges confirmed at the Council of Constance and ancient custom. This recognition of dual responsibility shall not diminish the reform of elections, but shall acknowledge the reality of these unique offices.

ARTICLE III: On the Reform of Annates and Papal Taxation

We acknowledge that the Holy See requires revenue to fulfill its sacred mission. We do not seek to impoverish Rome, but to end the abuses that have made papal taxation a byword for corruption throughout Christendom.

We declare: Annates shall not exceed one-quarter of the first year's revenue of any benefice. This cap shall be absolute and shall apply to all payments made upon receiving ecclesiastical office.

Furthermore: The Apostolic Camera shall retain authority for assessing the value of benefices, but shall exercise this authority with transparency and accountability. Valuations shall be published and made available to those assessed. Any cleric who believes his benefice has been unfairly valued shall have right of appeal to a neutral body. Assessments shall be reviewed at regular intervals to ensure they reflect true values, not arbitrary impositions.

ARTICLE IV: On Institutional Accountability

The Church, like all institutions of men, is subject to the corruption that flows from human sin. Where corruption takes root, it must be exposed and corrected. Yet who shall correct the correctors? Who shall hold accountable those who hold others accountable?

We declare: There shall be established a standing commission for the oversight of Church institutions, appointed jointly by the Holy Father and the Sacred Council during sessions of the Council, and continuing its work between sessions. This commission shall have authority to investigate complaints of corruption, to audit the practices of Church offices including the Apostolic Camera, and to publish its findings for all Christendom to see.

This commission shall not possess authority to dismiss the Holy Father or to overrule papal decisions. It shall not claim supremacy over any office of the Church. Its power shall be the power of sunlight—to expose what is hidden, to name what is corrupt, to document what has been denied. Let shame accomplish what legal authority cannot, until such time as the Church is prepared for stronger medicine.

ARTICLE V: On the Reconciliation of Bohemia

For thirty-five years, Christian has slain Christian in the lands of Bohemia. Five crusades have failed. Tens of thousands have perished. And still the war continues, draining the strength of Christendom while the Ottoman masses his forces in the East.

We declare: This war must end. Not through the extermination of the Bohemian people, but through genuine reconciliation.

The moderate Hussites—those called Utraquists—seek not to destroy the Church but to reform it. Their central demand, communion under both kinds for the laity, touches no essential doctrine. The Council of Constance declared that Christ is entirely present in the bread alone; the granting of the cup to the laity therefore deprives them of nothing they do not already receive.

We support the negotiations presently underway at Basel to grant communion in both kinds to the faithful of Bohemia and Moravia, as a pastoral accommodation that preserves doctrine while ending bloodshed. We call upon all parties to embrace this reconciliation in good faith, that the wound in the Body of Christ may finally be healed.

ARTICLE VI: On Our Common Commitment

We, Sigismund and Juan, do hereby pledge to coordinate our efforts in support of these reforms. We shall encourage their adoption by all Christian princes. We shall work toward Church unity through genuine reform rather than factional victory.

We take this position not from hostility to the Holy Father, whom we recognize as Vicar of Christ and head of the Church on earth, but from the conviction that unity without reform is impossible, and reform without unity is meaningless.

The alternative to reform is schism. The alternative to unity is the destruction of everything our ancestors built and bled to defend. We cannot accept these alternatives. We will not accept them.

Therefore let it be known: The Emperor of the Romans and the King of Castile stand together in this cause. We speak with one voice. We shall not be divided. And we call upon all Christian rulers, all princes of the Church, and all faithful people to join us in demanding that the Church be reformed in head and members, that unity be preserved, and that Christendom be made ready to face the enemies who even now gather at our gates.

Given under our hands and seals at Como, in the Duchy of Milan, on this seventh day of June, in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-three.

Sigismundus Dei Gratia Romanorum Rex semper Augustus, Hungariae, Bohemiae, Dalmatiae, Croatiae Rex

[SEAL]

Ioannes Dei Gratia Rex Castellae, Legionis, Toleti, Galleciae, Hispalis, Cordubae, Murciae, Gienni, Algarbiae, Algecirae, Gibraltaris, ac Dominus Vizcaiae et Molinae

[SEAL]

Witnesses:

- Fray Hernando de Talavera, O.F.M., Confessor to His Majesty of Castile
- [Imperial Secretary]
- [Archbishop of Como or representative]

LETTER TO HIS HOLINESS POPE EUGENIUS IV

From His Imperial Majesty Sigismund and His Most Christian Majesty Juan II

Given at Como, the 7th day of June, 1433

To the Most Holy Father in Christ, Eugenius IV, by Divine Providence Supreme Pontiff of the Universal Church, from his devoted sons Sigismund, King of the Romans, and Juan, King of Castile, greeting and filial obedience.

Most Holy Father,

We write to Your Holiness jointly, a thing uncommon between rulers whose lands lie far apart, because the matter before us demands uncommon measures. The unity of Holy Mother Church—and with it the safety of all Christendom—stands in peril such as we have not seen since the dark days of the Great Schism.

We do not write as adversaries of Your Holiness. We write as sons of the Church who see our mother bleeding from wounds inflicted by her own children. We write as rulers who must answer to God for the souls in our care, and who cannot stand silent while the Body of Christ is torn asunder.

Most Holy Father, we beg you to hear us.

The Sacred Council of Basel has passed decrees of genuine reform—reforms that address corruptions long acknowledged, abuses long lamented, scandals long deplored. These reforms touch pluralism, whereby single clerics hold multiple benefices while the faithful go unshepherded. They touch simony, whereby sacred offices are bought and sold like goods in a marketplace. They touch the taxation that has made Rome a byword for extraction rather than sanctity.

We know that Your Holiness has been locked in dispute with the Council over questions of authority. We know that the specter of Haec Sancta haunts these proceedings—the question of whether councils stand above popes or popes above councils. We know that Your Holiness fears that accepting conciliar reforms means accepting conciliar supremacy.

We propose another path.

Your Holiness possesses full apostolic authority to reform the Church by your own decree. What the Council has passed, Your Holiness may pass independently—the same reforms, the same language, issued on your own initiative as Supreme Pontiff. In this way, the Church is reformed without any admission that councils may command popes. The substance is achieved; the principle is preserved.

We have enclosed with this letter a declaration of our common position on specific reforms. We ask Your Holiness to consider adopting these reforms by papal decree, demonstrating to all Christendom that the Holy Father leads the cause of reform rather than resisting it.

We ask this not as a demand, but as a plea.

The alternative is too terrible to contemplate. If Pope and Council cannot find common ground, schism becomes inevitable. Another generation of Christians killing Christians over who leads the Church while the Ottoman Sultan watches and waits. Another cycle of rival popes and competing obediences while heresy spreads unchecked.

His Majesty of Castile intends to visit Your Holiness in Rome following the safe delivery of his queen. He wishes to discuss these matters personally, to offer whatever assistance Castile can provide, and to demonstrate his devotion to Your Holiness and to the unity of the Church.

Until that happy day, we commend ourselves to Your Holiness's prayers and blessing. We remain, as ever, faithful sons of the Church and obedient servants of the Vicar of Christ.

May God guide Your Holiness in wisdom, and may the Holy Spirit bring peace to His Church.

Given under our hands at Como, the seventh day of June, in the year of Our Lord 1433.

Your Holiness's devoted sons in Christ,

Sigismundus Rex Romanorum

Ioannes Rex Castellae

LETTER TO THE CASTILIAN DELEGATION AT BASEL

From His Most Christian Majesty Juan II, King of Castile

Given at Como, the 7th day of June, 1433

To our beloved and faithful servants Abbott Rodrigo González, Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena, and the members of our royal delegation at the Sacred Council of Basel, greeting.

My faithful friends,

I write from Como, where by God's providence I have met with His Imperial Majesty Sigismund on his return from coronation in Rome. We have spoken at length—through an entire night—on the crisis facing the Church and on what we, as Christian rulers, might do to address it.

I am pleased to report that we have reached full agreement.

Enclosed with this letter you will find the Declaration of Como, a joint statement of our common position on Church reform, signed by both the Emperor and myself. You will also find a copy of our letter to His Holiness Pope Eugenius IV, which is being dispatched to Rome by imperial courier.

Your instructions are as follows:

First, make the Declaration known to Cardinal Cesarini and to our allies among the German moderates. The Emperor and I have committed to coordinating our efforts; our delegations should do the same. What the German delegation advocates, the Castilian delegation should support, and vice versa. We must present a united front.

Second, continue to advocate for the specific reforms outlined in the Declaration. These represent our firm position: limits on pluralism, restoration of chapter elections, caps on annates with Camera transparency, and the establishment of an oversight commission. On these matters, we do not bend.

Third, support the ongoing negotiations with the Bohemian delegation regarding communion in both kinds. The Emperor has made clear that Utraquist reconciliation is essential to ending thirty-five years of bloodshed. Castile stands with the Empire on this matter. Those who oppose accommodation with the moderate Hussites oppose the Emperor and oppose us.

Fourth, regarding Haec Sancta and the question of papal versus conciliar supremacy—maintain our position of neutrality. We support reform. We support unity. We do not take sides in the constitutional dispute. Our hope is that successful cooperation on reform will make the constitutional question less urgent, allowing both Pope and Council to save face while accomplishing what matters.

Fifth, keep me informed. Write regularly. If circumstances change—if the French faction moves against our position, if Cardinal Aleman attempts to force a vote on papal deposition, if anything threatens the fragile progress we have made—I must know immediately.

A personal word:

Fray Hernando returns with me to Castile and will accompany me on my subsequent journeys. Abbott Rodrigo and Bishop Alfonso, you bear the burden of representing Castile at Basel in my absence. I have complete confidence in your judgment and your faithfulness. The work you have done these eight months has earned Castile a reputation as a voice of reason in a council full of factions. Maintain that reputation. Build on it.

The Emperor departs for Basel within days. He will seek you out when he arrives. Receive him as you would receive me. We are allies now—more than allies. We are partners in a cause that transcends our individual kingdoms.

God grant you wisdom and strength. I will see you again when circumstances permit.

Given under my hand at Como, the seventh day of June, in the year of Our Lord 1433.

Your king and friend,

Juan

Post Scriptum: The seventeen crusaders who departed with the Byzantine delegation carry my blessing and my prayers. If word reaches Basel of their progress toward Constantinople, send it to me in Castile immediately. And tell the Greeks, if any remain at Basel, that Castile has not forgotten them. The thousand knights and sixty thousand florins are being assembled even now.

[END OF DOCUMENTS]

Drafted by Fray Hernando de Talavera, O.F.M.
Como, June 6-7, 1433

laws.title: Council of Basel Session 12: Electoral Reform Decree
laws.summary: The Council of Basel establishes comprehensive reform of papal elections, requiring conclaves to begin within ten days of a pope's death, limiting cardinal electors to a maximum of twenty-four, and instituting strict procedures to prevent simony and undue political influence in the selection of the Supreme Pontiff.
laws.full_text:
COUNCIL OF BASEL - SESSION 12
DECREE ON ELECTIONS AND CONFIRMATIONS OF BISHOPS AND PRELATES
Decretum de Electionibus et Confirmationibus Episcoporum et Praelatorum

Session 12 - July 13, 1433
Sessio XII - XIII Iulii MCDXXXIII

PART I: INTITULATIO & INVOCATIO

Latin Text

Sacrosancta generalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, ad perpetuam rei memoriam.

Haec sancta synodus, divina favente clementia, ad reformationem ecclesiae in capite et in membris congregata, omnibus Christi fidelibus tam praesentibus quam futuris, salutem in Domino sempiternam.

English Translation

The holy general synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, for an everlasting record.

This holy synod, assembled by divine favor for the reformation of the church in head and members, to all the faithful of Christ both present and future, eternal salvation in the Lord.

PART II: PREAMBLE & ARENGA - THEOLOGICAL JUSTIFICATION

Latin Text

Sicut in aedificando domo praecipua architecti cura est tale fundamentum ponere, ut super illud constructa fabrica maneat immobilis; sic in generali ecclesiae reformatione praecipua huius sanctae synodi sollicitudo est, ut pastores ecclesiae praeficiendi tales sint, qui quasi columnae et bases ecclesiam doctrina et meritis suis fortiter sustineant.

Nam quemadmodum domus super arenam aedificata facile ruit, sic ecclesia sub indignis pastoribus constituta in brevi corrumpitur. Unde scriptum est: "Si dominus non aedificaverit domum, in vanum laboraverunt qui aedificant eam."

Considerantes igitur, quod multae et gravissimae corruptelae in ecclesia Dei provenerunt ex pravis electionibus et indebitis provisionibus ad ecclesias cathedrales, metropolitanas, collegiatas et monasteria, per quas personae indignae et inhonestae ad regimen animarum assumebantur;

Et attendentes, quod haec mala maxime ex duabus causis processerunt: primo, ex generali reservatione, qua Romani pontifices sibi ipsis provisiones ad praedictas ecclesias reservaverunt; secundo, ex simoniacae pravitatis crimine, quo electiones et provisiones infectae fuerunt;

Volens igitur haec sancta synodus talibus malis providere et ecclesiam Dei in meliorato statu conservare, praesentem legem perpetuo valiturarn statuit et decernit:

English Translation

Just as in building a house the architect's chief concern is to lay such a foundation that the edifice built on it will endure immovable, so in the general reformation of the church the principal preoccupation of this holy synod is that the pastors set over the church may be such that, like pillars and bases, they will firmly uphold the church by the strength of their doctrine and merits.

For just as a house built on sand easily falls, so a church established under unworthy pastors is soon corrupted. Whence it is written: "Unless the Lord builds the house, in vain do they labor who build it."

Considering therefore that many and most serious corruptions in God's church have arisen from wicked elections and undue provisions to cathedral, metropolitan, collegiate churches and monasteries, by which unworthy and dishonest persons were assumed to the government of souls;

And noting that these evils proceeded chiefly from two causes: first, from the general reservation by which Roman pontiffs reserved to themselves provisions to the aforesaid churches; second, from the crime of simoniacal depravity by which elections and provisions were infected;

Willing therefore to provide for such evils and to preserve God's church in an improved state, this holy synod establishes and decrees the present law to be valid in perpetuity:

PART III: NARRATIO - HISTORICAL CIRCUMSTANCES

Latin Text

Cum olim per sacrorum canonum instituta, electiones ad ecclesias cathedrales et metropolitanas, necnon ad monasteria et ecclesias collegiatas, pertinebant ad capitula et conventus earundem ecclesiarum et monasteriorum, ita ut canonice et libere possent personas idoneas eligere;

Sed procedente tempore, diversos abusus inoleverunt: primo, per reservationes generales a Romanis pontificibus factas, quibus ius electionis fere totaliter sublatum fuit; secundo, per simoniaca commercia, quibus dignitates ecclesiasticae venduntur et emuntur quasi res venales in foro;

Constat autem, quod per tales reservationes et corruptelas, ecclesia Dei graviter laesa est: nam personae indignae ad regimen animarum pervenunt, qui nec scientiam habent ad docendum, nec vitam ad exemplum praestandum, nec zelum ad animarum salutem procurandam;

Praeterea, per huiusmodi abusus, libertas ecclesiastica oppressa est, et capitula atque conventus a suo iure electoris fraudata sunt, contra antiquam ecclesiae consuetudinem et sacrorum canonum auctoritatem;

Porro, experientia docuit, quod personae per electionem canonicam assumptae, meliores pastores fuerunt quam illae quae per provisionem apostolicam vel per simoniaca suffragia ad praelationem pervenerunt;

Ideo haec sancta synodus, auctoritate dei omnipotentis et beatorum apostolorum Petri et Pauli et sua, revocat omnes reservationes generales hactenus factas, et libertatem electionis capitulis et conventibus restituit, prout in sequentibus plenius declarabitur.

English Translation

Whereas of old, by the institution of the sacred canons, elections to cathedral and metropolitan churches, as well as to monasteries and collegiate churches, belonged to the chapters and convents of the same churches and monasteries, so that they could canonically and freely elect suitable persons;

But as time proceeded, various abuses grew up: first, through general reservations made by Roman pontiffs, by which the right of election was almost totally taken away; second, through simoniacal transactions, by which ecclesiastical dignities are sold and bought like vendible things in the marketplace;

It is established moreover that through such reservations and corruptions, God's church has been gravely injured: for unworthy persons attain to the government of souls, who have neither knowledge for teaching, nor life for giving example, nor zeal for procuring the salvation of souls;

Furthermore, through such abuses, ecclesiastical liberty has been oppressed, and chapters and convents have been defrauded of their right to elect, contrary to the ancient custom of the church and the authority of the sacred canons;

Moreover, experience has taught that persons assumed through canonical election have been better pastors than those who attained to prelacy through apostolic provision or through simoniacal votes;

Therefore this holy synod, by the authority of almighty God and of the blessed apostles Peter and Paul and its own, revokes all general reservations hitherto made, and restores the liberty of election to chapters and convents, as will be more fully declared in what follows.

PART IV: DISPOSITIO - LEGAL PROVISIONS

SECTION A: ABOLITION OF RESERVATIONS

Latin Text

Articulus Primus: De Revocatione Reservationum

Haec sancta synodus, reformationem ecclesiae principaliter intendens, statuit et decernit: quod omnes et singulae reservationes generales hactenus factae de ecclesiis metropolitanis, cathedralibus, monasteriis et ecclesiis collegiatis, quotcumque fuerunt et qualitercumque factae, penitus revocantur et cassantur, ac pro revocatis et cassatis habeantur.

Declarans expresse, quod huiusmodi reservationes nullam vim habent nec habebunt in futurum, et quod nullus, cuiuscumque dignitatis aut status existat, etiam si Romanus pontifex sit, poterit contra hanc revocationem aliquid attemptare, nisi hoc idem concilium generale aliud duxerit statuendum.

Ius ergo electionis, quod per huiusmodi reservationes capitula et conventus amiserant, eis integre et plene restituitur, ita ut libere et canonice possint procedere ad electionem personarum idonearum, secundum formam in hoc decreto contentam.

English Translation

Article One: On the Revocation of Reservations

This holy synod, principally intending the reformation of the church, establishes and decrees that all and singular general reservations hitherto made concerning metropolitan, cathedral churches, monasteries and collegiate churches, howsoever many and in whatever manner made, are entirely revoked and annulled, and are to be held as revoked and annulled.

Declaring expressly that such reservations have no force nor shall have any in the future, and that no one, of whatever dignity or estate he may be, even if he be the Roman pontiff, shall be able to attempt anything contrary to this revocation, unless this same general council shall have decided to establish otherwise.

Therefore the right of election, which chapters and convents had lost through such reservations, is restored to them fully and completely, so that they may freely and canonically proceed to the election of suitable persons, according to the form contained in this decree.

SECTION B: THE THREE-STAGE ELECTORAL PROCESS

Latin Text

Articulus Secundus: De Modo Procedendi in Electionibus

Ad removendum omnem occasionem erroris et pravitatis in futuris electionibus, haec sancta synodus statuit et ordinat, quod omnes electiones ad ecclesias metropolitanas, cathedrales, monasteria et collegiatas, fiant secundum modum infrascriptum, sub poena nullitatis et aliis poenis inferius expressis.

Primus Gradus: De Praeparatione Spirituali

Quando sedes alicuius ecclesiae cathedralis vel metropolitanae, aut praelatio alicuius monasterii vel ecclesiae collegiatae vacat, capitulum vel conventus, intra mensem a die vacationis computandum, debet procedere ad electionem.

In die autem electionis, antequam ad ipsum actum procedatur, omnes electores tenentur:

Primo, interesse missae de Spiritu Sancto, quae solemniter celebrari debet in ecclesia capitulari vel monastica, cum hymno "Veni Creator Spiritus" et collecta "Deus qui corda fidelium."

Secundo, confiteri peccata sua proprio confessario et recipere absolutionem sacramentalem, nisi aliud iustum impedimentum obstiterit.

Tertio, suscipere sacram communionem in eadem missa, ut purificati et fortificati divina gratia, possint libere et digne procedere ad electionem.

Et si aliquis elector praedictis non communicaverit, nisi ex legitima causa, pro illa vice amittet vocem activam in electione, et votum eius nullius erit momenti.

Secundus Gradus: De Sacramento contra Simoniam

Post missam celebratam et communionem perceptam, omnes electores, singuli et in solidum, coram altari ecclesiae, tactis sacris evangeliis, praestabunt sequens sacramentum:

"Ego, N., iuro et promitto Deo omnipotenti et sancto N. (secundum ecclesiae dedicationem) quod eligam illam personam quam credo magis utilem fore ecclesiae in spiritualibus et temporalibus, et non dabo vocem meam alicui quem puto procurare sibi electionem per promissionem aut donationem alicuius temporalis rei, vel per rogationem factam per se vel per alium, vel aliquo alio modo directe vel indirecte.

Item iuro, quod non recepi nec recipiam, nec mihi promitti feci, aliquid temporale vel spirituale, occasione huius electionis, a quocumque candidato vel ab aliquo pro eo.

Item iuro, quod in hac electione attendam solummodo honorem Dei, utilitatem ecclesiae, et salutem animarum, non favorem personarum, non propinquitatem sanguinis, non munerum largitionem, non timorem potentium, sed solam conscientiarn meam et dictamen rectae rationis.

Sic me Deus adiuvet et haec sancta Dei evangelia."

Quod sacramentum omnes et singuli praestare tenentur, sub poena excommunicationis latae sententiae ipso facto incurrendae, et privationis vocis activae in perpetuum.

Tertius Gradus: De Qualitate Eligendorum

Postquam omnes electores praedictum sacramentum praestiterint, tunc et non prius, possunt procedere ad electionem, observando quod sequitur:

Eligenda est persona quae sit:

Primo, legitimae aetatis secundum canones, id est, triginta annorum completa ad minus pro episcopatu, viginti quinque pro abbatia vel praepositura maiori.

Secundo, probatae honestatis et bonae famae, ita quod nullum scandalum publicum de ipsa constet.

Tertio, congruae litteraturae et scientiae, scilicet quod habeat saltem graduum in theologia vel in iure canonico, aut alioquin per experientiam sit erudita in his quae ad regimen animarum pertinent.

Quarto, in sacris ordinibus iam constituta, vel saltem subdiaconatus ordinem habens, qui infra annum post electionem teneatur ad sacerdotium promoveri.

Quinto, alioquin idonea secundum canonicas sanctiones, ut ad animarum regimen assumi possit sine periculo.

Nec liceat eligere aliquem qui sit:

Primo, notorie infamis propter aliquod crimen, maxime haeresis, symonie, homicidii vel luxuriae.

Secundo, irregularis secundum canones, nisi de ipsa irregularitate fuerit dispensatum.

Tertio, excommunicatus vel suspensus vel interdicto subiectus.

Quarto, mentis compos non sit, vel alio morbo perpetuo laborans, quo ecclesiae regimini inutilis redderetur.

English Translation

Article Two: On the Manner of Proceeding in Elections

To remove every occasion of error and wickedness in future elections, this holy synod establishes and ordains that all elections to metropolitan, cathedral churches, monasteries and collegiate churches shall be made according to the manner written below, under penalty of nullity and other penalties expressed hereafter.

First Stage: On Spiritual Preparation

When the see of any cathedral or metropolitan church, or the prelacy of any monastery or collegiate church becomes vacant, the chapter or convent, within one month computed from the day of the vacancy, must proceed to election.

On the day of the election, before proceeding to the act itself, all electors are bound:

First, to attend Mass of the Holy Spirit, which must be solemnly celebrated in the chapter or monastic church, with the hymn "Come Creator Spirit" and the collect "God who teaches the hearts of the faithful."

Second, to confess their sins to their own confessor and receive sacramental absolution, unless some other just impediment should prevent it.

Third, to receive holy communion in the same Mass, so that purified and strengthened by divine grace, they may freely and worthily proceed to the election.

And if any elector shall not have communicated in the aforesaid manner, unless for a legitimate cause, he shall lose for that occasion the active voice in the election, and his vote shall be of no moment.

Second Stage: On the Oath Against Simony

After the Mass has been celebrated and communion received, all electors, individually and jointly, before the altar of the church, touching the holy gospels, shall take the following oath:

"I, N., swear and promise to almighty God and to saint N. (according to the dedication of the church) that I will elect that person whom I believe will be more useful to the church in spiritual and temporal things, and I will not give my vote to anyone whom I think is procuring the election for himself by the promise or gift of some temporal thing, or by a request made by himself or through another, or in any other way directly or indirectly.

Likewise I swear that I have not received nor shall I receive, nor have I caused to be promised to me, anything temporal or spiritual, on occasion of this election, from any candidate or from anyone for him.

Likewise I swear that in this election I shall attend only to the honor of God, the utility of the church, and the salvation of souls, not favor of persons, not kinship of blood, not largesse of gifts, not fear of the powerful, but only my conscience and the dictate of right reason.

So help me God and these holy gospels of God."

Which oath all and each are bound to take, under penalty of excommunication of sentence already passed to be incurred by the very fact, and deprivation of active voice in perpetuity.

Third Stage: On the Quality of Those to be Elected

After all the electors have taken the aforesaid oath, then and not before, they may proceed to the election, observing what follows:

There must be elected a person who is:

First, of legitimate age according to the canons, that is, at least thirty years completed for the episcopate, twenty-five for an abbacy or major provostship.

Second, of proven honesty and good reputation, so that no public scandal is established about him.

Third, of suitable learning and knowledge, namely that he have at least a degree in theology or in canon law, or otherwise be learned by experience in those things which pertain to the government of souls.

Fourth, already established in sacred orders, or at least having the order of subdeacon, who within a year after election shall be bound to be promoted to the priesthood.

Fifth, otherwise suitable according to canonical sanctions, so that he may be assumed to the government of souls without danger.

Nor is it lawful to elect anyone who is:

First, notoriously infamous for any crime, especially heresy, simony, homicide or lechery.

Second, irregular according to the canons, unless dispensation for such irregularity has been granted.

Third, excommunicated or suspended or subject to interdict.

Fourth, not of sound mind, or laboring under some other perpetual disease, by which he would be rendered useless for the government of the church.

SECTION C: VOTING PROCEDURES

Latin Text

Articulus Tertius: De Forma Votandi

Observatis omnibus praemissis, electores procedant ad votandum secundum unum ex modis infrascriptis, prout maiori parti videbitur expedire:

Primus Modus: Per Scrutinium

Si electio fiat per scrutinium, tres electores probatae fidei et conscientiae eligantur a capitulo vel conventu ad recipiendum suffragia et scrutanda.

Qui scrutatores, postquam sacramentum praestiterint de fideliter officio fungendo et secreto servando, vocabunt singulos electores sigillatim, et recipient ab eis schedulam scriptam vel vocem oretenus expressam, continentem nomen personae cui dant suffragium.

Quolibet autem electore suffragium dante, scrutatores diligenter notabunt nomen eius et nomen personae electae, ita ut nullus possit negare quid fecerit.

Completo scrutinio, tres scrutatores coram omnibus publicabunt quot suffragia quaelibet persona receperit.

Et si aliqua persona receperit duas partes ex omnibus suffragiis, vel saltem maiorem partem, declarabitur electa, et statim Te Deum laudamus solemniter cantabitur.

Secundus Modus: Per Compromissum

Si electores concorditer velint eligere per compromissum, possunt eligere tres vel quinque vel septem de capitulo vel conventu, discretos et probatae conscientiae, dando eis plenam potestatem eligendi aliquem de ipso capitulo vel de extra.

Qui compromissarii, acceptato onere, procedent ad electionem secundum formam superius prescriptam, scilicet cum sacramento et observatione qualitatum requisitarum.

Et quem ipsi compromissarii elegerint, si duas partes eorum in eo convenerint, habeatur pro canonice electo.

Tertius Modus: Per Inspirationem

Si vero, Spiritu Sancto inspirante, omnes unanimiter et concorditer, nemine penitus discrepante, in aliquam personam idoneam consenserint, ac voce proclamaverint: "Eligimus N. in episcopum" vel "in abbatem," absque ulla praevia tractatione vel collatione habita, talis electio per inspirationem facta valebit, dummodo persona electa sit canonica et idonea, et omnes praedictum sacramentum praestiterint.

Sed quia huiusmodi modus valde rarus est, et de facili fingere posset, electores bene caveant ne sub praetextu inspirationis aliqua fraus vel colludio subintrare valeat.

English Translation

Article Three: On the Form of Voting

All the aforesaid being observed, the electors shall proceed to vote according to one of the modes written below, as shall seem expedient to the greater part:

First Mode: By Scrutiny

If the election is made by scrutiny, three electors of proven faith and conscience shall be chosen by the chapter or convent to receive and scrutinize the votes.

These scrutineers, after they have taken an oath to faithfully perform their office and keep secrecy, shall call the individual electors one by one, and shall receive from them a written schedule or a voice expressed orally, containing the name of the person to whom they give their vote.

When any elector gives his vote, the scrutineers shall diligently note his name and the name of the person elected, so that none may deny what he has done.

The scrutiny being completed, the three scrutineers shall publish before all how many votes each person has received.

And if any person has received two parts of all the votes, or at least the greater part, he shall be declared elected, and immediately the Te Deum laudamus shall be solemnly sung.

Second Mode: By Compromise

If the electors unanimously wish to elect by compromise, they may elect three or five or seven from the chapter or convent, discreet and of proven conscience, giving them full power to elect someone from the chapter itself or from outside.

These compromise electors, having accepted the burden, shall proceed to the election according to the form prescribed above, namely with the oath and observance of the required qualifications.

And whomever these compromise electors shall have elected, if two parts of them agree on him, let him be held as canonically elected.

Third Mode: By Inspiration

If truly, the Holy Spirit inspiring, all unanimously and concordantly, with absolutely no one dissenting, shall have consented to some suitable person, and proclaimed with one voice: "We elect N. as bishop" or "as abbot," without any previous discussion or conference held, such an election made by inspiration shall be valid, provided that the person elected is canonical and suitable, and all have taken the aforesaid oath.

But because this mode is very rare, and could easily be feigned, the electors should beware lest under the pretext of inspiration any fraud or collusion be able to enter.

SECTION D: CONFIRMATION OF ELECTIONS

Latin Text

Articulus Quartus: De Confirmatione Electionis

Electione canonice facta secundum praemissam formam, electus infra octo dies debet postulare confirmationem a suo superiore competenti, scilicet:

Si fuerit electus in episcopum suffraganeum, postulabit confirmationem a metropolitano suo.

Si fuerit electus in archiepiscopum seu metropolitanum, postulabit confirmationem a Romano pontifice.

Si fuerit electus in abbatem monasterii exempti, postulabit confirmationem a Romano pontifice vel a delegato eius.

Si fuerit electus in abbatem monasterii non exempti, postulabit confirmationem ab episcopo dioecesano.

De Modo Confirmandi

Superior qui confirmationem petitam receperit, teneatur infra tres menses a die postulationis, diligenter examinare iudicialiter:

Primo, an electio fuerit facta secundum formam in hoc decreto praescriptam, et utrum electores omnia servaverint quae servari debent.

Secundo, an electus habeat omnes qualitates requisitas et nullum habeat impedimentum canonicum.

Tertio, an in electione fuerit aliqua simonia vel alia fraus commissa.

Ad quod examen, superior vocabit electum personaliter, et etiam duos vel tres ex electoribus, qui de modo electionis et qualitate electi possint testimonium perhibere.

Si vero aliqui de capitulo vel conventu, aut aliquis alius, voluerit opponere contra electionem vel contra electum, superior eum citabit nomine suo ad comparendum coram se, et audiet rationes utriusque partis.

Examinatione diligenter facta, si superior invenerit electionem esse canonicam et electum esse idoneum, eam confirmabit; sin autem, eam cassabit et pro non facta habebit.

Confirmatio autem fiat in scriptis per litteras patentes sigillo superiores munitas, in quibus expresse dicatur quod superior, visis actis electionis et examinato electo et auditis testibus, invenit electionem esse canonicam et electum esse idoneum, et ideo confirmationem concedit.

De Prohibitione Exactionum

In hac autem confirmatione, superior omnino abstineat, tam per se quam per alios, ab exigendo vel recipiendo aliquid quocumque nomine, occasione confirmationis vel sub praetextu obedientiae, subventionis, gratitudinis, aut alio quocumque praetextu consuetudinis vel privilegii.

Solummodo liceat scribis et notariis recipere moderatam mercedem pro labore scribendi, proportionatam operi scripturae et non valori praelationis, secundum taxam consuetam in diocesi vel provincia.

Et si aliquis superior contra hoc praesumpserit aliquid exigere vel recipere, vel etiam munera gratis oblata sub quocumque colore accipere, ipso facto incurrat sententiam excommunicationis, a qua non possit absolvi nisi per Romanum pontificem, praeterquam in mortis articulo.

English Translation

Article Four: On the Confirmation of Elections

The election having been canonically made according to the aforesaid form, the elected person within eight days must petition for confirmation from his competent superior, namely:

If he has been elected as suffragan bishop, he shall petition confirmation from his metropolitan.

If he has been elected as archbishop or metropolitan, he shall petition confirmation from the Roman pontiff.

If he has been elected as abbot of an exempt monastery, he shall petition confirmation from the Roman pontiff or from his delegate.

If he has been elected as abbot of a non-exempt monastery, he shall petition confirmation from the diocesan bishop.

On the Manner of Confirming

The superior who receives the petition for confirmation shall be bound within three months from the day of petition to diligently examine judicially:

First, whether the election was made according to the form prescribed in this decree, and whether the electors observed all that ought to be observed.

Second, whether the elected person has all the required qualifications and has no canonical impediment.

Third, whether in the election any simony or other fraud was committed.

For which examination, the superior shall summon the elected person personally, and also two or three of the electors, who may bear witness concerning the manner of election and the quality of the elected person.

If truly any from the chapter or convent, or any other person, wishes to oppose the election or the elected person, the superior shall cite him by name to appear before him, and shall hear the reasons of each party.

The examination being diligently made, if the superior finds the election to be canonical and the elected person to be suitable, he shall confirm it; otherwise, he shall annul it and hold it as not made.

The confirmation moreover shall be made in writing by letters patent sealed with the seal of the superior, in which it shall be expressly stated that the superior, having seen the acts of the election and examined the elected person and heard the witnesses, found the election to be canonical and the elected person to be suitable, and therefore grants confirmation.

On the Prohibition of Exactions

In this confirmation, moreover, the superior shall altogether refrain, both personally and through others, from demanding or receiving anything whatsoever by any name, on occasion of the confirmation or under the pretext of obedience, subvention, gratitude, or any other pretext whatsoever of custom or privilege.

It shall be lawful only for writers and notaries to receive a moderate fee for the labor of writing, proportionate to the work of writing and not to the value of the prelacy, according to the customary rate in the diocese or province.

And if any superior shall presume contrary to this to exact or receive anything, or even to accept gifts freely offered under any color whatsoever, he shall by that very fact incur sentence of excommunication, from which he cannot be absolved except by the Roman pontiff, except at the point of death.

PART V: SANCTIO & POENA - PENALTIES

Latin Text

Articulus Quintus: De Poenis Simoniacae Pravitatis

Quia simoniaca pravitas est pestis animarum et scandalum ecclesiae, in horrorem tanti criminis haec sancta synodus statuit poenas infrascriptas, quae ipso facto incurruntur absque omni declaratione:

Contra Electores Simoniacos

Si aliqui electores dederint vel receperint aliquid temporale vel spirituale occasione electionis, vel fecerint pactum de recipiendo, vel promiserint suffragium suum occasione munerum vel promissionum, ipso facto incurrent sequentes poenas:

Primo, privatio vocis activae in perpetuum, ita quod nunquam amplius in aliqua electione votum habebunt.

Secundo, privatio omnium beneficiorum quae tunc obtinent.

Tertio, inhabilitatio perpetua ad quaecumque beneficia obtinenda in futurum.

Quarto, sententia excommunicationis, a qua non possunt absolvi nisi restituerint omnia illicite recepta.

Contra Electos Simoniacos

Si vero electus procuraverit sibi electionem per munerum largitionem, per promissiones, per preces, per minas, vel per alium quemcumque modum directe vel indirecte, aut sciverit aliquem pro se tale aliquid fecisse et non contradixerit, talis electio nulla est et ipso iure nullius roboris vel momenti.

Et electus sic per simoniam assumptus:

Primo, ipso facto incurrit sententiam excommunicationis maioris.

Secundo, inhabilitatur perpetuo ad obtinendum illam dignitatem seu beneficium, etiam si postea alio modo provideretur de eo.

Tertio, non potest absolvi ab excommunicatione nisi prius sponte resignaverit dignitatem sive beneficium quod sic illicite obtinuerat.

Quarto, post resignationem, inhabilis remanet perpetuo ad illud idem beneficium recuperandum, licet ad alia beneficia, facta satisfactione, possit per superiorem admitti.

Contra Confirmantes Simoniacos

Superior qui confirmationem dederit occasione alicuius temporalis emolumenti dati vel promissi, ipso facto incurret sententiam excommunicationis, a qua non potest absolvi nisi per Romanum pontificem, excepto mortis articulo.

Et insuper, si fuerit episcopus, suspendatur a suo officio per triennium; si fuerit archiepiscopus vel metropolitanus, suspendatur per quinquennium; et omnia quae illicite receperit, tenetur restituere usque ad quadruplum.

English Translation

Article Five: On the Penalties of Simoniacal Depravity

Because simoniacal depravity is a pestilence of souls and a scandal to the church, in horror of so great a crime this holy synod establishes the penalties written below, which are incurred by the very fact without any declaration:

Against Simoniacal Electors

If any electors shall have given or received anything temporal or spiritual on occasion of the election, or made a pact about receiving, or promised their vote on occasion of gifts or promises, they shall by that very fact incur the following penalties:

First, deprivation of active voice in perpetuity, so that never again shall they have a vote in any election.

Second, deprivation of all benefices which they then hold.

Third, perpetual disqualification from obtaining any benefices whatsoever in the future.

Fourth, sentence of excommunication, from which they cannot be absolved unless they restore all things illicitly received.

Against Simoniacal Elected Persons

If truly the elected person shall have procured the election for himself through largesse of gifts, through promises, through prayers, through threats, or through any other mode whatsoever directly or indirectly, or shall have known that someone did any such thing for him and did not contradict it, such an election is null and by the law itself of no force or moment.

And the elected person thus assumed through simony:

First, by that very fact incurs sentence of major excommunication.

Second, is perpetually disqualified from obtaining that dignity or benefice, even if afterward he should be provided for in another manner.

Third, cannot be absolved from excommunication unless first he has spontaneously resigned the dignity or benefice which he had thus illicitly obtained.

Fourth, after resignation, he remains perpetually disqualified from recovering that same benefice, although for other benefices, satisfaction being made, he may be admitted by a superior.

Against Simoniacal Confirmers

A superior who shall have given confirmation on occasion of any temporal profit given or promised, shall by that very fact incur sentence of excommunication, from which he cannot be absolved except by the Roman pontiff, except at the point of death.

And moreover, if he be a bishop, let him be suspended from his office for three years; if he be an archbishop or metropolitan, let him be suspended for five years; and all that he has illicitly received, he is bound to restore up to fourfold.

Latin Text (continued)

Articulus Sextus: De Poenis Violantium Formam Electionis

Si capitulum vel conventus in aliqua electione non servaverit formam in hoc decreto praescriptam, scilicet si electores non audierint missam, vel non praestiterint sacramentum, vel elegerint personam non habentem qualitates requisitas, talis electio ipso iure nulla est et pro non facta habebitur.

Et praeterea:

Primo, omnes et singuli electores qui scientes et volentes in tali electione invalida consenserunt, suspenduntur ab ingressu ecclesiae et a divinis officiis per sex menses.

Secundo, capitulum vel conventus privatur iure eligendi in illa vice, et provisio pertinebit ad superiorem immediate, qui tamen eligere debebit aliquem de illo capitulo vel conventu, si idoneus inveniatur.

Tertio, si capitulum vel conventus ter successive contra formam huius decreti elegerit, amittet ius eligendi in perpetuum, et provisio semper fiet per superiorem.

De Appellatione

Si aliquis gravatus fuerit per hanc sententiam vel aliam poenam in hoc decreto contentam, potest appellare ad concilium generale vel ad Romanum pontificem, secundum quod materia postulaverit.

Sed appellatio non suspendit executionem poenarum ipso facto incurrentium, nisi superior competens aliter duxerit ordinandum.

English Translation (continued)

Article Six: On Penalties for Violating the Form of Election

If a chapter or convent in any election shall not have observed the form prescribed in this decree, namely if the electors did not hear Mass, or did not take the oath, or elected a person not having the required qualifications, such an election is by the law itself null and shall be held as not made.

And furthermore:

First, all and each of the electors who knowingly and willingly consented in such an invalid election are suspended from entry into the church and from divine offices for six months.
