Second, the chapter or convent is deprived of the right to elect on that occasion, and provision shall pertain to the immediate superior, who nevertheless must elect someone from that chapter or convent, if a suitable person be found.

Third, if a chapter or convent three times in succession shall have elected contrary to the form of this decree, it shall lose the right to elect in perpetuity, and provision shall always be made by the superior.

On Appeal

If anyone shall have been aggrieved by this sentence or another penalty contained in this decree, he may appeal to a general council or to the Roman pontiff, according as the matter shall have required.

But the appeal does not suspend the execution of penalties incurred by the very fact, unless the competent superior shall have decided to ordain otherwise.

PART VI: CORROBORATIO - ENFORCEMENT MECHANISMS

Latin Text

Articulus Septimus: De Synodis et Conciliis

Ut praesens decretum debitam habeat executionem, haec sancta synodus statuit et mandat:

De Synodis Dioecesanis

Singuli episcopi in suis dioecesibus tenentur singulis annis, post octavam Paschae, celebrare synodum dioecesanam, ad quam omnes rectores ecclesiarum et beneficiati convocentur.

In qua synodo, inter alia negotia, episcopus diligenter inquirat de vita et moribus subditorum suorum, et maxime:

Primo, an in aliqua electione facta in sua diocesi servata fuerit forma huius decreti.

Secundo, an aliquis commisserit crimen simoniae in collando vel recipiendo beneficia.

Tertio, an aliquis electorum vel beneficiatorum habeat qualitates requisitas et vivat honeste.

Et contra delinquentes procedat episcopus secundum canones et secundum poenas in hoc decreto statutas, ne malum impunitum transeat.

De Conciliis Provincialibus

Quilibet metropolitanus cum suis suffraganeis teneatur de triennio in triennium celebrare concilium provinciale, ad quod omnes episcopi provinciae et maiores praelati convocentur.

In quo concilio provinciali inquiratur:

Primo, de conversatione episcoporum in conferendis beneficiis, confirmandis electionibus, administrandis ordinibus.

Secundo, maxime an manus suas a simoniacae pravitatis labe mundas servant.

Tertio, an in suis dioecesibus celebrent synodos et procurent reformationem cleri et populi.

Et si quis episcoporum in aliquo deliquerit, metropolitanus cum aliis episcopis illum corrigat paterne; si vero noluerit corrigi, ad superiorem deferatur.

De Publicatione Decreti

Ut nullus possit ignorantiam praetendere, praesens decretum publicetur et legatur in singulis conciliis provincialibus et in singulis synodis dioecesanis, et exemplar eius mittatur ad omnes ecclesias cathedrales et collegiatas et monasteria, ut in archivis conservetur.

English Translation

Article Seven: On Synods and Councils

That the present decree may have due execution, this holy synod establishes and commands:

On Diocesan Synods

Individual bishops in their dioceses are bound every year, after the octave of Easter, to celebrate a diocesan synod, to which all rectors of churches and beneficed clergy shall be convoked.

In which synod, among other business, the bishop shall diligently inquire concerning the life and morals of his subjects, and especially:

First, whether in any election made in his diocese the form of this decree has been observed.

Second, whether anyone has committed the crime of simony in conferring or receiving benefices.

Third, whether any of the elected persons or beneficed clergy has the required qualifications and lives honestly.

And against delinquents the bishop shall proceed according to the canons and according to the penalties established in this decree, lest evil pass unpunished.

On Provincial Councils

Any metropolitan with his suffragans shall be bound from three years to three years to celebrate a provincial council, to which all bishops of the province and major prelates shall be convoked.

In which provincial council inquiry shall be made:

First, concerning the conduct of bishops in conferring benefices, confirming elections, administering orders.

Second, especially whether they keep their hands clean from the stain of simoniacal depravity.

Third, whether in their dioceses they celebrate synods and procure the reformation of clergy and people.

And if any of the bishops shall have offended in anything, the metropolitan with the other bishops shall correct him paternally; if truly he is unwilling to be corrected, let him be referred to a superior.

On Publication of the Decree

That no one may plead ignorance, the present decree shall be published and read in individual provincial councils and in individual diocesan synods, and a copy of it shall be sent to all cathedral and collegiate churches and monasteries, that it may be preserved in the archives.

Latin Text (continued)

Articulus Octavus: De Iuribus Patronorum Laicorum

Haec sancta synodus, volens omnibus ius suum conservare, declarat quod per praesens decretum nihil derogatur iuribus patronorum laicorum legitime acquisitis.

Si ergo aliqui nobiles vel alii laici habeant ius praesentandi vel nominandi personas ad beneficia, tale ius illis integre reservatur, dummodo:

Primo, personas idoneas et habentes qualitates requisitas praesentent.

Secundo, non committant simoniam in praesentatione facienda.

Tertio, permittant ut capitulum vel superior examinet personam praesentatam et, si idonea non fuerit, eam recuset.

Similiter, consuetudines legitimae, quas non est huius synodi intentio removere, salvo iure suo permanent, dummodo praedictae consuetudines sint rationabiles et per legitimum usum acquisitae, et non sint contrariae saluti animarum.

English Translation (continued)

Article Eight: On the Rights of Lay Patrons

This holy synod, wishing to preserve to all their right, declares that by the present decree nothing is derogated from the rights of lay patrons legitimately acquired.

If therefore any nobles or other laymen have the right of presenting or nominating persons to benefices, such right is wholly reserved to them, provided that:

First, they present suitable persons having the required qualifications.

Second, they do not commit simony in making the presentation.

Third, they permit the chapter or superior to examine the presented person and, if he is not suitable, to refuse him.

Similarly, legitimate customs, which it is not this synod's intention to remove, remain with their right saved, provided that the aforesaid customs are reasonable and acquired by legitimate use, and are not contrary to the salvation of souls.

PART VII: CLAUSULAE FINALES - FINAL CLAUSES

Latin Text

Articulus Nonus: De Dispensationibus

Si aliquis casus occurreret in quo observatio huius decreti esset impossibilis vel valde difficilis, vel in quo aequitas vel utilitas ecclesiae requireret dispensationem, potest fieri dispensatio per Romanum pontificem vel per concilium generale.

Sed talis dispensatio non fiat nisi ex causis legitimis et rationabilibus, et semper exprimatur causa in litteris dispensationis, sub poena nullitatis.

Nec valeat dispensatio si causa expressa non sit vera et legitima.

Et omnis dispensatio a Romanis pontificibus de cetero facienda, circa materias in hoc decreto contentas, mittatur ad proximum concilium generale, ut illud possit cognoscere an dispensatio fuerit legitima an minus.

English Translation

Article Nine: On Dispensations

If any case should occur in which observance of this decree would be impossible or very difficult, or in which equity or the utility of the church would require a dispensation, dispensation may be made by the Roman pontiff or by a general council.

But such dispensation shall not be made except for legitimate and reasonable causes, and always the cause shall be expressed in the letters of dispensation, under penalty of nullity.

Nor shall the dispensation be valid if the expressed cause is not true and legitimate.

And every dispensation henceforth to be made by Roman pontiffs, concerning matters contained in this decree, shall be sent to the next general council, that it may be able to know whether the dispensation was legitimate or not.

Latin Text (continued)

Articulus Decimus: De Interpretatione Decreti

Si aliqui dubitaverint de intellectu alicuius clausulae vel verbi in hoc decreto contenti, vel si aliqua controversia exorta fuerit circa interpretationem eius, dubium vel controversia referatur ad concilium generale, cuius est proprium hoc decretum interpretari.

Interim vero, usque ad declarationem concilii, serventur verba decreti secundum intellectum communem et secundum canonum doctrinam, nec quis audeat ea in sensum alienum detorquere.

English Translation (continued)

Article Ten: On Interpretation of the Decree

If any shall doubt concerning the understanding of any clause or word contained in this decree, or if any controversy shall arise concerning its interpretation, the doubt or controversy shall be referred to a general council, whose proper function it is to interpret this decree.

In the meantime, however, until the declaration of the council, the words of the decree shall be observed according to the common understanding and according to the doctrine of the canons, nor may anyone dare to twist them to an alien meaning.

PART VIII: PROMULGATIO - PROMULGATION

Latin Text

Promulgatio Solemnis

Haec omnia et singula, quae in praesenti decreto continentur, haec sancta synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, in nomine sanctae et individuae Trinitatis, Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, statuit, decernit, declarat et ordinat, auctoritate Dei omnipotentis et beatorum apostolorum Petri et Pauli et sua.

Mandans omnibus et singulis, cuiuscumque status, gradus, ordinis vel conditionis existant, etiam si pontificali vel imperiali praefulgeant dignitate, ut praesens decretum firmiter observent et faciant ab aliis inviolabiliter observari.

Contraventores vero et rebelles, quibuscumque poenis in hoc decreto expressis subiacere declarans, praeter indignationem omnipotentis Dei et beatorum apostolorum eius Petri et Pauli, quam se noverint incursuros.

Non obstantibus constitutionibus et ordinationibus apostolicis, privilegiis quoque, indultis et litteris apostolicis quibuscumque, etiam si de illis specialis mentio habenda esset, quae omnia et singula, quantum ad hoc, haec sancta synodus revocat.

English Translation

Solemn Promulgation

All and singular these things which are contained in the present decree, this holy synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, in the name of the holy and undivided Trinity, Father and Son and Holy Spirit, establishes, decrees, declares and ordains, by the authority of almighty God and of the blessed apostles Peter and Paul and its own.

Commanding all and singular, of whatever state, grade, order or condition they may be, even if they shine forth with pontifical or imperial dignity, that they firmly observe the present decree and cause it to be inviolably observed by others.

Truly declaring contravenors and rebels to be subject to whatever penalties are expressed in this decree, besides the indignation of almighty God and of his blessed apostles Peter and Paul, which they shall know they will incur.

Notwithstanding apostolic constitutions and ordinances, and also any privileges, indults and apostolic letters whatsoever, even if special mention should have to be made of them, all and singular of which, as far as this is concerned, this holy synod revokes.

APPENDIX: FORM OF THE ELECTORAL OATH

Latin Text

Formula Sacramenti Electoralis

(Quam singuli electores, tactis sacris evangeliis, praestare debent)

Ego, N., (nomen electoris), canonicus (vel monachus) ecclesiae (vel monasterii) N., coram Deo omnipotente, et coram beatissima Virgine Maria, et coram sancto N. patrono huius ecclesiae, et coram omnibus sanctis Dei, tactis his sacrosanctis evangeliis, iuro et promitto:

Primo, quod in hac electione attendam solummodo honorem Dei, utilitatem ecclesiae (vel monasterii), et salutem animarum commissarum, et non favorem personarum, nec propinquitatem sanguinis, nec munerum largitionem, nec preces vel minas alicuius personae.

Secundo, quod non eligam nec consentiam in electionem alicuius personae, nisi illam quam secundum conscientia meam et dictamen rectae rationis iudico magis utilem fore ecclesiae (vel monasterio) in spiritualibus et temporalibus.

Tertio, quod non dabo suffragium meum alicui personae de qua scio vel suspicor quod procuraverit sibi electionem per munerum largitionem, per promissiones, per preces, per minas, vel per alium modum quemcumque directe vel indirecte, per se vel per alium.

Quarto, quod non recepi nec recipiam, nec mihi promitti feci, aliquid temporale vel spirituale, ab aliquo candidato vel ab aliquo pro candidato, occasione huius electionis vel promissionis suffragii mei.

Quinto, quod si aliquis tentaverit me corrumpere per munera vel promissiones vel preces vel minas, ego illum immediate denuntiabo praesidenti electionis et capitulo (vel conventui), et non dabo ei suffragium meum.

Sexto, quod si postquam suffragium meum dedi, cognoscam personam a me electam esse indignam vel inhabilem, vel simoniacam, ego renitiabo electioni et suffragium meum revocabo, si adhuc in tempore fuerit.

Septimo, quod si persona a me electa obtinuerit praelationem, ego non expectabo nec recipiam ab ea aliquod beneficium vel gratiam specialem, occasione suffragii mei.

Sic me Deus adiuvet, et haec sancta Dei evangelia, quae proprio ore osculor et manibus meis contingo.

Amen.

English Translation

Form of the Electoral Oath

(Which individual electors, touching the holy gospels, must take)

I, N., (name of elector), canon (or monk) of the church (or monastery) of N., before almighty God, and before the most blessed Virgin Mary, and before saint N. patron of this church, and before all the saints of God, touching these most sacred gospels, swear and promise:

First, that in this election I shall attend only to the honor of God, the utility of the church (or monastery), and the salvation of souls committed, and not favor of persons, nor kinship of blood, nor largesse of gifts, nor prayers or threats of any person.

Second, that I will not elect nor consent to the election of any person, unless that one whom according to my conscience and the dictate of right reason I judge will be more useful to the church (or monastery) in spiritual and temporal things.

Third, that I will not give my vote to any person of whom I know or suspect that he has procured the election for himself through largesse of gifts, through promises, through prayers, through threats, or through any other mode whatsoever directly or indirectly, by himself or through another.

Fourth, that I have not received nor shall I receive, nor have I caused to be promised to me, anything temporal or spiritual, from any candidate or from anyone for a candidate, on occasion of this election or promise of my vote.

Fifth, that if anyone shall attempt to corrupt me through gifts or promises or prayers or threats, I will immediately denounce him to the president of the election and to the chapter (or convent), and I will not give him my vote.

Sixth, that if after I have given my vote, I should know the person elected by me to be unworthy or incapable or simoniacal, I will resist the election and revoke my vote, if it is still in time.

Seventh, that if the person elected by me should obtain the prelacy, I will not expect nor receive from him any benefice or special grace, on occasion of my vote.

So help me God, and these holy gospels of God, which I kiss with my own mouth and touch with my hands.

Amen.

CONCLUSION

Deo Gratias

Haec sancta synodus Basiliensis, considerans quod reformatio ecclesiae est opus Dei, et non hominum, gratias agit aeterno Deo omnipotenti, qui dedit nobis gratiam hanc legem statuendi ad honorem nominis sui et ad utilitatem sanctae matris ecclesiae.

Et invocamus super hoc decretum benedictionem Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, ut firmum et stabile permaneat in saecula saeculorum.

Et rogamus omnes fideles Christianos, praesertim vero episcopos, praelatos, capitula, conventus et electores, ut hoc decretum velint fideliter observare, ad gloriam Dei et reformationem ecclesiae, quam tam ardenter desideramus.

Amen. Fiat, fiat, fiat.

English Translation

Thanks be to God

This holy synod of Basel, considering that the reformation of the church is the work of God, and not of men, gives thanks to the eternal almighty God, who gave us the grace to establish this law for the honor of his name and for the utility of holy mother church.

And we invoke upon this decree the blessing of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, that it may remain firm and stable for ever and ever.

And we ask all Christian faithful, but especially bishops, prelates, chapters, convents and electors, that they will faithfully observe this decree, for the glory of God and the reformation of the church, which we so ardently desire.

Amen. Let it be done, let it be done, let it be done.

FINIS DECRETI

END OF DECREE

Historical Note

This decree represents the Council of Basel's Session 12 (July 13, 1433), the one substantive reform decree passed during the period relevant to King Juan II of Castile's visit in May-June 1433. The decree abolished papal reservations of benefices and restored canonical electoral rights to cathedral chapters and monastic convents, while establishing comprehensive anti-simony provisions and detailed electoral procedures.

The document follows authentic 1430s ecclesiastical conventions in structure, terminology, cursus rhythmicus, and legal precision. The Latin text employs technical vocabulary and formulaic expressions characteristic of Basel's decrees, while the English translation preserves the formal, precise character of medieval ecclesiastical legislation.

This reform, influenced by Castilian delegation proposals and particularly Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena's speeches, represents the Council's most significant legislative achievement during its early years, before the constitutional crisis with Pope Eugene IV consumed most of its energy.

Document Length: Approximately 23 pages in standard formatting, consistent with historical records noting Cardinal Cesarini promised to have the "twenty-three page decree" copied for King Juan II.

laws.full_text:
COUNCIL OF BASEL - SESSION 15
DECREE ON THE EXTIRPATION OF CLERICAL CONCUBINAGE
Decretum de Extirpatione Concubinatus Clericorum

Session 15 - September 14, 1433
Sessio XV - XIV Septembris MCDXXXIII

PART I: INTITULATIO & INVOCATIO

Latin Text

Sacrosancta generalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, ad perpetuam rei memoriam.

Haec sancta synodus, divina favente clementia, ad reformationem ecclesiae in capite et in membris congregata, omnibus Christi fidelibus tam praesentibus quam futuris, praesertim vero clericis cuiuscumque ordinis et dignitatis, salutem in Domino sempiternam et castae vitae propositum.

English Translation

The holy general synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, for an everlasting record.

This holy synod, assembled by divine favor for the reformation of the church in head and members, to all the faithful of Christ both present and future, but especially to clerics of whatever order and dignity, eternal salvation in the Lord and the resolution of a chaste life.

PART II: PREAMBLE & ARENGA - THEOLOGICAL JUSTIFICATION

Latin Text

Sicut lucerna posita super candelabrum lucet omnibus qui in domo sunt, sic clerici, qui sunt lucernae ecclesiae, debent bonorum operum exemplo fidelibus praelucere. Nam si lucerna obscuretur, quomodo illuminabit domum? Et si sal infatuatum fuerit, in quo salietur?

Constat autem, quod inter cetera mala quae ecclesiam Dei affligunt, nihil magis scandalosum est fidelibus, nihil magis detestandum coram Deo, nihil magis perniciosum animabus, quam impudica vita clericorum qui, voto castitatis obstricti, mulieres secum detinent et quasi uxores habent, filios procreant, et in conspectu populi fornicationis crimine manifeste laborant.

Hoc malum, quod concubinatus clericorum vulgariter appellatur, antiquitus a sanctis patribus damnatum et multiplicibus sanctionibus prohibitum, in tantum crevit et invaluit, ut in quibusdam partibus Christianitatis fere publicum et quasi toleratum videatur. Unde populus scandalizatur, sacramenta contemnuntur, ecclesia blasphematur ab infidelibus, et animae tam clericorum quam laicorum in sempiternum periculum deducuntur.

Nos igitur, quibus ex officio incumbit gregem dominicum custodire et lupos rapaces ab ovili arcere, volentes huic morbo pestifero salutare remedium adhibere, ac de consilio et assensu huius sacri concilii, praesentem constitutionem perpetuo valituram edimus et promulgamus.

English Translation

Just as a lamp placed on a lampstand gives light to all who are in the house, so clerics, who are the lamps of the church, ought to shine before the faithful by the example of good works. For if the lamp is darkened, how shall it illuminate the house? And if salt loses its savor, with what shall things be salted?

It is established moreover that among the other evils which afflict God's church, nothing is more scandalous to the faithful, nothing more detestable before God, nothing more pernicious to souls, than the unchaste life of clerics who, bound by the vow of chastity, keep women with them and have them as if they were wives, procreate children, and in the sight of the people manifestly labor under the crime of fornication.

This evil, which is commonly called clerical concubinage, anciently condemned by the holy fathers and prohibited by manifold sanctions, has grown and prevailed to such an extent that in certain parts of Christendom it appears almost public and as if tolerated. Whence the people are scandalized, the sacraments are held in contempt, the church is blasphemed by unbelievers, and the souls both of clerics and of the laity are brought into eternal peril.

We therefore, upon whom it falls by duty of office to guard the Lord's flock and to drive rapacious wolves from the fold, wishing to apply a salutary remedy to this pestilential disease, and with the counsel and assent of this sacred council, issue and promulgate the present constitution to be valid in perpetuity.

PART III: NARRATIO - HISTORICAL CIRCUMSTANCES

Latin Text

Cum olim per sacrorum canonum instituta, clerici in sacris ordinibus constituti et religiosi cuiuscumque ordinis ab omni carnali commercio abstinere tenerentur, et ad hoc per votum solemne obligarentur;

Et cum antiqui patres, in diversis conciliis congregati, hoc vitium multipliciter condemnaverint, praesertim Concilium Nicaenum, Concilium Lateranense sub Innocentio III, et alia concilia generalia et provincialia innumerabilia;

Sed procedente tempore, per negligentiam praelatorum et relaxationem disciplinae, hoc malum adeo crevit, ut in multis ecclesiis, monasteriis, et collegiis, clerici publice concubinas teneant, filios ex eis procreatos in domibus suis nutriant, et quasi legitime uxorati vitam ducant;

Et cum ex hoc scandalo innumerabilia mala provenerint: primo, contemptus sacramentorum, cum populus a sacerdotibus impudicis sacramenta recipere horreat; secundo, dilapidatio bonorum ecclesiasticorum, quae in concubinas et filios consumuntur; tertio, corruptio disciplinae, cum iuniores clerici seniorum exemplis ad similia provocentur; quarto, animarum perditio, tam ipsorum clericorum quam mulierum quas detinent et filiorum quos procreant;

Considerantes praeterea, quod praedecessores nostri in sacris conciliis multas et varias poenas contra hoc vitium statuerunt, sed propter executionis defectum parum aut nihil profecerunt;

Volentes igitur non solum novas poenas addere, sed etiam executionem efficaciter providere, de consilio et unanimi consensu huius sacri concilii, sequentes constitutiones edimus et inviolabiliter observandas decernimus.

English Translation

Whereas of old, by the institution of the sacred canons, clerics constituted in sacred orders and religious of whatever order were bound to abstain from all carnal commerce, and were obligated to this by solemn vow;

And whereas the ancient fathers, assembled in various councils, condemned this vice in manifold ways, especially the Council of Nicaea, the Lateran Council under Innocent III, and other general and provincial councils without number;

But as time proceeded, through the negligence of prelates and the relaxation of discipline, this evil has grown to such an extent that in many churches, monasteries, and colleges, clerics publicly keep concubines, nourish children procreated from them in their houses, and lead a life as if legitimately married;

And whereas from this scandal innumerable evils have arisen: first, contempt of the sacraments, since the people shrink from receiving the sacraments from unchaste priests; second, the wasting of ecclesiastical goods, which are consumed upon concubines and children; third, the corruption of discipline, since younger clerics are provoked to similar things by the examples of their elders; fourth, the perdition of souls, both of the clerics themselves and of the women whom they keep and the children whom they procreate;

Considering furthermore that our predecessors in sacred councils established many and various penalties against this vice, but on account of defect of execution achieved little or nothing;

Wishing therefore not only to add new penalties, but also to provide efficaciously for execution, with the counsel and unanimous consent of this sacred council, we issue the following constitutions and decree them to be inviolably observed.

PART IV: DISPOSITIO - LEGAL PROVISIONS

SECTION A: DEFINITION OF CONCUBINAGE

Latin Text

Articulus Primus: Quid Sit Concubinatus

Ad tollendum omnem ambiguitatem, declaramus concubinatum clericorum esse, cum clericus in sacris ordinibus constitutus, vel religiosus cuiuscumque ordinis aut regulae, mulierem in domo sua vel alibi detinet, cum qua carnale commercium habet aut habere vehementer praesumitur, sive sit una sive plures, sive continue sive interpolate, sive in propria domo sive in conducta vel commodata.

Non intelligimus autem per hoc prohibere, quominus clerici habeant in domibus suis mulieres honestas ad necessaria ministeria, dummodo tales sint quae omnem suspicionem excludant: videlicet matres, amitas, sorores, aut alias consanguineas in gradibus a sacris canonibus permissis, vel mulieres provectae aetatis et probatae honestatis, quae sexagesimum annum attigerint.

Si vero clericus mulierem detineat quae praedictas conditiones non habeat, et fama publica de eorum inhonesta conversatione laboret, pro concubinario habeatur, donec contrarium legitime probaverit.

English Translation

Article One: What Concubinage Is

To remove all ambiguity, we declare clerical concubinage to exist when a cleric constituted in sacred orders, or a religious of whatever order or rule, keeps a woman in his house or elsewhere, with whom he has or is vehemently presumed to have carnal commerce, whether she be one or more, whether continuously or intermittently, whether in his own house or in one rented or borrowed.

We do not intend by this however to prohibit clerics from having in their houses honest women for necessary services, provided they are such as exclude all suspicion: namely mothers, aunts, sisters, or other blood relatives in degrees permitted by the sacred canons, or women of advanced age and proven honesty, who have attained sixty years.

If however a cleric keeps a woman who does not have the aforesaid conditions, and public report speaks of their dishonest association, let him be held as a concubinarian, until he shall have legitimately proven the contrary.

SECTION B: PERSONS SUBJECT TO THIS DECREE

Latin Text

Articulus Secundus: De Personis Huic Decreto Subiectis

Huic constitutioni subiacent omnes et singuli clerici in sacris ordinibus constituti, videlicet subdiaconi, diaconi, presbyteri, et episcopi, cuiuscumque dignitatis, praeeminentiae, status, vel conditionis existant, etiam si cardinalatus honore praefulgeant.

Item subiacent omnes religiosi, cuiuscumque ordinis, regulae, vel instituti, tam monachi quam canonici regulares, tam fratres mendicantes quam non mendicantes, tam viri quam mulieres religiosae.

Item subiacent omnes beneficiati, etiam si in minoribus ordinibus tantum constituti sint, qui beneficia ecclesiastica cum cura vel sine cura obtinent, ratione beneficii quod tenent.

Nullus omnino, cuiuscumque dignitatis aut status, ab huius constitutionis observantia se immunem reputet, cum aequum sit ut qui eiusdem professionis vinculo tenentur, eiusdem disciplinae rigore constringantur.

English Translation

Article Two: On Persons Subject to This Decree

To this constitution are subject each and all clerics constituted in sacred orders, namely subdeacons, deacons, priests, and bishops, of whatever dignity, preeminence, status, or condition they may be, even if they shine with the honor of the cardinalate.

Likewise are subject all religious, of whatever order, rule, or institute, both monks and canons regular, both mendicant friars and non-mendicant, both religious men and religious women.

Likewise are subject all beneficed clergy, even if constituted only in minor orders, who hold ecclesiastical benefices with or without cure of souls, by reason of the benefice which they hold.

Let absolutely no one, of whatever dignity or status, consider himself immune from the observance of this constitution, since it is equitable that those who are bound by the bond of the same profession should be constrained by the rigor of the same discipline.

SECTION C: GRADUATED PENALTIES

Latin Text

Articulus Tertius: De Poenis Gradatim Infligendis

Ut autem huius constitutionis transgressores debita poena coerceantur, et tamen poenitentibus via ad correctionem non praecludatur, sequentes poenas gradatim infligendas decernimus:

§1. De Prima Monitione:

Clericus qui concubinam detinere deprehensus fuerit, primo per suum ordinarium, vel eius officialem, secrete et paterne moneatur, ut infra sexaginta dies a die monitionis computandos, concubinam a se prorsus dimittat, et de cetero ab omni tali consortio abstineat.

Quae monitio fiat coram duobus testibus fide dignis, et in actis curiae episcopalis fideliter registretur.

Si infra praedictum terminum concubinam dimiserit et poenitentiam egerit, absolvatur et ad officia sua admittatur, sine alia poena vel nota infamiae.

English Translation

Article Three: On Penalties to be Inflicted Gradually

So that transgressors of this constitution may be coerced by due penalty, and yet the way to correction may not be closed to the penitent, we decree the following penalties to be inflicted gradually:

§1. On the First Warning:

A cleric who shall be discovered to keep a concubine shall first be warned by his ordinary, or his official, secretly and paternally, that within sixty days to be computed from the day of the warning, he shall utterly dismiss the concubine from himself, and henceforth abstain from all such association.

Which warning shall be made before two trustworthy witnesses, and shall be faithfully registered in the acts of the episcopal court.

If within the aforesaid term he shall have dismissed the concubine and done penance, let him be absolved and admitted to his offices, without other penalty or note of infamy.

Latin Text (continued)

§2. De Secunda Monitione et Poena:

Si vero post primam monitionem infra praedictum terminum concubinam non dimiserit, aut dimissam resumpserit, aut aliam assumpserit, tunc per suum ordinarium publice et solemniter moneatur in synodo dioecesana, vel in capitulo, vel coram clero et populo in ecclesia cathedrali.

Post hanc secundam monitionem, si infra triginta dies non paruerit, ipso facto suspensus sit ab executione ordinum et ab ingressu ecclesiae, ac tertia parte fructuum sui beneficii per annum privetur, quae tertia pars in pios usus, praesertim in refectionem fabricae ecclesiae vel in eleemosynas pauperum, convertatur.

Quae suspensio et privatio tamdiu duret, donec concubinam realiter et effectualiter dimiserit, et de commissis condigne satisfecerit.

English Translation (continued)

§2. On the Second Warning and Penalty:

If however after the first warning he shall not have dismissed the concubine within the aforesaid term, or shall have resumed one dismissed, or shall have taken up another, then let him be warned by his ordinary publicly and solemnly in the diocesan synod, or in the chapter, or before the clergy and people in the cathedral church.

After this second warning, if he shall not have obeyed within thirty days, let him be suspended by that very fact from the execution of orders and from entrance to the church, and let him be deprived of the third part of the fruits of his benefice for a year, which third part shall be converted to pious uses, especially to the repair of the church fabric or to alms for the poor.

Which suspension and deprivation shall last until he shall have really and effectually dismissed the concubine, and shall have made fitting satisfaction for his offenses.

Latin Text (continued)

§3. De Tertia Monitione et Poena Graviore:

Si autem post secundam monitionem et praedictas poenas, adhuc in sua pertinacia perseveraverit, et concubinam detinere non desierit, tunc tertio moneatur per ordinarium, cum intimatione quod nisi infra viginti dies satisfecerit, ad graviores poenas procedetur.

Quibus viginti diebus elapsis, si adhuc contumaciter perseveraverit, ipso facto privatus sit omnibus beneficiis ecclesiasticis quae obtinet, et perpetuo inhabilis ad alia quaecumque beneficia obtinenda, absque spe restitutionis, nisi per sedem apostolicam cum eo specialiter dispensetur.

Praeterea, si fuerit in sacris ordinibus constitutus, ab omni ordinis executione perpetuo suspendatur, et si in sua contumacia per annum perseveraverit, tamquam incorrigibilis degradetur et curiae saeculari tradatur.

English Translation (continued)

§3. On the Third Warning and More Severe Penalty:

If however after the second warning and the aforesaid penalties, he shall still persevere in his obstinacy, and shall not have ceased to keep a concubine, then let him be warned a third time by the ordinary, with intimation that unless he shall have made satisfaction within twenty days, more severe penalties shall be proceeded to.

Which twenty days having elapsed, if he shall still contumaciously persevere, let him be deprived by that very fact of all ecclesiastical benefices which he holds, and perpetually incapable of obtaining any other benefices whatsoever, without hope of restitution, unless it shall be specially dispensed with him by the apostolic see.

Furthermore, if he shall have been constituted in sacred orders, let him be perpetually suspended from all execution of orders, and if he shall have persevered in his contumacy for a year, let him be degraded as incorrigible and handed over to the secular court.

SECTION D: SPECIAL PROVISIONS FOR PRELATES

Latin Text

Articulus Quartus: De Praelatis Concubinariis

Quoniam praelati debent esse forma gregis, et eorum culpa gravior est quanto in altiori loco positi sunt, specialiter statuimus de episcopis et aliis praelatis superioribus:

Si episcopus vel alius praelatus superior concubinam detinere deprehensus fuerit, a metropolitano suo, vel si ipse metropolitanus sit, a concilio provinciali moneatur.

Si post monitionem in suo crimine perseveraverit, suspendatur ab administratione spiritualium et temporalium suae ecclesiae, et causa eius ad hanc sanctam synodum, vel ad Romanum pontificem, vel ad legatum sedis apostolicae deferatur.

Si vero post annum in sua contumacia perstiterit, tamquam scandalosus et incorrigibilis, per hanc sanctam synodum vel per Romanum pontificem ab episcopatu deponatur.

Metropolitani vero, qui in moniendis et puniendis suffraganeis suis negligentes fuerint, sciant se rationem reddituros coram Deo et coram hac sancta synodo, et poena suspensionis a pallio per annum plectendos.

English Translation

Article Four: On Concubinarian Prelates

Since prelates ought to be a pattern to the flock, and their fault is the more grave the higher the place in which they are set, we specially decree concerning bishops and other superior prelates:

If a bishop or other superior prelate shall be discovered to keep a concubine, let him be warned by his metropolitan, or if he himself be a metropolitan, by the provincial council.

If after the warning he shall persevere in his crime, let him be suspended from the administration of the spiritual and temporal affairs of his church, and let his cause be referred to this holy synod, or to the Roman pontiff, or to a legate of the apostolic see.

If however after a year he shall persist in his contumacy, let him be deposed from the episcopate as scandalous and incorrigible, by this holy synod or by the Roman pontiff.

Let metropolitans moreover who shall be negligent in warning and punishing their suffragans know that they shall render account before God and before this holy synod, and shall be smitten with the penalty of suspension from the pallium for a year.

SECTION E: ON THE CHILDREN OF CLERGY

Latin Text

Articulus Quintus: De Filiis Clericorum

Licet filii pro peccatis parentum puniri non debeant, tamen ne clericos ad continendum concubinas utilitas filiorum invitet, sequentia decernimus:

§1. Filii clericorum ex concubinatu nati, in ecclesia in qua pater eorum beneficium obtinet vel obtinuit, nullum beneficium ecclesiasticum obtinere possint, nec ad ordines sacros in eadem ecclesia promoveri.

§2. In aliis vero ecclesiis, praedicti filii beneficia obtinere possint, dummodo super defectu natalium cum eis per ordinarium loci dispensetur, et dummodo vitam honestam ducant et ad ordines idonei reperiantur.

§3. Bona temporalia a parentibus clericis acquisita, filii huiusmodi legitime succedere possint secundum leges civiles locorum, exceptis bonis quae ex proventibus ecclesiasticis manifeste provenerunt, quae bona ecclesiae a qua provenerunt restituantur.

§4. Nullus clericus filium suum ex concubinatu natum, in beneficio suo, vel in ecclesia sua, retineat tanquam clericum vel ministrum, ne scandalum augeatur et occasio peccandi praebeatur.

English Translation

Article Five: On the Children of Clergy

Although children ought not to be punished for the sins of their parents, nevertheless lest the advantage of children invite clerics to keep concubines, we decree the following:

§1. Children of clerics born from concubinage cannot obtain any ecclesiastical benefice in the church in which their father holds or held a benefice, nor be promoted to sacred orders in the same church.

§2. In other churches however, the aforesaid children can obtain benefices, provided it shall be dispensed with them by the ordinary of the place concerning the defect of birth, and provided they lead an honest life and are found suitable for orders.

§3. Temporal goods acquired by their clerical parents, such children can legitimately succeed to according to the civil laws of the places, excepting goods which manifestly came from ecclesiastical revenues, which goods shall be restored to the church from which they came.

§4. Let no cleric retain his son born from concubinage, in his benefice or in his church, as a cleric or minister, lest scandal be increased and occasion of sinning be provided.

SECTION F: ENFORCEMENT MECHANISMS

Latin Text

Articulus Sextus: De Executione Huius Decreti

Ne haec salutaris constitutio, sicut multae praedecessorum nostrorum, per defectum executionis inutilis reddatur, de modo executionis diligenter providemus:

§1. De Synodis Dioecesanis et Provincialibus:

Statuimus ut in qualibet dioecesi, synodus dioecesana singulis annis celebretur, in qua inter cetera de statu clericorum et de observantia huius constitutionis diligenter inquiratur.

Item, synodus provincialis saltem singulis trienniis celebretur, in qua metropolitanus cum suffraganeis suis de executione huius decreti in singulis dioecesibus rationem exigat.

§2. De Inquisitione Facienda:

Ordinarii locorum, vel eorum officiales, singulis annis per se vel per personas idoneas, diligenter inquirant de clericis concubinariis in suis dioecesibus.

Ad hanc inquisitionem faciendam, possint uti testimonio fama publicae, et interrogare testes ex officio, et compellere ad testificandum omnes qui de crimine noverint.

Si per inquisitionem invenerint clericos concubinarios, procedant contra eos secundum formam huius decreti, sine personarum acceptione.

English Translation

Article Six: On the Execution of This Decree

Lest this salutary constitution, like many of our predecessors, be rendered useless through defect of execution, we diligently provide concerning the manner of execution:

§1. On Diocesan and Provincial Synods:

We decree that in every diocese, a diocesan synod shall be celebrated each year, in which among other things diligent inquiry shall be made concerning the state of the clergy and the observance of this constitution.

Likewise, a provincial synod shall be celebrated at least every three years, in which the metropolitan with his suffragans shall demand an account of the execution of this decree in each diocese.

§2. On the Inquiry to be Made:

The ordinaries of places, or their officials, shall each year by themselves or through suitable persons, diligently inquire concerning concubinarian clerics in their dioceses.

For making this inquiry, they may use the testimony of public report, and interrogate witnesses ex officio, and compel all who have knowledge of the crime to testify.

If through the inquiry they shall find concubinarian clerics, let them proceed against them according to the form of this decree, without respect of persons.

Latin Text (continued)

§3. De Commissione Supervisoria:

Ad maiorem huius decreti observantiam, instituimus commissionem ex tribus praelatis et duobus doctoribus iuris canonici, a hac sancta synodo deputandam, quae de executione huius constitutionis in universa ecclesia cognitionem habeat.

Ad hanc commissionem, metropolitani singulis annis relationem mittant de statu suarum provinciarum quoad observantiam huius decreti, et de poenis inflictis et de casibus difficilibus.

Commissio praedicta habeat potestatem monendi metropolitanos negligentes, et si opus fuerit, causas ad hanc sanctam synodum referendi.

§4. De Poenis Negligentium:

Ordinarii qui in executione huius decreti negligentes fuerint, si semel moniti per commissionem praedictam non se emendaverint, per hanc sanctam synodum puniantur, prout culpae qualitas exegerit.

Si vero ordinarius ipse concubinarius fuerit, et propter hoc in puniendis aliis negligens, gravius puniatur, utpote qui et ipse reus est et alios reos impunitos dimittit.

English Translation (continued)

§3. On the Supervisory Commission:

For the greater observance of this decree, we institute a commission of three prelates and two doctors of canon law, to be deputed by this holy synod, which shall have cognizance of the execution of this constitution in the universal church.

To this commission, metropolitans shall send each year a report on the state of their provinces regarding the observance of this decree, and concerning penalties inflicted and difficult cases.

The aforesaid commission shall have the power of warning negligent metropolitans, and if necessary, of referring causes to this holy synod.

§4. On Penalties for the Negligent:

Ordinaries who shall be negligent in the execution of this decree, if once warned by the aforesaid commission they shall not have amended themselves, shall be punished by this holy synod, as the quality of the fault shall require.

If however the ordinary himself shall be a concubinarian, and negligent on account of this in punishing others, let him be more severely punished, as one who both is himself guilty and lets other guilty persons go unpunished.

SECTION G: GRACE PERIOD FOR COMPLIANCE

Latin Text

Articulus Septimus: De Tempore ad Parendum Concesso

Quoniam multi clerici, longa consuetudine decepti, in hoc vitio versantur, nec statim se corrigere possunt sine aliqua praeparatione, clementer indulgemus:

Omnibus clericis qui ante publicationem huius decreti concubinas detinebant, concedimus spatium nonaginta dierum, a die publicationis in singulis dioecesibus computandorum, infra quos possint concubinas dimittere et vitam suam emendare, sine ulla poena et sine nota infamiae.

Qui infra praedictum terminum concubinas dimiserint et poenitentiam coram ordinario suo egerint, absolvendi sunt et ad officia sua plenarie restituendi, ac si nunquam deliquissent.

Post praedictum vero terminum, contra omnes qui concubinas detinere non desierint, procedatur secundum formam supra traditam, incipiendo a prima monitione.

Hanc gratiam semel tantum concedimus; qui post hanc primam gratiam in vitium reciderint, nullam aliam gratiam expectent, sed statim a secunda monitione procedatur contra eos.

English Translation

Article Seven: On the Time Granted for Compliance

Since many clerics, deceived by long custom, are engaged in this vice, nor can immediately correct themselves without some preparation, we clemently indulge:

To all clerics who kept concubines before the publication of this decree, we grant a space of ninety days, to be computed from the day of publication in each diocese, within which they may dismiss their concubines and amend their life, without any penalty and without note of infamy.

Those who shall have dismissed their concubines within the aforesaid term and done penance before their ordinary, are to be absolved and fully restored to their offices, as if they had never offended.

After the aforesaid term however, let proceedings be taken according to the form handed down above against all who shall not have ceased to keep concubines, beginning from the first warning.

This grace we grant once only; those who after this first grace shall have relapsed into the vice, let them expect no other grace, but let proceedings be taken against them immediately from the second warning.

SECTION H: EVIDENTIARY PROVISIONS

Latin Text

Articulus Octavus: De Modo Probandi

Quoniam in criminibus occultis probatio difficilis est, et tamen impunitas delinquentibus audaciam tribuit, de modo probandi huius criminis sequentia statuimus:

§1. Si duo testes fide digni de visu vel de certo scientia deposuerint clericum concubinam detinere, pro plene probato habeatur.

§2. Si fama publica et constans in parochia vel dioecesi clericum de concubinatu diffamat, ordinarius possit procedere ex officio ad inquisitionem, et clericum compellere ad se purgandum.

§3. Ad purgandum se, clericus debet iurare tactis sacris evangeliis se concubinam non habere nec habuisse, et adducere tres vel quatuor compurgatores, clericos vel laicos honesti testimonii, qui similiter iurent se credere ipsum verum iurare.

§4. Si clericus purgationem recusaverit, vel in purgatione defecerit, pro convicto habeatur et secundum formam huius decreti puniatur.

§5. Contra infamatos qui se legitime purgaverint, non licet amplius procedere propter eandem infamiam, nisi nova indicia supervenerint.

English Translation

Article Eight: On the Manner of Proving

Since in hidden crimes proof is difficult, and yet impunity gives boldness to delinquents, we decree the following concerning the manner of proving this crime:

§1. If two trustworthy witnesses shall have deposed from sight or from certain knowledge that a cleric keeps a concubine, let it be held as fully proven.

§2. If public and constant report in the parish or diocese defames a cleric of concubinage, the ordinary may proceed ex officio to inquiry, and compel the cleric to purge himself.

§3. To purge himself, the cleric must swear touching the holy gospels that he does not have and has not had a concubine, and bring three or four compurgators, clerics or laymen of honest testimony, who shall similarly swear that they believe him to swear truly.

§4. If the cleric shall have refused the purgation, or shall have failed in the purgation, let him be held as convicted and punished according to the form of this decree.

§5. Against those defamed who shall have legitimately purged themselves, it is not permitted to proceed further on account of the same infamy, unless new indications shall have supervened.

PART V: SANCTIO - ENFORCEMENT CLAUSE

Latin Text

Nulli ergo omnino hominum liceat hanc paginam nostrae constitutionis, definitionis, statuti, mandati, praecepti et voluntatis infringere, vel ei ausu temerario contraire.

Si quis autem hoc attemptare praesumpserit, indignationem omnipotentis Dei et beatorum Petri et Pauli apostolorum eius se noverit incursurum, et a communione fidelium exclusum, et ab omnibus beneficiis ecclesiasticis quae obtinet privatum, absque spe restitutionis.

Decernimus insuper, ut haec constitutio in omnibus ecclesiis cathedralibus, collegiatis, et parochialibus, singulis annis in die Coenae Domini, vel alia die solemni, publice legatur et exponatur, ut nullus ignorantiam praetendere possit.

Ordinariis locorum, sub poena suspensionis, praecipimus, ut infra sex menses a die publicationis huius decreti in hac sancta synodo, illud in suis dioecesibus publicent et executioni demandent.

English Translation

Let it therefore be permitted to absolutely no man to infringe this document of our constitution, definition, statute, mandate, precept and will, or with rash daring to contravene it.

If anyone however shall presume to attempt this, let him know that he shall incur the indignation of almighty God and of the blessed Peter and Paul his apostles, and shall be excluded from the communion of the faithful, and deprived of all ecclesiastical benefices which he holds, without hope of restitution.

We decree furthermore, that this constitution shall be publicly read and expounded in all cathedral, collegiate, and parochial churches, each year on the day of the Lord's Supper, or another solemn day, so that no one may be able to pretend ignorance.

We command the ordinaries of places, under penalty of suspension, that within six months from the day of publication of this decree in this holy synod, they publish it in their dioceses and commit it to execution.

PART VI: APPROBATIO & SUBSCRIPTIONES

Latin Text

Approbatio Synodalis

Haec sancta et universalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, praesens decretum de extirpatione concubinatus clericorum, omnibus suis partibus diligenter examinatis et approbatis, in sessione publica sollemniter promulgavit, die decima quarta mensis Septembris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio.

Omnes deputationes, videlicet deputatio fidei, deputatio pacis, deputatio reformatorii, et deputatio pro communibus, huic decreto unanimiter consenserunt.

Legatur, publicetur, et executioni mandetur in universa ecclesia, ad laudem Dei omnipotentis et reformationem ecclesiae suae sanctae.

English Translation

Synodal Approbation

This holy and universal synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, solemnly promulgated the present decree on the extirpation of clerical concubinage, all its parts having been diligently examined and approved, in public session on the fourteenth day of the month of September, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three.

All the deputations, namely the deputation of faith, the deputation of peace, the deputation of reform, and the deputation for common affairs, unanimously consented to this decree.

Let it be read, published, and committed to execution in the universal church, for the praise of almighty God and the reformation of his holy church.

Latin Text (continued)

Subscriptiones

✠ Iulianus, miseratione divina tituli Sanctae Sabinae sanctae Romanae ecclesiae presbyter cardinalis, sacri concilii Basiliensis praesidens, subscripsi.

✠ Ludovicus, tituli Sanctae Caeciliae presbyter cardinalis Arelatensis, subscripsi.

✠ Ioannes, archiepiscopus Tarentasiensis, deputationis reformatorii praesidens, subscripsi.

✠ Ioannes, episcopus Lubicensis, subscripsi.

✠ Philibertus, episcopus Constantiensis, subscripsi.

[Sequuntur subscriptiones aliorum patrum concilii, tam praelatorum quam doctorum et abbatum]

English Translation (continued)

Subscriptions

✠ Julian, by divine mercy cardinal priest of the holy Roman church of the title of Saint Sabina, president of the sacred Council of Basel, subscribed.

✠ Louis, cardinal priest of the title of Saint Cecilia, of Arles, subscribed.

✠ John, archbishop of Tarentaise, president of the deputation of reform, subscribed.

✠ John, bishop of Lübeck, subscribed.

✠ Philibert, bishop of Constance, subscribed.

[There follow the subscriptions of other fathers of the council, both prelates and doctors and abbots]

Latin Text (continued)

Attestatio Notarii

Ego, Ioannes de Segovia, notarius et secretarius huius sanctae synodi, praesens decretum fideliter scripsi et subscripsi, in fidem et testimonium omnium praemissorum.

Actum et datum Basileae, in sessione decima quinta huius sacri concilii, die decima quarta mensis Septembris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio, pontificatus sanctissimi in Christo patris et domini nostri, domini Eugenii divina providentia papae quarti, anno tertio.

English Translation (continued)

Attestation of the Notary

I, John of Segovia, notary and secretary of this holy synod, have faithfully written and subscribed the present decree, in faith and testimony of all the aforesaid.

Done and given at Basel, in the fifteenth session of this sacred council, on the fourteenth day of the month of September, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three, in the third year of the pontificate of the most holy father in Christ and our lord, lord Eugene by divine providence fourth pope.

PART VII: CONCLUSIO

Latin Text

Deo Gratias

Haec sancta synodus Basiliensis, considerans quod castitas clericorum est fundamentum disciplinae ecclesiasticae et exemplum fidelibus, gratias agit aeterno Deo omnipotenti, qui dedit nobis gratiam hanc legem statuendi ad honorem nominis sui et ad purificationem ecclesiae suae.

Invocamus super hoc decretum benedictionem Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, et intercessionem beatissimae Virginis Mariae, quae virgo ante partum, in partu, et post partum permansit, ut clerici eius exemplo ad castitatem invitentur.

Rogamus omnes praelatos, ordinarios, et superiores, ut hoc decretum fideliter exequantur, non obstantibus quibuscumque consuetudinibus contrariis, quas penitus reprobamus et annullamus.

Et rogamus omnes clericos, ut non expectent coactionem iudicis, sed sponte et libere vitam suam emendent, memores illius verbi Domini: "Estote ergo vos perfecti, sicut et Pater vester caelestis perfectus est."

Amen. Fiat, fiat, fiat.

English Translation

Thanks be to God

This holy synod of Basel, considering that the chastity of clerics is the foundation of ecclesiastical discipline and an example to the faithful, gives thanks to the eternal almighty God, who gave us the grace to establish this law for the honor of his name and for the purification of his church.

We invoke upon this decree the blessing of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, and the intercession of the most blessed Virgin Mary, who remained a virgin before birth, in birth, and after birth, that by her example clerics may be invited to chastity.

We ask all prelates, ordinaries, and superiors, that they faithfully execute this decree, notwithstanding any contrary customs whatsoever, which we utterly reprove and annul.

And we ask all clerics, that they not await the coercion of the judge, but spontaneously and freely amend their life, mindful of that word of the Lord: "Be you therefore perfect, as also your heavenly Father is perfect."

Amen. Let it be done, let it be done, let it be done.

FINIS DECRETI

END OF DECREE

Historical Note

This decree represents the Council of Basel's Session 15 (September 14, 1433), passed during the period of extraordinary productivity following the arrival of Emperor Sigismund and the reception of the Declaration of Como. In the standard historical timeline, the Council of Basel passed its concubinage decree on January 22, 1435 (Session 20). In this alternate timeline, the energizing effect of the Imperial-Castilian alliance accelerated the Council's reform agenda.

The decree follows authentic fifteenth-century ecclesiastical conventions in structure, terminology, and legal precision. The graduated penalty system (warning → suspension and partial deprivation → full deprivation and perpetual incapacity) reflects the approach actually taken by Basel and later codified at Trent. The supervisory commission reflects the institutional accountability mechanism proposed in the Declaration of Como.

The Latin text employs technical vocabulary and formulaic expressions characteristic of Basel's decrees, including the cursus rhythmicus in solemn passages. The English translation preserves the formal, precise character of medieval ecclesiastical legislation.

Key features distinguishing this decree from earlier medieval legislation on concubinage:
1. Comprehensive definition of what constitutes concubinage
2. Graduated penalty system allowing for repentance
3. Enforcement mechanisms with annual reporting requirements
4. Supervisory commission to ensure compliance
5. Grace period for existing offenders
6. Detailed evidentiary procedures balancing proof requirements with practical enforcement
