laws.title: Council of Basel Session 16: Decree on Pluralism
laws.summary: The Council prohibits the holding of multiple benefices with cure of souls, requiring clergy to choose one benefice within six months and vacate all others, with revenues from vacated benefices redirected to parish maintenance and clerical education.
laws.full_text:
COUNCIL OF BASEL - SESSION 16
DECREE ON THE LIMITATION OF PLURALISM AND THE HOLDING OF MULTIPLE BENEFICES
Decretum de Limitatione Pluralitatis et Detentione Plurium Beneficiorum

Session 16 - September 28, 1433
Sessio XVI - XXVIII Septembris MCDXXXIII

PART I: INTITULATIO & INVOCATIO

Latin Text

Sacrosancta generalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, ad perpetuam rei memoriam.

Haec sancta synodus, divina favente clementia, ad reformationem ecclesiae in capite et in membris congregata, omnibus Christi fidelibus tam praesentibus quam futuris, praesertim vero praelatis, collatoribus beneficiorum, et clericis beneficia ecclesiastica obtinentibus vel obtinere cupientibus, salutem in Domino sempiternam et pastoralis officii debitam executionem.

English Translation

The holy general synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, for an everlasting record.

This holy synod, assembled by divine favor for the reformation of the church in head and members, to all the faithful of Christ both present and future, but especially to prelates, collators of benefices, and clerics holding or desiring to hold ecclesiastical benefices, eternal salvation in the Lord and the due execution of pastoral office.

PART II: PREAMBLE & ARENGA - THEOLOGICAL JUSTIFICATION

Latin Text

Sicut pastor bonus animam suam ponit pro ovibus suis, et oves suas vocat nominatim, et cognoscit eas, et cognoscitur ab eis; sic clericus cui cura animarum commissa est, debet gregem sibi creditum personaliter pascere, cognoscere, et ab eo cognosci. Quomodo enim pastor cognoscet oves suas, si eas nunquam videt? Quomodo oves cognoscent vocem pastoris sui, si eam nunquam audiunt?

Constat autem, quod inter cetera mala quae ecclesiam Dei affligunt, nihil magis perniciosum est animabus fidelium, nihil magis contrarium institutioni divinae, nihil magis scandalosum populo Christiano, quam cum unus clericus plura beneficia ecclesiastica detinet, quorum curam exercere non potest, et oves sibi commissas mercenariis relinquit, qui non curant de ovibus sed solummodo de lana et lacte.

Hoc malum, quod pluralitas beneficiorum vulgariter appellatur, antiquitus a sanctis patribus damnatum et multiplicibus sanctionibus prohibitum, praesertim in sacrosancto Concilio Lateranensi sub felicis recordationis Innocentio III celebrato, in tantum crevit et invaluit, ut hodie reperiantur clerici qui tres, quatuor, quinque, aut etiam plures ecclesias parochiales detinent, quarum nullam visitant, nullam cognoscunt, nullam personaliter regunt.

Inveniuntur etiam praelati qui plures episcopatus simul obtinent, plures abbatias, plures dignitates, et ex omnibus fructus colligunt, sed in nullis residentiam faciunt, nullis pastoralem curam impendunt. Unde fit ut animae pereant sine pastore, sacramenta negligantur, ecclesiae corruant, populus in ignorantia versetur, et nomen Dei blasphemetur inter gentes.

Nos igitur, quibus ex officio incumbit providere ne oves Christi sine pastore errent, volentes huic morbo antiquo et inveterato efficax tandem remedium adhibere, ac de consilio et assensu huius sacri concilii, praesentem constitutionem perpetuo valituram edimus et promulgamus.

English Translation

Just as the good shepherd lays down his life for his sheep, and calls his sheep by name, and knows them, and is known by them; so a cleric to whom the cure of souls has been committed ought to feed personally the flock entrusted to him, to know them, and to be known by them. For how shall a shepherd know his sheep, if he never sees them? How shall sheep know the voice of their shepherd, if they never hear it?

It is established moreover that among the other evils which afflict God's church, nothing is more pernicious to the souls of the faithful, nothing more contrary to divine institution, nothing more scandalous to the Christian people, than when one cleric holds several ecclesiastical benefices, the care of which he cannot exercise, and leaves the sheep committed to him to hirelings, who care not for the sheep but only for the wool and milk.

This evil, which is commonly called plurality of benefices, anciently condemned by the holy fathers and prohibited by manifold sanctions, especially in the most holy Lateran Council celebrated under Innocent III of happy memory, has grown and prevailed to such an extent that today there are found clerics who hold three, four, five, or even more parish churches, none of which they visit, none of which they know, none of which they personally govern.

There are found also prelates who hold several bishoprics at once, several abbacies, several dignities, and from all of them collect the fruits, but in none make residence, to none extend pastoral care. Whence it comes that souls perish without a shepherd, sacraments are neglected, churches fall into ruin, the people are kept in ignorance, and the name of God is blasphemed among the nations.

We therefore, upon whom it falls by duty of office to provide lest Christ's sheep wander without a shepherd, wishing to apply at last an efficacious remedy to this ancient and inveterate disease, and with the counsel and assent of this sacred council, issue and promulgate the present constitution to be valid in perpetuity.

PART III: NARRATIO - HISTORICAL CIRCUMSTANCES

Latin Text

Cum olim per sacrorum canonum instituta, et praesertim per constitutionem Concilii Lateranensis quarti, cap. "De multa," prohibitum fuerit ne quis plura beneficia ecclesiastica cum cura animarum obtineret, sub poena amissionis beneficii prius obtenti et inhabilitatis ad aliud obtinendum;

Et cum eadem constitutio statuerit, quod si quis beneficium cum cura animarum habens, aliud simile receperit, priori ipso iure privatus existat, et si illud retinere contenderit, etiam alio spolietur;

Sed procedente tempore, per frequentes dispensationes a sede apostolica impetratas, haec salubris constitutio fere penitus evacuata est, ita ut hodie dispensatio sit regula et lex sit exceptio;

Et cum ex hac corruptela innumerabilia mala provenerint: primo, derelictio animarum, cum pastores absentes oves suas mercenariis committant qui non curant de ovibus; secundo, dilapidatio bonorum ecclesiasticorum, cum fructus beneficiorum in luxum et pompam consumantur, et nihil in fabricam ecclesiarum vel in pauperum sustentationem erogetur; tertio, contemptus legis divinae et canonicae, cum clerici videant legem impune violari et violatores honoribus et divitiis cumulari;

Considerantes praeterea, quod praedecessores nostri in sacris conciliis multoties contra hoc vitium statuerunt, sed propter dispensationum facilitatem et executionis defectum nihil profecerunt;

Volentes igitur non solum antiquam legem renovare, sed etiam viam dispensationibus praecludere et executionem efficaciter providere, de consilio et unanimi consensu huius sacri concilii, sequentes constitutiones edimus et inviolabiliter observandas decernimus.

English Translation

Whereas of old, by the institution of the sacred canons, and especially by the constitution of the Fourth Lateran Council, chapter "De multa," it was prohibited that anyone should hold several ecclesiastical benefices with cure of souls, under penalty of loss of the benefice previously held and incapacity to obtain another;

And whereas the same constitution decreed that if anyone having a benefice with cure of souls should receive another similar one, he should exist deprived by the law itself of the former, and if he should contend to retain it, he should be despoiled also of the other;

But as time proceeded, through frequent dispensations obtained from the apostolic see, this salutary constitution has been almost entirely emptied out, so that today dispensation is the rule and law is the exception;

And whereas from this corruption innumerable evils have arisen: first, the abandonment of souls, since absent pastors commit their sheep to hirelings who care not for the sheep; second, the wasting of ecclesiastical goods, since the fruits of benefices are consumed in luxury and pomp, and nothing is expended on the fabric of churches or the sustenance of the poor; third, contempt of divine and canonical law, since clerics see the law violated with impunity and violators heaped with honors and riches;

Considering furthermore that our predecessors in sacred councils have many times decreed against this vice, but on account of the facility of dispensations and the defect of execution have achieved nothing;

Wishing therefore not only to renew the ancient law, but also to close the way to dispensations and to provide efficaciously for execution, with the counsel and unanimous consent of this sacred council, we issue the following constitutions and decree them to be inviolably observed.

PART IV: DISPOSITIO - LEGAL PROVISIONS

SECTION A: DEFINITIONS

Latin Text

Articulus Primus: De Definitionibus

Ad tollendum omnem ambiguitatem circa materiam huius decreti, sequentes definitiones statuimus:

§1. Beneficium ecclesiasticum est ius perpetuum percipiendi fructus ex bonis ecclesiasticis, ratione spiritualis officii a legitima auctoritate ecclesiastica constitutum.

§2. Beneficium cum cura animarum est illud cui annexa est obligatio pascendi fideles per administrationem sacramentorum, praedicationem verbi Dei, et alia spiritualia ministeria. Huiusmodi sunt episcopatus, parochiae, prioratus conventuales cum subiectis, abbatiae cum cura parochianorum, et similia.

§3. Beneficium sine cura animarum est illud cui non est annexa directa obligatio pascendi fideles, sed solummodo aliquod spirituale ministerium, ut cantare in choro, interesse officiis divinis, vel similia. Huiusmodi sunt canonicatus, praebendae, capellaniae simplices, et similia.

§4. Beneficia incompatibilia sunt illa quae simul ab uno homine teneri non possunt, vel propter naturam ipsorum, vel propter distantiam localem, vel propter legis prohibitionem.

§5. Pluralitas beneficiorum est detentio plurium beneficiorum incompatibilium ab uno et eodem clerico.

English Translation

Article One: On Definitions

To remove all ambiguity concerning the matter of this decree, we establish the following definitions:

§1. An ecclesiastical benefice is a perpetual right of receiving the fruits from ecclesiastical goods, constituted by legitimate ecclesiastical authority by reason of a spiritual office.

§2. A benefice with cure of souls is one to which is annexed the obligation of feeding the faithful through the administration of sacraments, the preaching of the word of God, and other spiritual ministries. Of this kind are bishoprics, parishes, conventual priories with subjects, abbacies with care of parishioners, and the like.

§3. A benefice without cure of souls is one to which is not annexed the direct obligation of feeding the faithful, but only some spiritual ministry, such as singing in choir, being present at divine offices, or the like. Of this kind are canonries, prebends, simple chaplaincies, and the like.

§4. Incompatible benefices are those which cannot be held simultaneously by one man, either on account of their very nature, or on account of local distance, or on account of the prohibition of law.

§5. Plurality of benefices is the holding of several incompatible benefices by one and the same cleric.

SECTION B: GENERAL PROHIBITION

Latin Text

Articulus Secundus: De Generali Prohibitione Pluralitatis

Renovantes et confirmantes constitutionem Concilii Lateranensis quarti, et eam ampliantes et declarantes, statuimus et ordinamus:

§1. Nullus clericus, cuiuscumque ordinis, dignitatis, status, vel conditionis existat, etiam si cardinalatus honore praefulgeat, possit vel debeat de cetero obtinere vel retinere plura beneficia ecclesiastica cum cura animarum.

§2. Qui unum beneficium cum cura animarum obtinet, si aliud beneficium cum cura animarum acceptaverit, priori ipso iure privatus existat, absque alia declaratione, et secundum beneficium nulliter et invalide obtineat.

§3. Similiter, nullus possit vel debeat obtinere simul duas dignitates in eadem ecclesia, vel duas dignitates principales in diversis ecclesiis, etiam si neutrae sit annexa cura animarum.

§4. Nullus possit obtinere simul episcopatum et abbatiam, vel duo episcopatus, vel duas abbatias, etiam si unus vel una sit in commendam.

§5. Haec prohibitio extenditur ad omnes modos acquirendi beneficia, sive per electionem, sive per collationem, sive per praesentationem, sive per quemcumque alium modum canonicum vel non canonicum.

English Translation

Article Two: On the General Prohibition of Plurality

Renewing and confirming the constitution of the Fourth Lateran Council, and amplifying and declaring it, we decree and ordain:

§1. No cleric, of whatever order, dignity, status, or condition he may be, even if he shines with the honor of the cardinalate, can or ought henceforth to obtain or retain several ecclesiastical benefices with cure of souls.

§2. He who holds one benefice with cure of souls, if he shall have accepted another benefice with cure of souls, shall exist deprived by the law itself of the former, without other declaration, and shall hold the second benefice nullly and invalidly.

§3. Similarly, no one can or ought to hold simultaneously two dignities in the same church, or two principal dignities in different churches, even if neither has cure of souls annexed.

§4. No one can hold simultaneously a bishopric and an abbacy, or two bishoprics, or two abbacies, even if one is held in commendam.

§5. This prohibition extends to all modes of acquiring benefices, whether by election, or by collation, or by presentation, or by any other mode canonical or non-canonical.

SECTION C: BENEFICES WITHOUT CURE OF SOULS

Latin Text

Articulus Tertius: De Beneficiis Sine Cura Animarum

Quamvis beneficia sine cura animarum minus periculosa sint animabus quam illa cum cura, tamen eorum nimia cumulatio scandalosum est et ecclesiae damnosum. Ideo statuimus:

§1. Nullus clericus possit obtinere simul plures quam tres canonicatus vel praebendas in diversis ecclesiis cathedralibus vel collegiatis.

§2. Nullus possit obtinere simul plures quam duas dignitates vel personatus sine cura animarum.

§3. Si quis plures canonicatus vel praebendas quam supra dictum est obtineat, teneatur infra sex menses a die publicationis huius decreti resignare omnes praeter tres, quos ipse elegerit retinere. Quod si non fecerit, omnes ipso iure vacent.

§4. Excipiuntur tamen a praedicta limitatione canonicatus et praebendae quorum fructus annui decem florenos auri de camera non excedunt; tales enim propter tenuitatem reddituum cumulari possunt usque ad summam quadraginta florenorum annuorum.

English Translation

Article Three: On Benefices Without Cure of Souls

Although benefices without cure of souls are less dangerous to souls than those with cure, nevertheless their excessive accumulation is scandalous and harmful to the church. Therefore we decree:

§1. No cleric can hold simultaneously more than three canonries or prebends in different cathedral or collegiate churches.

§2. No one can hold simultaneously more than two dignities or personates without cure of souls.

§3. If anyone holds more canonries or prebends than stated above, he shall be bound within six months from the day of publication of this decree to resign all except three, which he himself shall choose to retain. If he shall not have done so, all shall be vacant by the law itself.

§4. Excepted however from the aforesaid limitation are canonries and prebends whose annual fruits do not exceed ten gold florins of the camera; for such, on account of the slenderness of their revenues, can be accumulated up to a sum of forty annual florins.

SECTION D: INCOMPATIBLE BENEFICES

Latin Text

Articulus Quartus: De Beneficiis Incompatibilibus Ratione Distantiae

Praeter incompatibilitatem quae oritur ex natura beneficiorum, statuimus incompatibilitatem ratione distantiae localis:

§1. Duo beneficia cum residentia, etiam sine cura animarum, sunt incompatibilia si distent ab invicem plus quam per unam dietam, id est triginta milliaria.

§2. Beneficium cum cura animarum et aliud beneficium quodcumque cum residentia sunt incompatibilia si distent plus quam per dimidiam dietam, id est quindecim milliaria.

§3. Duo beneficia cum cura animarum sunt semper incompatibilia, etiam si sint in eadem civitate vel eodem oppido, quia una persona non potest duobus gregibus simul invigilare.

§4. Si quis beneficia incompatibilia ratione distantiae de facto obtineat, teneatur infra tres menses alterum resignare; alioquin utroque ipso iure privatus existat.

English Translation

Article Four: On Benefices Incompatible by Reason of Distance

Besides the incompatibility which arises from the nature of benefices, we decree incompatibility by reason of local distance:

§1. Two benefices with residence, even without cure of souls, are incompatible if they are distant from each other by more than one day's journey, that is, thirty miles.

§2. A benefice with cure of souls and any other benefice with residence are incompatible if they are distant by more than half a day's journey, that is, fifteen miles.

§3. Two benefices with cure of souls are always incompatible, even if they are in the same city or the same town, because one person cannot watch over two flocks at once.

§4. If anyone in fact holds benefices incompatible by reason of distance, he shall be bound within three months to resign one; otherwise he shall exist deprived of both by the law itself.

SECTION E: GRANDFATHERING OF EXISTING ARRANGEMENTS

Latin Text

Articulus Quintus: De Beneficiis Ante Hoc Decretum Obtentis

Quoniam multi clerici ante publicationem huius decreti plura beneficia legitime, id est cum dispensatione apostolica vel ordinaria, obtinuerunt, et eorum iura acquisita ex aequitate respicienda sunt, clementer indulgemus:

§1. Clerici qui ante diem publicationis huius decreti plura beneficia cum legitima dispensatione obtinebant, possunt illa retinere quoad vixerint, dummodo in uno saltem ex beneficiis cum cura animarum personaliter resideant et per se vel per idoneum vicarium curam animarum exerceant.

§2. Post mortem vel resignationem talium clericorum, beneficia sic retenta non possunt alteri conferri nisi secundum formam huius decreti, id est uni personae unum beneficium cum cura, vel tria sine cura secundum limitationes supra positas.

§3. Si clericus beneficia plura sine dispensatione obtinebat, nullam gratiam ex hoc decreto consequitur, sed statim tenetur ad formam iuris antiqui se reducere.

§4. Dispensationes pro pluralitate beneficiorum ante hoc decretum concessae validae manent quoad vitam obtinentium; post hoc decretum vero nullae tales dispensationes concedantur, nisi in casibus infra expressis.

English Translation

Article Five: On Benefices Obtained Before This Decree

Since many clerics before the publication of this decree obtained several benefices legitimately, that is, with apostolic or ordinary dispensation, and their acquired rights are to be respected in equity, we clemently indulge:

§1. Clerics who before the day of publication of this decree held several benefices with legitimate dispensation, can retain them as long as they live, provided they personally reside in at least one of the benefices with cure of souls and exercise the cure of souls by themselves or through a suitable vicar.

§2. After the death or resignation of such clerics, benefices so retained cannot be conferred on another except according to the form of this decree, that is, one benefice with cure to one person, or three without cure according to the limitations set forth above.

§3. If a cleric held several benefices without dispensation, he obtains no grace from this decree, but is immediately bound to reduce himself to the form of the ancient law.

§4. Dispensations for plurality of benefices granted before this decree remain valid for the lifetime of the holders; after this decree however let no such dispensations be granted, except in the cases expressed below.

SECTION F: LIMITED DISPENSATIONS

Latin Text

Articulus Sextus: De Dispensationibus Restrictis

Ad praecludendam viam abusibus qui ex nimia dispensationum facilitate provenerunt, strictissime statuimus:

§1. Post publicationem huius decreti, nulla dispensatio pro obtinendis pluribus beneficiis cum cura animarum a quocumque concedi possit, etiam a Romano pontifice, nisi in casibus sequentibus:

(a) Cum duo beneficia cum cura animarum adeo tenuia sint, ut ambo simul non excedant valorem annuum viginti florenorum, et distent ab invicem minus quam per unam leucam;

(b) Cum beneficium cum cura annexum sit de iure et ab antiquo alicui dignitati vel praebendae, et separari non possit sine gravi damno ecclesiae;

(c) Cum clericus insignis doctrinae et vitae requiratur ad legendum in universitate studii generalis, et beneficium suum non sufficiat ad eius sustentationem, et aliud beneficium sine cura vel cum modica cura ei conferatur ad tempus lectionis.

§2. Dispensationes in casibus praedictis non a sede apostolica, sed ab ordinario loci concedantur, qui de causa dispensationis diligenter inquirat, et dispensationem in scriptis cum expressione causae concedat, et in registro suo fideliter annotet.

§3. Dispensationes a sede apostolica contra formam huius decreti concessae nullius sint roboris vel momenti, et conferentes beneficia in virtute talium dispensationum a collatione suspensi sint per annum.

§4. Si quis dispensationem per subreptionem vel obreptionem obtinuerit, ultra nullitatem dispensationis, inhabilis sit per quinquennium ad quodcumque beneficium obtinendum.

English Translation

Article Six: On Restricted Dispensations

To close the way to abuses which have arisen from excessive facility of dispensations, we most strictly decree:

§1. After the publication of this decree, no dispensation for obtaining several benefices with cure of souls can be granted by anyone, even by the Roman pontiff, except in the following cases:

(a) When two benefices with cure of souls are so slender that both together do not exceed the annual value of twenty florins, and are distant from each other less than one league;

(b) When a benefice with cure is annexed by law and from ancient times to some dignity or prebend, and cannot be separated without grave harm to the church;

(c) When a cleric of outstanding doctrine and life is required to lecture in a university of general studies, and his benefice does not suffice for his sustenance, and another benefice without cure or with moderate cure is conferred on him for the time of his lecturing.

§2. Dispensations in the aforesaid cases shall be granted not by the apostolic see, but by the ordinary of the place, who shall diligently inquire into the cause of the dispensation, and shall grant the dispensation in writing with expression of the cause, and faithfully note it in his register.

§3. Dispensations granted by the apostolic see contrary to the form of this decree shall be of no force or moment, and those conferring benefices by virtue of such dispensations shall be suspended from collation for a year.

§4. If anyone shall have obtained a dispensation through subreption or obreption, beyond the nullity of the dispensation, he shall be incapable for five years of obtaining any benefice whatsoever.

SECTION G: SPECIAL PROVISIONS FOR CARDINALS AND PRELATES

Latin Text

Articulus Septimus: De Cardinalibus et Praelatis

Quoniam cardinales sanctae Romanae ecclesiae et alii praelati superiores debent esse speculum disciplinae et exemplum ceteris clericis, nec decet ut ipsi faciant quod in aliis reprehendunt, specialiter de eis statuimus:

§1. Nullus cardinalis de cetero possit obtinere vel retinere plures quam unum episcopatum vel archiepiscopatum. Si plures ante hoc decretum obtinebat, possit eos retinere quoad vixerit secundum articulum quintum supra, sed post eius mortem non possint conferri nisi secundum formam huius decreti.

§2. Nullus cardinalis possit obtinere abbatiam in commendam, nisi abbatia sit adeo tenuis ut non sufficiat ad sustentationem abbatis regularis. Commendae ante hoc decretum factae validae manent quoad vitam commendatariorum.

§3. Archiepiscopi et episcopi non possunt obtinere aliquod aliud beneficium cum cura animarum praeter suum episcopatum, nec aliquam abbatiam, nec aliquam dignitatem principalem in alia ecclesia.

§4. Abbates regulares non possunt obtinere aliquod beneficium extra suum monasterium, excepto uno simplici beneficio sine cura ad sustentationem.

§5. Contra praelatos huic decreto contrafacientes, procedatur per hanc sanctam synodum vel per Romanum pontificem ad privationem praelaturae, servatis servandis.

English Translation

Article Seven: On Cardinals and Prelates

Since cardinals of the holy Roman church and other superior prelates ought to be a mirror of discipline and an example to other clerics, nor is it fitting that they themselves do what they reprove in others, we specially decree concerning them:

§1. No cardinal can henceforth obtain or retain more than one bishopric or archbishopric. If he held several before this decree, he can retain them as long as he lives according to article five above, but after his death they cannot be conferred except according to the form of this decree.

§2. No cardinal can obtain an abbacy in commendam, unless the abbacy is so slender that it does not suffice for the sustenance of a regular abbot. Commendams made before this decree remain valid for the lifetime of the commendatories.

§3. Archbishops and bishops cannot obtain any other benefice with cure of souls besides their bishopric, nor any abbacy, nor any principal dignity in another church.

§4. Regular abbots cannot obtain any benefice outside their monastery, except one simple benefice without cure for sustenance.

§5. Against prelates contravening this decree, let proceedings be taken by this holy synod or by the Roman pontiff for deprivation of the prelacy, observing what should be observed.

SECTION H: ENFORCEMENT MECHANISMS

Latin Text

Articulus Octavus: De Executione Huius Decreti

Ne haec salutaris constitutio, sicut praedecessorum nostrorum constitutiones, per defectum executionis inutilis reddatur, de modo executionis diligenter providemus:

§1. De Inquisitione Ante Collationem:

Nullus collator, sive sit papa, sive legatus, sive ordinarius, sive quicumque alius, conferat alicui beneficium cum cura animarum, nisi prius diligenter inquirat an ille iam aliud beneficium cum cura obtineat. Ad hoc, candidatus teneatur praestare iuramentum tactis sacris evangeliis, quod nullum aliud beneficium incompatibile obtinet.

Si postea constiterit eum falsum iurasse, ultra periurii poenam, privetur utroque beneficio et inhabilis sit in perpetuum ad quodcumque beneficium obtinendum.

§2. De Registro Beneficiorum:

In qualibet dioecesi, ordinarius teneatur habere registrum omnium beneficiorum cum cura animarum et omnium beneficiorum cum residentia, in quo annotentur nomina obtinentium, dies collationis, et valor annuus beneficii.

Hoc registrum singulis annis renovetur et ad commissionem supervisoriam infra instituendam transmittatur.

§3. De Commissione Supervisoria:

Confirmamus et renovamus commissionem supervisoriam in decreto de concubinatu institutam, et eius potestatem extendimus ad cognoscendum de observantia huius decreti de pluralitate beneficiorum.

Ad hanc commissionem, ordinarii singulis annis relationem mittant de statu suarum dioecesium quoad pluralitatem beneficiorum, et de casibus dispensationum concessarum cum expressione causarum.

§4. De Poenis Collatorum:

Collatores qui beneficia contra formam huius decreti contulerint, si sint episcopi, suspensi sint a collatione beneficiorum per biennium; si sint inferiores, privati sint iure conferendi illud beneficium pro illa vice, et beneficium ad superiorem devolvatur.

Si vero scienter et dolose contra hoc decretum beneficium contulerint, ultra praedictas poenas, excommunicationis sententiam incurrant, a qua non possint absolvi nisi per hanc sanctam synodum vel per Romanum pontificem.

English Translation

Article Eight: On the Execution of This Decree

Lest this salutary constitution, like the constitutions of our predecessors, be rendered useless through defect of execution, we diligently provide concerning the manner of execution:

§1. On Inquiry Before Collation:

Let no collator, whether pope, or legate, or ordinary, or anyone else, confer on anyone a benefice with cure of souls, unless he first diligently inquires whether that person already holds another benefice with cure. For this, the candidate shall be bound to take an oath touching the holy gospels, that he holds no other incompatible benefice.

If afterwards it shall be established that he swore falsely, beyond the penalty for perjury, let him be deprived of both benefices and be perpetually incapable of obtaining any benefice whatsoever.

§2. On the Register of Benefices:

In every diocese, the ordinary shall be bound to have a register of all benefices with cure of souls and all benefices with residence, in which shall be noted the names of holders, the day of collation, and the annual value of the benefice.

This register shall be renewed each year and transmitted to the supervisory commission instituted below.

§3. On the Supervisory Commission:

We confirm and renew the supervisory commission instituted in the decree on concubinage, and extend its power to take cognizance of the observance of this decree on plurality of benefices.

To this commission, ordinaries shall send each year a report on the state of their dioceses regarding plurality of benefices, and concerning cases of dispensations granted with expression of the causes.

§4. On Penalties for Collators:

Collators who shall have conferred benefices contrary to the form of this decree, if they are bishops, shall be suspended from the collation of benefices for two years; if they are inferiors, they shall be deprived of the right of conferring that benefice for that turn, and the benefice shall devolve to the superior.

If however they shall have knowingly and deceitfully conferred a benefice contrary to this decree, beyond the aforesaid penalties, they shall incur the sentence of excommunication, from which they cannot be absolved except by this holy synod or by the Roman pontiff.

SECTION I: TRANSITION PERIOD

Latin Text

Articulus Nonus: De Tempore Transitionis

Ad ordinatam executionem huius decreti, sequentes terminos statuimus:

§1. Clerici qui ante publicationem huius decreti plura beneficia sine dispensatione obtinebant, habent spatium sex mensium a die publicationis in singulis dioecesibus computandorum, ad se reducendum ad formam iuris, id est ad resignandum omnia beneficia praeter unum cum cura vel tria sine cura.

§2. Infra praedictum terminum, possunt libere eligere quae beneficia retinere velint et quae resignare.

§3. Post praedictum terminum, qui se non reduxerit, omnibus beneficiis suis ipso iure privatus existat, et ad nulla beneficia per quinquennium sit habilis.

§4. Ordinarii locorum tenentur, infra annum a publicatione huius decreti, conficere registra de quibus supra, et ad commissionem supervisoriam transmittere.

English Translation

Article Nine: On the Transition Period

For the orderly execution of this decree, we establish the following terms:

§1. Clerics who before the publication of this decree held several benefices without dispensation, have a space of six months to be computed from the day of publication in each diocese, to reduce themselves to the form of law, that is, to resign all benefices except one with cure or three without cure.

§2. Within the aforesaid term, they can freely choose which benefices they wish to retain and which to resign.

§3. After the aforesaid term, he who shall not have reduced himself shall exist deprived of all his benefices by the law itself, and shall be capable of no benefices for five years.

§4. Ordinaries of places are bound, within a year from the publication of this decree, to draw up the registers spoken of above, and to transmit them to the supervisory commission.

PART V: SANCTIO - ENFORCEMENT CLAUSE

Latin Text

Nulli ergo omnino hominum liceat hanc paginam nostrae constitutionis, definitionis, statuti, mandati, praecepti et voluntatis infringere, vel ei ausu temerario contraire.

Si quis autem hoc attemptare praesumpserit, indignationem omnipotentis Dei et beatorum Petri et Pauli apostolorum eius se noverit incursurum.

Praeterea, omnes constitutiones, privilegia, indulta, exemptiones, et dispensationes quascumque, quae huic decreto in aliquo adversantur, etiam si de eis specialis mentio facienda esset, penitus revocamus et annullamus, et pro revocatis et annullatis haberi volumus.

Decernimus insuper, ut haec constitutio in omnibus ecclesiis cathedralibus singulis annis in synodo dioecesana publice legatur, ut nullus ignorantiam praetendere possit.

Ordinariis locorum, sub poena suspensionis ab ingressu ecclesiae per sex menses, praecipimus, ut infra sex menses a die publicationis huius decreti in hac sancta synodo, illud in suis dioecesibus publicent et executioni demandent.

English Translation

Let it therefore be permitted to absolutely no man to infringe this document of our constitution, definition, statute, mandate, precept and will, or with rash daring to contravene it.

If anyone however shall presume to attempt this, let him know that he shall incur the indignation of almighty God and of the blessed Peter and Paul his apostles.

Furthermore, all constitutions, privileges, indults, exemptions, and dispensations whatsoever, which are in any way contrary to this decree, even if special mention of them should be made, we utterly revoke and annul, and we will them to be held as revoked and annulled.

We decree furthermore, that this constitution shall be publicly read in all cathedral churches each year in the diocesan synod, so that no one may be able to pretend ignorance.

We command the ordinaries of places, under penalty of suspension from entrance to the church for six months, that within six months from the day of publication of this decree in this holy synod, they publish it in their dioceses and commit it to execution.

PART VI: APPROBATIO & SUBSCRIPTIONES

Latin Text

Approbatio Synodalis

Haec sancta et universalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, praesens decretum de limitatione pluralitatis et detentione plurium beneficiorum, omnibus suis partibus diligenter examinatis et approbatis, in sessione publica sollemniter promulgavit, die vigesima octava mensis Septembris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio.

Omnes deputationes, videlicet deputatio fidei, deputatio pacis, deputatio reformatorii, et deputatio pro communibus, huic decreto unanimiter consenserunt.

Legatur, publicetur, et executioni mandetur in universa ecclesia, ad laudem Dei omnipotentis et reformationem ecclesiae suae sanctae.

English Translation

Synodal Approbation

This holy and universal synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, solemnly promulgated the present decree on the limitation of plurality and the holding of multiple benefices, all its parts having been diligently examined and approved, in public session on the twenty-eighth day of the month of September, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three.

All the deputations, namely the deputation of faith, the deputation of peace, the deputation of reform, and the deputation for common affairs, unanimously consented to this decree.

Let it be read, published, and committed to execution in the universal church, for the praise of almighty God and the reformation of his holy church.

Latin Text (continued)

Subscriptiones

✠ Iulianus, miseratione divina tituli Sanctae Sabinae sanctae Romanae ecclesiae presbyter cardinalis, sacri concilii Basiliensis praesidens, subscripsi.

✠ Ludovicus, tituli Sanctae Caeciliae presbyter cardinalis Arelatensis, subscripsi.

✠ Ioannes, archiepiscopus Tarentasiensis, deputationis reformatorii praesidens, subscripsi.

✠ Ioannes, episcopus Lubicensis, subscripsi.

✠ Philibertus, episcopus Constantiensis, subscripsi.

✠ Alfonsus, episcopus Burgensis, legationis Castellanae orator, subscripsi.

[Sequuntur subscriptiones aliorum patrum concilii, tam praelatorum quam doctorum et abbatum]

English Translation (continued)

Subscriptions

✠ Julian, by divine mercy cardinal priest of the holy Roman church of the title of Saint Sabina, president of the sacred Council of Basel, subscribed.

✠ Louis, cardinal priest of the title of Saint Cecilia, of Arles, subscribed.

✠ John, archbishop of Tarentaise, president of the deputation of reform, subscribed.

✠ John, bishop of Lübeck, subscribed.

✠ Philibert, bishop of Constance, subscribed.

✠ Alfonso, bishop of Burgos, orator of the Castilian legation, subscribed.

[There follow the subscriptions of other fathers of the council, both prelates and doctors and abbots]

Latin Text (continued)

Attestatio Notarii

Ego, Ioannes de Segovia, notarius et secretarius huius sanctae synodi, praesens decretum fideliter scripsi et subscripsi, in fidem et testimonium omnium praemissorum.

Actum et datum Basileae, in sessione decima sexta huius sacri concilii, die vigesima octava mensis Septembris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio, pontificatus sanctissimi in Christo patris et domini nostri, domini Eugenii divina providentia papae quarti, anno tertio.

English Translation (continued)

Attestation of the Notary

I, John of Segovia, notary and secretary of this holy synod, have faithfully written and subscribed the present decree, in faith and testimony of all the aforesaid.

Done and given at Basel, in the sixteenth session of this sacred council, on the twenty-eighth day of the month of September, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three, in the third year of the pontificate of the most holy father in Christ and our lord, lord Eugene by divine providence fourth pope.

PART VII: CONCLUSIO

Latin Text

Deo Gratias

Haec sancta synodus Basiliensis, considerans quod cura animarum est suprema lex ecclesiae, et quod pastor debet cognoscere oves suas et ab eis cognosci, gratias agit aeterno Deo omnipotenti, qui dedit nobis gratiam hanc legem statuendi ad salutem animarum et ad reformationem disciplinae ecclesiasticae.

Invocamus super hoc decretum benedictionem Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, et intercessionem beatissimae Virginis Mariae et omnium sanctorum, praesertim sanctorum pastorum qui greges suos usque ad sanguinem fideliter paverunt.

Rogamus omnes praelatos, collatores, et patronos beneficiorum, ut hoc decretum fideliter observent, memores illius verbi Domini per prophetam Ezechielem: "Vae pastoribus Israel, qui pascebant semetipsos! Nonne greges a pastoribus pascuntur?"

Et rogamus omnes clericos, ut non quaerant pluralitatem beneficiorum propter avaritiam vel ambitionem, sed contenti sint uno beneficio secundum apostolum dicentem: "Habentes alimenta et quibus tegamur, his contenti simus."

Amen. Fiat, fiat, fiat.

English Translation

Thanks be to God

This holy synod of Basel, considering that the cure of souls is the supreme law of the church, and that the shepherd ought to know his sheep and be known by them, gives thanks to the eternal almighty God, who gave us the grace to establish this law for the salvation of souls and for the reformation of ecclesiastical discipline.

We invoke upon this decree the blessing of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, and the intercession of the most blessed Virgin Mary and of all the saints, especially the holy shepherds who faithfully fed their flocks even unto blood.

We ask all prelates, collators, and patrons of benefices, that they faithfully observe this decree, mindful of that word of the Lord through the prophet Ezekiel: "Woe to the shepherds of Israel, who fed themselves! Should not the flocks be fed by the shepherds?"

And we ask all clerics, that they not seek plurality of benefices through avarice or ambition, but be content with one benefice according to the apostle saying: "Having food and covering, with these let us be content."

Amen. Let it be done, let it be done, let it be done.

FINIS DECRETI

END OF DECREE

Historical Note

This decree represents the Council of Basel's Session 16 (September 28, 1433), passed during the period of accelerated reform following the arrival of Emperor Sigismund and the reception of the Declaration of Como. In the standard historical timeline, Basel addressed pluralism gradually through various decrees, with the major reform coming on June 9, 1435 (Session 21). In this alternate timeline, the energizing effect of the Imperial-Castilian alliance allowed earlier and more comprehensive action.

The decree builds upon the Fourth Lateran Council's Canon 29 (1215), which had prohibited pluralism but was undermined by easy papal dispensations. The key innovations of this Basel decree are:

1. Grandfathering with sunset: Existing legitimate pluralists can keep their benefices for life, but the arrangements cannot be renewed—ensuring gradual reform without immediate chaos.

2. Closing the dispensation loophole: Dispensations are now granted by ordinaries, not Rome, and only for three narrow causes. This addresses the central failure of all previous anti-pluralism legislation.

3. Cardinal restriction: Limiting cardinals to one bishopric was extremely controversial but reflected Basel's anti-curial sentiment.

4. Benefice registers: Creating diocesan databases of all benefices and their holders enables systematic enforcement.

5. Supervisory commission: Extending the same oversight body from the concubinage decree creates institutional continuity.

The Latin text employs technical vocabulary and formulaic expressions characteristic of Basel's decrees. The English translation preserves the formal, precise character of medieval ecclesiastical legislation.

The inclusion of Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena among the signatories reflects the Castilian delegation's prominent role in reform efforts at Basel.

Document Length: Approximately 20 pages in standard formatting.

END OF DOCUMENT

laws.title: Council of Basel Session 17: Decree on Annates
laws.summary: The Council abolishes annates and first fruits payments to the papal curia, replacing them with a reformed system of moderate confirmation fees, redirecting surplus revenues to diocesan needs and eliminating the practice of taxing new bishops' first year of income.
laws.full_text:
COUNCIL OF BASEL - SESSION 17
DECREE ON THE REFORM OF ANNATES AND OTHER PAPAL TAXES ON BENEFICES
Decretum de Reformatione Annatarum et Aliarum Taxarum Papalium super Beneficiis

Session 17 - October 19, 1433
Sessio XVII - XIX Octobris MCDXXXIII

PART I: INTITULATIO & INVOCATIO

Latin Text

Sacrosancta generalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, ad perpetuam rei memoriam.

Haec sancta synodus, quae ad reformationem ecclesiae in capite et in membris congregata est, omnibus Christi fidelibus tam clericis quam laicis, praesertim vero praelatis, beneficiatis, et collatoribus beneficiorum, nec non officialibus Camerae Apostolicae et Romanae Curiae, salutem in Domino sempiternam et iustitiam cum misericordia.

English Translation

The holy general synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, for an everlasting record.

This holy synod, which has been assembled for the reformation of the church in head and members, to all the faithful of Christ both clerics and laypeople, but especially to prelates, benefice-holders, and collators of benefices, as well as to officials of the Apostolic Camera and the Roman Curia, eternal salvation in the Lord and justice with mercy.

PART II: PREAMBLE & ARENGA - THEOLOGICAL JUSTIFICATION

Latin Text

Cum Dominus noster Iesus Christus ad pharisaeos dixerit: "Reddite quae sunt Caesaris Caesari, et quae sunt Dei Deo," docuit nos quod tam spiritualia quam temporalia iuxta ordinem debitum disponenda sunt. Ecclesia Dei indiget subsidiis temporalibus ad exercenda opera spiritualia: ad cultum divinum celebrandum, ad evangelium praedicandum, ad pauperes sustentandos, ad haeresim extirpandam, ad unitatem fidei conservandam.

Nec reprehendendum est quod ministri ecclesiae stipendia accipiant pro laboribus suis, cum Apostolus dicat: "Qui altari deserviunt, de altari participantur," et iterum: "Dignus est operarius mercede sua." Ipsa sedes apostolica, quae totius Christianitatis curam gerit, indiget pecuniis ad tot et tantas necessitates providendum.

Verum tamen ea quae iuste et moderate exiguntur, cum excedunt modum, in iniuriam et oppressionem vertuntur. Conqueruntur enim multi praelati et clerici, quod taxae quae super beneficiis ecclesiasticis imponuntur, adeo graves et onerosae factae sint, ut beneficiati saepe non possint de residuo fructuum suorum vivere honeste, nec ecclesias suas decenter sustentare.

Conqueruntur praeterea, quod modus exigendi harum taxarum obscurus sit et incertus, et quod diversi exactores diversas summas petant, et quod nulla ratio reddatur de pecuniis collectis, et quod gravamina inferantur his qui solvere non possunt.

Nos igitur, qui volumus ut ecclesia Dei habeat necessaria subsidia sine iniuria subditorum, et ut taxationes sint certae et moderatae et manifeste ordinatae, de consilio et assensu huius sacri concilii, praesentem constitutionem edimus, per quam antiquas exactiones reformamus, novas ordinationes statuimus, et tam capiti quam membris iustitiam facere intendimus.

English Translation

When our Lord Jesus Christ said to the Pharisees: "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's," he taught us that both spiritual and temporal things are to be disposed according to due order. The church of God needs temporal subsidies to exercise spiritual works: to celebrate divine worship, to preach the gospel, to sustain the poor, to extirpate heresy, to preserve the unity of the faith.

Nor is it to be reproved that ministers of the church receive stipends for their labors, since the Apostle says: "They who serve the altar share in the altar," and again: "The laborer is worthy of his wages." The apostolic see itself, which bears the care of all Christendom, needs monies to provide for so many and such great necessities.

Nevertheless, those things which are justly and moderately exacted, when they exceed measure, are turned into injury and oppression. For many prelates and clerics complain that the taxes which are imposed on ecclesiastical benefices have become so heavy and burdensome that benefice-holders often cannot live honorably from the remainder of their fruits, nor decently sustain their churches.

They complain moreover that the manner of exacting these taxes is obscure and uncertain, and that different exactors demand different sums, and that no account is rendered of the monies collected, and that grievances are inflicted on those who cannot pay.

We therefore, who wish that the church of God may have necessary subsidies without injury to its subjects, and that taxations may be certain and moderate and manifestly ordered, with the counsel and assent of this sacred council, issue the present constitution, by which we reform the ancient exactions, decree new ordinances, and intend to do justice both to head and to members.

PART III: NARRATIO - HISTORICAL CIRCUMSTANCES

Latin Text

Cum per longam consuetudinem et diversas constitutiones apostolicas introductae fuerint variae taxae et exactiones super beneficiis ecclesiasticis, quae communiter "annatae" vocantur, quarum principales sunt:

Primo, servitia communia, quae solvuntur Camerae Apostolicae et Collegio Cardinalium a praelatis maioribus, videlicet archiepiscopis, episcopis, et abbatibus, super eorum confirmatione vel translatione, et quae taxantur secundum antiquas aestimationes ad unius anni integri fructus;

Secundo, servitia minuta, quae solvuntur diversis officialibus Curiae Romanae pro expeditione litterarum et aliis servitiis, ultra servitia communia;

Tertio, annatae proprie dictae, quae solvuntur de beneficiis minoribus a sede apostolica collatis vel confirmatis, et quae taxantur ad medietatem fructuum primi anni;

Quarto, quindennia, quae solvuntur de beneficiis perpetuo unitis, singulis quindecim annis;

Et cum hae taxae olim moderate introductae fuerint, sed procedente tempore per augmentationem taxarum et multiplicationem exactorum, in grave onus cleri et scandalum populi Christiani conversae sint;

Et cum Concilium Constantiense in concordatis cum diversis nationibus factis, aliquas moderationes induxerit, sed non sufficientes ad tollendum omnia gravamina;

Et cum multi clamores ad hanc sanctam synodum pervenerint de excessivis exactionibus, de incertitudine taxarum, de obscuritate computationum, et de defectu iustitiae in causis appellationum;

Nos, considerantes quod reformatio capitis et membrorum ab hac sancta synodo intenta, incipere debet a moderatione eorum quae onus clero imponunt, sequentes constitutiones statuimus et decernimus inviolabiliter observandas.

English Translation

Whereas through long custom and diverse apostolic constitutions there have been introduced various taxes and exactions on ecclesiastical benefices, which are commonly called "annates," the principal of which are:

First, the servitia communia, which are paid to the Apostolic Camera and the College of Cardinals by major prelates, namely archbishops, bishops, and abbots, upon their confirmation or translation, and which are assessed according to ancient valuations at one full year's fruits;

Second, the servitia minuta, which are paid to various officials of the Roman Curia for the expedition of letters and other services, beyond the servitia communia;

Third, the annates properly so called, which are paid on minor benefices collated or confirmed by the apostolic see, and which are assessed at half the fruits of the first year;

Fourth, the quindennia, which are paid on benefices perpetually united, every fifteen years;

And whereas these taxes were once moderately introduced, but as time proceeded, through augmentation of assessments and multiplication of exactors, have been converted into a heavy burden on the clergy and a scandal to the Christian people;

And whereas the Council of Constance in concordats made with various nations introduced some moderations, but not sufficient to remove all grievances;

And whereas many outcries have come to this holy synod concerning excessive exactions, concerning uncertainty of assessments, concerning obscurity of accountings, and concerning defect of justice in causes of appeals;

We, considering that the reformation of head and members intended by this holy synod ought to begin from the moderation of those things which impose a burden on the clergy, decree and determine the following constitutions to be inviolably observed.

PART IV: DISPOSITIO - LEGAL PROVISIONS

SECTION A: REDUCTION OF RATES

Latin Text

Articulus Primus: De Reductione Servitii Communis

Statuimus et ordinamus, quod de cetero servitia communia non excedant quartam partem fructuum primi anni beneficii, secundum aestimationem de qua infra dicetur.

§1. Ubi antiquae taxationes in libris Camerae Apostolicae servitium commune ad unius anni integri fructus taxabant, de cetero non exigatur nisi quarta pars illius summae, id est, ubi taxabatur ad centum florenos, nunc taxetur ad viginti quinque florenos.

§2. Haec reductio applicetur tam ad archiepiscopatus et episcopatus, quam ad abbatias et prioratus conventuales qui in consistorio conferuntur.

§3. Servitia communia dividantur sicut antea, videlicet medietate ad Cameram Apostolicam et medietate ad Collegium Cardinalium.

§4. Praelati qui propter paupertatem ecclesiarum suarum solvere non possunt etiam quartam partem, possint petere moderationem ab ordinario metropolitano, qui cum consilio duorum suffraganeorum, possit reducere taxam usque ad octavam partem, vel etiam totaliter remittere si vera paupertas probetur.

English Translation

Article One: On the Reduction of the Common Service

We decree and ordain that henceforth the servitia communia shall not exceed a fourth part of the first year's fruits of the benefice, according to the valuation spoken of below.

§1. Where ancient assessments in the books of the Apostolic Camera taxed the common service at one full year's fruits, henceforth let not more than a fourth part of that sum be exacted, that is, where it was taxed at one hundred florins, let it now be taxed at twenty-five florins.

§2. This reduction shall apply both to archbishoprics and bishoprics, and to abbacies and conventual priories which are conferred in consistory.

§3. The servitia communia shall be divided as before, namely half to the Apostolic Camera and half to the College of Cardinals.

§4. Prelates who on account of the poverty of their churches cannot pay even a fourth part, can petition for moderation from the metropolitan ordinary, who with the counsel of two suffragans, can reduce the tax down to an eighth part, or even remit it totally if true poverty is proven.

Latin Text (continued)

Articulus Secundus: De Reductione Annatarum Proprie Dictarum

Similiter statuimus, quod annatae proprie dictae, quae solvuntur de beneficiis minoribus a sede apostolica collatis, non excedant quartam partem fructuum primi anni.

§1. Ubi antea exigebatur medietas fructuum primi anni, de cetero non exigatur nisi quarta pars.

§2. Beneficia quorum fructus annui non excedunt viginti quatuor florenos auri de camera, omnino libera sint ab annatis, sicut per Concordatum Constantiense statutum fuit.

§3. Beneficia quorum fructus annui excedunt viginti quatuor florenos sed non excedunt quinquaginta florenos, solvant tantummodo decem florenos fixos, non quartam partem.

§4. Beneficia quorum fructus annui excedunt quinquaginta florenos, solvant quartam partem secundum veram aestimationem fructuum, non secundum antiquas taxationes inflatas.

English Translation (continued)

Article Two: On the Reduction of Annates Properly So Called

Similarly we decree that annates properly so called, which are paid on minor benefices collated by the apostolic see, shall not exceed a fourth part of the first year's fruits.

§1. Where formerly half the first year's fruits were exacted, henceforth let not more than a fourth part be exacted.

§2. Benefices whose annual fruits do not exceed twenty-four gold florins of the camera shall be entirely free from annates, as was decreed by the Concordat of Constance.

§3. Benefices whose annual fruits exceed twenty-four florins but do not exceed fifty florins, shall pay only ten fixed florins, not a fourth part.

§4. Benefices whose annual fruits exceed fifty florins shall pay a fourth part according to the true valuation of the fruits, not according to inflated ancient assessments.

SECTION B: REFORM OF MINOR SERVICES

Latin Text

Articulus Tertius: De Servitiis Minutis et Aliis Expensis

Quoniam servitia minuta et aliae expensae quae ultra servitia communia exiguntur, multiplicatae sunt in grave onus praelatorum, statuimus:

§1. Servitia minuta, quae solvuntur camerariis, notariis, scriptoribus, et aliis officialibus Curiae, omnino aboleantur. Officiales Curiae de cetero recipiant stipendia fixa a Camera Apostolica, non propinas a praelatis.

§2. Pro expeditione bullarum et litterarum apostolicarum, non exigatur ultra iustas expensas pergameni, scripturae, et sigilli, quae expensae in tabulis publicis affixis in Camera Apostolica declarentur.

§3. Nullus officialis Curiae possit exigere vel recipere aliquod donum, munus, vel gratificationem a praelato vel beneficiato, ultra ea quae in tabulis publicis taxantur, sub poena privationis officii et restitutionis dupli.

§4. Si quis praelatus vel beneficiatus coactus fuerit ad solvendum ultra taxas publice ordinatas, habeat actionem recuperandi duplum contra exactorem coram auditore Camerae, absque ulteriori appellatione.

English Translation

Article Three: On Minor Services and Other Expenses

Since the minor services and other expenses which are exacted beyond the common services have been multiplied into a heavy burden on prelates, we decree:

§1. The servitia minuta, which are paid to chamberlains, notaries, scribes, and other officials of the Curia, shall be entirely abolished. Officials of the Curia shall henceforth receive fixed stipends from the Apostolic Camera, not tips from prelates.

§2. For the expedition of bulls and apostolic letters, let not more be exacted than the just expenses of parchment, writing, and seal, which expenses shall be declared in public tables affixed in the Apostolic Camera.

§3. No official of the Curia can exact or receive any gift, present, or gratification from a prelate or benefice-holder, beyond those things which are assessed in the public tables, under penalty of deprivation of office and restitution of double.

§4. If any prelate or benefice-holder has been compelled to pay beyond the publicly ordained taxes, he shall have an action to recover double against the exactor before the auditor of the Camera, without further appeal.

SECTION C: NEW VALUATION SYSTEM

Latin Text

Articulus Quartus: De Nova Aestimatione Beneficiorum

Quoniam antiquae taxationes in libris Camerae Apostolicae saepe non correspondent veris fructibus beneficiorum, sed sunt vel nimis altae propter antiquitatem, vel nimis bassae propter corruptionem, ordinamus novam aestimationem fieri:

§1. Intra quinquennium a publicatione huius decreti, in qualibet provincia ecclesiastica fiat nova aestimatio omnium beneficiorum quae servitiis communibus vel annatis subiiciuntur.

§2. Haec aestimatio fiat per metropolitanum cum duobus suffraganeis a synodo provinciali electis, qui iuramento astringantur ad aestimandos veros fructus beneficiorum secundum communem cursum decem annorum praecedentium, deductis oneribus ordinariis.

§3. Aestimationes sic factae transmittantur ad Cameram Apostolicam et ad commissionem supervisoriam huius sacri concilii, et publicentur in libris impressis vel manuscriptis, ut omnibus notae sint.

§4. Post publicationem novarum aestimationum, antiquae taxationes nullam vim habeant, et servitia communia et annatae secundum novas aestimationes tantummodo exigantur.

§5. Si Camera Apostolica vel aliquis exactor exigat secundum antiquas taxationes post novas aestimationes publicatas, beneficiatus non teneatur solvere nisi secundum novam aestimationem, et exactor incurrat poenas articuli praecedentis.

English Translation

Article Four: On the New Valuation of Benefices

Since the ancient assessments in the books of the Apostolic Camera often do not correspond to the true fruits of benefices, but are either too high on account of their age, or too low on account of corruption, we ordain a new valuation to be made:

§1. Within five years from the publication of this decree, in every ecclesiastical province let a new valuation be made of all benefices which are subject to common services or annates.

§2. This valuation shall be made by the metropolitan with two suffragans elected by the provincial synod, who shall be bound by oath to value the true fruits of benefices according to the common course of the ten preceding years, with ordinary burdens deducted.

§3. Valuations so made shall be transmitted to the Apostolic Camera and to the supervisory commission of this sacred council, and shall be published in printed or manuscript books, so that they may be known to all.

§4. After the publication of the new valuations, the ancient assessments shall have no force, and common services and annates shall be exacted only according to the new valuations.

§5. If the Apostolic Camera or any exactor exacts according to ancient assessments after the new valuations have been published, the benefice-holder shall not be bound to pay except according to the new valuation, and the exactor shall incur the penalties of the preceding article.

SECTION D: TRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY

Latin Text

Articulus Quintus: De Ratione Reddenda a Camera Apostolica

Ad tollendum scandalum quod oritur ex eo quod nemo scit quid fiat de pecuniis quae a clero exiguntur, statuimus de rationibus Camerae Apostolicae publicandis:

§1. Camera Apostolica teneatur singulis annis, infra mensem Ianuarium, conficere rationem generalem omnium introituum et exituum anni praecedentis.

§2. Haec ratio generalis contineat distincte:
- Quantum receptum sit de servitiis communibus, et a quibus praelatis;
- Quantum receptum sit de annatis, et de quibus beneficiis;
- Quantum receptum sit de quindenniis;
- Quantum receptum sit de aliis fontibus, ut censu, visitationibus, et similibus;
- Quantum expositum sit pro administratione Curiae Romanae;
- Quantum expositum sit pro defensione fidei et ecclesiae;
- Quantum expositum sit pro eleemosynis et piis operibus;
- Quantum remaneat in aerario.

§3. Haec ratio transmittatur ad commissionem supervisoriam huius sacri concilii, et summarium eius publicetur, ut clerici sciant quo eorum pecuniae eant.

§4. Si Camera Apostolica per duos annos continuos negligat transmittere rationes, hoc sacrum concilium vel eius commissio supervisoria possit suspendere collectionem annatarum donec rationes reddantur.

English Translation

Article Five: On the Account to be Rendered by the Apostolic Camera

To remove the scandal which arises from the fact that no one knows what is done with the monies which are exacted from the clergy, we decree concerning the accounts of the Apostolic Camera to be published:

§1. The Apostolic Camera shall be bound each year, within the month of January, to draw up a general account of all receipts and expenditures of the preceding year.

§2. This general account shall contain distinctly:
- How much was received from common services, and from which prelates;
- How much was received from annates, and from which benefices;
- How much was received from quindennia;
- How much was received from other sources, such as census, visitations, and the like;
- How much was expended for the administration of the Roman Curia;
- How much was expended for the defense of the faith and the church;
- How much was expended for alms and pious works;
- How much remains in the treasury.

§3. This account shall be transmitted to the supervisory commission of this sacred council, and a summary of it shall be published, so that clerics may know where their monies go.

§4. If the Apostolic Camera for two continuous years neglects to transmit accounts, this sacred council or its supervisory commission can suspend the collection of annates until accounts are rendered.

SECTION E: RIGHT OF APPEAL

Latin Text

Articulus Sextus: De Iure Appellandi in Causis Annatarum

Quoniam multi praelati et beneficiati conqueruntur quod non habent remedium contra iniustas exactiones, quia exactores sunt simul iudices in propriis causis, statuimus de appellationibus:

§1. Si quis praelatus vel beneficiatus se gravatum sentit de taxatione imposita super suo beneficio, possit appellare ad auditorem generalem Camerae Apostolicae, qui teneatur infra triginta dies cognoscere de causa et iustitiam facere.

§2. Si appellans non sit satisfactus de sententia auditoris Camerae, possit ulterius appellare ad commissionem supervisoriam huius sacri concilii, quae habeat potestatem finaliter decidendi causam, absque ulteriori recursu ad quemcumque.

§3. Pendente appellatione, praelatus vel beneficiatus teneatur solvere tantummodo illam partem taxae de qua non est controversia; de parte controversa non cogatur solvere donec causa decidatur.

§4. Si appellans obtineat in toto vel in parte, exactor condemnetur ad restituendum quod iniuste exegit, cum expensis litis.

§5. Nullus praelatus vel beneficiatus possit cogi ad iurandum de non appellando, vel ad renuntiandum iuri appellationis, sub poena nullitatis talis iuramenti vel renuntiationis.

English Translation

Article Six: On the Right of Appeal in Causes of Annates

Since many prelates and benefice-holders complain that they have no remedy against unjust exactions, because the exactors are at the same time judges in their own causes, we decree concerning appeals:

§1. If any prelate or benefice-holder feels himself aggrieved by the assessment imposed on his benefice, he can appeal to the auditor general of the Apostolic Camera, who shall be bound within thirty days to take cognizance of the cause and do justice.

§2. If the appellant is not satisfied with the sentence of the auditor of the Camera, he can further appeal to the supervisory commission of this sacred council, which shall have power to finally decide the cause, without further recourse to anyone.

§3. Pending appeal, the prelate or benefice-holder shall be bound to pay only that part of the tax about which there is no controversy; concerning the controverted part he shall not be compelled to pay until the cause is decided.

§4. If the appellant prevails in whole or in part, the exactor shall be condemned to restore what he unjustly exacted, with costs of suit.

§5. No prelate or benefice-holder can be compelled to swear not to appeal, or to renounce the right of appeal, under penalty of nullity of such oath or renunciation.

SECTION F: PAYMENT TERMS

Latin Text

Articulus Septimus: De Modo et Tempore Solutionis

Quoniam multi praelati, praesertim pauperes, non possunt statim solvere servitia communia, et coguntur contrahere debita cum usuris, statuimus de modo solutionis:

§1. Servitia communia possint solvi in duabus partibus aequalibus: prima medietas infra sex menses a confirmatione, secunda medietas infra annum a confirmatione.

§2. Si praelatus propter iustas causas non possit solvere infra praedictos terminos, possit petere dilationem ab ordinario metropolitano, qui possit concedere dilationem usque ad duos annos, dummodo praelatus det cautionem idoneam.

§3. Nulla usura vel interesse possit exigi pro dilatione solutionis, dummodo praelatus solvat infra terminum concessum.

§4. Si praelatus non solvat infra terminum concessum absque iusta causa, tunc demum possit suspendi ab administratione temporalium sui beneficii, sed non a spiritualibus, donec solvat.

§5. Annatae de beneficiis minoribus possint solvi infra sex menses a collatione, absque ulla usura.

English Translation

Article Seven: On the Manner and Time of Payment

Since many prelates, especially poor ones, cannot immediately pay the common services, and are compelled to contract debts with usury, we decree concerning the manner of payment:

§1. Common services can be paid in two equal parts: the first half within six months of confirmation, the second half within one year of confirmation.

§2. If a prelate on account of just causes cannot pay within the aforesaid terms, he can petition for delay from the metropolitan ordinary, who can grant a delay up to two years, provided the prelate gives suitable security.

§3. No usury or interest can be exacted for delay of payment, provided the prelate pays within the granted term.

§4. If the prelate does not pay within the granted term without just cause, then and only then can he be suspended from the administration of the temporalities of his benefice, but not from spiritualities, until he pays.

§5. Annates on minor benefices can be paid within six months of collation, without any usury.

SECTION G: QUINDENNIA

Latin Text

Articulus Octavus: De Quindenniis

De quindenniis, quae solvuntur de beneficiis perpetuo unitis, statuimus:

§1. Quindennia de cetero non exigantur nisi de beneficiis quorum unio facta est auctoritate apostolica, et quorum fructus uniti excedunt quinquaginta florenos annuos.

§2. Quindennia taxentur ad decimam partem fructuum unius anni beneficii uniti, non ad quartam partem sicut annatae ordinariae.

§3. Uniones factae pro sustentando collegia, hospitalia, monasteria pauperum, vel alia pia opera, omnino exemptae sint a quindenniis.

§4. Si dubium sit an unio subiaceat quindenniis, beneficiatus possit petere declarationem a commissione supervisoria, cuius decisio sit finalis.

English Translation

Article Eight: On Quindennia

Concerning quindennia, which are paid on benefices perpetually united, we decree:

§1. Quindennia shall henceforth not be exacted except from benefices whose union was made by apostolic authority, and whose united fruits exceed fifty annual florins.

§2. Quindennia shall be assessed at a tenth part of the fruits of one year of the united benefice, not at a fourth part like ordinary annates.

§3. Unions made for sustaining colleges, hospitals, monasteries of the poor, or other pious works, shall be entirely exempt from quindennia.

§4. If there is doubt whether a union is subject to quindennia, the benefice-holder can petition for a declaration from the supervisory commission, whose decision shall be final.

SECTION H: ENFORCEMENT AND SUPERVISION

Latin Text

Articulus Nonus: De Executione et Supervisione

Ad efficacem executionem huius decreti, statuimus:

§1. Commissio supervisoria in decretis de concubinatu et pluralitate instituta, habeat etiam potestatem cognoscendi de observantia huius decreti de annatis.

§2. Camera Apostolica teneatur transmittere ad commissionem supervisoriam:
- Singulis annis, rationem generalem de qua supra;
- Singulis trimestris, notitiam de servitiis communibus et annatis exactis, cum nominibus praelatorum et beneficiatorum;
- Infra quinquennium, novas aestimationes de quibus supra.

§3. Si Camera Apostolica vel eius officiales non observent hoc decretum, commissio supervisoria possit:
- Monere Cameram de non observantia;
- Si monitio non proficiat, suspendere collectionem annatarum in una vel pluribus provinciis;
- Referre causam ad hanc sanctam synodum vel ad Romanum pontificem pro ulteriori remedio.

§4. Ordinarii locorum tenentur publicare hoc decretum in suis dioecesibus, et informare clericos de eorum iuribus secundum hoc decretum, et denuntiare ad commissionem supervisoriam quascumque transgressiones de quibus cognoverint.

English Translation

Article Nine: On Execution and Supervision

For the effective execution of this decree, we decree:

§1. The supervisory commission instituted in the decrees on concubinage and plurality shall also have the power of taking cognizance of the observance of this decree on annates.

§2. The Apostolic Camera shall be bound to transmit to the supervisory commission:
- Each year, the general account spoken of above;
- Each quarter, a notice of common services and annates exacted, with names of prelates and benefice-holders;
- Within five years, the new valuations spoken of above.

§3. If the Apostolic Camera or its officials do not observe this decree, the supervisory commission can:
- Warn the Camera of non-observance;
- If the warning does not avail, suspend the collection of annates in one or more provinces;
- Refer the cause to this holy synod or to the Roman pontiff for further remedy.

§4. Ordinaries of places are bound to publish this decree in their dioceses, and to inform clerics of their rights according to this decree, and to denounce to the supervisory commission whatever transgressions of which they become aware.

PART V: SANCTIO - ENFORCEMENT CLAUSE

Latin Text

Nulli ergo omnino hominum liceat hanc paginam nostrae constitutionis, reductionis, ordinationis, mandati, et voluntatis infringere, vel ei ausu temerario contraire.

Si quis autem hoc attemptare praesumpserit, praeter poenas in singulis articulis expressas, indignationem omnipotentis Dei et beatorum Petri et Pauli apostolorum eius se noverit incursurum.

Omnes constitutiones, ordinationes, privilegia, indulta, et consuetudines quascumque, quae huic decreto in aliquo adversantur, etiam si de eis specialis mentio facienda esset, penitus revocamus et annullamus quantum ad ea quae huic decreto contrariantur.

Mandamus insuper omnibus praelatis, collatoribus, beneficiatis, et officialibus Camerae Apostolicae, ut hoc decretum fideliter observent, sub poenis in singulis articulis expressis.

Hoc decretum vim habeat a die publicationis in hac sancta synodo, et applicetur ad omnia servitia communia et annatas quae de cetero exigentur, etiam si beneficia ante hanc diem vacaverint.

English Translation

Let it therefore be permitted to absolutely no man to infringe this document of our constitution, reduction, ordinance, mandate, and will, or with rash daring to contravene it.

If anyone however shall presume to attempt this, besides the penalties expressed in the individual articles, let him know that he shall incur the indignation of almighty God and of the blessed Peter and Paul his apostles.

All constitutions, ordinances, privileges, indults, and customs whatsoever, which are in any way contrary to this decree, even if special mention of them should be made, we utterly revoke and annul as far as pertains to those things which are contrary to this decree.

We command moreover all prelates, collators, benefice-holders, and officials of the Apostolic Camera, that they faithfully observe this decree, under the penalties expressed in the individual articles.

This decree shall have force from the day of publication in this holy synod, and shall apply to all common services and annates which shall henceforth be exacted, even if benefices became vacant before this day.

PART VI: APPROBATIO & SUBSCRIPTIONES

Latin Text

Approbatio Synodalis

Haec sancta et universalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, praesens decretum de reformatione annatarum et aliarum taxarum papalium super beneficiis, omnibus suis partibus diligenter examinatis et approbatis, in sessione publica sollemniter promulgavit, die decima nona mensis Octobris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio.

Quatuor deputationes huius sacri concilii, videlicet deputatio fidei, deputatio pacis, deputatio reformatorii, et deputatio pro communibus, huic decreto consenserunt, deputatione reformatorii praecipue promovente.

Legatur, publicetur, et executioni mandetur in universa ecclesia, ad iustitiam faciendam tam capiti quam membris, et ad tollendum scandala quae ex excessivis exactionibus oriuntur.

English Translation

Synodal Approbation

This holy and universal synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, solemnly promulgated the present decree on the reform of annates and other papal taxes on benefices, all its parts having been diligently examined and approved, in public session on the nineteenth day of the month of October, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three.

The four deputations of this sacred council, namely the deputation of faith, the deputation of peace, the deputation of reform, and the deputation for common affairs, consented to this decree, with the deputation of reform especially promoting it.

Let it be read, published, and committed to execution in the universal church, for doing justice both to head and to members, and for removing the scandals which arise from excessive exactions.

English Translation (continued)

Attestation of the Notary

I, John of Segovia, professor of sacred theology and secretary of this holy synod, have faithfully written and subscribed the present decree, in faith and testimony of all the aforesaid.

Done and given at Basel, in the seventeenth session of this sacred council, on the nineteenth day of the month of October, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three, in the third year of the pontificate of the most holy father in Christ and our lord, lord Eugene by divine providence fourth pope.

PART VII: CONCLUSIO

Latin Text

Deo Gratias

Haec sancta synodus, desiderans iustitiam facere omnibus, tam Romano pontifici qui indiget subsidiis ad gerenda onera universalis ecclesiae, quam praelatis et clericis qui non debent opprimi exactionibus iniustis, gratias agit omnipotenti Deo qui inspiravit hanc viam mediam inter abolitionem totalem annatarum et continuationem abusuum.

Non intendimus spoliare sedem apostolicam iustis subsidiis, sed volumus ut haec subsidia moderata sint et certa et manifesta, ut dantes sciant quantum debent et quo vadant pecuniae eorum.

Non intendimus excusare clericos ab obligatione contribuendi ad necessitates universalis ecclesiae, sed volumus ut contributio sit proportionata facultatibus, et ut via appellationis pateat contra iniustas exactiones.

Rogamus sanctissimum dominum nostrum papam ut hanc constitutionem benigne recipiat, non tamquam diminutionem suae auctoritatis, sed tamquam reformationem qua honor sedis apostolicae defenditur ab infamia avidae cupiditatis.

Rogamus praelatos et clericos ut fideliter solvant quae secundum hoc decretum debent, nec nitantur per fraudes vel subterfugia eludere iustam contributionem.

In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti. Amen.

English Translation

Thanks be to God

This holy synod, desiring to do justice to all, both to the Roman pontiff who needs subsidies to bear the burdens of the universal church, and to prelates and clerics who ought not be oppressed by unjust exactions, gives thanks to almighty God who inspired this middle way between total abolition of annates and continuation of abuses.

We do not intend to despoil the apostolic see of just subsidies, but we wish that these subsidies be moderate and certain and manifest, so that those giving may know how much they owe and where their monies go.

We do not intend to excuse clerics from the obligation of contributing to the necessities of the universal church, but we wish that the contribution be proportionate to abilities, and that a way of appeal lie open against unjust exactions.

We ask our most holy lord the pope that he graciously receive this constitution, not as a diminution of his authority, but as a reform by which the honor of the apostolic see is defended from the infamy of greedy cupidity.

We ask prelates and clerics that they faithfully pay what they owe according to this decree, and that they not strive through frauds or subterfuges to evade just contribution.

In the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit. Amen.

FINIS DECRETI

END OF DECREE

Historical Note

This decree represents the Council of Basel's Session 17 (October 19, 1433), passed during the period of accelerated reform following the Declaration of Como. In the standard historical timeline, Basel's decree on annates came on June 9, 1435 (Session 21) and abolished annates entirely without providing replacement revenue for the papacy. This radical approach contributed to the breakdown of papal-conciliar relations.

In this alternate timeline, the moderating influence of the Imperial-Castilian alliance (as expressed in the Como Declaration) produced a more balanced reform:

Key Features of This Decree:

1. Reduction, not abolition: Rates reduced from 50% to 25% of first year's income—a substantial relief but not papal bankruptcy.

2. Transparency requirements: The Apostolic Camera must publish annual accounts showing where the money goes. This addresses the scandal of obscure finances while preserving papal revenue.
