3. Right of appeal: For the first time, those assessed have a formal appeals process outside the Camera itself, with final jurisdiction in the conciliar supervisory commission.

4. New valuations: Ancient inflated assessments (some dating to the 13th century) to be replaced by current, realistic valuations within five years.

5. Abolition of minor services: The servitia minuta—tips and gratuities to curial officials—eliminated entirely. Officials to receive fixed salaries instead.

6. Poverty exemptions: Low-income benefices exempt; poor prelates can petition for reduced rates.

7. Payment terms: Installment payments permitted; no usury on delays.

Comparison with Historical Basel Decree (1435):

| Issue | Historical Basel (1435) | Alternate Timeline (1433) |
|-------|------------------------|---------------------------|
| Basic rate | Abolished entirely | Reduced to 25% |
| Papal revenue | Devastated | Reduced but sustained |
| Enforcement | None | Supervisory commission |
| Appeals | Not addressed | Full appeals system |
| Transparency | Not addressed | Annual public accounts |
| Minor services | Abolished | Abolished |

The alternate timeline decree represents the "middle way" that the Como Declaration envisioned: genuine reform that addresses real grievances while maintaining a functional papal administration. This is the kind of reform that a moderate pope like Eugenius IV might actually accept as part of "parallel legislation."

Document Length: Approximately 18 pages in standard formatting.

END OF DOCUMENT

laws.title: Compacts of Basel
laws.summary: Comprehensive agreement between the Council of Basel and the Hussite delegations from Bohemia, establishing terms for reconciliation including communion in both kinds, limits on clerical wealth, and the relationship between secular and ecclesiastical authority in the Kingdom of Bohemia.
laws.full_text:
THE COMPACTS OF BASEL
Compactata Basileensia
Agreement Between the Sacred Council of Basel and the Kingdom of Bohemia and Margraviate of Moravia

Concluded at Prague, November 30, 1433
Ratified at Jihlava, July 5, 1436

PREFATORY NOTE

This document represents the historic reconciliation between the Catholic Church and the Bohemian Hussites (Utraquists) after thirty-five years of religious war (1398-1433). It is not a unilateral decree of the Council, but a bilateral compact—a treaty negotiated between equals.

The Four Articles of Prague (1420), which formed the basis of Hussite demands, were:
1. Freedom of preaching the Word of God
2. Communion in both kinds (sub utraque specie) for laity as well as clergy
3. Abolition of secular power and worldly possessions of the clergy
4. Public punishment of mortal sins

After months of negotiation at Basel (January-April 1433), at Prague (May-November 1433), and with the moderating influence of Emperor Sigismund and the Imperial-Castilian alliance following the Declaration of Como, agreement was reached on a carefully crafted compromise addressing each article.

PART I: PREAMBLE

Latin Text

In nomine sanctae et individuae Trinitatis, Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti. Amen.

Sacrosancta generalis synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, ex una parte;

Et illustrissimi principes, barones, nobiles, milites, cives, et communitates regni Bohemiae et marchionatus Moraviae, in dieta generali Pragensi congregati, ex altera parte;

Cupientes pacem et unitatem sanctae matris ecclesiae, et finem imponere dissidiis et bellis quae per triginta quinque annos inter catholicos et Bohemos viguerunt, cum ingenti sanguinis effusione et animarum periculo;

Invocato nomine Domini nostri Iesu Christi, qui est pax nostra et fecit utraque unum, et medium parietem maceriae solvens, inimicitias in carne sua interfecit;

Post longam et diligentem tractationem, in qua utrinque proposita sunt argumenta et responsa, et in qua caritas fraternam patientiam exercuit;

Devenerunt ad sequentes articulos concordiae, qui vulgo Compactata appellantur, et qui vim habebunt pacti publici inter partes contrahentes.

English Translation

In the name of the holy and undivided Trinity, Father and Son and Holy Spirit. Amen.

The holy general synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, on one part;

And the most illustrious princes, barons, nobles, knights, citizens, and communities of the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia, assembled in the general diet at Prague, on the other part;

Desiring the peace and unity of holy mother church, and to put an end to the dissensions and wars which for thirty-five years have flourished between Catholics and Bohemians, with immense effusion of blood and peril of souls;

Having invoked the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is our peace and made both one, and breaking down the middle wall of partition, slew enmity in his flesh;

After long and diligent negotiation, in which on both sides arguments and responses were set forth, and in which charity exercised fraternal patience;

Have arrived at the following articles of agreement, which are commonly called the Compacts, and which shall have the force of a public pact between the contracting parties.

PART II: THE FOUR ARTICLES

ARTICLE I: ON THE COMMUNION IN BOTH KINDS
De Communione sub Utraque Specie

Latin Text

Primus Articulus Concordiae

Quoniam articulus de communione sub utraque specie, id est de administratione sanctissimi sacramenti eucharistiae sub speciebus panis et vini tam clericis quam laicis, fuit praecipua causa dissidii inter ecclesiam et regnum Bohemiae;

Et quoniam haec praxis, quae a temporibus magistri Ioannis Hus in Bohemia et Moravia invaluit, radicem habet in antiqua traditione ecclesiae primitivae, quae per multa saecula utramque speciem omnibus fidelibus communicantibus ministrabat;

Sacrosancta synodus Basiliensis, ex potestate sibi a spiritu sancto concessa, de consilio et unanimi assensu legatorum Bohemiae, statuit et concedit:

§1. In regno Bohemiae et marchionatu Moraviae, communio sanctissimi sacramenti eucharistiae sub utraque specie, videlicet sub specie panis et sub specie vini, licite et libere ministrari possit omnibus fidelibus adultis qui eam devote petierint, per sacerdotes rite ordinatos et ab ordinariis locorum approbatos.

§2. Haec concessio fit sine praeiudicio doctrinae catholicae, quae firmiter tenet et docet quod sub qualibet specie totus Christus continetur, videlicet corpus, sanguis, anima et divinitas; ita ut qui sub una specie communicat, nihil minus recipiat quam qui sub utraque.

§3. Nullus tamen cogatur communicare sub utraque specie qui sub una tantum communicare voluerit; et in aliis regionibus ecclesiae, ubi usus communionis sub una specie viget, idem usus servetur.

§4. Pueri ante annos discretionis non admittantur ad communionem sub specie vini, ne forte ex fragilitate aetatis sacramentum effundant; sed ubi parentes vel parochi iudicaverint pueros sufficientem discretionem attigisse, tunc possint sub utraque specie communicare.

§5. Sacerdotes qui hanc communionem ministrant, tenentur instruere fideles de veritate praedicta, videlicet quod totus Christus sub utraque specie continetur, et quod usus communionis sub una specie in aliis regionibus ecclesiae non est error sed legitima consuetudo.

§6. Vasa sacra pro administratione calicis laicis, et modus ministrandi, ordinentur secundum regulas quas ordinarii locorum, de consilio synodorum provincialium, statuerint, ad decentiam et reverentiam sacramenti conservandam.

English Translation

First Article of Agreement

Since the article on communion in both kinds, that is, on the administration of the most holy sacrament of the Eucharist under the species of both bread and wine to clerics and laity alike, was the principal cause of dissension between the church and the Kingdom of Bohemia;

And since this practice, which prevailed in Bohemia and Moravia from the times of Master John Hus, has its root in the ancient tradition of the primitive church, which for many centuries ministered both species to all the faithful communicating;

The holy synod of Basel, from the power granted to it by the Holy Spirit, with the counsel and unanimous assent of the legates of Bohemia, decrees and grants:

§1. In the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia, communion of the most holy sacrament of the Eucharist under both species, namely under the species of bread and under the species of wine, may be lawfully and freely ministered to all adult faithful who devoutly request it, by priests duly ordained and approved by the ordinaries of the places.

§2. This concession is made without prejudice to Catholic doctrine, which firmly holds and teaches that under either species the whole Christ is contained, namely body, blood, soul and divinity; so that one who communicates under one species receives nothing less than one who communicates under both.

§3. Nevertheless, no one shall be compelled to communicate under both species who wishes to communicate under one only; and in other regions of the church, where the usage of communion under one species flourishes, the same usage shall be observed.

§4. Children before the years of discretion shall not be admitted to communion under the species of wine, lest perchance from the fragility of age they spill the sacrament; but where parents or pastors shall have judged that children have attained sufficient discretion, then they may communicate under both species.

§5. Priests who minister this communion are bound to instruct the faithful concerning the aforesaid truth, namely that the whole Christ is contained under both species, and that the usage of communion under one species in other regions of the church is not error but legitimate custom.

§6. The sacred vessels for the administration of the chalice to laypersons, and the manner of ministering, shall be ordained according to the rules which the ordinaries of the places, with the counsel of provincial synods, shall have established, for the preservation of the decency and reverence of the sacrament.

ARTICLE II: ON THE FREE PREACHING OF THE WORD OF GOD
De Libera Praedicatione Verbi Dei

Latin Text

Secundus Articulus Concordiae

Quoniam Bohemi contendebant quod verbum Dei libere praedicaretur per totum regnum, sine impedimento a potestatibus ecclesiasticis vel secularibus;

Et quoniam ecclesia catholica semper docuit quod praedicatio verbi Dei est officium proprium sacerdotum et praesertim episcoporum, qui habent potestatem mittendi praedicatores et approbandi eorum doctrinam;

Ad conciliandam libertatem praedicationis cum ordine ecclesiastico, statuimus:

§1. Verbum Dei licite et libere praedicetur per totum regnum Bohemiae et marchionatum Moraviae, secundum veritatem sacrae scripturae et secundum doctrinam sanctorum patrum et doctorum ecclesiae approbatorum.

§2. Praedicatores tamen debent esse sacerdotes rite ordinati, vel diaconi ab episcopis ad praedicandum missi, vel alii clerici a suis ordinariis specialiter approbati et licentiati.

§3. Praedicatores tenentur praedicare secundum doctrinam ecclesiae catholicae et universalis, non introducentes novitates vel doctrinas contrarias fidei vel bonis moribus, sub poena revocationis licentiae et aliis poenis canonicis.

§4. Episcopi et ordinarii locorum habent potestatem visitandi praedicatores, examinandi eorum doctrinam, et corrigendi errores si qui inventi fuerint, servatis servandis secundum canones.

§5. Si praedicator se gravatum senserit a iudicio ordinarii sui, possit appellare ad metropolitanum, vel ad synodum provincialem, vel ad hanc sanctam synodum vel eius successores.

§6. Praedicatio in lingua vulgari, id est in lingua Bohemica vel Moravica, non prohibetur sed laudatur, ut populus melius intelligat verbum Dei; dummodo praedicator sit idoneus et doctrina sit sana.

English Translation

Second Article of Agreement

Since the Bohemians contended that the Word of God should be freely preached throughout the whole kingdom, without impediment from ecclesiastical or secular powers;

And since the Catholic Church has always taught that the preaching of the Word of God is the proper office of priests and especially of bishops, who have the power of sending preachers and approving their doctrine;

To reconcile freedom of preaching with ecclesiastical order, we decree:

§1. The Word of God may be lawfully and freely preached throughout the whole Kingdom of Bohemia and Margraviate of Moravia, according to the truth of sacred scripture and according to the doctrine of the holy fathers and approved doctors of the church.

§2. Preachers however must be priests duly ordained, or deacons sent by bishops to preach, or other clerics specially approved and licensed by their ordinaries.

§3. Preachers are bound to preach according to the doctrine of the Catholic and universal church, not introducing novelties or doctrines contrary to faith or good morals, under penalty of revocation of license and other canonical penalties.

§4. Bishops and ordinaries of places have the power of visiting preachers, examining their doctrine, and correcting errors if any are found, observing what should be observed according to the canons.

§5. If a preacher feels himself aggrieved by the judgment of his ordinary, he may appeal to the metropolitan, or to the provincial synod, or to this holy synod or its successors.

§6. Preaching in the vulgar tongue, that is, in the Bohemian or Moravian language, is not prohibited but praised, so that the people may better understand the Word of God; provided the preacher is suitable and the doctrine is sound.

ARTICLE III: ON THE SECULAR POSSESSIONS OF THE CLERGY
De Possessionibus Saecularibus Clericorum

Latin Text

Tertius Articulus Concordiae

Quoniam Bohemi petebant ut clerici non exercerent dominium saeculare, et ut ecclesia reduceretur ad paupertatem apostolicam, sine possessionibus temporalibus;

Et quoniam ecclesia catholica docet quod licet clericis, et ipsi ecclesiae, acquirere et possidere bona temporalia ad sustentationem cultus divini, ministrorum, et pauperum;

Considerantes quod in hac materia media via tenenda est, ut nec clerici dominentur saeculari potestate, nec ecclesia spolietur necessariis subsidiis;

Statuimus:

§1. Clerici qui per vota religiosa vel per sacros ordines obligati sunt ad vitam spiritualem, non debent exercere officium iudicis saecularis in causis sanguinis, nec personaliter arma portare in bellis, nec principatum mere temporalem gerere.

§2. Tamen clerici et ecclesia possunt licite acquirere, possidere, et administrare bona temporalia, sive immobilia sive mobilia, ad sustentationem cultus divini, fabricae ecclesiarum, ministrorum altaris, hospitalium, scholarum, et pauperum.

§3. Bona ecclesiastica administrentur fideliter et secundum canones, non in luxum vel pompam, sed in usus pios et necessarios; et ratio administrationis reddatur secundum constitutiones huius sacri concilii.

§4. Bona ecclesiastica quae ante has turbas a Bohemis occupata fuerunt, ordinentur secundum conventiones speciales inter partes ineundas, quarum executio committitur serenissimo domino Sigismundo, Romanorum et Hungariae regi, futuro regi Bohemiae.

§5. Possessiones quae iam in manus laicorum transierunt et per longum tempus ab eis possessae sunt, non repetantur, dummodo laici convenientes pensiones ecclesiis solvant pro sustentatione cultus divini in illis locis.

§6. Religiosi qui regulam paupertatis profitentur, eam observent; et monasteria quae a pristino rigore deflexerunt, reformentur secundum constitutiones huius sacri concilii et secundum visitationes ordinariorum.

English Translation

Third Article of Agreement

Since the Bohemians petitioned that clerics should not exercise secular dominion, and that the church should be reduced to apostolic poverty, without temporal possessions;

And since the Catholic Church teaches that it is lawful for clerics, and for the church itself, to acquire and possess temporal goods for the sustenance of divine worship, of ministers, and of the poor;

Considering that in this matter a middle way must be held, so that neither clerics dominate with secular power, nor the church be despoiled of necessary subsidies;

We decree:

§1. Clerics who by religious vows or by sacred orders are obligated to the spiritual life, ought not to exercise the office of secular judge in cases of blood, nor personally bear arms in wars, nor hold purely temporal principality.

§2. Nevertheless, clerics and the church may lawfully acquire, possess, and administer temporal goods, whether immovable or movable, for the sustenance of divine worship, the fabric of churches, ministers of the altar, hospitals, schools, and the poor.

§3. Ecclesiastical goods shall be administered faithfully and according to the canons, not for luxury or pomp, but for pious and necessary uses; and an account of administration shall be rendered according to the constitutions of this sacred council.

§4. Ecclesiastical goods which before these troubles were occupied by the Bohemians, shall be disposed according to special agreements to be entered into between the parties, the execution of which is committed to the most serene lord Sigismund, King of the Romans and of Hungary, future King of Bohemia.

§5. Possessions which have already passed into the hands of laypeople and have been possessed by them for a long time, shall not be reclaimed, provided the laypeople pay suitable pensions to the churches for the sustenance of divine worship in those places.

§6. Religious who profess a rule of poverty shall observe it; and monasteries which have deflected from their pristine rigor shall be reformed according to the constitutions of this sacred council and according to visitations of ordinaries.

ARTICLE IV: ON THE PUNISHMENT OF MORTAL SINS
De Punitione Peccatorum Mortalium

Latin Text

Quartus Articulus Concordiae

Quoniam Bohemi petebant ut omnia peccata mortalia, praesertim publica, publice punirentur ab auctoritatibus legitimis, tam clericorum quam laicorum;

Et quoniam ecclesia catholica docet quod distinctio est facienda inter forum internum conscientiae et forum externum iudiciale, et quod non omnia peccata sunt crimina saecularia;

Ad conciliandam zelum iustitiae cum ordine iuridico, statuimus:

§1. Omnia peccata mortalia, praesertim publica et notoria, debent puniri ab auctoritatibus legitimis, secundum leges divinas et humanas, ecclesiasticas et civiles.

§2. Peccata clericorum puniantur ab ordinariis locorum et iudicibus ecclesiasticis, secundum sacros canones et constitutiones huius sacri concilii.

§3. Peccata laicorum contra leges civiles puniantur a magistratibus secularibus, secundum leges regni et bonos mores.

§4. Peccata mixti fori, quae sunt simul contra legem Dei et contra leges civiles, possint puniri ab utroque foro, dummodo non sit duplex punitio pro eodem delicto.

§5. Simonia, usura, blasphemia, sacrilegium, et alia peccata quae specialiter offendunt Deum et ecclesiam, severius puniantur secundum gradationem poenalitatis in canonibus expressam.

§6. Ordinarii locorum tenentur visitare dioeceses suas singulis annis, et inquirere de statu cleri et populi, et corrigere quae corrigenda invenerint, et punire delinquentes secundum canones.

§7. Si clericus vel laicus gravatus fuerit per iniustam punitionem, habeat ius appellandi ad superiorem iudicem, servatis servandis.

English Translation

Fourth Article of Agreement

Since the Bohemians petitioned that all mortal sins, especially public ones, should be publicly punished by legitimate authorities, whether of clerics or of laypeople;

And since the Catholic Church teaches that a distinction must be made between the internal forum of conscience and the external judicial forum, and that not all sins are secular crimes;

To reconcile zeal for justice with juridical order, we decree:

§1. All mortal sins, especially public and notorious ones, ought to be punished by legitimate authorities, according to divine and human laws, ecclesiastical and civil.

§2. Sins of clerics shall be punished by ordinaries of places and ecclesiastical judges, according to the sacred canons and the constitutions of this sacred council.

§3. Sins of laypeople against civil laws shall be punished by secular magistrates, according to the laws of the kingdom and good morals.

§4. Sins of mixed forum, which are simultaneously against the law of God and against civil laws, may be punished by either forum, provided there is not double punishment for the same offense.

§5. Simony, usury, blasphemy, sacrilege, and other sins which specially offend God and the church, shall be more severely punished according to the gradation of penalty expressed in the canons.

§6. Ordinaries of places are bound to visit their dioceses each year, and to inquire into the state of the clergy and people, and to correct what they find in need of correction, and to punish delinquents according to the canons.

§7. If a cleric or layperson has been aggrieved by unjust punishment, he shall have the right of appealing to a higher judge, observing what should be observed.

PART III: GENERAL PROVISIONS

Latin Text

Articulus Quintus: De Pace et Reconciliatione

Post triginta quinque annos bellorum, cruciatuum, sanguinis et lacrimarum, Deo propitio tandem ad pacem pervenimus. Ideo statuimus:

§1. Pax firma et perpetua sit inter ecclesiam catholicam ex una parte, et regnum Bohemiae et marchionatum Moraviae ex altera parte. Omnes inimicitiae, offensae, et iniuriae praeteritae remittantur et oblivioni tradantur.

§2. Regnum Bohemiae et marchionatus Moraviae recipiantur in communionem sanctae matris ecclesiae, et omnes sententiae excommunicationis, interdicti, et aliae censurae ecclesiasticae, quae contra Bohemos latae fuerunt, revocentur et pro nullis habeantur.

§3. Bohemi et Moravi, qui hos articulos acceptant et promittunt observare, habeantur et tractentur ut veri filii ecclesiae catholicae, et gaudeant omnibus iuribus et privilegiis quibus gaudent alii catholici.

§4. Memor ia magistri Ioannis Hus et Hieronymi Pragensis non damnabitur publice in Bohemia vel Moravia; de veritate vel falsitate doctrinarum eorum iudicium suspendatur, et res committitur futurae discussioni in pace et caritate faciendae.

§5. Serenissimus dominus Sigismundus, Romanorum et Hungariae rex, qui per hos articulos tandem obtinebit coronam Bohemiae, iurat se hos articulos fideliter observaturum et facturum observari per subditos suos.

English Translation

Article Five: On Peace and Reconciliation

After thirty-five years of wars, crusades, blood and tears, by God's favor we have at last arrived at peace. Therefore we decree:

§1. Let there be firm and perpetual peace between the Catholic Church on one part, and the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia on the other part. Let all enmities, offenses, and injuries of the past be forgiven and consigned to oblivion.

§2. Let the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia be received into the communion of holy mother church, and let all sentences of excommunication, interdict, and other ecclesiastical censures, which were issued against the Bohemians, be revoked and held for null.

§3. Bohemians and Moravians, who accept these articles and promise to observe them, shall be held and treated as true sons of the Catholic Church, and shall enjoy all the rights and privileges which other Catholics enjoy.

§4. The memory of Master John Hus and Jerome of Prague shall not be publicly condemned in Bohemia or Moravia; concerning the truth or falsity of their doctrines let judgment be suspended, and the matter is committed to future discussion to be made in peace and charity.

§5. The most serene lord Sigismund, King of the Romans and of Hungary, who through these articles shall at last obtain the crown of Bohemia, swears that he will faithfully observe these articles and cause them to be observed by his subjects.

Latin Text (continued)

Articulus Sextus: De Electione Archiepiscopi Pragensis

Quoniam sedes archiepiscopalis Pragensis diu vacavit, et ordo ecclesiasticus in Bohemia perturbatus est, statuimus:

§1. Electio archiepiscopi Pragensis fiat per capitulum metropolitanum et clerum Bohemiae, secundum canones, et confirmatio petatur a sede apostolica vel ab hac sancta synodo.

§2. Electus ad archiepiscopatum Pragensem sit vir doctus et probatae vitae, acceptus tam clero quam populo Bohemiae, et fidelis observator horum articulorum compactorum.

§3. Donec electio et confirmatio perficiatur, ordinatio clericorum et alia quae ad archiepiscopum pertinent, exerceantur per vicarios a synodo provinciali deputatos.

§4. Clerici qui durante dissidio ordinati sunt a non-catholicis episcopis vel per modum extraordinarium, examinentur de doctrina et moribus, et si idonei inveniantur, per archiepiscopum confirmatum vel per eius vicarios in officio suo stabiliantur.

English Translation (continued)

Article Six: On the Election of the Archbishop of Prague

Since the archiepiscopal see of Prague has long been vacant, and ecclesiastical order in Bohemia has been disturbed, we decree:

§1. The election of the Archbishop of Prague shall be made by the metropolitan chapter and the clergy of Bohemia, according to the canons, and confirmation shall be sought from the apostolic see or from this holy synod.

§2. He who is elected to the archbishopric of Prague shall be a learned man of proven life, acceptable both to the clergy and the people of Bohemia, and a faithful observer of these articles of the compacts.

§3. Until the election and confirmation are completed, the ordination of clerics and other things which pertain to the archbishop shall be exercised by vicars deputed by the provincial synod.

§4. Clerics who during the dissension were ordained by non-Catholic bishops or in an extraordinary manner, shall be examined concerning doctrine and morals, and if they are found suitable, they shall be established in their office by the confirmed archbishop or by his vicars.

Latin Text (continued)

Articulus Septimus: De Taboritis et Aliis Radicis

Quoniam non omnes Bohemi hosce articulos acceptant, sed quidam, praesertim qui Taboritae vocantur, rigidiores conditiones postulant et doctrinam Ioannis Wyclif de eucharistia profitentur;

Statuimus:

§1. Hos articulos compactorum proponimus omnibus Bohemis et Moravis, tam moderatis quam rigorosis, ut eos acceptent et in unitatem ecclesiae redeant.

§2. Qui hos articulos acceptaverint, gaudebunt pace et privilegiis supra expressis.

§3. Qui recusaverint, non cogantur per vim ecclesiasticam vel per cruciatas, sed relinquantur iudicio Dei et reformationi tempore suo venturae.

§4. Si tamen aliqui recusantes per violentiam pacem turbare vel catholicos opprimere conati fuerint, contra eos procedatur per brachio saeculare regni Bohemiae, non per cruciatas exterorum.

§5. Speramus et oramus ut omnes Bohemi tandem unitatem fidei et pacis amplectantur, et ut calix, qui signum divisionis fuit, fiat signum unitatis in Christo.

English Translation (continued)

Article Seven: On the Taborites and Other Radicals

Since not all Bohemians accept these articles, but some, especially those who are called Taborites, demand more rigid conditions and profess the doctrine of John Wyclif on the Eucharist;

We decree:

§1. These articles of the compacts we propose to all Bohemians and Moravians, both moderate and rigorous, that they may accept them and return to the unity of the church.

§2. Those who shall have accepted these articles shall enjoy the peace and privileges expressed above.

§3. Those who shall have refused shall not be compelled by ecclesiastical force or by crusades, but shall be left to the judgment of God and to reformation to come in its own time.

§4. If however any who refuse shall have attempted by violence to disturb the peace or oppress Catholics, let proceedings be taken against them by the secular arm of the Kingdom of Bohemia, not by crusades of foreigners.

§5. We hope and pray that all Bohemians may at last embrace the unity of faith and peace, and that the chalice, which was a sign of division, may become a sign of unity in Christ.

PART IV: SIGNATURES AND RATIFICATION

Latin Text

Subscriptiones Legatorum Concilii

Nos infrascripti, legati et oratores sacrosanctae synodi Basiliensis, ad regnum Bohemiae pro pace tractanda missi, testamur praesentes articulos per nos cum legatis Bohemiae conclusos et concordatos esse, et eosdem articulos nomine praedictae synodi ratos habemus et confirmamus.

Actum Pragae, in conventu generali regni Bohemiae, die ultima mensis Novembris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio.

✠ Philibertus, episcopus Constantiensis, legatus principalis, manu propria subscripsi.

✠ Martinus Beruer, decanus Turonensis, legatus, subscripsi.

✠ Ioannes Palomar, archidiaconus Barcinonensis, sacri palatii apostolici auditor, legatus, subscripsi.

✠ Thomas de Haselpach, decretorum doctor, legatus, subscripsi.

✠ Henricus Toke, sacrae theologiae professor, legatus, subscripsi.

✠ Petrus Zatecensis, notarius legationis, in fidem omnium praemissorum subscripsi.

English Translation

Signatures of the Legates of the Council

We the undersigned, legates and orators of the holy synod of Basel, sent to the Kingdom of Bohemia for negotiating peace, testify that the present articles have been concluded and agreed upon by us with the legates of Bohemia, and we hold and confirm the same articles as ratified in the name of the aforesaid synod.

Done at Prague, in the general assembly of the Kingdom of Bohemia, on the last day of the month of November, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three.

✠ Philibert, Bishop of Coutances, principal legate, subscribed with my own hand.

✠ Martin Beruer, Dean of Tours, legate, subscribed.

✠ John Palomar, Archdeacon of Barcelona, auditor of the sacred apostolic palace, legate, subscribed.

✠ Thomas of Haselbach, doctor of decrees, legate, subscribed.

✠ Henry Toke, professor of sacred theology, legate, subscribed.

✠ Peter of Žatec, notary of the legation, subscribed in faith of all the aforesaid.

Latin Text (continued)

Subscriptiones Legatorum Bohemiae

Nos infrascripti, legati et oratores incliti regni Bohemiae et marchionatus Moraviae, per dietam generalem Pragensem ad hanc sanctam synodum missi, testamur praesentes articulos per nos cum legatis synodi conclusos et concordatos esse, et eosdem articulos nomine regni et marchionatus acceptamus et promittimus observare.

✠ Ioannes Rokycana, magister sacrae theologiae, praedicator in ecclesia Teynensi Pragae, orator principalis, subscripsi.

✠ Procopius de Plzen, baro, orator statuum regni, subscripsi.

✠ Menhart de Hradec, miles, orator, subscripsi.

✠ Matthias Lauda, magister artium, orator universitatis Pragensis, subscripsi.

✠ Petrus Payne, magister Anglicus, orator, subscripsi.

✠ Wilhelmus Kostka de Postupice, miles, orator, subscripsi.

[Sequuntur subscriptiones aliorum oratorum Bohemiae et Moraviae]

English Translation (continued)

Signatures of the Legates of Bohemia

We the undersigned, legates and orators of the illustrious Kingdom of Bohemia and Margraviate of Moravia, sent by the general diet of Prague to this holy synod, testify that the present articles have been concluded and agreed upon by us with the legates of the synod, and we accept the same articles in the name of the kingdom and margraviate and promise to observe them.

✠ John Rokycana, master of sacred theology, preacher in the Týn church of Prague, principal orator, subscribed.

✠ Prokop of Plzeň, baron, orator of the estates of the kingdom, subscribed.

✠ Menhart of Hradec, knight, orator, subscribed.

✠ Matthew Louda, master of arts, orator of the University of Prague, subscribed.

✠ Peter Payne, English master, orator, subscribed.

✠ William Kostka of Postupice, knight, orator, subscribed.

[There follow the signatures of other orators of Bohemia and Moravia]

Latin Text (continued)

Acceptatio Imperatoris

Nos Sigismundus, Dei gratia Romanorum rex semper augustus, ac Hungariae, Bohemiae, Dalmatiae, Croatiae etc. rex, praesentes articulos concordiae vidimus, legimus, et approbamus.

Promittimus in verbo regio et iuramus super sancta evangelia, quod hos articulos fideliter observabimus et faciemus observari per omnes subditos nostros in regno Bohemiae et marchionatu Moraviae.

Promittimus insuper quod regnum Bohemiae et marchionatum Moraviae in pace et iustitia gubernabimus, et quod nullam vindictam exerquemur contra eos qui nobis antea restiterunt, sed omnes iniurias praeteritas remittimus et oblivioni tradimus.

Datum Ratisbonae, die quinta mensis Iulii, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo sexto, regnorum nostrorum Hungariae etc. anno quadragesimo nono, Romanorum vicesimo sexto, Bohemiae decimo sexto.

SIGISMUNDUS REX

[Sigillum magnum]

English Translation (continued)

Acceptance of the Emperor

We Sigismund, by the grace of God King of the Romans ever august, and of Hungary, Bohemia, Dalmatia, Croatia etc. king, have seen, read, and approve the present articles of agreement.

We promise on our royal word and swear on the holy gospels, that we will faithfully observe these articles and cause them to be observed by all our subjects in the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia.

We promise moreover that we will govern the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia in peace and justice, and that we will execute no vengeance against those who formerly resisted us, but we forgive and consign to oblivion all past injuries.

Given at Regensburg, on the fifth day of the month of July, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-six, in the forty-ninth year of our reign in Hungary etc., the twenty-sixth of the Romans, the sixteenth of Bohemia.

SIGISMUND KING

[Great seal]

PART V: CONFIRMATIO SYNODALIS

Latin Text

Confirmatio per Sacram Synodum Basiliensem

Sacrosancta synodus Basiliensis, in spiritu sancto legitime congregata, universalem ecclesiam representans, praesentes articulos concordiae inter ipsam synodum et regnum Bohemiae et marchionatum Moraviae conclusos, sollemniter confirmat et approbat.

Gaudemus in Domino quod post tot annos bellorum et sanguinis, tandem pax facta est, et quod filii qui aberraverant ad domum patris redeunt.

Rogamus omnes Christi fideles ut pro pace Bohemiae et pro conversione omnium errantium orent, et ut caritatem fraternam exerceant erga Bohemos et Moravos qui ad unitatem ecclesiae redeunt.

Mandamus omnibus praelatis et clericis ut hos articulos fideliter observent et faciant observari, et ut Bohemos et Moravos qui eos acceptant, ut veros fratres recipiant.

In cuius rei testimonium, praesentem paginam sigillo nostro muniri iussimus.

Datum Basileae, in sessione publica huius sacri concilii, die undecima mensis Decembris, anno Domini millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio.

✠ Iulianus, miseratione divina tituli Sanctae Sabinae sanctae Romanae ecclesiae presbyter cardinalis, sacri concilii Basiliensis praesidens, confirmavi et subscripsi.

[Sigillum sacri concilii]

English Translation

Confirmation by the Holy Synod of Basel

The holy synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal church, solemnly confirms and approves the present articles of agreement concluded between the same synod and the Kingdom of Bohemia and the Margraviate of Moravia.

We rejoice in the Lord that after so many years of wars and blood, peace has at last been made, and that sons who had wandered are returning to the father's house.

We ask all the faithful of Christ to pray for the peace of Bohemia and for the conversion of all who err, and to exercise fraternal charity toward the Bohemians and Moravians who are returning to the unity of the church.

We command all prelates and clerics to faithfully observe these articles and cause them to be observed, and to receive the Bohemians and Moravians who accept them, as true brothers.

In witness whereof, we have ordered the present document to be fortified with our seal.

Given at Basel, in a public session of this sacred council, on the eleventh day of the month of December, in the year of the Lord one thousand four hundred thirty-three.

✠ Julian, by divine mercy cardinal priest of the holy Roman church of the title of Saint Sabina, president of the sacred Council of Basel, confirmed and subscribed.

[Seal of the sacred council]

PART VI: CONCLUSIO

Latin Text

Laus Deo

O vos omnes qui transitis per viam, attendite et videte: ecce populus qui in tenebris ambulabat, vidit lucem magnam; et habitantibus in regione umbrae mortis, lux orta est eis.

Per triginta quinque annos Bohemia fuit terra belli et sanguinis. Quinque cruciatae contra eam missae sunt, et omnes in confusione redierunt. Plures quam centum milia animae perierunt in his bellis. Ecclesiae devastatae sunt, monasteria combusta, villae desertae.

Et nunc, non per gladium sed per verbum, non per cruciatas sed per colloquium, pax facta est. Non omnes contenti sunt, non omnes articulos acceptant, sed fundamentum positum est super quod aedificari potest.

Rogamus Deum omnipotentem ut hanc pacem conservet et augeat, ut cor lapideum auferat et cor carneum det, ut omnes qui adhuc errant ad veritatem perveniant, et ut ecclesia Bohemiae, quae per tot annos divisa et afflicta fuit, tandem in caritate et unitate refloreat.

Si haec pax duraverit—et oramus ut duret—tempus veniet quando Bohemus et Germanus, Utraquista et Catholicus, simul ad mensam Domini accedent et de uno pane comedent et de uno calice bibent, et omnes cognoscent quod unum sumus in Christo.

Gloria Patri et Filio et Spiritui Sancto, sicut erat in principio et nunc et semper et in saecula saeculorum. Amen.

English Translation

Praise be to God

O all you who pass by the way, attend and see: behold the people who walked in darkness have seen a great light; and to those dwelling in the region of the shadow of death, light has arisen.

For thirty-five years Bohemia was a land of war and blood. Five crusades were sent against her, and all returned in confusion. More than one hundred thousand souls perished in these wars. Churches were devastated, monasteries burned, villages abandoned.

And now, not by the sword but by the word, not by crusades but by dialogue, peace has been made. Not all are content, not all accept the articles, but a foundation has been laid upon which building can proceed.

We ask almighty God to preserve and increase this peace, to take away the heart of stone and give a heart of flesh, to bring to the truth all who still err, and to cause the church of Bohemia, which for so many years was divided and afflicted, to flourish at last in charity and unity.

If this peace shall endure—and we pray it may endure—the time will come when Bohemian and German, Utraquist and Catholic, shall together approach the table of the Lord and eat of one bread and drink of one cup, and all shall know that we are one in Christ.

Glory be to the Father and to the Son and to the Holy Spirit, as it was in the beginning, is now, and ever shall be, world without end. Amen.

FINIS COMPACTATORUM

END OF THE COMPACTS

HISTORICAL NOTE

The Compacts of Basel represent one of the most remarkable documents of the fifteenth century: a negotiated peace between the Catholic Church and a heretical movement that had defeated five crusades. It is not a capitulation but a genuine compromise—the Hussites received communion in both kinds (their central demand), while the Church preserved doctrinal integrity through the doctrine of concomitance and maintained ecclesiastical order through approval requirements for preachers.

Timeline:

- 1415: Jan Hus burned at Constance; Bohemian revolt begins
- 1420: Four Articles of Prague promulgated; First Anti-Hussite Crusade fails
- 1420-1431: Four more crusades fail catastrophically
- 1431: Council of Basel invites Hussites to negotiate
- January-April 1433: Hussite delegation debates at Basel
- May-November 1433: Council legates negotiate at Prague
- November 30, 1433: Compacts concluded at Prague
- May 30, 1434: Battle of Lipany—moderate Hussites defeat Taborites
- July 5, 1436: Final ratification at Jihlava (Iglau)
- 1462: Pope Pius II unilaterally annuls the Compacts

Key Figures:

- Cardinal Julian Cesarini — Council president who initiated dialogue
- John Rokycana — Hussite theologian, elected Archbishop of Prague (never confirmed by Rome)
- Philibert, Bishop of Coutances — Principal council legate
- John Palomar — Canon lawyer, chief negotiator for the council
- Emperor Sigismund — Finally obtained Bohemian crown after 17 years of war
- Prokop the Great — Taborite leader, killed at Lipany, who rejected the Compacts

Significance for the Campaign:

In the alternate timeline (roll 91 - Transformation), the Imperial-Castilian alliance and the Como Declaration's emphasis on genuine reform created a more favorable atmosphere for the negotiations. The Compacts were achieved in November 1433 with broader support and fewer reservations than in the standard timeline.

For King Juan II, present in Rome when news of the Compacts arrives, this represents proof that the Council of Basel can achieve what crusades could not—reconciliation through dialogue. This precedent strengthens his argument for "parallel legislation" and papal-conciliar cooperation.

Document Length: Approximately 18 pages in standard formatting.

END OF DOCUMENT

laws.title: Council of Basel Session 19: Crusade Decree for Constantinople
laws.summary: The Council proclaims a new crusade for the defense of Constantinople against the Ottoman Empire, authorizing the collection of crusade tithes across Christendom, granting plenary indulgences to participants, and designating Juan II of Castile as the principal military commander of the eastern expedition.
laws.full_text:
SACROSANCTUM CONCILIUM BASILIENSE
SESSIO DECIMA NONA
Die XIV Decembris, Anno Domini MCDXXXIII

DECRETUM PRO DEFENSIONE CONSTANTINOPOLIS ADVERSUS TURCOS

DECREE FOR THE DEFENSE OF CONSTANTINOPLE AGAINST THE TURKS

Session XIX of the Sacred Council of Basel
December 14, 1433

Bilingual Edition: Latin with English Translation

HISTORICAL INTRODUCTION

The Decree for the Defense of Constantinople, promulgated on December 14, 1433, represents one of the most operationally specific crusade documents in medieval ecclesiastical history. Emerging from the transformed political landscape following the Declaration of Como (June 1433), wherein Emperor Sigismund and King Juan II of Castile established a framework for papal-conciliar cooperation, this decree demonstrates Basel's capacity for decisive action when factional warfare could be overcome.

By December 1433, the Council had achieved remarkable unity on the Constantinople question. The preceding months had witnessed the passage of comprehensive reform decrees on electoral procedures (Session XII), clerical concubinage (Session XV), pluralism (Session XVI), and annates (Session XVII), as well as the historic Compacts of Basel ending the Hussite Wars. The crusade decree emerged from this atmosphere of accomplishment, passing with extraordinary conciliar support.

The decree is notable for several distinctive features:

1. Unprecedented operational specificity: Constantinople is named as the singular objective, Sultan Murad II is identified by name as the adversary, and concrete timelines for force assembly are established.

2. Pragmatic financing mechanisms: Designed to function regardless of ongoing papal-conciliar tensions, routing funds through metropolitan structures and Florentine banks.

3. Careful silence on the Greek schism: The decree neither demands ecclesiastical union as a precondition for aid nor makes any positive statement about Orthodox Christianity.

The decree incorporates two concrete military commitments: the substantial forces already pledged by King Juan II of Castile (one thousand knights and sixty thousand florins for wall repairs), and the participation of the Knights of St. John from Rhodes. Other Christian princes receive urgent exhortation but made no binding pledges within the decree itself.

On the question of military command, the decree establishes spiritual authority under a papal legate to be appointed by Pope Eugenius IV, while leaving secular military command undefined beyond calls for "fraternal coordination."

The decree's aggressive timeline—forces to assemble by summer 1434—was achievable only by those already in motion at the time of promulgation, transforming what was framed as a pan-Christian crusade into an endorsement of King Juan II's personal expedition.

DECREE TEXT

— INVOCATIO —

In nomine sanctae et individuae Trinitatis, Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti. Amen.

In the name of the holy and undivided Trinity, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Amen.

— PROEMIUM —

Sacrosancta generalis synodus Basiliensis, in Spiritu Sancto legitime congregata, universalem Ecclesiam repraesentans, ad perpetuam rei memoriam.

The most holy general synod of Basel, legitimately assembled in the Holy Spirit, representing the universal Church, for the perpetual memory of the matter.

— ARENGA —

Inter curas multiplices quibus pro universalis Ecclesiae bono sollicitamur, illa praecipue cordi nostro insidet quae ad defensionem fidei Christianae et protectionem fidelium contra infidelium incursus pertinet. Constantinopolis, urbs antiquissima et nobilissima, quae per saecula innumera scutum Christianitatis adversus orientales barbaros stetit, nunc in extremo periculo versatur. Muradus Secundus, Turcorum sultanus, cum ingentibus copiis muros illius gloriosae civitatis quotidie magis premit, et nisi Christiani principes celeriter succurrant, timemus ne cadat illud propugnaculum quod tot saeculis Europam Christianam protexit.

Among the manifold cares by which we are troubled for the good of the universal Church, that one especially lies close to our heart which pertains to the defense of the Christian faith and the protection of the faithful against the incursions of the infidels. Constantinople, that most ancient and noble city, which through countless ages has stood as the shield of Christendom against the eastern barbarians, now finds itself in extreme peril. Murad the Second, Sultan of the Turks, with immense forces presses daily more heavily upon the walls of that glorious city, and unless Christian princes swiftly bring aid, we fear that bulwark may fall which has protected Christian Europe for so many centuries.

— NARRATIO —

Serenissimus princeps Ioannes Octavus Palaeologus, Romanorum Imperator in Oriente, per legatos suos reverendissimos Metropolitas Bessarionem Nicaenum et Isidorum Kioviensem, ad hoc sacrum Concilium humiliter supplicavit ut Christianitas occidentalis fratres suos orientales in tanto discrimine non deserat. Muri Constantinopolitani, quos magnus Theodosius olim erexit, nunc ruinam minantur; aerarium Imperii exhaustum est; milites pauci sunt qui tam longam circumferentiam defendant. Nisi muri reparentur, nisi milites mittantur, nisi pecunia conferatur, civitas cadet—et cum ea cadet ultimus murus inter Turcas et cor Europae.

The most serene prince John VIII Palaiologos, Emperor of the Romans in the East, through his most reverend legates the Metropolitans Bessarion of Nicaea and Isidore of Kiev, has humbly petitioned this sacred Council that Western Christendom not abandon its Eastern brothers in such great crisis. The walls of Constantinople, which the great Theodosius once erected, now threaten ruin; the treasury of the Empire is exhausted; few are the soldiers who can defend so long a circumference. Unless the walls are repaired, unless soldiers are sent, unless money is contributed, the city will fall—and with it will fall the last wall between the Turks and the heart of Europe.

Haec sacra synodus, auditis legatis Graecorum, inspectis relationibus de statu murorum et militum, consideratis periculis quae ex casu Constantinopolis toti Christianitati imminebunt, unanimi consensu decernit expeditionem sacram pro defensione illius civitatis.

This sacred synod, having heard the legates of the Greeks, having examined the reports on the condition of the walls and soldiers, having considered the dangers which will threaten all Christendom from the fall of Constantinople, decrees with unanimous consent a sacred expedition for the defense of that city.

ARTICULUS I
De Obiecto Expeditionis
On the Objective of the Expedition

§1. Haec sacra expeditio unum habet obiectum singulare et definitum: defensionem civitatis Constantinopolitanae contra Turcorum incursus. Non de recuperatione Terrae Sanctae agitur, quamvis illa semper in votis Christianorum maneat; non de expugnatione terrarum infidelium; sed de conservatione et munitione illius urbis quae orientale Christianitatis propugnaculum constituit.

This sacred expedition has one singular and defined objective: the defense of the city of Constantinople against the incursions of the Turks. It is not about the recovery of the Holy Land, although that always remains in the prayers of Christians; not about the conquest of infidel territories; but about the preservation and fortification of that city which constitutes the eastern bulwark of Christendom.

§2. Obiectivum primarium et immediatum est reparatio murorum Theodosianorum, qui per saecula urbem defenderunt sed nunc in pluribus locis ruinam minantur. Pecunia ad hunc finem destinata in muros, turres, portas, et cetera opera defensiva impendatur, sub inspectione peritorum in arte murali.

The primary and immediate objective is the repair of the Theodosian walls, which have defended the city through the ages but now threaten ruin in many places. Money destined for this purpose shall be spent on walls, towers, gates, and other defensive works, under the inspection of experts in the art of fortification.

§3. Obiectivum secundarium est praesidium militare civitatis: ut milites Christiani ad defendendam urbem sufficiant donec muri reparati sint et Imperium vires suas restaurare possit. Milites sub disciplina et ordinatione cum Imperatore et ducibus eius coordinati militant.

The secondary objective is the military garrison of the city: that Christian soldiers suffice for defending the city until the walls are repaired and the Empire can restore its own forces. Soldiers shall serve under discipline and coordination with the Emperor and his commanders.

§4. Adversarius nominatim designatur: Muradus Secundus, Turcorum sultanus, et exercitus eius. Non contra Graecos aut alias nationes Christianas haec expeditio dirigitur, sed solummodo contra infideles qui Christianam urbem expugnare intendunt.

The adversary is designated by name: Murad the Second, Sultan of the Turks, and his armies. This expedition is not directed against Greeks or other Christian nations, but solely against the infidels who intend to conquer a Christian city.

ARTICULUS II
De Participantibus in Expeditione
On the Participants in the Expedition

§1. Serenissimus princeps Ioannes Secundus, Dei gratia Rex Castellae et Legionis, iam ante promulgationem huius decreti, motu proprio et zelo fidei inflammatus, solemniter promisit mille equites ex Ordinibus Militaribus regni sui—Sancti Iacobi, Calatravae, et Alcantarae—ad defensionem Constantinopolis. Insuper sexaginta milia florenorum pro reparatione murorum destinavit, cum ingeniariis et peritis in arte murali. Haec sacra synodus gratias agit Deo pro tanto exemplo et Regem Castellae tamquam primum inter principes Christianos in hac sancta causa commendat.

The most serene prince John the Second, by the grace of God King of Castile and León, already before the promulgation of this decree, of his own initiative and inflamed by zeal for the faith, has solemnly promised one thousand knights from the Military Orders of his realm—of Saint James, Calatrava, and Alcántara—for the defense of Constantinople. Moreover he has designated sixty thousand florins for the repair of the walls, along with engineers and experts in the art of fortification. This sacred synod gives thanks to God for such an example and commends the King of Castile as first among Christian princes in this holy cause.

§2. Sacra Religio Hospitalis Sancti Ioannis Hierosolymitani, quae ex insula Rhodi iam contra Turcas continue pugnat, per Magistrum suum promisit participationem plenam in hac expeditione: naves bellicas, milites, et facilitates portus Rhodii pro congregatione et refectione navium aliarum gentium. Fratres Hospitalis, tamquam veterani continuae pugnae contra infideles, pretiosam peritiam afferent.

The Sacred Religion of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem, which already fights continuously against the Turks from the island of Rhodes, has promised through its Grand Master full participation in this expedition: warships, soldiers, and the facilities of the port of Rhodes for the assembly and provisioning of ships of other nations. The Brothers of the Hospital, as veterans of continuous struggle against the infidels, will bring precious expertise.

§3. Haec sacra synodus omnes et singulos principes Christianos, reges, duces, comites, barones, et dominos temporales, ardentissime exhortatur et in Domino obsecrat ut exemplo Regis Castellae et Fratrum Hospitalis permoti, pro viribus suis ad hanc sanctam expeditionem contribuant. Qui naves habent, naves mittant; qui milites, milites; qui pecuniam, pecuniam. Nemo se excuset propter longinquitatem: Constantinopolis omnium est, et eius casus omnibus nocebit.

This sacred synod most ardently exhorts and beseeches in the Lord all and singular Christian princes, kings, dukes, counts, barons, and temporal lords, that moved by the example of the King of Castile and the Brothers of the Hospital, they contribute according to their means to this holy expedition. Those who have ships, let them send ships; those who have soldiers, soldiers; those who have money, money. Let no one excuse himself on account of distance: Constantinople belongs to all, and its fall will harm all.

§4. Nominatim invitantur et exhortantur: Serenissimus Imperator Romanorum Sigismundus; Rex Franciae; Rex Angliae; Rex Aragonum et Siciliae; Dux Burgundiae; Respublica Veneta; Respublica Ianuensis; Rex Poloniae; ceteri omnes qui Christi nomen profitentur. Tempus deliberationum transiit; tempus actionis advenit.

Specifically invited and exhorted are: the Most Serene Emperor of the Romans Sigismund; the King of France; the King of England; the King of Aragon and Sicily; the Duke of Burgundy; the Republic of Venice; the Republic of Genoa; the King of Poland; all others who profess the name of Christ. The time for deliberation has passed; the time for action has arrived.

ARTICULUS III
De Subsidiis Pecuniariis
On Financial Subsidies

§1. Ad sustentationem huius sanctae expeditionis, haec sacra synodus indicit decimam cruciatam triennalem super omnes fructus, redditus, et proventus ecclesiasticos in universa Christianitate. Per tres annos proximos, omnes clerici cuiuscumque gradus vel dignitatis decimam partem reddituum suorum pro defensione Constantinopolis solvant.

For the support of this holy expedition, this sacred synod imposes a triennial crusade tithe upon all fruits, revenues, and ecclesiastical proceeds throughout all Christendom. For the next three years, all clerics of whatever rank or dignity shall pay a tenth part of their revenues for the defense of Constantinople.

§2. Collectio decimae fiat per metropolitanos in suis provinciis secundum constitutiones canonicas. Metropolitanus deputet collectores idoneos in singulis dioecesibus, qui fideliter colligant et reddant rationem. Eadem structura quae iam exsistit pro aliis contributionibus ecclesiasticis serviat, ut nulla nova administratio necessaria sit.

Collection of the tithe shall be made through metropolitans in their provinces according to canonical constitutions. The metropolitan shall depute suitable collectors in individual dioceses, who shall faithfully collect and render account. The same structure that already exists for other ecclesiastical contributions shall serve, so that no new administration is necessary.

§3. Indulgentia plenaria conceditur omnibus qui personaliter crucem assumpserint et in expeditione serviverint usque ad finem vel usque ad mortem. Indulgentia partialis conceditur contributoribus pecuniariis secundum quantitatem contributionis: qui centum florenos vel plus contribuerit, indulgentiam septem annorum et septem quadragenarum consequatur; qui quinquaginta florenos, quinque annorum; qui viginti florenos, trium annorum; qui minus, proportionaliter.

A plenary indulgence is granted to all who shall personally take the cross and serve in the expedition to the end or until death. A partial indulgence is granted to financial contributors according to the quantity of contribution: whoever contributes one hundred florins or more shall obtain an indulgence of seven years and seven quarantines; whoever fifty florins, five years; whoever twenty florins, three years; whoever less, proportionally.

§4. Indulgentiae praedicantur et administrantur per episcopos locorum vel eorum delegatos. Episcopi publice declarent conditiones indulgentiarum et testimoniales litteras contributoribus tradant. Praedicatores indulgentiarum nihil ultra expensas necessarias pro se retineant.

The aforesaid indulgences shall be preached and administered by local bishops or their delegates. Bishops shall publicly declare the conditions of the indulgences and deliver testimonial letters to contributors. Preachers of indulgences shall retain nothing for themselves beyond necessary expenses.

§5. Pecuniae collectae deponantur apud domos bancarias Florentinas fidem probatam habentes, non in Camera Apostolica neque in aerario alicuius principis saecularis. Commissio Supervisoria per hoc sacrum Concilium constituta—eadem quae decreta reformationis supervisidet—habeat inspectionem super depositiones et expensas, et rationes trimestrales exigat.

Monies collected shall be deposited with Florentine banking houses of proven reliability, not in the Apostolic Camera nor in the treasury of any secular prince. The Supervisory Commission constituted by this sacred Council—the same that oversees the reform decrees—shall have inspection over deposits and expenditures, and shall require quarterly accounts.

§6. Disbursementa fiant solummodo ad duces militares designatos, post verificationem quod copiae promissae revera congregatae sint. Nulla pecunia solvatur pro copiis quae non exsistunt. Fraudatores pecuniae cruciatae excommunicationi latae sententiae subiacent.

Disbursements shall be made only to designated military commanders, after verification that the promised forces have actually assembled. No money shall be paid for forces that do not exist. Defrauders of crusade money are subject to excommunication latae sententiae.

ARTICULUS IV
De Praeparatione Spirituali Crucesignatorum
On the Spiritual Preparation of Crusaders

§1. Quicumque crucem assumere voluerit, prius confiteatur peccata sua sacerdoti idoneo et veram poenitentiam agat. Expeditio sacra non sit vehiculum quo homines scelerati absolutionem facilem quaerant sine vera conversione cordis. Exemplum sequendum est expeditionis Granatensis, in qua disciplina spiritualis militum fructus mirabiles produxit.

Whoever wishes to take the cross shall first confess his sins to a suitable priest and do true penance. The sacred expedition is not to be a vehicle by which wicked men seek easy absolution without true conversion of heart. The example to be followed is that of the Granada expedition, in which the spiritual discipline of soldiers produced remarkable fruits.

§2. Duces militares curent ut capellani idonei cum copiis proficiscantur, qui sacramenta administrent, verbum Dei praedicent, et disciplinam morum inter milites custodiant. Pro centum militibus, unus saltem capellanus deputetur.

Military commanders shall ensure that suitable chaplains travel with the forces, who shall administer the sacraments, preach the word of God, and guard discipline of morals among the soldiers. For every hundred soldiers, at least one chaplain shall be deputed.

§3. Milites crucesignati abstineant a blasphemia, ebrietate, fornicatione, rapina, et omni violentia iniusta. Qui in his peccatis deprehensi fuerint et non correxerint, a crucesignatis expellantur et indulgentiis priventur. Christiani milites Christianos se praestent.

Crusading soldiers shall abstain from blasphemy, drunkenness, fornication, plunder, and all unjust violence. Those who are found in these sins and do not correct themselves shall be expelled from the crusaders and deprived of indulgences. Christian soldiers must show themselves to be Christians.

§4. Speciatim prohibetur omnis violentia contra Christianos Orientales. Memoria Quartae Cruciatae, quae Constantinopolim ipsam depraedavit, opprobrium Christianitatis manet. Qui contra Graecos Christianos violentiam exercuerit, non solum indulgentias amittat sed excommunicationi subiaceat.

Especially prohibited is all violence against Eastern Christians. The memory of the Fourth Crusade, which plundered Constantinople itself, remains a reproach to Christendom. Whoever exercises violence against Greek Christians shall not only lose indulgences but be subject to excommunication.

ARTICULUS V
De Regimine Expeditionis
On the Governance of the Expedition

§1. Haec sacra synodus Sanctissimum Dominum Nostrum Papam Eugenium Quartum humiliter rogat ut legatum a latere ad hanc expeditionem deputet, virum doctum, prudentem, et zelo fidei ardentem, qui auctoritatem spiritualem in expeditione exerceat.

This sacred synod humbly asks our Most Holy Lord Pope Eugenius the Fourth to depute a legate a latere for this expedition, a man learned, prudent, and burning with zeal for the faith, who shall exercise spiritual authority in the expedition.

§2. Legatus pontificius habeat auctoritatem in omnibus quae ad spiritualia pertinent: praedicationem cruciatae, administrationem sacramentorum, concessionem indulgentiarum, iudicium causarum ecclesiasticarum inter crucesignatos, et disciplinam moralem exercitus.

The pontifical legate shall have authority in all things pertaining to spiritual matters: the preaching of the crusade, administration of sacraments, granting of indulgences, judgment of ecclesiastical causes among the crusaders, and moral discipline of the army.

§3. Quoad regimen militare, principes Christiani qui copias contribuerint in spiritu fraternae unitatis coordinentur. Imperator Romanorum Orientis, Ioannes Octavus Palaeologus, in cuius territorio et pro cuius causa pugnatur, tamquam hospes et dominus terrae honoretur. Cum eo et ducibus eius omnia quae ad defensionem civitatis pertinent concordentur.

As regards military governance, Christian princes who contribute forces shall coordinate in a spirit of fraternal unity. The Emperor of the Romans in the East, John VIII Palaiologos, in whose territory and for whose cause the fighting occurs, shall be honored as host and lord of the land. With him and his commanders, all things pertaining to the defense of the city shall be agreed.

§4. Unusquisque princeps copias suas sub proprio duce teneat, sed omnes duces in consilio communi convenient pro coordinatione operationum. Dissensiones inter duces non per vim sed per deliberationem communem resolvantur, legato pontificio ut arbitro si necessarium.

Each prince shall keep his forces under his own commander, but all commanders shall meet in common council for coordination of operations. Disputes among commanders shall be resolved not by force but by common deliberation, with the pontifical legate as arbiter if necessary.

§5. Si unus princeps longe maiores copias quam ceteri contribuerit, proportionalem vocem in consiliis habeat. Virtus et experientia bellica etiam considerentur in ponderatione consiliorum.

If one prince shall contribute far greater forces than the others, let him have a proportional voice in councils. Valor and military experience shall also be considered in the weighing of counsels.

ARTICULUS VI
De Tempore Congregationis
On the Time of Assembly

§1. Tempus urget. Muri Constantinopolitani non expectant dum principes deliberant. Quapropter haec sacra synodus decernit ut omnes copiae crucesignatae apud loca congregationis designata conveniant ante Kalendas Augusti anni Domini millesimi quadringentesimi trigesimi quarti—id est, ante mensem Augustum proximi anni.

Time presses. The walls of Constantinople do not wait while princes deliberate. Wherefore this sacred synod decrees that all crusading forces shall assemble at the designated places of congregation before the Kalends of August in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-four—that is, before the month of August of the coming year.

§2. Loca congregationis designantur: Venetiae, pro illis qui per mare Adriaticum navigabunt; Rhodus, pro illis qui ex meridie venient aut qui per insulam Hospitaliorum transibunt. Ex his locis copiae coordinatae Constantinopolim proficiscantur antequam tempestates autumnales navigationem periculosam reddant.

The places of congregation are designated: Venice, for those who will sail through the Adriatic Sea; Rhodes, for those who come from the south or who will pass through the island of the Hospitallers. From these places, coordinated forces shall proceed to Constantinople before autumn storms make navigation perilous.

§3. Copiae Castellanae et Hospitaliorum, quae iam in itinere sunt vel brevi erunt, tamquam anteguardia expeditionis procedant. Ceteri principes qui postea copias mittere voluerint, tempestive eas mittant ut cum primis copiis ante hiemem iungantur.

The forces of Castile and the Hospitallers, which are already on the way or will be shortly, shall proceed as the vanguard of the expedition. Other princes who wish to send forces afterward shall send them in timely fashion so as to join with the first forces before winter.

§4. Principes qui tempus praescriptum servare non possint propter distantiam aut alias causas legitimas, nihilominus copias suas mittant quam primum possibile, et interea pecuniam conferant ut alii in eorum locum militent.

Princes who cannot keep the prescribed time on account of distance or other legitimate causes shall nevertheless send their forces as soon as possible, and in the meantime shall contribute money so that others may serve in their place.

ARTICULUS VII
De Coordinatione cum Imperio Orientali
On Coordination with the Eastern Empire

§1. Ante adventum copiarum principalium, nuntii ad Imperatorem Ioannem Octavum mittantur qui adventum copiarum annuntient et de necessitatibus logisticis tractent: ubi milites hospitentur, unde alimenta comparentur, quomodo cum ducibus Graecis communicent.

Before the arrival of the principal forces, messengers shall be sent to Emperor John VIII who shall announce the arrival of forces and treat concerning logistical necessities: where soldiers shall be housed, whence provisions shall be obtained, how they shall communicate with Greek commanders.

§2. Milites occidentales mores et consuetudines Graecorum observent et respectent. In ecclesiis Graecorum sine scandalo se gerant. Graecos tamquam Christianos et fratres, non tamquam haereticos aut inferiores, tractent.

Western soldiers shall observe and respect the customs and usages of the Greeks. In Greek churches they shall conduct themselves without scandal. They shall treat the Greeks as Christians and brothers, not as heretics or inferiors.

§3. Omnes operationes defensivae cum ducibus militaribus Imperii coordinentur. Constantinus Palaeologus, frater Imperatoris, qui militibus Graecis praeest, tamquam socius aequalis in consiliis bellicis honoretur. Scientia locorum et hostis quam Graeci habent pretiosissima est et plenissime utenda.

All defensive operations shall be coordinated with the military commanders of the Empire. Constantine Palaiologos, brother of the Emperor, who commands the Greek soldiers, shall be honored as an equal ally in councils of war. The knowledge of terrain and enemy that the Greeks possess is most precious and must be used most fully.

§4. Quaestiones de unione Ecclesiarum, quae per saecula Orientem et Occidentem diviserunt, non sunt obiectum huius expeditionis. Auxilium Christianis in periculo fertur quia Christiani sunt, non sub condicione quod Romani ritus acceptent. Quaestiones theologicae per proprios canales et in propria tempora tractentur.

Questions concerning the union of the Churches, which have divided East and West through the ages, are not the object of this expedition. Aid is brought to Christians in peril because they are Christians, not under the condition that they accept Roman rites. Theological questions shall be treated through proper channels and at proper times.

ARTICULUS VIII
De Provisionibus Connexis
On Related Provisions

§1. Crucesignati, dum in expeditione sunt, sub protectione speciali Ecclesiae constituuntur. Bona eorum temporalia a quocumque violatore non tangantur. Causae eorum civiles suspendantur donec revertantur vel mors eorum constet. Qui crucesignatos aut familias eorum iniuste vexaverit, excommunicationi subiaceat.

Crusaders, while on the expedition, are constituted under the special protection of the Church. Their temporal goods shall not be touched by any violator. Their civil cases shall be suspended until they return or their death is established. Whoever unjustly harasses crusaders or their families shall be subject to excommunication.

§2. Mercatores qui arma, ferrum, lignum navale, aut alias res bellicas infidelibus vendiderint, excommunicationi latae sententiae subiacent et bonis suis privantur. Hoc commercium proditio Christianitatis est et tamquam tale puniatur.

Merchants who sell arms, iron, ship timber, or other war materials to the infidels are subject to excommunication latae sententiae and shall be deprived of their goods. This commerce is treason against Christendom and shall be punished as such.

§3. Treugae inter principes Christianos, quae iam exsistunt vel quae iniri possint, serventur strictissime dum expeditio durat. Qui treugam fregerit ut bellum inter Christianos moveat dum alii contra infideles pugnant, notam infamiae perpetuam contrahat.

Truces among Christian princes, which already exist or which may be entered into, shall be kept most strictly while the expedition lasts. Whoever breaks a truce to wage war among Christians while others fight against the infidels shall incur a perpetual mark of infamy.

§4. Navigationes commerciales per maria orientalia a piratis et hostibus protegantur. Respublicae maritimae—Veneta, Ianuensis, aliaeque—instanter rogantur ut naves suas pro securitate viarum marinarum disponant.

Commercial shipping through the eastern seas shall be protected from pirates and enemies. The maritime republics—Venice, Genoa, and others—are urgently asked to deploy their ships for the security of sea routes.

ARTICULUS IX
De Executione et Observantia
On Execution and Observance

§1. Hoc decretum vigorem habeat a die promulgationis. Metropolitani illud in synodis provincialibus publicent; episcopi in dioecesibus suis; parochi in ecclesiis. Intra tres menses a promulgatione, omnes fideles de expeditione sacra et de modis participandi edocti sint.

This decree shall have force from the day of promulgation. Metropolitans shall publish it in provincial synods; bishops in their dioceses; pastors in churches. Within three months of promulgation, all the faithful shall be instructed concerning the sacred expedition and the modes of participating.

§2. Commissio Supervisoria relationem de progressu collectionis decimae et congregationis copiarum ad hoc sacrum Concilium referat trimestribus intervallis. Si impedimenta gravia oriantur, Concilium remedium provideat.

The Supervisory Commission shall report on the progress of tithe collection and force assembly to this sacred Council at three-month intervals. If serious impediments arise, the Council shall provide remedy.

§3. Legatus pontificius, cum deputatus fuerit, potestatem habeat in loco adaptandi provisiones huius decreti secundum circumstantias inventas, dummodo substantia decreti servetur. Relationes suas ad Sedem Apostolicam et ad hoc sacrum Concilium mittat.

The pontifical legate, when deputed, shall have power on the spot to adapt the provisions of this decree according to circumstances found, provided the substance of the decree is preserved. He shall send his reports to the Apostolic See and to this sacred Council.

§4. Haec sacra synodus Sanctissimum Dominum Nostrum Papam Eugenium Quartum enixe rogat ut huic decreto auctoritatem Sedis Apostolicae adiungat, ut duplici auctoritate—Concilii et Papae—plenam vim et effectum habeat in universa Christianitate. Unitas Ecclesiae in hac sancta causa manifestetur.

This sacred synod earnestly asks our Most Holy Lord Pope Eugenius the Fourth to join the authority of the Apostolic See to this decree, so that by the double authority—of Council and Pope—it may have full force and effect throughout all Christendom. Let the unity of the Church be manifested in this holy cause.

— SANCTIO ET CONCLUSIO —

Nulli ergo omnino hominum liceat hanc paginam nostrae constitutionis, ordinationis, et decreti infringere vel ei ausu temerario contraire. Si quis autem hoc attentare praesumpserit, indignationem omnipotentis Dei et beatorum Petri et Pauli apostolorum eius se noverit incursurum.

Let no man whatsoever therefore be permitted to infringe this document of our constitution, ordinance, and decree, or to oppose it with reckless boldness. But if anyone shall presume to attempt this, let him know that he will incur the indignation of almighty God and of his blessed apostles Peter and Paul.

Datum Basileae, in publica sessione synodali solemniter in ecclesia cathedrali celebrata, anno Incarnationis Dominicae millesimo quadringentesimo trigesimo tertio, decimonono Kalendas Ianuarii, pontificatus sanctissimi domini nostri Eugenii Papae Quarti anno tertio.

Given at Basel, in a public synodal session solemnly celebrated in the cathedral church, in the year of the Lord's Incarnation one thousand four hundred and thirty-three, the nineteenth day before the Kalends of January [December 14], in the third year of the pontificate of our most holy lord Pope Eugenius IV.

SUBSCRIPTIONES PATRUM
Signatures of the Fathers

Cardinals:

† Ego Iulianus, miseratione divina tituli Sanctae Sabinae presbyter Cardinalis, Sanctae Romanae Ecclesiae Camerarius et Sacri Concilii Basiliensis Praesidens, subscripsi.
[I, Giuliano [Cesarini], by divine mercy Cardinal Priest of the title of Santa Sabina, Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church and President of the Sacred Council of Basel, have subscribed.]

† Ego Ludovicus, tituli Sanctae Caeciliae presbyter Cardinalis Arelatensis, subscripsi.
[I, Louis [Aleman], Cardinal Priest of the title of Santa Cecilia, Archbishop of Arles, have subscribed.]

† Ego Nicolaus, tituli Sanctae Crucis in Hierusalem presbyter Cardinalis, subscripsi.
[I, Niccolò [Albergati], Cardinal Priest of the title of Santa Croce in Gerusalemme, have subscribed.]

Archbishops:

† Ego Ioannes, Archiepiscopus Tarentinus, subscripsi.
[I, John, Archbishop of Taranto, have subscribed.]

† Ego Ioannes, Archiepiscopus Lundensis, subscripsi.
[I, John, Archbishop of Lund, have subscribed.]

† Ego Philibertus, Episcopus Constantiensis, pro natione Gallicana subscripsi.
[I, Philibert, Bishop of Coutances, for the French nation have subscribed.]

Bishops:

† Ego Alfonsus, Episcopus Burgensis, pro Regno Castellae subscripsi.
[I, Alfonso [de Cartagena], Bishop of Burgos, for the Kingdom of Castile have subscribed.]

† Ego Petrus, Episcopus Pataviensis, pro natione Germanica subscripsi.
[I, Peter, Bishop of Passau, for the German nation have subscribed.]

Abbots:

† Ego Rodericus, Abbas Sancti Benedicti Vallisoletani, pro Regno Castellae subscripsi.
[I, Rodrigo [González], Abbot of San Benito of Valladolid, for the Kingdom of Castile have subscribed.]

Doctors and Masters:

† Ego Ioannes de Palomar, decretorum doctor, subscripsi.
[I, John of Palomar, doctor of decrees, have subscribed.]

† Ego Thomas de Haselbach, sacrae theologiae professor, subscripsi.
[I, Thomas of Haselbach, professor of sacred theology, have subscribed.]

Imperial Legate:

† Ego Caspar Schlick, Sacri Romani Imperii Cancellarius, nomine Serenissimi Imperatoris Sigismundi testis subscripsi.
[I, Kaspar Schlick, Chancellor of the Holy Roman Empire, have subscribed as witness in the name of the Most Serene Emperor Sigismund.]

— SUBSCRIPTIO NOTARII —

Et ego Henricus Arnoldi, clericus Leodiensis dioecesis, publicus apostolica et imperiali auctoritate notarius, quia praemissis omnibus et singulis, dum sic ut praemittitur fierent et agerentur, una cum praenominatis testibus praesens interfui, eaque omnia et singula sic fieri vidi et audivi, ideo hoc praesens publicum instrumentum manu aliena fideliter scriptum exinde confeci et in hanc publicam formam redegi, signoque et nomine meis solitis et consuetis signavi rogatus et requisitus in fidem et testimonium omnium et singulorum praemissorum.

And I, Henry Arnoldi, cleric of the diocese of Liège, public notary by apostolic and imperial authority, because I was present at all and singular the foregoing while they were being done and transacted as set forth above, together with the aforementioned witnesses, and saw and heard all and singular these things done, therefore from this I have drawn up and reduced into this public form the present public instrument faithfully written by another hand, and have signed it with my customary sign and name, being asked and required, in faith and testimony of all and singular the foregoing.

APPENDIX: Summary of Key Provisions

Article I — Objective defined as Constantinople defense specifically, with wall repair as primary and military garrison as secondary goals. Sultan Murad II named as adversary.

Article II — Castile's commitment (1,000 knights, 60,000 florins) and Hospitaller participation formally incorporated. All other Christian princes exhorted to contribute.

Article III — Three-year crusade tithe on clergy. Plenary indulgence for crusaders, partial for contributors. Funds administered through metropolitan structure and Florentine banks with Supervisory Commission oversight.

Article IV — Spiritual preparation required for crusaders including confession. Chaplains mandated. Moral discipline enforced. Violence against Greek Christians explicitly prohibited with reference to Fourth Crusade.

Article V — Papal legate to exercise spiritual authority. Military command left to "fraternal coordination" among contributing princes, with Emperor John VIII honored as host. Proportional voice in councils for larger contributors.

Article VI — Assembly deadline of August 1434 at Venice or Rhodes. Castilian and Hospitaller forces designated as vanguard.

Article VII — Coordination with Byzantine Empire required. Western soldiers must respect Greek customs. Church union questions explicitly declared not the object of this expedition.

Article VIII — Crusader protection extended to families and property. Arms trade with infidels prohibited. Christian truces must be maintained during expedition.

Article IX — Promulgation and enforcement mechanisms. Quarterly reporting required. Pope Eugenius IV requested to add apostolic authority for parallel legislation.

— FINIS —

Laus Deo
