laws.title: Commissio Extraordinaria Parentucelli
laws.summary: Pope Eugenius IV appoints Tommaso Parentucelli as Commissarius Extraordinarius for reforming the Apostolic Camera, granting him sweeping powers to examine all accounts, interrogate officials under oath, suspend corrupt functionaries, and propose new ordinances for financial administration.
laws.full_text:
COMMISSIO EXTRAORDINARIA

Pro Reformatione Camerae Apostolicae

EUGENIUS, EPISCOPUS, SERVUS SERVORUM DEI, dilecto filio Thomae
Parentucelli, clerico Sarzanensis diocesis, salutem et apostolicam
benedictionem.

[EUGENIUS, BISHOP, SERVANT OF THE SERVANTS OF GOD, to our beloved son
Tommaso Parentucelli, cleric of the diocese of Sarzana, greetings and
apostolic blessing.]

Motu proprio et ex certa scientia, non ad alicuius nobis super hoc
oblatae petitionis instantiam, sed de nostra mera liberalitate, te,
Thomam Parentucelli, virum doctrina et probitate conspicuum,
COMMISSARIUM EXTRAORDINARIUM PRO REFORMATIONE CAMERAE APOSTOLICAE
constituimus, facimus, et deputamus.

[By Our own initiative and certain knowledge, not at the instance of
any petition offered to Us, but of Our pure liberality, We constitute,
make, and appoint you, Tommaso Parentucelli, a man distinguished in
learning and probity, as EXTRAORDINARY COMMISSIONER FOR THE REFORM OF
THE APOSTOLIC CAMERA.]

Tibi plenam et liberam potestatem concedimus et auctoritatem:

[We grant you full and free power and authority:]

Primo: Omnes rationes, libros, registra, et documenta Camerae
Apostolicae examinandi, inspiciendi, et scrutandi, nullo officiali
contradicente vel impediente.

[First: To examine, inspect, and scrutinize all accounts, books,
registers, and documents of the Apostolic Camera, with no official
contradicting or impeding.]

Secundo: Quoscumque clericos, notarios, scriptores, et officiales
Camerae interrogandi, et ab eis veritatem sub iuramento requirensi.

[Second: To interrogate any and all clerks, notaries, scribes, and
officials of the Camera, and to require from them the truth under
oath.]

Tertio: Quemcumque officialem, cuiuscumque gradus vel conditionis, ab
officio suspendendi, quotiens tibi videbitur expedire, salvo tamen
iudicio Nostro finali.

[Third: To suspend any official whatsoever, of whatever grade or
condition, from office, as often as shall seem expedient to you, saving
nevertheless Our final judgment.]

Quarto: Novas ordinationes et statuta pro recta administratione Camerae
proponendi, Nobis approbanda.

[Fourth: To propose new ordinances and statutes for the right
administration of the Camera, to be approved by Us.]

In his omnibus nemini nisi Nobis ipsis rationem reddere tenearis.
Mandamus igitur universis et singulis officialibus Camerae Nostrae
Apostolicae, ut tibi in praemissis pareant et intendant, sub poena
suspensionis ab officio et beneficio.

[In all these matters you shall be bound to render account to no one
but Ourselves. We therefore command each and every official of Our
Apostolic Camera to obey and attend to you in the aforesaid matters,
under pain of suspension from office and benefice.]

Personam tuam sub Nostra speciali protectione suscipimus. Si quis autem
huic Nostrae constitutioni contraire praesumpserit, indignationem
Omnipotentis Dei et beatorum Petri et Pauli Apostolorum eius se noverit
incursurum.

[We take your person under Our special protection. If anyone shall
presume to contravene this Our constitution, let him know that he will
incur the indignation of Almighty God and of the blessed Apostles Peter
and Paul.]

Datum Romae, apud Sanctum Petrum, anno Incarnationis Dominicae millesimo
quadringentesimo trigesimo quarto, undecimo Kalendas Aprilis,
pontificatus Nostri anno quarto.

[Given at Rome, at Saint Peter's, in the year of the Lord's
Incarnation one thousand four hundred and thirty-four, the eleventh day
before the Kalends of April [March 22], in the fourth year of Our
pontificate.]

† EUGENIUS PP. IV

[SEAL]

Witnessed this day by:

His Most Catholic Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León

laws.title: Declaratio Apostolica Motu Proprio
laws.summary: Pope Eugenius IV asserts independent papal authority over church reforms by voluntarily adopting the Basel reform decrees on pluralism, concubinage, and annates through his own apostolic authority rather than conciliar compulsion, thereby preserving papal sovereignty while implementing substantive reform.
laws.full_text:
DECLARATIO APOSTOLICA

De Reformatione Ecclesiae Motu Proprio Suscepta

EUGENIUS, EPISCOPUS, SERVUS SERVORUM DEI, AD PERPETUAM REI MEMORIAM.

[EUGENIUS, BISHOP, SERVANT OF THE SERVANTS OF GOD, FOR THE PERPETUAL
RECORD OF THE MATTER.]

Regimen Ecclesiae Universalis, Nobis a Divina Providentia commissum,
constantem vigilantiam exigit contra illos abusus qui, per humanam
fragilitatem, in ipsa sacratissima instituta irrepunt. Ab ipsis
Apostolorum diebus, Ecclesia se ipsam per reformationem purificavit,
corruptionem abscindens ut Corpus Christi integrum permaneret.

[The governance of the Universal Church, committed to Us by Divine
Providence, demands constant vigilance against those abuses which,
through human weakness, creep into even the most sacred institutions.
From the earliest days of the Apostles, the Church has purified herself
through reform, cutting away corruption that the Body of Christ might
remain whole.]

Proximis annis, postulationes reformationis ex multis Christianitatis
partibus surrexerunt---a conciliis, a principibus, ab ipsis fidelibus.
Audivimus. Examinavimus. Oravimus.

[In recent years, calls for reform have arisen from many quarters of
Christendom---from councils, from princes, from the faithful themselves.
We have listened. We have examined. We have prayed.]

Quaedam propositiones ad reformationem disciplinae clericalis
pertinentes ad Nostram notitiam pervenerunt, de malis pluralitatis
beneficiorum, de scandalo concubinatus clericorum, et de onere nimiae
taxationis super ecclesias. Has propositiones examinantes et eas
consonas invenientes cum antiquo iure canonico, cum decretis
praedecessorum Nostrorum, et cum bono animarum Christianarum, nunc
agimus.

[Certain proposals touching the reform of clerical discipline have come
to Our attention, concerning the evils of pluralism, the scandal of
clerical concubinage, and the burden of excessive taxation upon the
churches. Having examined these proposals and found them consonant with
ancient canon law, the decrees of Our predecessors, and the good of
Christian souls, We now act.]

MOTU PROPRIO, Nostra propria initiativa et certa scientia, non ad
mandatum alicuius concilii vel principis, sed in harmonia cum antiqua
traditione Ecclesiae et in plenitudine Nostrae apostolicae auctoritatis,
decernimus et ordinamus ut sequentes reformationes in tota Ecclesia
observentur:

[BY OUR OWN INITIATIVE, by Our own motion and certain knowledge, not at
the command of any council or prince, but in harmony with the ancient
tradition of the Church and in the fullness of Our apostolic authority,
We hereby decree and ordain that the following reforms be observed
throughout the Church:]

I. De Pluralitate Beneficiorum --- secundum ordinationes
infrascriptas

[I. Concerning Pluralism of Benefices --- according to the ordinances
written below]

II. De Concubinatu Clericorum --- secundum ordinationes
infrascriptas

[II. Concerning Clerical Concubinage --- according to the ordinances
written below]

III. De Annatis Reformandis --- secundum ordinationes infrascriptas

[III. Concerning the Reform of Annates --- according to the ordinances
written below]

Nemo dicat Episcopum Romanum expectare concilia ad reformandam Ecclesiam
curae suae commissam. Nemo dicat auctoritatem papalem requirere
licentiam ad agendum. Agimus quia rectum est. Agimus quia necessarium
est. Agimus quia Vicarius Christi debet esse primus inter eos qui
Evangelio serviunt, non ultimus inter eos qui morantur.

[Let no man say that the Bishop of Rome waits upon councils to reform
the Church committed to his care. Let no man say that papal authority
requires permission to act. We act because it is right. We act because
it is necessary. We act because the Vicar of Christ must be first among
those who serve the Gospel, not last among those who delay.]

Si alii easdem veritates locuti sunt, unitatem conscientiae Christianae
agnoscimus. Ubi fideles homines de bono conveniunt, ipsa convenientia
benedictio est, quaecumque sit origo. Pastor non quaerit quae ovis prima
lupum viderit---agit ut gregem protegat.

[If others have spoken these same truths, We acknowledge the unity of
Christian conscience. Where faithful men agree on what is good,
agreement itself is a blessing, whatever the source. The shepherd does
not ask which sheep first saw the wolf---he acts to protect the flock.]

Datum Romae, apud Sanctum Petrum, anno Incarnationis Dominicae millesimo
quadringentesimo trigesimo quarto, undecimo Kalendas Aprilis,
pontificatus Nostri anno quarto.

[Given at Rome, at Saint Peter's, in the year of the Lord's
Incarnation one thousand four hundred and thirty-four, the eleventh day
before the Kalends of April [March 22], in the fourth year of Our
pontificate.]

† EUGENIUS PP. IV

[SEAL]

--- Attached hereto: Full texts of the Decrees on Pluralism,
Concubinage, and Annates ---

laws.title: Bulla Reformationis Camerae Apostolicae
laws.summary: Comprehensive Bull of Reform containing twenty articles restructuring the Apostolic Camera, separating its judicial and financial functions, establishing transparent accounting procedures, capping administrative fees, creating an independent audit mechanism, and granting amnesty for past financial irregularities in exchange for cooperation.
laws.full_text:
BULLA REFORMATIONIS

De Reformatione Camerae Apostolicae et Recta Administratione Bonorum
Ecclesiae

EUGENIUS EPISCOPUS, SERVUS SERVORUM DEI, AD PERPETUAM REI MEMORIAM.

[EUGENIUS, BISHOP, SERVANT OF THE SERVANTS OF GOD, FOR THE PERPETUAL
RECORD OF THE MATTER.]

--- ARENGA ---

Inter multiplices pastoralis officii curas, quibus assidue premimur,
illa praecipue Nostrum animum tangit sollicitudo, ut Ecclesia Dei,
sponsa Christi immaculata, ab omni labe mundetur et in pristinum
splendorem restituatur. Non enim latet Nos quod per decursum temporum,
humana fragilitate faciente, abusus quidam in administrationem rerum
ecclesiasticarum irrepserint, qui et conscientias gravant et fideles
scandalizant et hostibus Ecclesiae arma praebent.

[Among the manifold cares of Our pastoral office, by which We are
constantly pressed, that concern especially touches Our soul: that the
Church of God, the immaculate spouse of Christ, be cleansed of every
stain and restored to her former splendor. For it does not escape Our
notice that through the course of time, by human weakness, certain
abuses have crept into the administration of ecclesiastical affairs,
which burden consciences, scandalize the faithful, and provide weapons
to the enemies of the Church.]

Agnoscimus quod consuetudines quaedam invaluerunt quae, licet longa
tolerantia permissae, non concordant cum antiqua disciplina Ecclesiae
nec cum Evangelio Christi. Tempus est agendi. Tempus est reformandi.
Pastor non quaerit quae ovis prima lupum viderit---agit ut gregem
protegat.

[We acknowledge that certain customs have taken root which, though long
permitted by tolerance, do not accord with the ancient discipline of the
Church nor with the Gospel of Christ. It is time to act. It is time to
reform. The shepherd does not ask which sheep first saw the wolf---he
acts to protect the flock.]

--- PARS PRIMA ---

De Separatione Camerae Apostolicae et Sacri Collegii Cardinalium

Articulus I: De Nova Ordinatione Camerae

Statuimus et ordinamus ut Camera Apostolica deinceps sit officium
domesticum Summi Pontificis, ad haec et non alia deputatum: expensas
domus pontificalis, stipendia custodum palatii apostolici, missiones
diplomaticas nomine Pontificis missas, manutentionem aedificiorum
papalium, opera caritatis, et solutionem debitorum legitimorum.

[We establish and ordain that the Apostolic Camera shall henceforth be
a household office of the Supreme Pontiff, deputized for these and no
other purposes: the expenses of the papal household, the stipends of the
guards of the apostolic palace, diplomatic missions sent in the name of
the Pontiff, the maintenance of papal buildings, works of charity, and
the payment of legitimate debts.]

Articulus II: De Reditibus Camerae

Camera Apostolica recipiet dimidiam partem annatarum et aliorum redituum
secundum decreta de annatis reformandis, necnon fructus beneficiorum
vacantium, Denarium Sancti Petri, et oblationes directe Sedi Apostolicae
factas. Ex his reditibus, et non aliis, expensas supradictas solvat.

[The Apostolic Camera shall receive half of the annates and other
revenues according to the decrees on the reform of annates, as well as
the fruits of vacant benefices, Peter's Pence, and offerings made
directly to the Apostolic See. From these revenues, and no others, shall
it pay the expenses described above.]

Articulus III: De Sacro Collegio Cardinalium

Sacrum Collegium Cardinalium recipiet alteram dimidiam partem annatarum
secundum decreta praedicta. Ex hac portione, Collegium solvat: subsidia
cardinalibus indigentibus secundum necessitatem, non secundum dignitatem
vel antiquitatem; expensas officiorum curialium quae toti Ecclesiae
serviunt, praesertim Rotae Romanae et Poenitentiariae Apostolicae; et
alia onera quae Collegium sibi assumere voluerit.

[The Sacred College of Cardinals shall receive the other half of the
annates according to the aforesaid decrees. From this portion, the
College shall pay: subsidies to cardinals in need according to
necessity, not according to dignity or seniority; the expenses of curial
offices which serve the whole Church, especially the Roman Rota and the
Apostolic Penitentiary; and other burdens which the College shall wish
to assume for itself.]

Articulus IV: De Cessatione Subsidiorum ex Camera

A die publicationis huius decreti, Camera Apostolica nullum subsidium,
pensionem, vel stipendium solvet alicui cardinali ratione dignitatis
cardinalitiae. Cardinales qui subsidia requirunt ad Sacrum Collegium se
convertant, quod secundum regulas proprias distribuet.

[From the day of publication of this decree, the Apostolic Camera shall
pay no subsidy, pension, or stipend to any cardinal by reason of
cardinalatial dignity. Cardinals who require subsidies shall turn to the
Sacred College, which shall distribute according to its own rules.]

--- PARS SECUNDA ---

De Transparentia et Rationibus Reddendis

Articulus V: De Rationibus Publicandis

Quolibet quartali anno, Camera Apostolica rationes publicas edat,
continentes: summam omnium redituum receptorum; summam omnium expensarum
solutarum per categoriam; statum debitorum et creditorum; et pecuniam in
thesauro restantem. Hae rationes pateant inspectioni cuiuslibet
cardinalis vel legati regii qui eas videre voluerit.

[Each quarter of the year, the Apostolic Camera shall publish accounts
containing: the sum of all revenues received; the sum of all expenses
paid by category; the state of debts and credits; and the money
remaining in the treasury. These accounts shall be open to inspection by
any cardinal or royal legate who wishes to see them.]

Articulus VI: De Rationibus Collegii

Similiter, Sacrum Collegium Cardinalium rationes suas quolibet quartali
publicet, ostendens quomodo portionem suam distribuerit. Nullus
cardinalis subsidium recipiat nisi in rationibus publicis nominetur, cum
summa recepta et causa assignata.

[Similarly, the Sacred College of Cardinals shall publish its accounts
each quarter, showing how it has distributed its portion. No cardinal
shall receive a subsidy unless he is named in the public accounts, with
the sum received and the reason assigned.]

Articulus VII: De Relationibus cum Argentariis

Omnes reditus Camerae Apostolicae transeant per rationes sub solo
control officialium papalium. Nullus argentarius retineat pecunias
nomine Camerae nisi ad brevissimum tempus transitus necessarium. Nullus
argentarius deducat feoda vel expensas sine expressa licentia scripta
pro unaquaque transactione, a Commissario Extraordinario approbata.

[All revenues of the Apostolic Camera shall pass through accounts under
the sole control of papal officials. No banker shall retain monies in
the name of the Camera except for the briefest time necessary for
transfer. No banker shall deduct fees or expenses without express
written license for each transaction, approved by the Extraordinary
Commissioner.]

--- PARS TERTIA ---

De Officialibus et Documentis

Articulus VIII: De Suspensione Officialium

Omnes officiales Camerae Apostolicae, cuiuscumque gradus vel
conditionis, a die publicationis huius decreti suspendantur ab exercitio
officiorum suorum, salvo stipendio, donec a Commissario Extraordinario
examinentur. Qui idonei et fideles inventi fuerint, restituantur. Qui
minus idonei, cum gratiarum actione dimittantur, sine infamia vel
prosecutione.

[All officials of the Apostolic Camera, of whatever grade or condition,
shall from the day of publication of this decree be suspended from the
exercise of their offices, with salary preserved, until examined by the
Extraordinary Commissioner. Those found suitable and faithful shall be
reinstated. Those less suitable shall be dismissed with thanks, without
infamy or prosecution.]

Articulus IX: De Documentis Restituendis

Omnia documenta Camerae Apostolicae---rationes, libri, registra,
litterae, et instrumenta cuiuscumque generis---sunt proprietas Sanctae
Sedis. Quicumque talia documenta detinet, sive in officiis sive in
domibus privatis, ea intra triginta dies Commissario Extraordinario
restituat, sub poena suspensionis ab officio et beneficio.

[All documents of the Apostolic Camera---accounts, books, registers,
letters, and instruments of whatever kind---are the property of the Holy
See. Whoever holds such documents, whether in offices or in private
homes, shall restore them to the Extraordinary Commissioner within
thirty days, under pain of suspension from office and benefice.]

Articulus X: De Collectione Redituum

Intra annum unum in Italia, et intra annos duos in ceteris terris
Christianitatis, systema collectionis redituum simplicetur. Collectores
regionales directe Camerae respondeant, sine intermediariis
multiplicibus. Commissarius Extraordinarius ordinationes specificas edat
pro implementatione huius articuli.

[Within one year in Italy, and within two years in other lands of
Christendom, the system of revenue collection shall be simplified.
Regional collectors shall answer directly to the Camera, without
multiple intermediaries. The Extraordinary Commissioner shall issue
specific ordinances for the implementation of this article.]

--- PARS QUARTA ---

De Abolitione Abusuum

Articulus XI: De Compositionibus Abolendis

Praxis compositionum---per quas violatores canonum pecuniam solverunt
pro absolutione a poenis, continuantes in violationibus suis---omnino
aboleatur. Nullus deinceps absolutionem a poena canonica emat. Qui in
concubinatu vivit, concubinam dimittat vel poenas patiatur. Qui plura
beneficia illicite tenet, superflua resignet vel deponatur. Peccatum non
est merx vendenda.

[The practice of compositions---by which violators of canons paid money
for absolution from penalties while continuing in their violations---is
entirely abolished. No one shall henceforth purchase absolution from
canonical penalty. He who lives in concubinage shall dismiss his
concubine or suffer the penalties. He who illicitly holds multiple
benefices shall resign the surplus or be deposed. Sin is not a
merchandise to be sold.]

Articulus XII: De Expectativis

Expectativae ad beneficia futura deinceps registrentur apud Cameram et
limitentur. Nullus plus quam unam expectativam teneat. Nulla expectativa
vendatur, tradatur, vel aliter transferatur. Expectativae non
registratae intra sex menses nullae sint.

[Expectancies to future benefices shall henceforth be registered with
the Camera and limited. No one shall hold more than one expectancy. No
expectancy shall be sold, traded, or otherwise transferred. Expectancies
not registered within six months shall be void.]

Articulus XIII: De Coadiutoribus

Coadiutores cum iure successionis non nominentur nisi cum approbatione
metropolitani et pro causa legitima---scilicet infirmitate vel senectute
titularis---non pro pretio soluto. Quaelibet pecunia data occasione
nominationis coadiutoris praesumatur simoniaca, et nominatio irrita sit.

[Coadjutors with right of succession shall not be appointed except with
the approval of the metropolitan and for legitimate cause---namely the
infirmity or old age of the titular holder---not for a price paid. Any
money given on the occasion of the appointment of a coadjutor shall be
presumed simoniacal, and the appointment shall be void.]

Articulus XIV: De Pensionibus Super Beneficia

Pensiones super beneficia quae manifeste circumveniunt regulas contra
pluralitatem nullae sint. Si quis beneficium resignavit et plus quam
tertiam partem fructuum ut pensionem retinet, praesumatur non vere
resignasse, et beneficium vacare declaretur.

[Pensions charged upon benefices which manifestly circumvent the rules
against pluralism shall be void. If anyone has resigned a benefice and
retains more than one-third of the fruits as a pension, he shall be
presumed not to have truly resigned, and the benefice shall be declared
vacant.]

--- PARS QUINTA ---

De Amnestia et Novo Initio

Articulus XV: De Praeteritis Non Inquirendis

Non quaerimus punire eos qui vias secuti sunt quas circumstantia et
praecedentia permittere videbantur. Omnes servos Ecclesiae vocamus ut
deinceps in novitate vitae ambulent, priores mores deponentes sicut homo
deponit vestimenta iuventutis suae.

[We do not seek to punish those who followed paths that circumstance
and precedent seemed to permit. We call all servants of the Church to
walk henceforth in newness of life, setting aside former ways as a man
sets aside the garments of his youth.]

Articulus XVI: De Amnestia Conditionata

Nemo timeat prosecutionem pro iis quae sub antiqua dispensatione gesta
sunt, dummodo reformationes hic decretas bona fide amplectatur.
Praeterita misericordiae Dei redduntur. Futura communi labori nostro
committuntur. Qui vero reformationes amplecti simulat sed veterem
corruptionem occulte continuat, is amnestiam suis actionibus respuit et
tamquam violator novi iuris, non veteris consuetudinis, tractetur.

[Let no man fear prosecution for what was done under the old
dispensation, provided he embraces in good faith the reforms herein
decreed. The past is rendered to God's mercy. The future is committed
to our common labor. But he who pretends to embrace the reforms while
secretly continuing the old corruption rejects the amnesty by his own
actions and shall be treated as a violator of new law, not a
practitioner of old custom.]

Articulus XVII: De Iure Reservato

Sancta Sedes sibi reservat ius examinandi praeteritas praxes prout
circumstantiae postulaverint, praesertim in casibus corruptionis tam
enormis ut etiam sub veteribus consuetudinibus tolerari non potuerit.
Haec reservatio non minuit amnestiam generalem, sed agnoscit quod
quaedam scelera numquam licita fuerunt et numquam licita esse potuerunt.

[The Holy See reserves to itself the right to examine past practices as
circumstances warrant, especially in cases of corruption so enormous
that it could not have been tolerated even under the old customs. This
reservation does not diminish the general amnesty, but acknowledges that
certain crimes were never licit and never could have been licit.]

--- PARS SEXTA ---

De Executione et Poenis

Articulus XVIII: De Commissario Extraordinario

Ad implementationem huius decreti, constituimus Commissarium
Extraordinarium pro Reformatione Camerae Apostolicae, cui plenam
potestatem dedimus examinandi, inquirendi, suspendendi, et ordinationes
specificas edendi, secundum litteras commissionis separatim datas.

[For the implementation of this decree, We have constituted an
Extraordinary Commissioner for the Reform of the Apostolic Camera, to
whom We have given full power of examining, inquiring, suspending, and
issuing specific ordinances, according to the letter of commission
separately given.]

Articulus XIX: De Poenis Futuris

Quicumque post publicationem huius decreti praecepta eius violaverit,
praeter poenas specificas in singulis articulis statutas, subiacebit:
primo, suspensioni ab officio; secundo, recuperationi pecuniarum
illicite acceptarum; tertio, si pertinax fuerit, depositioni ab officio
et beneficio; quarto, in casibus gravioribus, censuris ecclesiasticis
usque ad excommunicationem.

[Whoever after the publication of this decree shall violate its
precepts, besides the specific penalties established in individual
articles, shall be subject to: first, suspension from office; second,
recovery of monies illicitly received; third, if he persists, deposition
from office and benefice; fourth, in more serious cases, ecclesiastical
censures up to excommunication.]

Articulus XX: De Protectione Reformatorum

Omnes qui reformationi fideliter cooperantur---sive officiales Camerae
sive alii---sub speciali protectione Nostra et successorum Nostrorum
suscipiuntur. Si quis eos propter cooperationem vexaverit, molestatorem
excommunicamus et anathematizamus.

[All who faithfully cooperate with the reform---whether officials of
the Camera or others---are taken under the special protection of
Ourselves and Our successors. If anyone shall harass them on account of
their cooperation, We excommunicate and anathematize the harasser.]

--- SANCTIO ---

Nulli ergo omnino hominum liceat hanc paginam nostrae constitutionis,
ordinationis, reformationis, et decreti infringere vel ei ausu temerario
contraire. Si quis autem hoc attentare praesumpserit, indignationem
omnipotentis Dei et beatorum Petri et Pauli apostolorum eius se noverit
incursurum.

[Let no man therefore be permitted to infringe this document of Our
constitution, ordinance, reform, and decree, or to oppose it with
reckless boldness. If anyone shall presume to attempt this, let him know
that he will incur the indignation of almighty God and of His blessed
apostles Peter and Paul.]

Datum Romae, apud Sanctum Petrum, anno Incarnationis Dominicae millesimo
quadringentesimo trigesimo quarto, undecimo Kalendas Aprilis,
pontificatus Nostri anno quarto.

[Given at Rome, at Saint Peter's, in the year of the Lord's
Incarnation one thousand four hundred and thirty-four, the eleventh day
before the Kalends of April [March 22], in the fourth year of Our
pontificate.]

† EUGENIUS PP. IV

[SEAL OF THE FISHERMAN]

Witnessed and endorsed by:

His Most Catholic Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León,

Defender of the Faith and Protector of the Holy See

Tommaso Parentucelli, Commissarius Extraordinarius

laws.title: Tomos of Apokatastasis
laws.summary: Synodal declaration establishing the theological foundation for the reconquest of Orthodox lands from Ottoman occupation, framing territorial restoration as a sacred duty of apokatastasis distinct from Latin crusading practice, and defining the spiritual obligations of participants in the eastern campaigns.
laws.full_text:
ΤΟΜΟΣ ΤΗΣ ΑΠΟΚΑΤΑΣΤΑΣΕΩΣ
TOMOS OF THE APOKATASTASIS

A Synodal Declaration Concerning the Sacred Restoration of Orthodox Lands

Drafted at Constantinople, in the Palace of Blachernae
The 15th day of April, in the Year of Our Lord 1434
In the Reign of His Imperial Majesty John VIII Palaiologos

INVOCATIO

Ἐν ὀνόματι τοῦ Πατρὸς καὶ τοῦ Υἱοῦ καὶ τοῦ Ἁγίου Πνεύματος. Ἀμήν.

In the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen.

PROOEMIUM: THE THEOLOGICAL FOUNDATION

We who subscribe our names to this sacred document, being bishops, priests, and clergy of the Holy Orthodox Church, assembled in synod at the God-protected city of Constantinople, do hereby set forth this tomos concerning the restoration of Orthodox Christian lands now held under the dominion of unbelievers.

On the Anastasis and the Apokatastasis:

Our most holy faith teaches that Christ our God descended into Hades not to wait for the righteous to ascend to Him, but to reach down and raise them up. This is the sacred mystery of the Anastasis—the Resurrection—depicted in our most venerable icons, wherein our Lord grasps the hands of Adam and Eve and draws them forth from darkness into light.

So also does the Apokatastasis—the Restoration of All Things—reflect the divine economy of salvation. As the Holy Apostle Peter proclaimed: "Heaven must receive Him until the time of the restoration of all things, which God spoke by the mouth of all His holy prophets since the world began" (Acts 3:21).

While the theological application of apokatastasis to the ultimate fate of souls remains a matter of reverent dispute among the Fathers, its temporal meaning admits no controversy: that which has been stolen from Christ's Church may—and must—be restored. That which was Orthodox shall be Orthodox again. That which was consecrated to the worship of the Trinity shall not remain forever in the hands of those who deny the Son.

On the Present Calamity:

For generations beyond counting, the Orthodox faithful have dwelt in the lands of Anatolia, Thrace, Macedonia, and the Peloponnese. Our fathers built churches there. Our mothers baptized children there. The bones of saints and martyrs rest in soil now trodden by those who call Christ a mere prophet and deny His divinity.

The great sees of the Church—Ephesus, where the Theotokos was proclaimed; Nicaea, where the Creed was written; Chalcedon, where the natures of Christ were defined—these holy places groan under foreign occupation. The bells are silent. The icons are hidden or destroyed. The faithful who remain must pay tribute for the privilege of worshipping the true God.

This is not the will of Heaven. This is not the eternal order of things. This is a wound in the Body of Christ that cries out for healing.

On the Distinction from Latin Practice:

We declare plainly that this sacred undertaking is not a crusade in the Latin manner. We grant no indulgences. We promise no remission of sins in exchange for killing. We do not claim that death in battle guarantees entrance to Paradise, for such presumption belongs to God alone.

The Latin crusade, whatever its merits or faults, springs from a different theological soil. It is not ours to judge it. But neither is it ours to imitate it.

What we proclaim is this: that the defense of Orthodox Christians and the restoration of Orthodox lands is a sacred duty, blessed by God and the Church. Those who contribute to this holy work perform acts of piety equivalent to pilgrimage, almsgiving, or the building of churches. They do not purchase salvation—for salvation cannot be purchased—but they participate in the healing of Christ's wounded Body.

ARTICULUS I: ON THE SACRED NATURE OF RESTORATION

§1. We declare and affirm that the defense of Constantinople, the New Rome, the seat of Orthodox Christendom for eleven hundred years, constitutes a sacred obligation upon all the faithful.

§2. We declare and affirm that the liberation of Orthodox lands currently under Ottoman dominion—including but not limited to the territories of Thessalonica, Adrianople, the Morea, and the ancient lands of Anatolia—constitutes a holy work pleasing to God.

§3. We declare and affirm that this apokatastasis seeks not conquest of that which was never ours, but restoration of that which was stolen. We do not march to impose our faith upon others, but to free our brothers and sisters who suffer under the yoke of unbelief.

§4. We declare and affirm that any Orthodox Christian who contributes to this sacred restoration—whether by arms, by treasure, by labor, or by prayer—performs a work of piety that shall be recognized and honored by the Church.

ARTICULUS II: ON CONTRIBUTIONS OF TREASURE

§1. The monasteries, churches, and ecclesiastical foundations of the Orthodox world possess treasuries accumulated through the pious donations of the faithful across many generations. These treasures were given for the glory of God and the sustenance of His Church.

§2. We declare that the voluntary contribution of gold, silver, or precious objects to the sacred apokatastasis constitutes a pious work of the highest order. No contribution shall be compelled; all must flow freely from hearts moved by love of God and compassion for suffering brethren.

§3. Monasteries and churches that contribute shall have their gifts recorded in a sacred register, the Codex Apokatastaseos, which shall be preserved in perpetuity as a testament to their faithfulness.

§4. Contributors of treasure shall have their names—whether of institutions or individual donors—inscribed in the diptychs of restored churches, to be commemorated during the Divine Liturgy until Christ returns in glory.

§5. We explicitly forbid the melting of sacred icons, consecrated vessels, or liturgical objects for this purpose. The treasury of piety is not the treasury of worship. Let that which was made for the altar remain upon the altar.

ARTICULUS III: ON CONTRIBUTIONS OF SUSTENANCE

§1. The monasteries of the Orthodox world hold granaries, olive presses, and storehouses filled with the fruits of their lands. These provisions were gathered through honest labor and prudent stewardship.

§2. We declare that the voluntary contribution of grain, oil, wine, dried fish, salt, and other provisions to sustain the defenders of Orthodoxy constitutes a pious work equivalent to feeding the hungry—for indeed, those who man the walls hunger, and those who march to liberation require sustenance.

§3. Monasteries that open their granaries shall receive formal acknowledgment in the Codex Apokatastaseos and commemoration in the diptychs as described above.

§4. Where monasteries have suffered hardship and cannot contribute without endangering their own communities, no contribution shall be expected or demanded. Charity that impoverishes the charitable is no charity at all.

ARTICULUS IV: ON CONTRIBUTIONS OF SERVICE

§1. Monks and clergy of the Orthodox Church are forbidden by sacred tradition from shedding blood. This prohibition remains absolute and inviolate. No priest shall take up the sword. No monk shall don armor for battle.

§2. Nevertheless, there are forms of service that do not violate these sacred boundaries:

- Healers: Monks trained in medicine may tend the wounded, bind injuries, and comfort the dying without sin.
- Scribes: Monks skilled in letters may serve as record-keepers, write letters for illiterate soldiers, and maintain the chronicles of the restoration.
- Chaplains: Priests may accompany armies to celebrate the Divine Liturgy, hear confessions, administer last rites, and pray over the fallen.
- Counselors: Learned clergy may advise commanders on matters of justice, mercy, and the treatment of prisoners and civilians.

§3. Clergy who serve in these capacities do so with the full blessing of the Church. Their service is not a departure from their vows but a fulfillment of Christ's command to love one another.

§4. Monks and priests who serve shall have their names inscribed in a special section of the Codex Apokatastaseos designated for those who gave not treasure but themselves.

ARTICULUS V: ON THE SACRED REMEMBRANCE

§1. The Diptychs of the Orthodox Church are the sacred lists of names—both living and dead—commemorated during the Divine Liturgy. To be inscribed in the diptychs is to be remembered before God, in the holiest moment of Christian worship, until the end of time.

§2. We hereby establish that all who contribute to the sacred apokatastasis—whether by treasure, sustenance, service, or sacrifice—shall have their names inscribed in the diptychs of the churches they helped to restore.

§3. The hierarchy of commemoration shall be as follows:

- Martyrs of the Restoration: Those who give their lives in defense of Orthodox lands or peoples shall be commemorated as martyrs, their names read on the anniversary of their death and on the Feast of All Saints.
- Benefactors of the Restoration: Those who contribute treasure or sustenance of exceptional magnitude shall be commemorated as ktitores (founders), their names inscribed above the doors of churches they helped to liberate.
- Servants of the Restoration: All others who contribute shall be commemorated in the general diptychs, their names read during the Liturgy on the anniversary of the liberation of each restored territory.

§4. This commemoration is not an indulgence. We do not promise forgiveness of sins in exchange for contribution. Forgiveness flows from repentance and the mercy of God, not from gold or service.

§5. What we promise is remembrance—that those who gave shall not be forgotten, that their descendants shall hear their names spoken in holy places, that the Church shall honor their sacrifice until the Lord returns.

ARTICULUS VI: ON THE GOVERNANCE OF CONTRIBUTIONS

§1. To ensure that contributions reach their sacred purpose and are not diverted by corruption or mismanagement, we establish the following:

§2. A council of oversight, the Synaxis Apokatastaseos, shall be formed consisting of:
- Two bishops (or their designated representatives)
- Two laymen of proven integrity, nominated by the Emperor
- One representative of the contributing monasteries

§3. This council shall maintain the Codex Apokatastaseos, recording all contributions and their disposition. The codex shall be open to inspection by any contributing party.

§4. Annual accounting shall be rendered to a full synod of subscribing bishops, detailing what was received, what was expended, and what remains.

§5. Any member of the Synaxis found to have diverted funds for personal use or purposes other than the sacred restoration shall be excommunicated and their name stricken from all diptychs.

ARTICULUS VII: ON THE LIMITS OF THIS DECLARATION

§1. This tomos addresses only the spiritual and ecclesiastical dimensions of the apokatastasis. Matters of military command, political governance of restored territories, and relations with foreign powers remain the province of His Imperial Majesty and his councils.

§2. This tomos does not require, authorize, or endorse any particular military campaign, alliance, or treaty. It establishes only that the principle of restoration is sacred and that contributions to such restoration are pious works.

§3. This tomos does not bind the conscience of any Orthodox Christian to support any particular strategy, commander, or political arrangement. The faithful must judge for themselves, with prayer and discernment, how best to serve the cause of restoration.

§4. This tomos does not supersede the authority of the Ecumenical Patriarch in matters of faith and doctrine. It addresses only the specific question of the apokatastasis and the piety of contributing to it.

CONCLUSIO

We who subscribe our names do so in full knowledge of the gravity of this declaration. We act not from pride or ambition, but from love of Christ's Church and compassion for our suffering brethren.

We know that some will oppose this tomos. We know that powerful voices will call it innovation, presumption, or worse. We answer only this: when the walls of Jerusalem fell to Nebuchadnezzar, the prophets did not counsel acceptance of eternal exile. They proclaimed restoration. They promised return. And God honored their faith.

Constantinople is not Jerusalem. We are not prophets. But we serve the same God, and we believe—we must believe—that He has not abandoned His Church to slow extinction.

Let those who have ears hear. Let those who have treasure give. Let those who have strength serve. And let all the faithful pray that God, in His mercy, will grant success to the sacred apokatastasis.

Ἡ χάρις τοῦ Κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ μετὰ πάντων ὑμῶν. Ἀμήν.

The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.

SUBSCRIPTIONES

Space reserved for the signatures of subscribing bishops, with their sees and the date of subscription

laws.title: Charter of the Latin Courts
laws.summary: Establishes a comprehensive legal system for Constantinople's Latin residents, creating commercial courts for trade disputes, a civil tribunal for property and contract matters, and a criminal court, with judges drawn from Venetian, Genoese, and Castilian communities operating under codified procedural rules.

laws.title: Taktikon of Romania
laws.summary: Restores and codifies the Byzantine system of imperial titles and offices, establishing a three-tier distribution framework for granting titles upon reconquest of territories, with ranks assigned based on military contribution, financial investment, and administrative capability rather than birth alone.

laws.title: Chrysobull of the Choice
laws.summary: Imperial proclamation offering the people of Constantinople a stark choice between decline under current conditions or accepting Latin settlement and military partnership for the city's defense, granting full Roman citizenship to Latin residents and establishing the framework for a multi-ethnic imperial restoration.
laws.full_text:
XPYEOBOYAAON THE EKAOFHE 
CHRYSOBULL OF THE CHOICE 
A Proclamation to the People of Constantinople Concerning Their Future 
Drafted at Constantinople, in the Palace of Blachernae The 15th day of April, in the Year of Our Lord 
1434 
INVOCATIO 
'Ev ÒVÔk1CITt TOj 11UTPÒç 1<C1ì cofi Yioj TOò Ayiot) ITVË6k1CITOÇ. Aghv. 
In the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen. 
PREAMBLE: THE TRUTH OF OUR CONDITION 
To all who dwell within the walls of Constantinople—Greek and Latin, noble and common, clergy and layman, 
rich and poor—hear now the truth of our condition, spoken plainly and without concealment. 
The Empire is dying. 
This is not prophecy. This is not despair. This is fact, known to all who have eyes to see. 
Where once the Roman Empire stretched from the Pillars of Hercules to the Euphrates, from the Danube to the 
Nile, we now hold only this city and a few scattered fragments. Thessalonica has fallen. Adrianople has fallen. 
The great cities of Anatolia—Nicaea, where the Creed was written; Ephesus, where the Theotokos was 
proclaimed—these are Turkish now. Our children are taken for the Sultan's armies. Our churches become 
mosques. Our people live as dhimmis, paying tribute for the privilege of remaining Christian. 
The Turks will come for Constantinople. 
Not today. Perhaps not this year. But they will come. Sultan Murad II commands armies that dwarf anything we 
can field. His cannon grow larger each year. His treasury fills while ours empties. He has been patient because 
patience costs him nothing. Time is his ally. Every year we grow weaker. Every year he grows stronger. 
When he decides the moment has come, our walls—the greatest walls in Christendom—will face bombardment 
such as they have never known. Our defenders—brave but few—will face numbers beyond counting. And 
unless something fundamental changes, Constantinople will fall as Thessalonica fell. As Adrianople fell. As a 
hundred cities have fallen before. 
This is not meant to breed despair, but clarity. 
You deserve to know the truth. You deserve to make your choice with open eyes. The comfortable lies—that 
God will provide a miracle, that the West will send armies at the last moment, that somehow things will work 
out—these lies serve no one. They leave you unprepared for the storm that is coming. 
There is still time to choose. 
The Turks have not yet marched. The walls still stand. And from the West has come an offer—unprecedented, 
unexpected, and requiring careful consideration. 
Juan II, King of Castile and Leon, Conqueror of Granada, has brought nine hundred knights to Constantinople. 
He has offered not merely temporary aid but permanent alliance. He has proposed not merely defense but 
restoration—the recovery of lost Roman lands, the rebuilding of Roman power, the transformation of a dying 
empire into something that might live again. 
But his offer comes with conditions. Significant conditions. Conditions that would change Constantinople 
forever. 
You must choose. 
Not the Emperor alone. Not the nobles alone. Not the Patriarch alone. You—the people of Constantinople, in 
whose hands the city's fate has always ultimately rested. 
This document presents your choices. Read them. Debate them. Pray over them. And then decide what future 
you will have. 
THE THREE CHOICES 
CHOICE THE FIRST: Sanctuary in the West 
For those who would leave: 
Ifyou cannot accept the conditions of restoration, and cannot face the future alone, there is a third path: 
departure. 
King Juan II offers sanctuary in his kingdom to any Greek who wishes to leave Constantinople before the storm 
breaks. The terms are these: 
Land: The Kingdom of Granada, recently conquered from the Moors, has land in abundance. Greek families 
who resettle will receive grants sufficient to support themselves—farms, workshops, homes. You will not arrive 
as beggars but as settlers with rights and property. 
Citizenship: Those who accept sanctuary become subjects of the Crown of Castile, with all the rights and 
protections this entails. You will be taxed no differently than native Castilians. You will have access to the same 
courts, the same markets, the same opportunities. 
Religion: Your Orthodox faith will be honored and protected. You may worship according to your traditions, 
maintain your liturgy in Greek, raise your children in the faith ofyour fathers. The King of Castile does not 
demand conversion. He asks only loyalty to the crown that shelters you. 
What you surrender: Constantinople. The Empire. The hope of restoration. You would leave as refugees, 
preserving your lives and your faith but abandoning the city that has been the heart of Orthodox Christendom 
for eleven centuries. Your grandchildren will be Castilian, not Roman. The memory of Byzantium will fade into 
songs and stories. 
T his choice is available to all. Noble or common, wealthy or poor. Ships will be provided for those who 
choose this path. You may bring what you can carry. You will arrive in a land at peace, far from Turkish swords. 
But you will never see the City again. 
CHOICE THE SECOND: To Stand Alone 
For those who would refuse all foreign aid: 
Ifyou cannot accept Latin help—ifthe memory of 1204 burns too hot, if the price of alliance seems too high, if 
you would rather die Greek than live in a transformed city—you may refuse. 
King Juan will honor this choice. He will complete the repairs to the walls that his knights have already begun. 
He will leave such supplies as have been gathered. And then he will sail away, returning to his own wars and his 
own kingdoms, leaving Constantinople to face the future alone. 
What this means: 
The walls will hold for a time. Perhaps years. Perhaps decades. The Turks may find other targets more tempting. 
Miracles are not impossible. 
But understand clearly: no other army is coming. The West has sent its crusades before—they ended in disaster 
or betrayal. The Pope issues bulls and calls for aid; the princes of Europe ignore them. Ifyou refuse this offer, 
you refuse the only substantial military force that has reached Constantinople in living memory. 
You will face the Turks alone, with the forces you have now. Approximately five thousand men capable of 
bearing arms, to defend fourteen miles of walls against armies that may number a hundred thousand. 
This is not meant as threat, but as truth. 
Ifyou choose to stand alone, you choose with courage and pride. No one can take that from you. But you also 
choose, in all probability, to fall. And when Constantinople falls, the slaughter of Thessalonica will be repeated. 
Three days of sack, by Ottoman custom. The men killed or enslaved. The women violated. The children taken. 
The churches defiled. 
This is what the Turks do. This is what they have done in every city they have taken. There is no reason to 
believe Constantinople will be different. 
Choose this path ifyou must. But choose it knowing what it means. 
CHOICE THE THIRD: The Restoration 
For those who would fight to live: 
Ifyou are willing to accept help—Latin help, with all that entails—there is a path to survival. More than 
survival: to restoration. To becoming again what the Roman Empire once was. 
But this path demands much. Read carefully what acceptance means. 
Part I: The Defensor Romaniae 
You would accept Juan II, King of Castile and Leon, as Defensor Romaniae—Defender of the Roman Realm. 
This is not Emperor. The Emperor remains John VIII Palaiologos, isapostolos, God's vice-regent, sacred 
sovereign of the Roman people. The Defensor serves the Empire; he does not replace it. 
But the Defensor would hold supreme military command. All armies. All navies. All forces raised for defense or 
restoration would answer to him. The Old system of independent commanders, of nobles who field private 
armies answering only to themselves, would end. 
The Defensor would have authority to: 
• Summon all persons owing military service 
Appoint and dismiss military officers 
Direct strategy and campaigns 
Requisition supplies for military necessity 
Distribute conquered lands according to established systems 
Enforce military justice 
The Defensor would NOT have authority over: 
• 
• 
Civil governance of Constantinople (which remains Imperial) 
Matters of Orthodox faith and doctrine (which remain with the Church) 
Ordinary taxation (except that specifically designated for military purposes) 
Civil justice in non-military matters (except as provided in the Latin Courts charter) 
This arrangement persists until the Empire can stand secure on its own foundations—a matter for the Defensor 
and Emperor to determine together when that day comes. 
Part II: Military Obligations 
Everyone fights. 
This is not rhetoric. This is law. 
The Urban Militia: Every able-bodied male resident between sixteen and fifty-five owes service in the city 
militia. No exceptions for wealth. No exceptions for rank. The noble's son and the baker's apprentice stand 
together on the walls. 
Monthly training required 
Wall assignments for every unit 
Equipment provided by military stores 
Penalties for those who evade service 
The Pronoia Obligations: Nobles who hold revenue grants owe military service proportional to their wealth. 
The ancient system, long corrupted into mere collection of revenues without corresponding duty, would be 
restored and enforced. 
No noble may collect pronoia revenues without fulfilling military obligations 
Household guards must serve under the Defensor's command when summoned 
Personal service required of great nobles, not merely provision of retainers 
Penalties up to forfeiture of grants for those who evade 
The Thematic System: As territories are reconquered, soldier-farmers would be settled on the land, creating 
self-sustaining military forces. 
• 
• 
Land grants in exchange for military service 
Training and equipment provided initially 
Hereditary tenure so long as obligations are met 
Opportunity for common soldiers and militiamen to become landholders 
The Professional Forces: A core of paid, full-time soldiers—the tagmata—would form the elite force for 
offensive operations. 
The full details of military obligation are set forth in the Taktikon of Romania, available for examination by 
any who wish to understand precisely what service would be required. 
Part III: Justice and Law 
Acceptance means accepting a new legal order—one that treats Greek and Latin alike under common law. 
The Charter of the Latin Courts establishes: 
• 
• 
Courts with jurisdiction over disputes between persons of different nations 
Judges drawn from nations not party to the dispute, ensuring impartiality 
The lex mercatoria (merchant law) for commercial disputes 
Byzantine law (Basilika) for criminal matters 
Clear procedures for accusation, defense, evidence, and judgment 
Enforcement mechanisms that bind all subscribing nations 
For Greeks, this means: 
Access to fair courts when wronged by Latins 
Protection from arbitrary Latin justice administered only by Latins 
The same law applying to all, regardless of origin 
For Latins, this means: 
Security that their rights will be respected 
Fair adjudication of disputes with Greeks 
A system they can trust to protect their interests 
The principle is equality. No one stands above the law. No one is denied justice because oftheir birth. 
Part IV: Property Rights for Latins 
This is perhaps the most difficult condition for many Greeks to accept. Read it carefully. 
Latins—Venetians, Genoese, Castilians, and others—would be permitted to own property throughout 
Constantinople, not merely within their traditional quarters. 
What this means: 
Latin merchants may purchase shops, warehouses, and homes in Greek neighborhoods 
Latin families may settle wherever they choose within the walls 
Latin churches may be built where congregations form 
Property rights are protected by the Latin Courts system 
What this does NOT mean: 
Latins do not receive property taken from Greeks; they must purchase fairly 
Latins remain subject to the same laws as Greeks 
Latins pay the same taxes as Greeks 
No special privileges beyond equality 
Why this condition? 
Because without it, Latins will not invest in Constantinople's future. They will not build, settle, raise families, or 
bind their fortunes to the city. They will remain temporary visitors, ready to flee when danger comes. 
1f Constantinople is to survive, it needs Latin gold, Latin ships, Latin soldiers. These will not come without 
security of property. This is the price of alliance. 
Some will say this is the beginning of Latin conquest by commerce rather than arms. Perhaps. Or perhaps it is 
the beginning of a true partnership—Greeks and Latins building something together that neither could build 
alone. 
You must decide which you believe. 
Part V: Religion and Marriage 
No one will be forced to change their faith. 
Greeks remain Orthodox. Latins remain Catholic. Each worships according to their tradition, in their own 
churches, under their own clergy. The Defensor Romaniae, though Catholic himself, does not seek to impose 
Rome's authority over Orthodox Christians. 
For mixed marriages: 
When a man and woman of different faiths marry, the household chooses which faith to follow. This choice is 
made at the moment of marriage—sealed by the church in which the wedding takes place. 1f married in an 
Orthodox church, the household is Orthodox. 1f married in a Latin church, the household is Latin. 
Children follow the faith of the household. T hey may, as adults, choose to convert. But the household's faith is 
established at marriage and does not change thereafter. 
This is compromise, not resolution. 
The theological disputes between Rome and Constantinople—the Filioque, papal supremacy, the nature of 
church authority—remain unresolved. This document does not address them. Perhaps someday a true council 
will heal the schism. Until then, we live side by Side, respecting each other's faith while maintaining our own. 
Part VI: The Church's Role 
Acceptance means accepting the framework established in the Tomos of the Apokatastasis. 
The Orthodox Church would not be taxed. But the Church would be called to contribute voluntarily to the 
sacred cause of restoration: 
• 
Grain and Oil from monastery storehouses 
Gold and silver from treasury reserves 
Horses, mules, and wagons from church lands 
Monks serving as healers, scribes, and chaplains 
Those who contribute—whether institutions or individuals—would have their names inscribed in the diptychs 
of restored churches, commemorated in the Divine Liturgy until Christ returns. 
This is not indulgence. We do not promise forgiveness of Sins in exchange for gold. We promise remembrance 
—that those who gave shall not be forgotten. 
The full theological framework is set forth in the Tomos, available for examination by clergy and laity alike. 
Part VII: Citizenship and Identity 
This document does not resolve questions of citizenship and cultural identity. 
A Venetian who settles in Constantinople remains Venetian for now. A Greek remains Greek. As more 
nationalities mingle, as children are born of mixed marriages, new identities may emerge. Some may choose to 
call themselves Roman—heirs to the ancient tradition that once united the Mediterranean world. 
For now, these are matters of personal choice, not legal definition. There is no practical benefit to declaring 
oneself Roman rather than Greek or Venetian. Perhaps benefits will develop over time. Perhaps they will not. 
What matters now is survival. Questions of identity can be debated by grandchildren who exist because we 
made the hard choices today. 
Part VIII: The Alliance of Kingdoms 
1f Constantinople accepts the Defensor, the Defensor accepts Constantinople. 
Juan II is not merely King of Castile. 1--1e is heir presumptive to the throne of Aragon. 1--1is alliance already 
encompasses Naples, with its strategic position in the central Mediterranean. His marriage binds Castile to 
Portugal's maritime power. 
1f you choose restoration, you do not stand alone with nine hundred knights. 
You become part of an alliance stretching from the Atlantic to your own shores. Castilian armies. Aragonese 
navies. Neapolitan ports. The combined resources of the Western Mediterranean kingdoms, directed toward a 
common purpose. 
The Defensor pledges: 
To command the Mediterranean kingdoms he rules toward the defense and restoration of Constantinople 
To bring Castile, Aragon, and Naples into alliance with the Roman Empire 
To use these kingdoms together as building blocks for something greater—the restoration of Roman pride 
and honor across the Mediterranean world 
This is not charity. This is partnership. The West needs the East; the East needs the West. Together, perhaps, we 
may drive back the Ottoman tide. Separately, we fall one by one. 
THE MANNER OF CHOOSING 
The choice belongs to the people of Constantinople. 
Not to the Emperor alone—though his voice cames weight. 
Not to the Patriarch alone—though his blessing matters. 
Not to the nobles alone—though their resources are needed. 
To all of you. 
The choice will be presented in the Hippodrome, the ancient gathering place where the people of 
Constantinople have acclaimed and rejected emperors for a thousand years. 
Those who choose sanctuary in Castile will make themselves known and begin preparations for departure. 
Those who choose to stand alone will make themselves known, and the Defensor will complete his work on the 
walls and sail away with honor. 
Those who choose restoration will make themselves known, and the work of transformation will begin. 
There is no shame in any choice. 
To leave is to preserve your families and your faith. To stand alone is to choose pride over submission. To 
accept restoration is to embrace change for the sake of survival. 
Only you can decide what matters most. Only you can weigh the costs and benefits. Only you can determine 
what future you are Willing to fight for—or to flee from—or to accept. 
CONCLUSION 
The hour is late, but not yet final. 
Constantinople has stood for eleven centuries. It has survived sieges, plagues, fires, earthquakes, and betrayals 
beyond counting. It has outlasted empires that seemed invincible. It has risen from disasters that seemed 
insurmountable. 
Perhaps it will rise again. 
But not without choice. Not without sacrifice. Not without transformation. 
Read these terms. Understand them fully. Debate them freely. Pray for guidance. 
And then choose. 
The documents referenced herein—the Tomos of the Apokatastasis, the Charter of the Latin Courts, and the 
Taktikon of Romania—are available for examination at the Palace of Blachernae, the Hagia Sophia, and such 
other locations as shall be designated. 
The choice will be called in the Hippodrome on a day to be announced. 
Until then, may God grant wisdom to all who must decide. 
SUBSCRIPTION 
Offered by: 
Juan II, by the Grace of God King of Castile, Leon, Toledo, Galicia, Seville, Côrdoba, Murcia, Jaén, the 
Algarve, Algeciras, Gibraltar, and Granada; Lord of Vizcaya and Molina; 1--leir Presumptive to the Crown of 
Aragon; Ally of the Kingdom of Naples 
Witnessed by: 
Demetrios Kantakouzenos, Strategos 
Commander of the Armies of Constantinople 
Father Gennadios Scholarios 
Priest and Scholar 
Marco Contarini 
Bailo of the Most Serene Republic of Venice in Constantinople 
Raffaele Lomellini 
Podestà of the Most Serene Republic of Genoa in Constantinople 
[Additional witnesses as appropriate] 
Awaiting acceptance or rejection by the People of Constantinople and ratification by His Imperial 
Majesty John VIII Palaiologos, Emperor of the Romans. 
[END OF CHRYSOBULLI

laws.title: Catalogue of Lost Imperial Titles
laws.summary: Comprehensive register of all Byzantine imperial offices and titles associated with territories currently under Ottoman occupation, cataloguing hundreds of positions from provincial governors to military commanders, preserved as a legal foundation for restoring the imperial administrative structure upon reconquest.
laws.full_text:
CATALOGUE OF LOST IMPERIAL TITLES
Compiled at Constantinople, April 1434
For the Restoration Council under the Authority of the Defensor Romaniae

Compiled by Nikephoros, Secretary to House Philanthropenos, at the direction of Alexios Philanthropenos the Elder and Juan II, King of Castile, during private consultation at the Blachernae Palace.

PURPOSE OF THIS DOCUMENT

This catalogue enumerates the titles, offices, and dignities lost by the Roman Empire over the past century, organized by importance and geographic region. It is intended to serve as the foundation for a Charter of Restoration, wherein claimant families may have their ancestral rights confirmed and uncommitted titles may be granted to loyal houses in anticipation of reconquest.

NOTES ON CLAIMS AND DISTRIBUTION

Titles with Strong, Clear Claimants:
- Doux of Adrianople — claimed by the Kantakouzenoi
- Doux of Mesembria — claimed by the Asanes
- Kephale of Serres — contested between Raoul and Melissenos
- Strategos of Nicaea — the Laskaris family (old claim)
- Various Thracian kephalates — multiple families hold documents

Titles with Weak or Disputed Claims:
- Doux of Thessalonica — last held by Palaiologos who died without clear heir; in imperial gift
- Doux of the Fleet — currently held by Loukas Notaras; reverts to imperial disposition if vacated
- Many Macedonian kephalates — families extinct or in exile
- Black Sea coastal offices below Mesembria — Tornikes claim some (diminished house)
- Anatolian commands — so long lost that most claims have faded

Titles Clearly in Imperial/Defensorial Gift:
- All Strategoi (military commands) — always appointed, not inherited
- All Prokathemenoi (revenue offices) — granted by imperial will
- New titles for reconquered lands held by Turks for over a century

PRELIMINARY GRANT RECORDED:
- House Philanthropenos — Granted the Doux of Thessalonica, conditional upon reconquest and the signing of the Golden Decree naming Juan II as Defensor Romaniae.

I. THE DOUKAI AND THEIR SUBORDINATE OFFICES

The Doukai are the great military governorships—the highest provincial dignities below the imperial house itself.

1. THESSALONICA AND MACEDONIA

Doux of Thessalonica
Status: AVAILABLE FOR GRANT (Palaiologos line unclear)
GRANTED TO: House Philanthropenos (conditional)

Supreme military governor of Macedonia and the second city of the Empire. Near-royal dignity. Commands the defenses of all Macedonia. The title carried quasi-independent authority; the last holder was Andronikos Palaiologos, kinsman to the Emperor, who died when the city fell to the Ottomans in 1430.

Population at time of fall: approximately 40,000.

Subordinate Titles within the Duchy:

| Title | Description | Status |
|-------|-------------|--------|
| Kephale of Thessalonica | Civil governor of the city. Responsible for markets, walls, urban administration. | Lost 1430 |
| Strategos of the Macedonian Theme | Field commander of the provincial army. Subordinate to Doux. | Lost 1430 |
| Prokathemenos of the Harbor | Master of the port. Controlled customs, anchorage fees, naval supplies. | Lost 1430 |
| Archon of the Lower City | Administrator of commercial districts and foreign quarters. | Lost 1430 |
| Kephale of Berroia | Governor of inland city, second largest in Macedonia. Key position on western road. | Lost 1430 |
| Kephale of Edessa | Ancient city north of Thessalonica. Controlled mountain passes toward Serbia. | Lost 1430 |
| Kephale of Rentina | Fortress town guarding eastern approaches. | Lost 1430 |
| Prokathemenos of the Axios Valley | Administrator of rich agricultural lands along the river. | Lost 1430 |
| Archon of Kalamaria | Lord of coastal district east of the city. | Lost 1430 |
| Kephale of Hierissos | Guardian of approaches to Mount Athos. | Lost 1430 |
| Prostates of Mount Athos | Imperial representative to the Holy Mountain. Spiritual prestige. | Status unclear |

Notable Lost Estates in Macedonia:
- The Metochion of the Philanthropenos — lands near Berroia, held for two centuries
- The Palaiologos estates along the Axios
- The Kantakouzenos properties near Rentina
- The Tarchaniotes holdings in Kalamaria

2. ADRIANOPLE AND THRACE

Doux of Adrianople
Status: CLAIMED by House Kantakouzenos
Claimant should be confirmed in their ancestral right

Military governor of Thrace. Commands the heartland between Constantinople and the Danube. Lost 1369. The city is now the Ottoman capital; they call it Edirne. Whoever holds Adrianople controls the road to Constantinople.

Subordinate Titles within the Duchy:

| Title | Description | Status |
|-------|-------------|--------|
| Kephale of Adrianople | Civil governor of the city. | Lost 1369 |
| Strategos of the Thracian Theme | Field commander. Once among the most important military posts. | Lost 1369 |
| Kephale of Didymoteichon | Governor of fortress city on Maritsa River. Once an imperial residence. | Lost 1361 |
| Kephale of Tzurulum | Modern Çorlu. Controls road from Constantinople to Adrianople. | Lost ~1360s |
| Kephale of Arcadiopolis | Strategic junction town. | Lost 1365 |
| Kephale of Bizye | Northern Thracian fortress. | Lost 1373 |
| Prokathemenos of the Ergene Valley | Rich agricultural lands. | Lost ~1360s |
| Archon of Mesene | Coastal district along Marmara shore. | Lost ~1360s |
| Kephale of Selymbria | Twenty miles from Constantinople. | STILL HELD (barely) |
| Kephale of Herakleia | On Marmara coast. | Technically ours, contested |
| Kephale of Raidestos | Important port on Marmara. | Lost 1354 |

Notable Lost Estates in Thrace:
- The Palaiologos ancestral lands near Didymoteichon
- The Kantakouzenos estates throughout central Thrace
- The Asen properties near Bizye
- The Bryennios holdings along the Ergene

3. THE BLACK SEA COAST

Doux of Mesembria
Status: CLAIMED by House Asanes
Claimant should be confirmed in their ancestral right

Military governor of the western Black Sea coast. Lost 1396. Key to the grain trade from Crimea.

Subordinate Titles within the Duchy:

| Title | Description | Status |
|-------|-------------|--------|
| Kephale of Mesembria | Governor of the ancient port city. | Lost 1396 |
| Kephale of Anchialos | Salt-producing port. Valuable revenues. | Lost 1396 |
| Kephale of Sozopolis | Southern coastal fortress. | Lost 1371 |
| Kephale of Agathopolis | Small coastal town. | Lost 1396 |
| Prokathemenos of the Salt Works | Administrator of Anchialos salt pans. Significant revenue. | Lost 1396 |
| Archon of Develtos | Inland district. Agricultural lands and horse pastures. | Lost ~1390s |
| Strategos of the Coastal Watch | Commander of patrol galleys and coastal fortifications. | Lost 1396 |

Notable Lost Estates on the Black Sea Coast:
- The Asanes estates throughout the coast
- The Tornikes holdings near Mesembria
- The Branades properties inland

4. EASTERN MACEDONIA AND THE STRYMON

Doux of Serres
Status: DISPUTED between Houses Raoul and Melissenos
Requires adjudication at council

Military governor of eastern Macedonia. Center of silk production. Lost to Serbia 1345, then to Turks 1383.

Subordinate Titles within the Duchy:

| Title | Description | Status |
|-------|-------------|--------|
