laws.title: Decree of Thracian Reservation
laws.summary: Reserves the provinces of Thrace and Macedonia for Greek noble families, excluding Latin settlers from claiming titles or lands in these historically Greek territories while allowing Greek nobles priority in the reconquest distribution system established by the Taktikon.
laws.full_text:
DECREE OF THRACIAN RESERVATION
Decretum de Reservatione Thraciae

Given at Constantinople, in the Palace of Blachernae
The Twelfth Day of May, in the Year of Our Lord 1434

JOHN VIII PALAIOLOGOS, by the Grace of God Emperor and Autocrat of the Romans, together with JUAN II, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, Defensor Romaniae, to all faithful Christians present and future, greeting and apostolic benediction.

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS the restoration of the Roman Empire, called the Apokatastasis, requires the reconquest of territories long held by the enemies of Christendom;

AND WHEREAS the noble houses of the Romans have suffered grievously under Ottoman domination, losing their ancestral lands, their patrimony, and their power to defend the Empire;

AND WHEREAS the Defensor Romaniae has generously committed the forces of Castile to the cause of restoration, asking no immediate recompense for this sacrifice;

AND WHEREAS justice demands that those who have lost most should be restored first, and that the ancient families of the Empire should rebuild their strength before new claimants divide the reconquered lands;

NOW THEREFORE, by imperial authority and with the consent of the Defensor Romaniae, we decree and establish the following:

ARTICLE I: THE THRACIAN RESERVATION

Section 1. All lands reconquered within the historical Theme of Thrace—bounded by the walls of Constantinople to the east, the Rhodope Mountains to the north, the Aegean Sea to the south, and the Nestos River to the west—are hereby RESERVED for distribution exclusively to noble houses of Greek Roman origin.

Section 2. This reservation applies to all grants of land, title, and lordship made as initial distribution following reconquest. No Latin lord, knight, or settler shall receive grants of land within Thrace under this initial distribution, regardless of their contributions to the Apokatastasis.

Section 3. For the purposes of this decree, "Latin" includes all persons of Western Christian origin, including those who have elected Roman citizenship under the Chrysobull of the Choice. The purpose of this reservation is to restore the original Byzantine nobility; citizenship election does not alter this classification for purposes of initial land distribution.

ARTICLE II: RECOGNITION OF LATIN CONTRIBUTIONS

Section 1. The contributions of Latin lords, knights, and soldiers to the Apokatastasis shall be documented fully and faithfully. Every man who fights, every florin contributed, every sacrifice made shall be recorded in the rolls of the Defensor.

Section 2. These contributions create claims upon future conquests. When the Apokatastasis extends beyond Thrace—into Macedonia, into Anatolia, into territories yet to be reclaimed—Latin claimants shall receive grants proportional to their documented contributions.

Section 3. No Latin contribution shall be forgotten or diminished by this reservation. The deferral of reward is not the denial of reward. Those who fight for the Empire shall receive their due, in lands beyond the Thracian boundary.

ARTICLE III: SECONDARY TRANSFERS

Section 1. Following the initial distribution of Thracian lands to Greek houses, all restrictions on transfer are lifted. Greek lords holding Thracian grants may sell, trade, gift, or bequeath their holdings to any person, Latin or Greek, citizen or foreign, as they see fit.

Section 2. The reservation applies only to the INITIAL distribution made by imperial and defensorial authority. Once land passes into private hands, it follows the ordinary laws of property applicable throughout the Empire.

Section 3. No Greek lord shall be compelled to sell or transfer his Thracian holdings. This provision exists to permit voluntary transactions, not to enable forced acquisition.

ARTICLE IV: CRITERIA FOR GREEK GRANTS

Section 1. Grants of Thracian land shall be made according to the principles established in the Taktikon of Romania: those who contribute more receive more, those who contribute less receive less, and those who contribute nothing receive nothing.

Section 2. Priority in distribution shall consider:
- The number and quality of soldiers committed to the Apokatastasis
- The duration and faithfulness of service
- Losses suffered in battle for the Empire's cause
- Historical claims of families dispossessed by Ottoman conquest
- The strategic importance of holdings and the grantee's ability to defend them

Section 3. The Emperor, in consultation with the Defensor Romaniae, shall determine all grants. Disputes regarding distribution shall be adjudicated by the tribunals established under the Decree of the Defensor.

ARTICLE V: DURATION AND AMENDMENT

Section 1. This reservation remains in force until the complete reconquest and distribution of the Theme of Thrace, or until amended by mutual agreement of the Emperor and the Defensor Romaniae.

Section 2. Should the Apokatastasis extend beyond Thrace while Thracian distribution remains incomplete, new conquests shall be available for Latin grants while the Thracian reservation continues in parallel.

Section 3. This decree may be amended, extended, or revoked only by joint action of the Emperor and the Defensor, or their lawful successors, with the consent of the noble houses affected thereby.

WITNESS AND SEAL

Given under our hands and seals at Constantinople, in the presence of the assembled council, on the twelfth day of May in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-four.

IOANNES VIII PALAIOLOGOS
Imperator et Autocrator RhomaiÅn

JUAN II OF CASTILE
Rex Castellae et Legionis, Defensor Romaniae

WITNESSES:

Georgios Sphrantzes, Imperial Secretary

The Doukas Patriarch, speaking for House Doukas

Lord Bryennios, speaking for House Bryennios

Raoul the Elder, Captain of the Tagmata

Kantakouzenos, Strategos of the Walls

Inscribed and sealed in the presence of the above witnesses. Let none alter or diminish these terms without lawful authority.

FIAT. FIAT. FIAT.

laws.title: Charter of Joint Treasury
laws.summary: Establishes a joint Castilian-Byzantine treasury for managing crusade finances and reconstruction funds, with dual oversight from both crowns, standardized accounting procedures, and provisions for equitable distribution of military expenses and territorial revenues.
laws.full_text:
CHARTER OF JOINT TREASURY ADMINISTRATION
Carta Administrationis Aerarii Coniuncti

Given at Constantinople, in the Palace of Blachernae
The Twelfth Day of May, in the Year of Our Lord 1434

JOHN VIII PALAIOLOGOS, by the Grace of God Emperor and Autocrat of the Romans, together with JUAN II, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, Defensor Romaniae, to all faithful Christians present and future, greeting and apostolic benediction.

PREAMBLE

WHEREAS the restoration of the Roman Empire, called the Apokatastasis, requires resources beyond what the Byzantine treasury alone can provide;

AND WHEREAS the Defensor Romaniae has generously committed the resources of Castile to the cause of restoration, seeking partnership rather than dominion;

AND WHEREAS effective defense and reconquest require unified administration of military resources, clear accounting, and mutual trust between the parties;

AND WHEREAS both parties desire an arrangement that preserves Byzantine sovereignty and dignity while enabling the flow of Castilian resources to the common cause;

NOW THEREFORE, by imperial authority and mutual agreement, we decree and establish the following:

ARTICLE I: ESTABLISHMENT OF JOINT ADMINISTRATION

Section 1. For the duration of King Juan II's tenure as Defensor Romaniae, the treasuries of the Roman Empire and the Kingdom of Castile shall be administered jointly for all matters pertaining to defense, military expenditure, and the Apokatastasis.

Section 2. This joint administration creates a common fund, hereinafter called the FUND OF THE APOKATASTASIS, from which all military expenses shall be drawn.

Section 3. The Defensor Romaniae shall have authority to direct expenditures from the Fund of the Apokatastasis for purposes of defense, military recruitment, wall repair, armament, fleet construction, and all other matters necessary to the restoration of the Empire.

ARTICLE II: IMPERIAL RESERVED EXPENDITURES

Section 1. The following categories of expenditure remain under the sole discretion of His Imperial Majesty and are NOT subject to joint administration:
- The Imperial Household and its maintenance
- Stipends for court officials and palace servants
- Ceremonial expenses of the Empire
- Personal expenses of the Imperial family
- Such other civil expenditures as have been customary

Section 2. These reserved expenditures shall be funded at their current levels from Byzantine revenues before any surplus flows to the Fund of the Apokatastasis.

Section 3. As the prosperity of Constantinople increases through reformed revenues and expanded trade, the allocation for Imperial Reserved Expenditures may be increased by mutual agreement, reflecting the renewed dignity and capability of the Empire.

ARTICLE III: BYZANTINE CONTRIBUTIONS

Section 1. All Byzantine revenues not allocated to Imperial Reserved Expenditures shall flow to the Fund of the Apokatastasis. These include but are not limited to:
- Customs duties and harbor fees
- Taxes on trade and commerce
- Revenues from Latin residents under the Chrysobull of the Choice
- Income from imperial properties and enterprises
- Such other revenues as may be collected

Section 2. The Defensor Romaniae is granted authority to reform the collection and administration of these revenues, with the purpose of increasing efficiency, reducing corruption, and maximizing income for the common cause.

Section 3. A full accounting of current Byzantine revenues and expenditures shall be conducted within thirty days of this Charter's signing, establishing a baseline from which improvements may be measured.

ARTICLE IV: CASTILIAN CONTRIBUTIONS

Section 1. The Kingdom of Castile commits to contribute its treasury surplus to the Fund of the Apokatastasis. This contribution represents the partnership of Castile in the restoration of the Roman Empire.

Section 2. The Castilian contribution shall vary according to resources available. In years of plenty, the contribution shall be generous. In years of hardship—whether from drought, plague, war, or other calamity—the contribution may be reduced as necessity demands, without breach of this arrangement.

Section 3. No fixed sum is inscribed as obligation. The commitment is to the principle of shared resources and common cause, not to a number that circumstances may render impossible.

Section 4. In the initial years of the Apokatastasis, when investment is most urgently needed, the Defensor anticipates contributions exceeding fifty thousand florins annually. This reflects present intention, not binding obligation.

ARTICLE V: ACCOUNTING AND TRANSPARENCY

Section 1. Full and accurate accounts shall be maintained of all contributions to and expenditures from the Fund of the Apokatastasis. Both Byzantine and Castilian officials shall have access to these records.

Section 2. The Imperial Secretary, or such officer as the Emperor shall designate, shall maintain the Byzantine accounts. The Defensor shall designate a Castilian officer to maintain parallel records.

Section 3. Accounts shall be reconciled quarterly, with discrepancies investigated and resolved. Neither party shall have cause to question the honesty of the administration.

Section 4. Annual summaries shall be prepared showing: total revenues collected, total contributions from Castile, total expenditures by category, and remaining balance in the Fund.

ARTICLE VI: MILITARY COMMITMENTS

Section 1. The Kingdom of Castile commits one thousand members of the Military Orders to the service of the Apokatastasis. These forces, together with their associated men-at-arms and support, shall serve the defense and restoration of the Empire.

Section 2. This commitment of Military Order forces binds not only King Juan II but his successors. Should the Defensor fall, his heir—or regent acting for a minor heir—inherits both the title's authority and its obligations.

Section 3. The wages, equipment, and maintenance of Castilian forces serving the Apokatastasis shall be drawn from the Fund of the Apokatastasis, not from Byzantine Reserved Expenditures.

ARTICLE VII: SUCCESSION AND CONTINUITY

Section 1. Should King Juan II fall while serving as Defensor Romaniae, and should his heir Prince Fernando be a minor, King Alfonso V of Aragon is hereby recognized as Regent of Castile with full authority to maintain this arrangement.

Section 2. All obligations established by this Charter pass to the Defensor's successors. The commitment to the Apokatastasis survives the death of any individual, continuing until the restoration is achieved or the arrangement is lawfully terminated.

Section 3. Should circumstances require, the Emperor and the Defensor—or their lawful successors—may by mutual agreement modify these terms, name a new Defensor, or establish alternative arrangements for continuing the Apokatastasis.

Section 4. The Apokatastasis is the goal; this Charter is the means. If the means must change to preserve the goal, both parties commit to good-faith negotiation of new arrangements.

ARTICLE VIII: SOVEREIGNTY PRESERVED

Section 1. This Charter establishes partnership, not subjugation. The Roman Empire retains its sovereignty, its ancient rights, and its dignity undiminished.

Section 2. The Emperor remains Emperor. His authority in civil matters, in appointments, in justice, in all things not pertaining to military defense, continues unimpaired.

Section 3. The Defensor serves the Empire; he does not rule it. His authority extends to defense and restoration, not to governance. When the Apokatastasis is achieved, the relationship shall be renegotiated to reflect new circumstances.

Section 4. Let it be recorded that this arrangement exists because it was offered generously and accepted freely—not extracted by force or demanded under duress. Constantinople chose this partnership; it was not imposed upon her.

ARTICLE IX: DURATION AND TERMINATION

Section 1. This Charter remains in force for so long as the title of Defensor Romaniae is held by King Juan II or his lawful successors, and the Apokatastasis remains incomplete.

Section 2. The Charter may be terminated by mutual agreement of both parties, with provisions made for the orderly separation of the treasuries and the settlement of any outstanding obligations.

Section 3. Should the Apokatastasis be achieved—should the Roman Empire be restored to strength sufficient to defend itself without external aid—this Charter may be renegotiated or dissolved as circumstances warrant.

Section 4. Neither party may unilaterally terminate this arrangement while the threat to Constantinople persists and the other party continues to fulfill its obligations in good faith.

WITNESS AND SEAL

Given under our hands and seals at Constantinople, in the presence of the assembled council, on the twelfth day of May in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-four.

IOANNES VIII PALAIOLOGOS
Imperator et Autocrator RhomaiÅn

JUAN II OF CASTILE
Rex Castellae et Legionis, Defensor Romaniae

WITNESSES:

Georgios Sphrantzes, Imperial Secretary

The Doukas Patriarch, speaking for House Doukas

Lord Bryennios, speaking for House Bryennios

Raoul the Elder, Captain of the Tagmata

Kantakouzenos, Strategos of the Walls

Inscribed and sealed in the presence of the above witnesses. Let none alter or diminish these terms without lawful authority.

FIAT. FIAT. FIAT.

laws.title: Constitution of Contributions and Claims
laws.summary: Establishes a merit-based system for granting territorial claims in reconquered lands, where military service, financial contributions, and administrative capability determine land allocation, with a formal tribunal to adjudicate competing claims and ensure that all territorial grants are contingent on actual reconquest.
laws.full_text:
CONSTITUTIO DE CONTRIBUTIONIBUS ET CLAIMIS

The Constitution of Contributions and Claims

Proclaimed by Juan II of Castile, Defensor Romaniae,

with the consent of John VIII Palaiologos, Emperor of the Romans

Constantinople, May 1434

PREAMBLE

The restoration of the Roman Empire requires the contribution of all who
would share in its renewal. Ancient claims carry weight, for they
represent the blood and sacrifice of ancestors. But parchment alone
rebuilds no walls, mans no battlements, sails no ships. Therefore, we
establish this system whereby claims to lands, titles, and offices shall
be measured by contribution---the men, arms, ships, and personal valor
committed to the cause of Christendom and the Empire.

No claim shall be granted by inheritance of theft. The disaster of 1204
was born of greed and treachery; titles granted by the Latin usurpers
hold no weight in this court. All claimants---Greek and Latin
alike---shall be judged by what they give, not merely what their
ancestors once took.

PART I: THE CONTRIBUTION FORMULA

Article 1. Base Calculation

A claimant's Contribution Strength shall be calculated thus:

Contribution Strength = (Weighted Troop Value × Claim Multiplier) +
Personal Service Bonus

Article 2. Claim Multiplier

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Claim Type                                        Multiplier
  ----------------------------------------------------- -----------------
  Ancient/legitimate claim (documented, predating 1204  ×3
  or granted by legitimate Roman Emperor)               

  No ancient claim, or claim derived from Latin Empire  ×1
  grants (1204-1261)                                    
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Article 3. Personal Service Bonus

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Condition                                         Bonus
  ----------------------------------------------------- -----------------
  Noble claimant fights personally in the campaign      +20

  Noble claimant does not fight personally              +0
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Note: "Fights personally" means present in the field for the
campaigning season, bearing arms, subject to the same dangers as his
men. Attendance at a single muster or brief ceremonial appearance does
not qualify.

PART II: TROOP VALUES

Article 4. Land Forces

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Troop Type     Minimum Equipment Standard        Value
  ------------------ ------------------------------------- --------------
  Infantry           Spear, shield, helmet, padded jack or ×1
                     better                                

  Light Cavalry      Horse, lance or javelin, sword,       ×3
                     helmet, leather or mail armor         

  Heavy Cavalry /    Warhorse, lance, sword, full mail or  ×5
  Knight             plate, shield, helmet with visor      
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Men who do not meet the minimum equipment standard shall not be counted.

Article 5. Naval Forces

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Vessel Type       Requirements                    Value
  --------------------- ----------------------------------- --------------
  War Galley            Fully crewed (150-200 men), armed   100
                        marines (20+), combat ready         

  Transport Galley      Crew present, fewer than 20 marines 40

  Armed Merchant        Armed crew, defensible              30
  (Cog/Carrack)                                             

  Small Coastal Vessel  Armed, seaworthy                    10
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Vessels must be presented at muster in seaworthy condition with crew
present. Hulls rotting in harbor do not count.

PART III: THE ANNUAL MUSTER

Article 6. Timing and Recording

A muster shall be called annually at a time and place determined by the
Emperor or the Defensor Romaniae. All claimants must present their
forces for inspection. Men and vessels are counted before the year's
campaigning begins. The muster roll constitutes the official record of
contribution for that year. Cumulative contribution across multiple
years determines total claim strength.

Article 7. Service Obligation

All men counted at muster are bound to serve for the full campaigning
year. Desertion after muster is punishable by death. Early departure
requires formal written permission from the Emperor, the Defensor, or
their designated commanders. Failure to obtain permission shall be
treated as desertion.

Article 8. Casualties

A house's contribution is fixed at its muster count for that year.
Losses suffered in battle do not reduce recorded contribution. Sacrifice
is honored, not punished. A house that loses all its men in faithful
service retains full credit for that year's contribution.

PART IV: FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTIONS

Article 9. Gold Alone Counts for Nothing

No claim shall be strengthened by gold, silver, or treasure alone.
Financial contribution is recognized only when converted to fighting men
or ships. A lord who hires mercenaries and presents them at muster
receives full credit for those men. The Tribunal does not distinguish
between household troops, feudal levies, or hired swords---only that
they fight.

Article 10. Prohibition of Fraud

Men presented at muster must serve the full campaign. "Muster and
vanish" fraud---presenting men who immediately depart---shall result
in: forfeiture of all contribution credit for that year; forfeiture of
any claim before the Tribunal; and possible criminal prosecution for
fraud against the crown.

PART V: APPLICATION OF CLAIMS

Article 11. Competing Claims

When multiple claimants seek the same title or territory: First,
calculate each claimant's Contribution Strength per the formula above.
Second, the claimant with the higher total receives preference. Third,
in cases of near-equal contribution, the Tribunal may consider duration
of service, quality and conduct of service, and strategic value of the
claimant's continued loyalty.

Article 12. Minimum Thresholds

The Tribunal shall establish minimum contribution thresholds for titles
of varying dignity:

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Title                                         Minimum
                                                    Contribution
                                                    Strength
  ------------------------------------------------- ---------------------
  Minor estate / village lordship                   25

  Prokathemenos (district administrator)            50

  Kephale (provincial governor)                     100

  Doux (Duke / military governor)                   200

  Megas Doux or equivalent                          400
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

These thresholds are guidelines. The Emperor and Defensor may adjust
based on strategic necessity.

Article 13. Patience Required

Claims to territories currently under Ottoman control cannot be granted
until those territories are reconquered. Claimants earn contribution
credit now; they receive their titles when Christian arms have liberated
the land.

PART VI: SPECIAL PROVISIONS

Article 14. Rejection of 1204 Claims

All titles, grants, and claims originating from the Latin Empire
(1204-1261) are hereby declared void. The Latin conquest was
illegitimate; its grants carry no legal weight. Latin claimants are
welcome to earn titles through the contribution system on equal terms
with all others. Their ancestors' crimes are not held against
them---but neither do they benefit from stolen goods.

Article 15. Desperate Cases

The Emperor and the Defensor Romaniae reserve authority to grant special
dispensation to: widows and orphans of men who died in service before
this system existed; aged or infirm persons who cannot fight but have
demonstrated loyalty; religious institutions that serve the common good;
and any case where strict application of the formula would produce
manifest injustice. Such grants shall be examined individually and
recorded separately from the normal claims process.

Article 16. The Notaras Precedent

Let it be recorded that the properties of the traitor Loukas Notaras,
convicted of proditio against the Empire, have been forfeit to the
imperial treasury. Treason voids all claims. Those who treat with the
enemy while claiming loyalty to the Empire shall lose everything.

PART VII: ADMINISTRATION

Article 17. The Tribunal

The Tribunal Latinorum et Graecorum shall administer this system,
maintaining: the register of ancient claims; the annual muster rolls;
the cumulative contribution records; and the queue of pending claims
awaiting reconquest.

Article 18. Appeals

Decisions of the Tribunal may be appealed to the Emperor or, in matters
concerning Latin claimants, jointly to the Emperor and the Defensor
Romaniae.

Article 19. Amendments

This Constitution may be amended only by joint decree of the Emperor and
the Defensor Romaniae, or their lawful successors.

EXAMPLES OF APPLICATION

Example 1: Established House with Ancient Claim

House Bryennios claims ancestral estates near Adrianople. Ancient claim:
Yes (×3 multiplier). Men contributed: 40 infantry. Lord Bryennios fights
personally: Yes (+20). Calculation: (40 × 1 × 3) + 20 = 140

Example 2: Wealthy House, Minimal Contribution

House Doukas claims vast estates in Macedonia. Ancient claim: Yes (×3
multiplier). Men contributed: 11 infantry. Patriarch does not fight
personally: No (+0). Calculation: (11 × 1 × 3) + 0 = 33

House Bryennios outranks House Doukas despite Doukas's greater paper
claims.

Example 3: Latin Knight, No Ancient Claim

Don Pedro de Rocafort claims Catalan Company holdings in Thessaly.
Ancient claim: No---derived from conquest (×1 multiplier). Men
contributed: 15 infantry. Fights personally: Yes (+20). Calculation: (15
× 1 × 1) + 20 = 35

Don Pedro outranks House Doukas.

Example 4: Naval Contribution

A maritime house contributes one war galley and 20 light cavalry. War
galley: 100 (infantry equivalent). Light cavalry: 20 × 3 = 60. Total
weighted value: 160. If ancient claim (×3): 480. If no ancient claim
(×1): 160.

Proclaimed under our hands and seals in the City of Constantinople,

in the year of Our Lord 1434.

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

Juan II of Castile, Defensor Romaniae

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

John VIII Palaiologos, Emperor of the Romans

laws.title: Letter to Sultan Murad II
laws.summary: Formal diplomatic communication from Juan II to Sultan Murad II proposing terms for coexistence, asserting Castilian-Byzantine defensive interests while acknowledging Ottoman power, and establishing the basis for future diplomatic relations between the Christian coalition and the Ottoman Empire.
laws.full_text:
Letter to Sultan Murad II

Constantinople, May 1434

سلام أيها السلطان!

Salaam, Sultan!

عظيمة هي عجائب الدنيا، وعظيم جلاله إذ ينظر إلينا من عليائه، هو الذي يحكم
كل شيء. وإذ أكدح كل يوم ساعياً إلى مشيئته، أجد الإلهام في أعماله العظيمة
وفيما بناه الذين سبقونا من صروح عظيمة تكريماً له. ما أعظم أن يجد كل من
يعبد اسمه مثل هذه الصروح ليسبّحه فيها.

Great are the wonders of the world and great is His majesty as He who
rules over all looks down on us. As I toil daily to seek His will, I
find inspiration in His great works and how those before me have built
great monuments in His honour. How great it is that all who worship His
name have such monuments available to praise Him.

بصفتي ملكاً لاتينياً، كثيراً ما أُذكَّر بما يفرّق بيننا. بما يجعلنا مختلفين.
وحين نرى ما هو مختلف لا نفهمه. ومن اليسير أن نكره ما لا نفهم. لكن الفهم
هو ما أنشده.

As a Latin king, I am often reminded of what divides us. What makes us
different. And when we see that which is different we do not understand
it. And it is easy to hate something we do not understand. But
understanding is what I seek.

أحقٌّ أن المسلمين يبجّلون عيسى نبياً؟ أثمة أوجه تشابه بين رؤيتنا لماهية الله
ورؤيتكم؟ أإبراهيم أيضاً من مؤسسي الإسلام؟ سبق أن طرحت هذه الأسئلة، لكنني
تعلمت أن الطريقة التي يجيب بها المرء تكشف الكثير عنه. وأظن أنها ستكشف
للآخر شيئاً عني أيضاً.

Is it true that Muslims worship Jesus as a prophet? Are there
similarities in our vision of what God is and yours? Is Abraham also a
founder of Islam? I have asked these questions before but I have learned
that how men answer these questions tells me a lot about them. As it
will, I suspect, tell the other something about me.

لقد دخلت مؤخراً في اتفاق مع الإمبراطورية البيزنطية بشأن التجارة والأمن.
ليس سراً أن خزينتها خاوية، وأنه بمساعدتي سيُدفع الجزية دون عناء.

I have recently entered into an agreement with the Byzantine Empire
regarding trade and security. It is no secret that their treasury is
empty and that with my help the tribute obligation shall be paid without
trouble.

آمل أن ألقاك حين أحمل الجزية. لقاء شخصي على أرض محايدة من اختيارك يؤكدها
إقراري. إن جلال منصبينا يقتضي ألا يسلّم أيٌّ منا نفسه في عهدة الآخر. أرجو
أن تتفهم هذا ولا أقصد إساءة بالإشارة إليه. أنتظر ردك.

I hope that I can meet you when I deliver the tribute. A meeting in
person on neutral grounds of your choosing to be confirmed by me. The
majesty of both our positions demands that neither surrenders himself
into the custody of the other. I hope you understand this and I mean no
offence pointing this out. I await your response.

حتى نلتقي،

Until we meet,

يوحنا ملك قشتالة

Ioannes of Castile

laws.title: Royal Economic Development Plan of 1434
laws.summary: Comprehensive investment program of 27,750 florins initial outlay plus 40,000 florins annually in infrastructure, targeting leather production in Cordoba, wool processing, shipbuilding, agricultural expansion in Granada, and trade route development across Castile's major industries.
laws.full_text:
ROYAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PLAN
Approved by King Juan II of Castile
Late Summer/Autumn 1434 — Toledo

OVERVIEW

This document records the economic investments and development initiatives approved by King Juan II following council sessions with representatives of Castile's major industries. The plan aims to increase production, capture greater value from raw materials, expand trade networks, and build the infrastructure necessary for sustained economic growth.

Total Initial Investment: Approximately 27,750 florins
Annual Ongoing Costs: Approximately 5,600-6,100 florins
Infrastructure Program: 40,000 florins annually for 5 years (200,000 total)

PART I: LEATHER INDUSTRY (CÓRDOBA)

Representatives: Rodrigo de Montilla, Master of the Gremio de Curtidores

Initiatives Approved

1. Sumac Cultivation
   - Begin deliberate cultivation of sumac for tanning
   - Establish plantations in areas where it currently grows wild
   - Timeline: 3-5 years to secure reliable supply

2. Hide Production Expansion
   - Increase goat herds with adequate grazing rights
   - Coordinate with goatherds (see Part V)
   - Excess meat to be preserved as sausages and dried meats for military supply

3. Workforce Expansion
   - Tie apprenticeship numbers to hide processing capacity
   - Expand hiring as production increases

4. New Production Facility
   - Construct tannery facility outside Córdoba city
   - Crown to invest in road infrastructure for accessibility
   - Removes stench from city while allowing expansion

5. Guadamecí Workshop Expansion
   - Establish finishing workshops (painted/gilded leather panels) in other cities
   - Toledo, Seville, and other locations to be determined
   - Separates artistic work from tanning to increase high-value production

6. Trade Protection
   - Adoption of lex mercatoria across all royal kingdoms
   - Protection for Castilian goods in foreign markets

Investment

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| Initial funding (2 years) | 3,000 |
| Infrastructure (included in general program) | — |
| TOTAL | 3,000 |

PART II: SALT AND FISHING INDUSTRY (SEVILLE)

Representatives: Gonzalo Pérez de Medina (Cofradía de Mareantes y Salineros), Alonso de Marchena (Factor)

Initiatives Approved

1. Ocean-Going Fishing Fleet
   - 8 smaller vessels (40-50 tons): ~1,800 florins
   - 2 larger vessels (80-100 tons): ~850 florins
   - Fully equipped for Atlantic fishing

2. Fleet Ownership Model
   - Ships leased to experienced fishermen through the Cofradía
   - Lease payments of 15-20 florins/year (smaller) or 30-40 florins/year (larger)
   - After 20 years of lease payments and self-funded maintenance, ownership transfers to fishermen

3. Royal Shipyard (Future)
   - To be discussed with incoming Admiral from Aragón
   - Estimated cost: 8,000-10,000 florins to establish
   - Capacity: 10-15 ships per year once operational
   - Location: Seville (river access, timber, iron nearby)

4. Exploration
   - Use new vessels to explore Atlantic fishing opportunities
   - Assess waters between Castile and Canary Islands
   - Investigate African coastal waters

5. Salt Production
   - No major investment in new salinas at this time
   - Await results of exploration for alternative salt sources

Investment

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| 8 smaller fishing vessels | 1,800 |
| 2 larger fishing vessels | 850 |
| Equipment and outfitting | 50 |
| TOTAL | 2,700 |

Future Investment (Pending Admiral's Arrival)

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| Royal Shipyard establishment | 8,000-10,000 |

PART III: SILK INDUSTRY (GRANADA)

Representatives: Hernán de Úbeda (Merchant), Yusef al-Rashid (Master Craftsman)

Current State

- Industry at approximately 75-85% of pre-war capacity
- Most craftsmen remained; production resuming
- Producing ~300 bolts worth of thread annually
- Current weaving capacity: ~180-200 bolts
- One-third of thread sold raw to Genoese middlemen

Initiatives Approved

1. Shift from Thread to Cloth Production
   - Goal: Weave all thread into cloth within Castile
   - Capture 3-5x value currently lost to Italian weavers

2. Loom Expansion
   - 50 additional silk looms required
   - Recruit wool/linen weavers for retraining
   - Master silk weavers to supervise trainees (1 master per 4-5 trainees)

3. Dye Workshop Expansion
   - Expand capacity of existing dyers
   - New vats, mordants, dye supplies

4. Direct Market Access
   - Sell directly to Italian and Castilian buyers
   - Eliminate Genoese middlemen
   - Leverage alliances with Aragón and Naples

5. Finished Garments (Future)
   - Deferred for now
   - Expertise exists for future manufactory
   - Revisit in 3-5 years once cloth production stabilized

Investment

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| 50 silk looms | 2,250 |
| Training wages (2 years) | 500 |
| Dye workshop expansion | 500 |
| INITIAL TOTAL | 3,250 |

| Ongoing Costs | Amount (Florins/Year) |
|---------------|----------------------|
| Master weaver supervision | 300-400 |

Timeline

- Year 1-2: Training period, gradual production increase
- Year 3: Full capacity reached, all thread woven into cloth
- Investment recovery: Within 2 years of full operation

PART IV: WOOL INDUSTRY (MESTA)

Representative: Don Alonso de Aguilar

Initiatives Approved

1. Infrastructure Improvements
   - Repair/replace bridges along cañadas reales
   - Expand watering points along drove roads
   - New wells where needed

2. Granada Expansion
   - Lowlands and river valleys reserved for sheep grazing
   - Assessment of pasture potential to be conducted
   - New routes into Granada to be developed

3. Coordination with Infrastructure Program
   - Mesta to provide detailed assessment within one month
   - Specific bridges, watering points, and routes to be identified
   - Integration with Diego de Daza's five-year plan

Investment

Included in general infrastructure program (see Part VI)

PART V: GOAT HERDING INDUSTRY

Representative: Martín Sánchez de Priego

Initiatives Approved

1. Legal Recognition
   - Royal charter granting goatherds formal standing
   - Legal protection in disputes over grazing rights
   - Equal treatment with Mesta in matters of law

2. Market Organization
   - Assistance in organizing for wider market access
   - Connection to Córdoba tanners for hide sales
   - Meat supply for military provisions

3. Granada Grazing Rights
   - Mountain territories (Sierra Nevada, Alpujarras) reserved for goats
   - Terrain division: mountains for goats, lowlands for sheep
   - Access to lands unsuitable for sheep grazing

4. Infrastructure Support
   - Martín to walk routes with royal surveyors
   - Identify water needs, path requirements
   - Integration with five-year infrastructure plan

Investment

Included in general infrastructure program (see Part VI)

PART VI: INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM

Administrator: Diego de Daza

Budget

| Period | Annual Amount | Total |
|--------|--------------|-------|
| 1434-1439 (5 years) | 40,000 florins | 200,000 florins |

Allocation

| Category | Annual Amount | Purpose |
|----------|--------------|---------|
| Herding Infrastructure | 12,000-15,000 | Drove roads, watering points, Granada routes |
| General Commerce | 25,000-28,000 | Ports, urban roads, bridges, facilities |

Priority Projects

1. Herding Infrastructure
   - Cañada real bridge repairs
   - Watering point expansion (wells, river access)
   - Mountain passes into Granada
   - New drove roads to Granada lowlands and highlands

2. Industrial Facilities
   - Road to new Córdoba tannery facility
   - Port improvements for fishing fleet

3. General Commerce
   - Major trade route improvements
   - Urban market access
   - Bridge replacements on key routes

Process

- Mesta to submit detailed assessment (1 month)
- Goatherds to guide surveyors through hill country
- Diego to integrate all needs into systematic plan
- Independent oversight, milestone payments, fraud penalties

PART VII: INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY

Spymaster: Isaac de Baeza (Position Secret)

Network Establishment

1. Venice Station
   - Permanent Castilian trade representative
   - Monitor East-West information flow
   - Cultivate Greek exile contacts
   - Annual cost: 800 florins

2. Rome Station
   - Minor cleric attached to Castilian delegation
   - Monitor papal curia politics
   - Track French faction activities
   - Annual cost: 500 florins

3. Naples Station
   - Secretary in Aragonese administration
   - Monitor Italian politics
   - Annual cost: 600 florins

4. Domestic Network
   - 12 observers in major ports (Seville, Barcelona, Bilbao, Valencia)
   - Monitor foreign ships, merchants, ambassadors
   - Annual cost: 2,000 florins

5. Communications
   - Trusted courier system
   - Memorized reports (nothing written)
   - Annual cost: 500 florins

Investment

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| Initial establishment (Year 1) | 6,000 |
| Personal grant to Isaac | 500 |
| INITIAL TOTAL | 6,500 |

| Ongoing Costs | Amount (Florins/Year) |
|---------------|----------------------|
| Network maintenance | 4,400 |

Principles

- Observation and intelligence gathering only
- No actions that would shame the crown if exposed
- Honorable methods; no assassination or blackmail
- Focus: Ottoman military movements, French diplomatic maneuvering

PART VIII: SHADOW PERSONNEL

Positions Established

1. Court Physician (Cover Position)
   - Name: Tomás de Cuenca
   - Background: Trained at Salamanca, former service to Bishop of Sigüenza
   - Skills: Knowledge of poisons and antidotes; can protect food, train tasters
   - Limitation: Not a master; competent but not expert in subtle arts
   - Status: Employed as regular healer; true purpose secret

2. Shadow Guardian
   - Name: Demetrios Komnenos
   - Background: Former Byzantine Hetaireia (imperial bodyguard), 12 years service
   - Skills: Exceptional threat detection, defensive thinking, personal protection
   - Limitation: Carries trauma from Despot Theodore's death; drinks at night
   - Status: En route from Venice; to be assigned to Queen Lucia and children
   - Approach: Requires patience and purpose; assignment to protect innocents may restore him

Investment

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| Ongoing salaries and expenses | To be determined |

PART IX: RELIGIOUS INITIATIVES

Lead: Fray Tomás de Torquemada, Prior of Santa Cruz (Segovia)

Inquisition Preparation

1. Facilities
   - Secure buildings in Granada near cathedral
   - Cells for accused, chambers for questioning
   - Public space for auto-da-fé

2. Personnel
   - 8 Dominican brothers assigned
   - Training of familiares from Christian settlers
   - Preparation of procedures and documents

3. Timeline
   - Preparation during 1434-1435
   - Papal approval expected within one year
   - Period of grace to follow approval

4. Funding Model
   - Crown bears all costs of operation
   - All seized properties revert to crown, not Holy Office
   - Removes financial incentive from inquisitorial work

Investment

| Item | Amount (Florins) |
|------|-----------------|
| Initial preparation funding | 5,000 |
| Ongoing costs | To be borne by crown |

FINANCIAL SUMMARY

Initial Investments (1434)

| Category | Amount (Florins) |
|----------|-----------------|
| Leather Industry (Córdoba) | 3,000 |
| Fishing Fleet (Seville) | 2,700 |
| Silk Industry (Granada) | 3,250 |
| Intelligence Network | 6,500 |
| Inquisition Preparation | 5,000 |
| TOTAL INITIAL | 20,450 |

Annual Ongoing Costs

| Category | Amount (Florins/Year) |
|----------|----------------------|
| Infrastructure Program | 40,000 |
| Intelligence Network | 4,400 |
| Silk Industry (supervision) | 300-400 |
| TOTAL ANNUAL | ~44,700-44,800 |

Future Investments (Pending)

| Category | Amount (Florins) |
|----------|-----------------|
| Royal Shipyard | 8,000-10,000 |

EXPECTED OUTCOMES

Short-Term (1-2 Years)

- Fishing fleet operational; Atlantic fishing begins
- Silk cloth production increasing; thread exports declining
- Leather production expanding as hide supply grows
- Intelligence network established; information flowing
- Inquisition prepared; awaiting papal mandate

Medium-Term (3-5 Years)

- All Granada silk woven into cloth domestically
- Sumac plantations producing; tanning supply secured
- Goat and sheep herds significantly expanded
- Infrastructure improvements completed
- Royal shipyard operational (if approved)
- Fishing fleet expanded to dozens of vessels

Long-Term (5-10 Years)

- Castile a major Mediterranean trading power
- Domestic manufacturing capturing value from raw materials
- Atlantic fishing and exploration yielding new opportunities
- Revenue significantly increased across all sectors

ADMINISTRATIVE NOTES

- Diego de Daza to oversee implementation of all economic initiatives
- Regular reporting to crown on progress and obstacles
- Coordination between industries (hides/leather, salt/fish, wool/goats)
- Admiral (pending arrival from Aragón) to oversee naval/shipyard development

Approved by Royal Authority
Juan II of Castile
Toledo, Autumn 1434

This document to be updated as initiatives progress and new investments are approved.

laws.title: Chrysobull of United Treasury (Amended)
laws.summary: Amended version of the Joint Treasury charter, revising the revenue-sharing formula between the Castilian and Byzantine crowns, adjusting contribution requirements based on actual territorial revenues, and strengthening audit provisions following the first year of joint financial operations.
laws.full_text:
☧ ☧ ☧

CHRYSOBULL OF THE UNITED TREASURY

Chrysobulla Aerarii Uniti

Given at Constantinople, in the Month of March, in the Year of Our Lord
1435

IN THE NAME OF THE FATHER, AND OF THE SON, AND OF THE HOLY SPIRIT.
We, John VIII Palaiologos, by the Grace of God Emperor and Autocrat of
the Romans, and Juan II, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León,
Defensor Romaniae, being of one mind in the defense of Christendom and
the preservation of the Sacred City of Constantinople, do hereby
establish and proclaim this Chrysobull for the governance of all
revenues pertaining to the defense and restoration of the Roman Empire.

Whereas the treasury of the Empire has been diminished by the trials of
past generations, and whereas the Defensor Romaniae has undertaken to
provide such funds as are necessary for the defense, restoration, and
prosperity of Constantinople and its territories, it is fitting and
proper that these arrangements be formalized in perpetuity, that there
be no confusion in administration, and that the sacred dignity of the
Imperial office be preserved inviolate.

Article I --- Declaration of Union

All revenues of the Roman Empire, howsoever derived---whether from
taxation, customs, trade, imperial estates, or any other
source---together with all revenues which the Defensor Romaniae shall
provide for the defense and restoration of the Empire's Eastern
territories, shall henceforth flow into a single Joint Treasury, to be
known as the Aerarium Unitum. No distinction shall be made between
revenues of Roman or Castilian origin. All funds shall be held and
administered as one.

Article II --- Administration

The Defensor Romaniae, or such Sakellarios as he shall designate, shall
administer the Joint Treasury with full authority to collect, disburse,
invest, and manage all funds therein for the defense, restoration, and
prosperity of the Empire and its territories.

Provided, however, that for any single expenditure exceeding five
thousand florins, or for any ongoing commitment exceeding five thousand
florins annually, the Emperor shall be consulted prior to such
expenditure being authorized. This consultation shall be genuine and
substantive, though the final authority to approve or deny such
expenditures shall rest with the Defensor. The Emperor's counsel shall
be sought and considered in good faith.

Provided further, that before any Sakellarios is appointed to
administer the Joint Treasury, the Emperor shall be consulted regarding
such appointment. The Sakellarios, whosoever he may be, shall have
assigned to him at least one deputy of Greek birth and Orthodox faith,
such deputy to be nominated by the Emperor, who shall serve to advise
the Sakellarios on matters of custom, precedent, and local practice, and
to ensure that the administration of the Treasury proceeds with full
knowledge of the traditions and expectations of the Roman people.

Article III --- Imperial Stipend

The Emperor shall receive from the Joint Treasury an annual stipend of
twenty-two thousand florins, payable in quarterly installments of five
thousand five hundred florins each, on the first day of January, April,
July, and October. This stipend is guaranteed in perpetuity and shall
not be reduced, delayed, or encumbered without the mutual written
consent of both the Emperor and the Defensor. This stipend shall be the
first obligation of the Treasury, taking precedence over all other
disbursements save only the immediate defense of Constantinople against
active military assault.

Article IV --- Imperial Dignity

Nothing in this Chrysobull shall be construed to diminish, reduce, or
impair the sacred dignity of the Imperial office. The Emperor remains
Emperor and Autocrat of the Romans, Basileus kai Autokrator ton
Romaion, with all titles, honors, precedences, and ceremonies
pertaining thereto. The Defensor serves the Empire; he does not supplant
it. All public acts shall honor the Emperor's supreme dignity, and the
Emperor shall preside over all ceremonies of state as is fitting for the
heir of Constantine and Justinian.

Article V --- Guardianship and Succession

This Chrysobull shall bind all successors to both the Imperial throne
and the office of Defensor Romaniae, continuing in force until such time
as both parties mutually agree to amend or dissolve these arrangements.

In the event that the Imperial line of Palaiologos should fail
entirely, with no legitimate male heir of the blood surviving to assume
the Imperial dignity, the Defensor Romaniae shall assume guardianship
over all obligations, institutions, and dignities of the Empire. The
Defensor shall preserve, protect, and administer all that pertains to
the Roman state, holding it in trust for Christendom.

Provided, however, that any assumption of the Imperial dignity
itself---the sacred title of Emperor and Autocrat of the Romans, the
wearing of the purple, and the receiving of Imperial acclamation---shall
require:

> First, the confirmation and blessing of the Patriarch of
> Constantinople, who shall attest that such assumption is proper,
> lawful, and pleasing to God;
>
> Second, the acclamation of such nobility, military commanders, and
> representatives of the people as remain to speak for the Roman nation.

Until such confirmation and acclamation are obtained, the Defensor shall
rule as Guardian and Protector, not as Emperor, preserving the forms and
institutions of the Empire against the day when a worthy successor may
be acclaimed according to the ancient customs of the Roman people.

Article VI --- Ratification

This Chrysobull shall take effect upon the affixing of both the Imperial
seal of the Palaiologoi and the royal seal of Castile and León. Two
copies shall be made: one to be kept in the Imperial archives at
Constantinople, one to be kept in the royal archives at Toledo. Both
copies shall have equal force and authority.

Datum et actum Constantinopoli, mense Martio, Anno Domini MCDXXXV.

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

IOANNES VIII PALAIOLOGOS

Basileus kai Autokrator ton Romaion

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

JUAN II OF CASTILE AND LEÓN

Defensor Romaniae

Witnesses

Demetrios Kantakouzenos, Strategos of the Walls of Constantinople

Don Juan de Sotomayor, Master of the Order of Alcántara

Georgios Sphrantzes, Megas Doux of the Roman Fleet

Alexios Philanthropenos, Commander of the Gate of Charisius

☧ ☧ ☧

In Nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti. Amen.

laws.title: Royal Naval Development Plan
laws.summary: Strategic plan for building Castile's naval capacity, establishing shipyards at Seville and Santander, training programs for crews, acquisition schedules for warships and transports, and the logistical framework for projecting military power across the Mediterranean.
laws.full_text:
ROYAL NAVAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN

Prepared by Don Berenguer de Vilaragut, Admiral of Castile

With Rodrigo de Salamanca, Crown Administrator

April 1435 --- Toledo

PART I: CASTILE'S NAVAL OBJECTIVES

Primary Objectives

1. Strategic Transport to Constantinople

Move 3,000-5,000 settlers annually with families, livestock, tools,
grain. Two voyages per sailing season. Journey: 6 weeks each way with
favorable conditions.

2. Military Projection

Capacity to transport 10,000-15,000 soldiers to the Eastern
Mediterranean. Deliver heavy equipment, horses, siege materials. Provide
fire support with shipboard artillery.

3. Atlantic Fishing & Exploration

Support Sevillian fishing industry expansion. Vessels capable of
Atlantic waters and African coastal exploration. Dual-use: fishing in
peace, transport in war.

4. Coastal Defense & Patrol

Counter Barbary pirates in the Strait of Gibraltar. Protect merchant
shipping. Secure approaches to Seville and Cádiz.

PART II: APPROVED MEASURES

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Action                                      Cost (Florins)
  ----------------------------------------------- -----------------------
  La Cartuja shipyard construction                16,000

  Aggressive workforce recruitment                10,000

  Atarazanas claim settlement & repairs           14,000

  Purchase of existing vessels                    18,000

  First year Basque contracts                     5,500

  First year operating costs                      5,000

  TOTAL YEAR ONE                                  68,500
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

PART III: IMMEDIATE VESSEL PURCHASES

  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Vessel Type       Number   Unit       Total   Source
                                     Cost                   
  --------------------- ------------ ------------ ----------- ----------------
  Used carracks         5            2,200        11,000      Genoa, Portugal
  (150-250 tons)                                              

  Used naos (80-120     6            700          4,200       Portugal, Aragon
  tons)                                                       

  Used galleys (40      4            700          2,800       Aragon (surplus)
  oars)                                                       

  TOTAL                 15                        18,000      
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Delivery: Summer-Autumn 1435

PART IV: SHIPYARD DEVELOPMENT

La Cartuja (New Construction)

Construction begins: Spring 1435

Operational: Autumn 1436 (18 months with aggressive recruitment)

Capacity: 6-8 vessels annually (double shifts)

Atarazanas (Repairs & Small Craft)

Claims settled: Summer 1435

Repairs complete: Spring 1436

Capacity: 4-6 smaller vessels annually, plus repair/refit services

Basque Yards (Contracted)

Ongoing: 7-10 vessels annually

Focus: Naos and fishing/utility vessels

Combined Annual Capacity (from 1437 onward): 17-24 vessels

PART V: ROYAL FLEET --- YEAR BY YEAR PROJECTION

Starting Position (Early 1435)

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Vessel Type                Number      Notes

Note: Costs increase as fleet grows. By 1440, annual naval expenditure
may reach 60,000-70,000 florins.

SUMMARY

By 1440, Castile will possess a fleet of over 140 vessels. The kingdom
will be able to move twenty thousand settlers annually to Constantinople
in comfort, or land twenty-four thousand soldiers in a single emergency
lift.

Combined with allied fleets---Aragon, Venice, the Military Orders,
perhaps Rhodes---Castile could project forty thousand men or more to the
Eastern Mediterranean.

Total investment over six years: 250,000-300,000 florins (including
vessel construction and operating costs).

This plan achieves a fleet built for Castile's purposes: transport,
projection, and the defense of Christendom in the East.

APPROVED BY ROYAL AUTHORITY

Juan II of Castile
