laws.title: Ottoman Truce Proposal
laws.summary: Formal proposal for a temporary truce with the Ottoman Empire to stabilize the eastern frontier, defining proposed boundaries, trade arrangements, prisoner exchanges, and conditions under which hostilities might resume, intended to buy time for military consolidation.
laws.full_text:
بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم

In the Name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

PROPOSAL OF TRUCE AND ACCOMMODATION

From the Sublime Porte of the Ottoman Sultanate

To His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León

Delivered by the Hand of Çandarlı Halil Pasha, Grand Vizier

The Month of Rajab, 838 AH / April 1435 AD

PREAMBLE

His Imperial Majesty Sultan Murad Han, Shadow of God upon Earth,
Commander of the Faithful, Sovereign of the House of Osman, has
considered with great deliberation the meeting at Tenedos and the words
spoken there between sovereign and sovereign.

The Sultan observed in the King of Castile a man of conviction and
honor---one who speaks plainly and does not dissemble, who demands much
but offers the courtesy of honest speech. Such men are rare among the
princes of the West, where promises are written in water and treaties
last only until convenience dictates otherwise.

The King of Castile declared that only the way of arms remains between
us. Perhaps this is so. Perhaps God has ordained that our peoples must
meet in blood until one prevails. Yet even the Prophet, peace be upon
him, made treaty with his enemies when wisdom counseled it, and broke no
oath he had sworn.

Therefore, before the sword is drawn and cannot be sheathed, the Sultan
offers this: a pause. Not surrender---never surrender. Not retreat---the
House of Osman does not retreat. But a truce of defined duration, in
which both parties may pursue their interests without the waste of war,
and in which the will of God may become clearer to those who seek it.

If the King of Castile finds merit in this proposal, let him send word.
If he does not, then let him come with his armies, and we shall meet as
he promised---before the face of God, with open visor.

ARTICLE I: DURATION AND SCOPE OF TRUCE

§1. Duration

This truce, if accepted, shall endure for a period of ten years from the
date of ratification, to be renewed by mutual agreement or to expire
without renewal, as the parties shall determine.

§2. Geographic Scope

The truce shall apply to all territories currently held by the Ottoman
Sultanate and to the city of Constantinople with its immediate environs,
as well as to the territories of Castile, León, and Granada. It shall
further apply to all waters of the Aegean Sea, the Sea of Marmara, and
the Straits of the Dardanelles and Bosphorus.

§3. Parties Bound

The Ottoman Sultanate shall be bound by this truce in all its actions.
The King of Castile shall be bound in his own name and in his capacity
as Defensor Romaniae, such that the forces under his command or
direction in the East shall observe its terms.

ARTICLE II: TERRITORIAL STATUS

§1. Recognition of Present Holdings

For the duration of this truce, both parties agree to recognize the
present territorial disposition without prejudice to future claims. The
Ottoman Sultanate retains all territories currently under its
administration. The Byzantine Empire, under the protection of the
Defensor Romaniae, retains Constantinople and such territories as it
presently holds.

§2. No Offensive Operations

Neither party shall conduct offensive military operations against the
territories of the other. This includes siege, assault, raid, naval
attack, or any other act of war. Defensive preparations within one's
own territory are not prohibited.

§3. Settlement and Fortification

The settlement of Latin Christians in Constantinople may continue,
provided such settlers do not bear arms against Ottoman territories. The
repair and maintenance of existing fortifications is permitted; the
construction of new fortifications beyond the existing walls of
Constantinople is not.

ARTICLE III: COMMERCE AND PASSAGE

§1. Freedom of the Straits

Merchant vessels of all nations allied to the King of Castile shall
enjoy free passage through the Dardanelles and Bosphorus, subject to
payment of customary tolls at rates no higher than those charged to
Venetian or Genoese merchants.

§2. Trade Relations

Merchants of Castile, and of such other Christian nations as the King of
Castile shall designate, may trade freely in Ottoman ports under the
same terms extended to other Christian merchants. Ottoman merchants may
likewise trade in the ports of Castile and its allies.

§3. War Vessels

Warships of either party may transit the Straits in numbers not
exceeding ten vessels at one passage, with prior notification to the
other party. Fleets exceeding this number shall be considered a hostile
act and void this truce.

ARTICLE IV: TREATMENT OF SUBJECTS

§1. Christian Subjects of the Sultan

Christian subjects dwelling in Ottoman territories shall continue to
practice their faith according to established custom. Churches presently
in use shall not be converted to other purposes. The Patriarch of
Constantinople in exile, should he wish to return, shall be permitted to
do so and to exercise his spiritual office among Orthodox Christians in
Ottoman lands.

§2. Muslim Subjects of the King

Muslim subjects dwelling in the territories of the King of Castile,
particularly in the former Emirate of Granada, shall be permitted to
practice their faith according to established custom, consistent with
the laws of Castile. Mosques presently in use shall not be converted to
other purposes without just compensation.

§3. Prisoner Exchange

All prisoners of war currently held by either party shall be released
within sixty days of ratification, without ransom. Future captures made
before word of the truce has spread shall likewise be released upon
identification.

ARTICLE V: DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS

§1. Ambassadors

Both parties agree to exchange permanent ambassadors who shall reside at
the court of the other sovereign. These ambassadors shall enjoy full
diplomatic immunity and the right to communicate freely with their home
courts.

§2. Resolution of Disputes

Disputes arising under this truce shall be referred first to the
resident ambassadors. If they cannot resolve the matter, it shall be
submitted to a joint tribunal of three judges---one appointed by each
party, and a third agreed upon by both.

§3. Notification of Termination

Should either party wish to terminate this truce before its natural
expiration, they shall provide one year's notice to the other party.
During this final year, all terms remain in force. No offensive
operations may commence until the notice period has expired.

ARTICLE VI: WHAT THIS TRUCE IS NOT

The Sultan wishes to speak plainly, as the King of Castile spoke plainly
at Tenedos.

This truce does not represent Ottoman recognition of Latin claims to
Byzantine territory. It does not represent abandonment of Ottoman
interests in Constantinople or the lands of Romania. It does not
represent Ottoman acceptance of the title 'Defensor Romaniae' as
conferring any legitimate authority.

This truce is a pause---nothing more. The Sultan's position remains as
stated at Tenedos: the House of Osman will not surrender what it has
won. When this truce expires, if no renewal is agreed, matters will
stand as they stood before---to be resolved by the will of God and the
strength of arms.

The King of Castile made clear his own position. He believes God has
chosen him to restore Christian lands. The Sultan does not expect this
truce to change that belief. He offers it because even those destined to
fight may benefit from time---time to prepare, time to consider, time to
determine whether God's will is truly as clear as both believe.

CLOSING

If these terms find favor with the King of Castile, he may signify his
acceptance by sending his sealed response to the Grand Vizier through
any channel he deems appropriate. The Sultan's ambassador will await
reply at Rhodes, where the Knights of the Hospital have agreed to serve
as neutral intermediaries.

If these terms do not find favor, then let the King of Castile know that
the Sultan received his words at Tenedos with the respect due to an
honest enemy. When they meet again---if God wills that they should
meet---it will be as the King proposed: before the face of God, with
honor observed on both sides.

والله ولي التوفيق

And God is the Guardian of Success.

Given under the Tughra of His Imperial Majesty

MURAD HAN

Sultan of the Ottoman Empire

Shadow of God upon Earth

Commander of the Faithful

Witnessed and delivered by:

ÇANDARLI HALİL PASHA

Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire

Sealed at Edirne, in the Month of Rajab, 838 AH

April, in the Year of Our Lord 1435

laws.title: Castile Economic Development Plan 1435-1440
laws.summary: Five-year strategic economic plan for Castile establishing production targets for wool, leather, and grain exports, infrastructure investment schedules, trade route expansion priorities, and the institutional framework for sustained economic growth through the end of the decade.
laws.full_text:
KINGDOM OF CASTILE

Comprehensive Economic Development Plan

1435 -- 1440

Prepared by Diego de Daza, Chief Financial Administrator

Under the Authority of His Majesty King Juan II

GM Reference Document --- Late Summer 1435

I. OVERVIEW

This document consolidates all economic development initiatives
undertaken by the Crown of Castile beginning in the summer of 1434. The
plan encompasses domestic industry expansion, foreign expert
recruitment, infrastructure investment, and naval development. All
projections cover the period 1435-1440.

The Junta de Manufacturas oversees industrial development. Diego de Daza
coordinates implementation with regular reporting to the Crown. Admiral
Don Berenguer de Vilaragut directs naval development under a separate
plan.

Key Strategic Goals:

-   Capture value from raw materials by processing domestically rather
    than exporting

-   Reduce dependence on foreign imports for strategic goods (arms,
    glass, textiles)

-   Expand fishing and Atlantic trade through naval investment

-   Build infrastructure to support herding expansion and commercial
    growth

-   Develop capacity for Constantinople settlement and military
    projection

II\. DOMESTIC INDUSTRIES

These industries utilize existing Castilian expertise and require
investment and coordination rather than foreign knowledge.

A. Leather Industry (Córdoba)

Representative: Rodrigo de Montilla, Master of the Gremio de
Curtidores

Status: Existing industry, world-famous for cordobanes and
guadamecíes

Initiatives:

-   Sumac cultivation --- deliberate plantations to secure tanning
    supply (3-5 years to maturity)

-   Hide production expansion --- tied to goat herd growth (see Herding
    section)

-   New tannery facility outside Córdoba city --- removes stench, allows
    expansion

-   Guadamecí workshop expansion --- finishing workshops in Toledo and
    Seville

-   Workforce tied to capacity --- apprenticeships expand as hide supply
    grows

Investment: 3,000 florins (1434, one-time). Infrastructure costs
included in general program.

B. Silk Industry (Granada)

Representatives: Hernán de Úbeda (merchant), Yusef al-Rashid (Muslim
silk master)

Status: Existing industry at 75-85% pre-war capacity; recovering

Problem: One-third of silk thread sold raw to Genoese middlemen who
capture weaving profits

Initiatives:

-   50 additional silk looms --- weave all thread into cloth
    domestically

-   Retrain wool/linen weavers for silk work with master supervision

-   Expand dye workshop capacity --- dyed cloth commands premium prices

-   Amān granted --- security guarantee for Muslim and Christian workers

Investment: 3,250 florins (1434, one-time: looms 2,250 + training
500 + dyes 500). Annual: 400 florins (master supervision).

C. Salt & Fishing Industry (Seville)

Representatives: Gonzalo Pérez de Medina (Cofradía de Mareantes),
Alonso de Marchena (Factor)

Status: Crown holds salt monopoly; fishing limited by small coastal
vessels

Initiatives:

-   Ocean-going fishing fleet --- 8 smaller vessels (40-50 tons), 2
    larger vessels (80-100 tons)

-   Lease model --- fishermen lease vessels at 15-20 florins/year
    (small) or 30-40 florins/year (large)

-   Ownership transfer after 20 years of lease payments and self-funded
    maintenance

-   Atlantic exploration --- assess waters between Castile and Canary
    Islands

Investment: 2,700 florins (1434, one-time). Lease revenue \~210
florins/year.

D. Ceramics Industry (Talavera)

Status: Existing industry producing fine ceramics

Measures Taken: None. Industry continues at current production
levels. No expansion planned without specific Crown initiative.

E. Wool & Goat Herding (Raw Materials)

Representatives: Don Alonso de Aguilar (Mesta), Martín Sánchez de
Priego (Goatherds)

Initiatives:

-   Terrain division in Granada --- mountains for goats, lowlands for
    sheep

-   Legal recognition for goatherds --- royal charter granting formal
    standing

-   Infrastructure improvements --- drove roads, watering points, new
    routes into Granada

-   Hide supply for leather industry; meat preserved for military
    provisions

Investment: Included in Infrastructure Program (12,000-15,000
florins/year allocated to herding infrastructure).

III\. FOREIGN EXPERT INDUSTRIES

These industries require expertise not currently available in Castile.
The Crown has recruited foreign masters to establish workshops and train
Castilian apprentices. Results vary based on quality of experts
attracted (determined by dice rolls).

A. Arms & Armor Workshops (Bilbao)

Roll: 74/100 --- GOOD

Master: Heinrich Steinmann of Augsburg, with brother-in-law (blades)
and mail-maker Konrad Fels

Location: Bilbao (iron access)

Focus: Practical military equipment --- hauberks, brigandines,
sallets, good steel blades. 'Weapons for soldiers, not for display.'

Production Capacity:

-   Years 1-2: \~200 complete soldier's kits annually

-   Year 5: 500-800 kits annually with trained Castilian workers

Investment: 8,900 florins (1435, one-time: workshop 8,000 + housing
900). Annual: 3,500 florins (retainer 1,500 + guaranteed purchases
2,000).

B. Textile Workshops (Segovia)

Roll: 24/100 --- POOR

Masters: Willem van der Berg, Pieter de Smet, Joos Claesen ---
journeymen of limited skill

Assessment: Second-rate craftsmen who could not succeed at home. Van
der Berg never achieved master status in Bruges. De Smet's credentials
purchased. Claesen's origin unclear.

Outcome: Single modest workshop established. Marginal improvement
over existing Castilian methods. Provides foundation for future true
master.

Investment: 2,600 florins (1435, one-time: workshop 2,000 + housing
600). Annual: 400 florins (retainer only, no guaranteed purchases).

Action: Continue search for true Flemish masters through Medici bank
and Burgundian court contacts.

C. Glass Workshop (Burgos)

Roll: 85/100 --- SUCCESS

Master: Alessandro Barbarigo of Venice (Murano)

Specialty: Cristallo (clear glass), colored glass, mirrors, vessel
work --- genuine Venetian quality

Background: Minor branch of noble Barbarigo family. Master
glassblower for 19 years. Fled after Venice 'disappeared' his son. No
family hostages remaining.

Security: SECRET OPERATION. Smuggled via Ragusa-Ancona-Genoa-Bilbao
route by Isaac de Baeza's network. Workshop location in Burgos kept
discreet. Guards posted.

Diplomatic Risk: Venice will protest when they discover his
location. Assassination attempts possible but difficult in distant
Castile.

Timeline: Estimates 10 years of productive work (eyes beginning to
fail). Can train Castilian apprentices in techniques Venice has guarded
for centuries.

Investment: 7,300 florins (1435, one-time: smuggling 500 + workshop
6,000 + housing 800). Annual: 1,200 florins (retainer 800 + security
400).

D. Paper Mills

Roll: 7/100 --- DISASTER

Candidates: Guillaume Fournier and Jean de Moulins of Troyes ---
frauds expelled from guild for incompetence

Outcome: Demonstration produced unusable paper --- uneven, riddled
with holes, ink bleeds. Sent away after minor hospitality expenses (\~50
florins).

Investment: \~50 florins lost (hospitality only).

Action: Retry 1436 through German contacts (Nuremberg/Augsburg) with
rigorous credential verification.

IV\. INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM

Administrator: Diego de Daza

Duration: Five years (1434-1438)

Budget: 40,000 florins annually (200,000 total)

Allocation:

  ----------------------------------- ----------------- -----------------
  Category                        Annual        Purpose

  Herding Infrastructure              12,000-15,000     Drove roads,
                                                        watering, Granada
                                                        routes

  General Commerce                    25,000-28,000     Ports, roads,
                                                        bridges,
                                                        facilities
  ----------------------------------- ----------------- -----------------

Priority Projects:

-   Cañada real bridge repairs and drove road maintenance

-   Watering point expansion (wells, river access)

-   Mountain passes into Granada highlands

-   Road to new Córdoba tannery facility

-   Port improvements for fishing and trade fleets

-   Major trade route improvements

Oversight: Independent oversight, milestone payments, penalties for
fraud.

V. NAVAL DEVELOPMENT

Admiral: Don Berenguer de Vilaragut (Aragonese, experienced
professional)

Reference: See Royal Naval Development Plan (April 1435) for
complete details

Summary:

Year One Investments (1435)

  ----------------------------------------------- -----------------------
  Action                                      Cost (Florins)

  La Cartuja shipyard construction                16,000

  Aggressive workforce recruitment                10,000

  Atarazanas claim settlement & repairs           14,000

  Purchase 15 existing vessels                    18,000

  First year Basque contracts                     5,500

  First year operating costs                      5,000

  TOTAL YEAR ONE                              68,500
  ----------------------------------------------- -----------------------

Fleet Projections

  ---------- -------------- ---------- ------------- --------------- ------------ -----------
  Year   Carracks   Naos   Galleys   Fish/Util   Patrol   TOTAL

  1435       9              9          9             15              2            44

  1436       11             14         9             21              5            60

  1437       15             20         11            29              10           85

  1438       20             25         13            36              14           108

  1439       24             30         13            42              18           127

  1440       28             34         13            48              20           143
  ---------- -------------- ---------- ------------- --------------- ------------ -----------

Annual Operating Costs (1436 onward)

  ----------------------------------------------- -----------------------
  Item                                        Range (Florins)

  La Cartuja operations                           12,000-15,000

  Atarazanas operations                           4,000-5,000

  Basque contracts                                5,000-7,000

  Crew wages                                      8,000-15,000

  Maintenance and repairs                         5,000-10,000

  Naval stores                                    3,000-5,000

  TOTAL ANNUAL                                37,000-57,000
  ----------------------------------------------- -----------------------

Note: Costs increase as fleet grows. By 1440, annual naval
expenditure may reach 60,000-70,000 florins.

Military Orders Fleet

The Orders build independently at Almería with their own funds plus
Crown grants of 5,000 florins annually per Order (15,000 total).

By 1440: Santiago 15 galleys, Calatrava 8 galleys + 6 naos + 2
transports, Alcántara 7 galleys = 38 total vessels.

VI\. FINANCIAL SUMMARY

A. One-Time Investments

  --------------------------------------------- ------------ -------------
  Initiative                                Year     Amount

  Leather Industry (Córdoba)                    1434         3,000

  Silk Industry (Granada)                       1434         3,250

  Fishing Fleet (Seville)                       1434         2,700

  Arms Workshops (Bilbao)                       1435         8,900

  Textile Workshop (Segovia)                    1435         2,600

  Glass Workshop (Burgos)                       1435         7,300

  Naval Development Year 1                      1435         68,500

  Portuguese Exploration Gift                   1434         10,000

  TOTAL ONE-TIME (Economic Development)     ---      106,250
  --------------------------------------------- ------------ -------------

B. Annual Recurring Costs

  --------------------------------------------- ------------ ---------------
  Item                                      Start    Annual

  Infrastructure Program                        1434         40,000

  Silk Master Supervision                       1435         400

  Arms Retainer + Purchases                     1435         3,500

  Textile Retainer                              1435         400

  Glass Retainer + Security                     1435         1,200

  Military Orders Fleet Grants                  1435         15,000

  Naval Operations (growing)                    1436         37,000-70,000

  TOTAL ANNUAL (1435, before naval ops)     ---      60,500

  TOTAL ANNUAL (1440, full naval ops)       ---      \~130,500
  --------------------------------------------- ------------ ---------------

VII\. REVENUE PROJECTIONS

These projections estimate ADDITIONAL revenue generated by economic
development initiatives above baseline crown revenue. Actual results
subject to dice rolls for industry performance.

Assumptions: Average outcomes assumed. All figures in florins.
Values represent incremental increase over 1434 baseline.

A. Revenue by Industry

  ------------------- ----------- ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------
  Industry        1435    1436     1437     1438     1439     1440

  Leather (Córdoba)   500         1,000        1,500        2,500        3,500        4,500

  Silk (Granada)      1,000       2,000        2,500        3,000        3,500        4,000

  Fishing (Seville)   400         800          1,200        1,500        2,000        2,500

  Arms (Bilbao)       0           200          500          800          1,000        1,200

  Textiles (Segovia)  100         150          150          200          200          200

  Glass (Burgos)      0           500          1,000        1,500        2,000        2,500

  Naval/Trade         3,000       6,000        10,000       14,000       17,000       20,000
  Expansion                                                                           

  Infrastructure      500         2,000        4,000        6,000        8,000        10,000
  Benefits                                                                            

  TOTAL             5,500   12,650   20,850   29,500   37,200   44,900
  ADDITIONAL                                                                        
  ------------------- ----------- ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------

B. Revenue Sources Explained

Leather: Increased alcabala on sales, export customs. Tied to goat
herd growth (slow start, accelerates as sumac matures and herds expand).

Silk: Value capture from cloth vs. thread sales (3-5x multiplier).
Immediate impact from existing production.

Fishing: Lease payments (\~210/year) plus alcabala on increased fish
supply. Grows with fleet expansion.

Arms: Reduced imports, some noble purchases. Strategic value exceeds
direct revenue. Slow start (workshop establishment).

Textiles: Minimal --- poor quality masters produce marginal
improvement only.

Glass: Luxury goods for wealthy buyers. Reduced imports, potential
exports. Slow start (secret establishment, ramping production).

Naval/Trade: More ships → more trade → more customs. More fishing
vessels → more fish → more alcabala. Reduced piracy → safer trade → more
merchants. Largest single revenue driver.

Infrastructure: Better roads/bridges → faster trade → more customs.
Benefits compound over time as network improves.

C. Net Position Analysis

Comparing annual costs against additional revenue generated:

  ------------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- -------------
  Category        1435      1436      1437      1438      1439      1440

  Additional Revenue  5,500         12,650        20,850        29,500        37,200        44,900

  Industry Annual     5,500         5,500         5,500         5,500         5,500         5,500
  Costs                                                                                     

  Infrastructure      40,000        40,000        40,000        40,000        40,000        0
  Costs                                                                                     

  Military Orders     15,000        15,000        15,000        15,000        15,000        15,000
  Grants                                                                                    

  Naval Operations    5,000         45,000        50,000        55,000        60,000        65,000

  NET POSITION    -60,000   -92,850   -89,650   -86,000   -83,300   -40,600
  ------------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- -------------

Interpretation: The economic development program operates at a
deficit through 1439, requiring treasury funding. By 1440, with
infrastructure complete and industries mature, the deficit shrinks
significantly. Post-1440, the program should approach break-even or
surplus as naval costs stabilize while revenues continue growing.

VIII\. OUTSTANDING ACTIONS

A. Annual Review --- Expert Recruitment (1436)

The following industries require renewed recruitment efforts:

  ----------------- ----------------- -----------------------------------
  Industry      1435 Result   1436 Action

  Textiles          Poor (24)         Seek true Flemish masters via
                                      Medici bank, Burgundian court

  Paper             Disaster (7)      Retry via German contacts
                                      (Nuremberg/Augsburg) with rigorous
                                      verification
  ----------------- ----------------- -----------------------------------

B. Industries Awaiting Development

-   Ceramics (Talavera) --- No measures taken; consider expansion if
    demand warrants

-   Canary Islands --- Claimed but unconquered; base for Atlantic
    expansion

C. Diplomatic Considerations

-   Venice --- Will protest when Barbarigo's location discovered;
    maintain discretion, prepare diplomatic response

-   Portugal --- Partnership developing; coordinate Atlantic
    exploration, share caravel designs

D. Monitoring Requirements

-   Herding expansion --- Track goat/sheep herd growth for leather/wool
    supply

-   Sumac plantations --- First harvest expected 1437-1438

-   Silk production --- Track cloth output vs. thread exports

laws.title: Castile Economic Measures of 1435
laws.summary: Summary of economic measures implemented in 1435 including tariff adjustments, guild regulation reforms, market standardization across Castilian towns, agricultural subsidies for Granada's resettlement, and progress reports on the five-year development plan's first-year targets.
laws.full_text:
Kingdom of Castile: Economic Development Measures Summary
January 1435 - December 1435

Reference Document for Campaign Continuity
Last Updated: End of 1435

Overview

This document summarizes all economic development measures undertaken by King Juan II of Castile, tracking investments, results, and future prospects. It distinguishes between crown-owned enterprises and privately-operated ventures receiving crown subsidies.

Total Economic Development Investment (1434-1435): ~68,000 florins
Annual Recurring Costs (1435): ~11,100 florins
Projected Annual Revenue from New Industries (1435): ~7,000 florins

Part I: Crown-Owned Industries

These industries are directly owned and operated by the Crown, with revenues flowing to the royal treasury.

1. Paper Mills (Segovia & Toledo)

Status: OPERATIONAL (Exceptional Success - Roll 88)
Year Established: 1435

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1435) | 10,000 florins total |
| Annual Operating Costs | ~1,500 florins (materials, wages) |
| Annual Revenue | 4,000 florins gross / ~2,500 florins net |
| Production | 700 reams/year combined |

The Two Mills:

Segovia Mill (Wilhelm Hartmann, German)
- Focus: Functional paper for correspondence, legal documents, ledgers
- Capacity: 500 reams/year
- Revenue: 1,800 florins/year
- Specialty: High volume, consistent quality
- Apprentices: 6 Castilians training in German methods

Toledo Mill (Marco da Pescia, Italian)
- Focus: Fine paper for royal documents, books, diplomatic use
- Capacity: 200 reams/year
- Revenue: 2,200 florins/year
- Specialty: Exceptional quality, royal watermark
- Apprentices: 4 Castilians training in Italian methods

Strategic Impact:
- Paper self-sufficiency achieved for functional paper
- Fine paper imports reduced by 75%
- Crown paper costs reduced by 40%
- Portuguese merchants inquiring about exports
- Both German and Italian techniques now in Castile
- First Castilian journeymen expected in 3-4 years

Future Projections:
| Year | Revenue (fl) | Notes |
|------|-------------|-------|
| 1436 | 4,000 | Full production |
| 1437 | 4,500 | Efficiency improvements |
| 1438 | 5,000 | First apprentices contributing |
| 1440 | 6,000 | Possible third mill |

2. Wool Breeding Program (Royal Flocks)

Status: IN PROGRESS (Adequate Success - Roll 42)
Year Established: 1435

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (Year 1, 1435) | 5,900 florins |
| Projected Investment (Years 2-3) | ~12,000 florins additional |
| Immediate Revenue | None (long-term investment) |

Year One Results:
- 20 English rams purchased
- 16 arrived healthy (4 died during sea crossing)
- Breeds: 6 Ryelands (finest), 5 Cotswolds, 5 Lincolns
- 640 ewes bred at Segovia

Timeline:
| Year | Milestone |
|------|-----------|
| 1437 | First crossbred lambs born |
| 1438 | First improved wool clip |
| 1440 | Second-generation breeding |
| 1445 | Castilian wool approaches English quality |

Strategic Impact:
- Foundation laid for wool quality transformation
- Genetic diversity established (multiple English breeds)
- Channels for Year Two acquisition identified
- Lessons learned: verify bloodlines, ship in smaller groups, avoid Southampton

Long-term Projection:
Within 10 years, Castilian wool could equal English quality. Shepherds will remember Juan as "the king who made our wool worth something."

Part II: Crown-Subsidized Private Industries

These industries are owned and operated by private masters or guilds, receiving crown subsidies, guaranteed purchases, or other support. Revenues accrue to the operators, with the crown benefiting through taxes, reduced imports, and economic growth.

3. Textile Workshop (Segovia)

Status: ESTABLISHING (Exceptional Success - Roll 87)
Year Established: 1435

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1435) | 5,500 florins one-time |
| Annual Subsidy | 500 florins (guaranteed purchases) |
| Projected Revenue (to masters) | 1,500 florins (1436), growing to 6,000 (1440) |
| Crown Revenue | Alcabala on production (~5% of sales) |

The Ghent Consortium:
Three masters who fled guild politics in Ghent together:
- Gillis de Coninck (52) - Master weaver, fine woolen broadcloths, specialized looms
- Arnout van Steenbergen (48) - Master fuller, trade secret fulling mixtures
- Mathijs Coppens (44) - Master dyer, renowned crimson, mordant expertise

Why They Left: Ghent city council export restrictions strangled their businesses after public protest. Planning departure together—each is part of complete production chain.

Terms:
- Workshop complex in Segovia (4,000 florins)
- Housing for families (1,000 florins)
- Guaranteed 500 florins/year crown purchases for 3 years
- Hidalguía after 5 years of service
- Right to establish guild
- Protection from Flemish retaliation

Strategic Impact:
- Complete cloth-making capability: wool in, finished fabric out
- Can train Castilian apprentices in techniques that were guild secrets for generations
- Major reduction in cloth imports within 3 years
- Quality improving from baseline 0.9 to 0.95 factor

Tariff Condition: All subsidized industries must pay standard tariffs on production regardless of fueros ports.

Revenue Projections (to masters):
| Year | Revenue (fl) | Notes |
|------|-------------|-------|
| 1436 | 1,500 | Establishment year |
| 1437 | 2,500 | Full production |
| 1438 | 3,500 | Apprentices contributing |
| 1439 | 4,500 | Castilian workers trained |
| 1440 | 6,000 | Industry established |

4. Arms & Armor Workshop (Bilbao)

Status: OPERATIONAL (Good Success - Roll 74)
Year Established: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1434) | 8,900 florins one-time |
| Annual Subsidy | 3,500 florins (retainer 1,500 + guaranteed purchases 2,000) |
| Production | ~200 soldier's kits/year (1435), scaling to 500-800 by 1439 |

The Augsburg Consortium:
- Heinrich Steinmann - Lead armorer, practical military equipment
- Brother-in-law - Blade-smith
- Konrad Fels - Mail-maker

Philosophy: "Weapons for soldiers, not for display." Practical military equipment—hauberks, brigandines, sallets, good steel blades.

Location: Bilbao (iron access from Basque country)

Strategic Impact:
- Reduced dependence on Italian arms imports
- Quality blades and armor for Castilian military
- Training Castilian apprentices
- Export potential to Constantinople garrison

Production Projections:
| Year | Kits/Year | Notes |
|------|-----------|-------|
| 1435 | 200 | Establishment year |
| 1436 | 300 | Ramping up |
| 1437 | 400 | Full capacity |
| 1438 | 500-600 | With trained Castilians |
| 1439 | 600-800 | Mature operation |

5. Glass Workshop (Burgos)

Status: OPERATIONAL - SECRET (Excellent Success - Roll 85)
Year Established: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1434) | 7,300 florins one-time |
| Annual Subsidy | 1,200 florins (retainer 800 + security 400) |
| Projected Revenue (to master) | 500 florins (1436), growing to 2,500 (1440) |

The Master:
Alessandro Barbarigo - Genuine Murano master glassblower (19 years experience)

Background: Minor branch of noble Barbarigo family. Venice "disappeared" his son two months before recruitment—punishment for perceived indiscretion. With no family hostages remaining, he no longer cares if he lives or dies, so long as he wounds Venice.

Specialties:
- Cristallo (clear glass) - Venice's signature technique
- Colored glass
- Mirrors
- Vessel work

SECURITY: SECRET OPERATION. Smuggled via Ragusa-Ancona-Genoa-Bilbao route by Isaac de Baeza's network. Workshop location in Burgos kept discreet. Guards posted.

Diplomatic Risk: Venice will protest when they discover his location. Assassination attempts possible but difficult in distant Castile.

Timeline: Estimates 10 years of productive work (eyes beginning to fail). Can train Castilian apprentices in techniques Venice has guarded for centuries.

Strategic Impact:
- Venetian glassmaking techniques now in Castile
- Reduced imports from Venice
- Potential for luxury goods export
- Training next generation of Castilian glassblowers

6. Leather Industry (Córdoba)

Status: ONGOING (Existing Industry)
Enhancement Year: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1434) | 3,000 florins one-time |
| Annual Revenue | ~500 florins additional (growing) |

Industry: World-famous for cordobanes (fine leather) and guadamecíes (gilded leather)

Initiatives:
- Sumac cultivation (3-5 years to maturity)
- Hide production expansion tied to goat herd growth
- New tannery facility outside Córdoba
- Guadamecí workshop expansion in Toledo and Seville

Strategic Impact:
- Building on existing strength
- Expanding capacity as Granada goat herds grow
- Export commodity to Italy and France

7. Silk Industry (Granada)

Status: RECOVERING (Existing Industry)
Enhancement Year: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1434) | 3,250 florins one-time |
| Annual Subsidy | 400 florins (master supervision) |
| Pre-Conquest Capacity | 100% |
| Current Capacity (1435) | ~75-80% |

Initiatives:
- 50 additional silk looms installed
- Retraining wool/linen weavers for silk work
- Dye workshop capacity expanded
- AmÄn granted to Muslim workers

Problem Addressed: One-third of silk thread was sold raw to Genoese middlemen who captured weaving profits. Now all thread woven into cloth domestically.

Strategic Impact:
- Value capture from cloth vs. thread (3-5x multiplier)
- Reduced dependence on Italian middlemen
- Granada's premier export commodity preserved
- Muslim craftsmen protected and productive

8. Fishing Fleet (Seville)

Status: OPERATIONAL (Existing Industry)
Enhancement Year: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1434) | 2,700 florins one-time |
| Annual Lease Revenue | ~210 florins |

Fleet:
- 8 smaller vessels (40-50 tons) - leased at 15-20 florins/year
- 2 larger vessels (80-100 tons) - leased at 30-40 florins/year

Lease Model: Fishermen lease vessels; ownership transfers after 20 years of lease payments and self-funded maintenance.

Strategic Impact:
- Expanded Atlantic fishing capacity
- Exploring waters toward Canary Islands
- Increased fish supply for domestic consumption
- Foundation for potential Atlantic expansion

Part III: Problem Industries

9. Ceramics (Málaga/Granada)

Status: CRITICAL RISK (Poor Success - Roll 25)
Year Assessed: 1435

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1435) | 2,500 florins |
| Current Revenue | ~400-500 florins/year |
| Knowledge Status | CRITICAL RISK |

The Situation:
Málaga was the original home of Hispano-Moresque lusterware—the technique that made Manises famous. The conquest (1433) devastated the industry:
- 12 master potters before conquest
- 3 fled to Fez
- 5 dead
- 2 unaccounted
- 2 fled
- 1 remains: Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar (age 73)

Ibrahim's Status:
- Sole surviving master of golden luster technique
- Son Ahmad killed defending Puerta de Granada during conquest
- Grandson Yusef fled to Fez with mother
- Bitter but skilled—demonstrated exceptional work
- Refuses to train Christian apprentices
- Perhaps 5-10 years productive work remaining

Personal Royal Intervention:
King Juan wrote personal letter expressing condolences for Ahmad's death, sharing own grief over Isabel's death, reflecting on legacy and beauty. Commissioned work with complete artistic freedom (50 florins advance, 50 on completion). No Christian symbols requested.

Ibrahim's Response (Roll 11): Suspicious distance. "Tell the King I read his letter. Tell him I will think on it." Commission produced 3 pieces of genuine quality. Door not entirely closed.

Options Remaining:
1. Continue personal approach
2. Recover grandson from Fez
3. Recruit from Manises (Valencia, Aragonese)
4. Combine approaches

Strategic Concern: When Ibrahim dies, the golden luster secret dies with him unless conditions change.

10. Ceramics Collaboration Model (Seville/Talavera)

Status: SUCCESS (Solid Success - Roll 41)
Year Established: 1435

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment (1435) | ~195 florins (120 gift set + 75 hospital) |
| Model | Crown commissions requiring multi-workshop collaboration |

Portuguese Diplomatic Gift Set Commission:
Terms: 12 decorative plates, 6 drinking vessels, 4 serving dishes, 2 vases. Must combine at least 2 distinct techniques from different workshops.

Partnership Emerged:
- Francisco de Toledo (34, Talavera) - Clean tin glazes, precise forms
- Alonso el Moro (61, Seville Morisco) - Intricate cuerda seca, Islamic geometric traditions

Results: Excellent quality. Clean white Talavera glaze + cuerda seca borders (green, blue, ochre). Geometric patterns drawing on Islamic tradition.

Follow-up: Hospital commission awarded (75 florins for drug jars, basins, vessels).

Strategic Impact:
- Precedent established for multi-workshop collaboration
- Market incentives drive innovation without forced knowledge sharing
- Other masters observing with interest
- Model for future crown commissions

Part IV: Failed Initiatives (1434)

11. Textile Workshop (First Attempt)

Status: DISCONTINUED (Poor Success - Roll 24)
Year: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment Lost | 2,600 florins one-time + 400 florins annual |
| Result | Journeymen, not true masters |

The Problem: Willem van der Berg, Pieter de Smet, and Joos Claesen presented themselves as Flemish masters but proved to be journeymen of limited skill. Van der Berg never achieved master status in Bruges; de Smet's credentials were purchased.

Lesson Learned: Verify credentials rigorously through trusted channels (Medici bank, Burgundian court contacts).

Resolution: Replaced by Ghent Consortium (1435, Roll 87).

12. Paper Mills (First Attempt)

Status: COMPLETE FAILURE (Disaster - Roll 7)
Year: 1434

| Item | Detail |
|------|--------|
| Investment Lost | ~50 florins (hospitality only) |
| Result | Frauds exposed and expelled |

The Problem: Guillaume Fournier and Jean de Moulins of Troyes presented themselves as experienced papermakers. Demonstration revealed the truth: unusable paper—uneven, riddled with holes, ink bleeds. They were frauds expelled from their guild for incompetence.

Lesson Learned: Require sample production in our presence before any agreement. Verify credentials through multiple sources.

Resolution: Replaced by dual recruitment through German and Italian channels (1435, Roll 88).

Part V: Financial Summary

Investment by Year

1434 Investments (One-Time):
| Initiative | Amount (fl) |
|------------|-------------|
| Arms Workshops (Bilbao) | 8,900 |
| Textile Workshop (failed, discontinued) | 2,600 |
| Glass Workshop (Burgos) | 7,300 |
| Paper Mills (failed) | 50 |
| Leather Industry (Córdoba) | 3,000 |
| Silk Industry (Granada) | 3,250 |
| Fishing Fleet (Seville) | 2,700 |
| 1434 TOTAL | 27,800 |

1435 Investments (One-Time):
| Initiative | Amount (fl) |
|------------|-------------|
| Paper Mills (Segovia/Toledo) | 10,000 |
| Textile Workshop (Ghent consortium) | 5,500 |
| English Ram Breeding (Year 1) | 5,900 |
| Ceramics Revival (Málaga) | 2,500 |
| Ceramics Commissions | ~195 |
| 1435 TOTAL | ~24,100 |

Annual Recurring Costs (1435)

| Initiative | Annual Cost (fl) | Notes |
|------------|-----------------|-------|
| Arms Workshops | 3,500 | Retainer + purchases |
| Glass Workshop | 1,200 | Retainer + security |
| Textile Workshop | 500 | Guaranteed purchases |
| Paper Mills | ~1,500 | Operating costs |
| Silk Industry | 400 | Master supervision |
| Leather Industry | — | Infrastructure only |
| Fishing Fleet | — | Self-sustaining (lease revenue) |
| TOTAL ANNUAL | ~7,100 |

Note: Textile Workshop (failed) had 400 fl/year recurring cost that is now discontinued.

Projected Costs (1436-1440)

| Year | One-Time | Annual | Notes |
|------|----------|--------|-------|
| 1436 | ~6,000 | ~7,100 | Ram breeding Year 2 |
| 1437 | ~6,000 | ~7,100 | Ram breeding Year 3 |
| 1438 | ~1,000 | ~7,100 | Maintenance only |
| 1439 | ~1,000 | ~6,600 | Textile purchases end |
| 1440 | ~1,000 | ~6,600 | Mature operations |

Revenue Summary (1435)

Crown-Owned Industries:
| Initiative | Gross Revenue | Net Revenue | Notes |
|------------|--------------|-------------|-------|
| Paper Mills | 4,000 | ~2,500 | After operating costs |
| Wool Breeding | 0 | 0 | Long-term investment |
| Crown Total | 4,000 | ~2,500 |

Crown Revenue from Private Industries:
| Source | Amount | Notes |
|--------|--------|-------|
| Alcabala (5%) on new production | ~300-400 | Arms, glass, textiles |
| Customs on reduced imports | Variable | Savings rather than revenue |
| Fishing fleet leases | 210 | Direct payment |
| Private Industry Crown Revenue | ~600 |

Total Crown Revenue from Economic Development (1435): ~3,100 florins
Net Position (Revenue - Costs): ~3,100 - 7,100 = -4,000 florins

The economic development program operates at a deficit through the initial years, with break-even expected around 1439-1440 as industries mature.

Part VI: Strategic Assessment

Import Substitution Achieved

| Product | Pre-1434 Status | 1435 Status |
|---------|-----------------|-------------|
| Paper | 100% imported | ~60% domestic |
| Cloth (quality) | 100% imported | Beginning domestic production |
| Glass (quality) | 100% imported | Beginning domestic production |
| Arms & Armor | ~80% imported | ~50% domestic, improving |
| Silk cloth | ~30% raw exported | All woven domestically |

Knowledge Transfer

| Industry | Foreign Masters | Castilian Apprentices | Years to Self-Sufficiency |
|----------|-----------------|----------------------|---------------------------|
| Paper | 2 (German, Italian) | 10 | 4-5 |
| Textiles | 3 (Flemish) | 12+ planned | 5-7 |
| Glass | 1 (Venetian) | 4+ planned | 8-10 |
| Arms | 3 (German) | 8+ | 5-7 |
| Ceramics | 1 (surviving local) | 0 (refused) | CRITICAL |

Key Lessons Learned

1. Verification is essential: Sample production required before commitment (learned from paper fraud)
2. True masters are rare: Poor-quality recruits waste resources (learned from textile failure)
3. Channels matter: Medici bank and German contacts more reliable than general recruitment
4. Collaboration can work: Market incentives for multi-workshop cooperation (ceramics)
5. Dual recruitment adds resilience: Two paper mills with different specialties provide redundancy
6. Tariff standardization: All subsidized industries pay standard tariffs regardless of fueros

Critical Risks

1. Ceramics Knowledge: Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar (73) is sole keeper of golden luster technique. When he dies, it may die with him.
2. Venetian Retaliation: Venice will eventually discover Barbarigo's location. Diplomatic incident and possible assassination attempts.
3. Flemish Guild Anger: Ghent consortium's departure may cause trade friction with Burgundy.
4. English Discovery: Ram smuggling could be exposed, causing diplomatic problems.

Part VII: Ownership Structure Summary

Crown-Owned
- Paper mills (Segovia, Toledo)
- Royal breeding flocks (wool improvement)

Crown-Subsidized, Privately Operated
- Textile workshop (Ghent consortium)
- Arms workshop (Steinmann consortium)
- Glass workshop (Barbarigo)
- Ceramics commissions (Francisco/Alonso collaboration)

Traditional Private/Guild (Enhanced)
- Leather industry (Córdoba guilds)
- Silk industry (Granada guilds + Muslim craftsmen)
- Fishing (Seville cofradía)
- Ceramics (Talavera/Seville guilds)

At Risk
- Málaga ceramics (Ibrahim alone, no succession)
