laws.title: Fueros de Aragon
laws.summary: The constitutional fueros of Aragon establishing that the king rules by consent, with the Justicia as guardian of liberties, noble and municipal self-governance, and the Cortes holding veto power over taxation and legislation.
laws.full_text:
FUEROS DE ARAGÓN
As Codified Under Jaime I and Confirmed by Successive Kings
Presented to Don Juan, Claimant to the Crown of Aragon, September 1437

PREAMBLE

In Nomine Domini. Amen.

These are the Fueros, Liberties, Customs, and Privileges of the Kingdom of Aragon, gathered and set down in the time of the most excellent King Don Jaime, called the Conqueror, confirmed and amended by his successors, and held inviolate by all who would wear the crown of this ancient realm.

Let it be known to all who read these words that the Kingdom of Aragon was not made by kings alone, but by the union of king and people against the enemies of Christ. In the mountains of Sobrarbe, when the Moors held all the land, free men chose a king from among themselves to lead them in war—and in choosing, they made a compact that has endured unto this day.

The king rules not by right of blood alone, nor by grace of God alone, but by the consent of the realm and the sacred oath that binds him to his people as they are bound to him.

Nos qui sumus æquales tibi. We who are as good as you.

This is the foundation. Let no man forget it.

BOOK I: OF THE KING AND HIS OATH

Title I: Of the Nature of Aragonese Kingship

Article 1. The King of Aragon holds his crown by inheritance according to the laws of succession, by the grace of Almighty God, and by the acceptance of the Cortes of the realm. No man may be crowned King of Aragon who has not been acknowledged by the Cortes and sworn the coronation oath in its ancient form.

Article 2. The King is the first among the Aragonese, but not their master. He is bound by the same laws that bind his subjects, save only those matters wherein the dignity of the crown requires special provision.

Article 3. The King may not be judged by any court within the realm, for there is no authority above him save God alone. Yet if the King violates the fueros, the people are released from their obedience, for an oath broken by one party binds not the other.

Title II: Of the Coronation Oath

Article 4. Before the crown shall touch his brow, the claimant must swear the following oath before the Cortes, upon the Holy Gospels and in the presence of the Justicia:

"We, Don [Name], by the grace of God King of Aragon, do swear upon these Holy Gospels and by the Precious Blood of Our Lord Jesus Christ, that we shall maintain, preserve, and defend the fueros, liberties, privileges, and customs of this Kingdom of Aragon, and of all its inhabitants, as they have been maintained by our predecessors; that we shall do justice to all men according to the laws of this realm; that we shall take no new tax nor levy without the consent of the Cortes; and that we shall in all things govern according to the ancient liberties of our people. And if we fail in this oath, may God judge us, and may our subjects be released from their allegiance. So help us God and these Holy Gospels."

Article 5. The Cortes shall respond to the oath with these words:

"We, who are as good as you, and who together are greater than you, accept you as our King and sovereign lord, provided that you keep our fueros and liberties; and if not, not."

Article 6. The oath once sworn may not be forsworn. A king who violates his coronation oath commits perjury before God and treason against the realm.

Title III: Of the Succession

Article 7. The crown of Aragon descends by primogeniture to the eldest legitimate son of the king, and failing sons, to daughters, and failing direct issue, to the nearest heir of the blood according to the laws of consanguinity.

Article 8. No bastard may inherit the crown, though he may be legitimated for other purposes by royal act.

Article 9. If the succession is disputed, the Cortes shall determine the rightful heir according to law, treaty, and the good of the realm.

BOOK II: OF THE JUSTICIA OF ARAGON

Title I: Of the Office and Its Powers

Article 10. There shall be in the Kingdom of Aragon an office called the Justicia, which shall stand between the King and the people as guardian of the fueros and judge of disputes between them.

Article 11. The Justicia shall be a knight of Aragon, learned in the laws, of good fame and unblemished honor. He shall hold office for life and may not be removed by the King for any cause, save only conviction of treason or heresy by proper ecclesiastical tribunal.

Article 12. The Justicia shall have power to interpret the fueros in all cases of doubt, and his interpretation shall be binding upon all parties, including the crown.

Article 13. If the King issues any decree, order, or command that violates the fueros, the Justicia may declare it void. Such declaration shall be made publicly, with reasons stated, and the decree so voided shall have no force in law.

Article 14. The Justicia shall maintain the authoritative text of these fueros and all amendments thereto. Any man may consult this text, and the Justicia's scribes shall provide certified copies for a reasonable fee.

Article 15. The Justicia shall have a court, staffed by lieutenants learned in the law, to hear all matters touching the fueros and the liberties of the realm.

Title II: Of the Manifestación

Article 16. Any freeman of Aragon who is imprisoned or detained by royal authority may invoke the Manifestación, appealing to the Justicia for protection.

Article 17. Upon such invocation, the Justicia shall send officers to remove the prisoner from royal custody and hold him in the Justicia's own prison until the matter is properly adjudicated.

Article 18. No royal officer may refuse to surrender a prisoner who has invoked the Manifestación. Any officer who refuses may be declared a breaker of the fueros and punished accordingly.

Article 19. The prisoner held under Manifestación may not be tortured, mutilated, or executed until the Justicia's court has determined whether proper procedures were followed in his arrest and detention. If the procedures were defective, the prisoner shall be released.

Article 20. The Manifestación protects against improper process, not against just punishment. If the Justicia's court finds that the arrest was lawful and the procedures correct, the prisoner shall be returned to royal custody for trial.

Title III: Of the Firma de Derecho

Article 21. Any man who believes he will be unjustly prosecuted or deprived of his property may seek the Firma de Derecho—the Justicia's preemptive protection.

Article 22. Upon granting the Firma, the Justicia issues a writ forbidding any court or officer from proceeding against the petitioner until the Justicia's court has examined the matter and determined whether the intended action is lawful.

Article 23. The Firma de Derecho may not be invoked to escape punishment for crimes already committed and proven, but only to prevent unjust prosecution or arbitrary seizure.

BOOK III: OF THE RIGHTS OF THE NOBILITY

Title I: Of Noble Privileges

Article 24. The nobles of Aragon—ricos hombres, knights, infanzones, and hidalgos—shall enjoy the following privileges, which no king may abridge:

Article 25. No noble may be imprisoned without first being tried and convicted by a court of his peers. The king may not order the arrest of a noble on suspicion alone, but must present charges before a proper tribunal.

Article 26. No noble may be subjected to torture under any circumstances whatsoever. Confession extracted by torture shall have no validity in any court.

Article 27. No noble may have his lands or goods confiscated save by judgment of his peers for proven crime. The king may not seize noble property by decree.

Article 28. Nobles may wage private war against one another according to the ancient custom, provided they first issue formal defiance (desafiamiento) and observe the established rules of feud. Such private war is not treason against the crown.

Article 29. Nobles may fortify their castles and maintain armed retainers without royal permission, save that they may not make war against the king or harbor the king's enemies.

Article 30. The noble who is wronged by the king may formally renounce his allegiance (desnaturamiento) and depart the realm with his goods, and this shall not be deemed treason, provided he does not take up arms against Aragon in service of a foreign power.

Title II: Of the Assembly of Nobles

Article 31. The nobles of Aragon shall have the right to assemble and deliberate upon matters touching their interests, and to present their grievances to the king through their chosen representatives in the Cortes.

Article 32. No law touching the rights of the nobility may be enacted without the consent of the noble estate in the Cortes.

BOOK IV: OF THE RIGHTS OF CITIES AND TOWNS

Title I: Of Municipal Liberties

Article 33. The cities and towns of Aragon that hold royal charters shall govern themselves according to those charters, and the king may not abridge their chartered liberties.

Article 34. Chartered cities may elect their own councils, judges, and officers according to their customs. The king may not appoint city officials nor override municipal elections.

Article 35. Chartered cities may administer justice in minor cases according to their own customs, subject to appeal to the Justicia in matters touching the fueros.

Article 36. Chartered cities may levy local taxes for municipal purposes without royal permission, subject to their own council's approval.

Article 37. The king may not quarter troops upon a chartered city without the council's consent, save in time of war and necessity, and then only with just compensation.

Title II: Of Markets and Commerce

Article 38. The cities and towns may hold markets and fairs according to their charters, and the king may not impose new tolls or customs duties upon internal trade save with the consent of the Cortes.

Article 39. Foreign merchants may trade in Aragon according to the treaties made with their sovereigns and the customs of each city, provided they pay the established duties and observe the laws of the realm.

BOOK V: OF THE RIGHTS OF THE COMMONS

Title I: Of Personal Liberty

Article 40. The peasants and common folk of Aragon shall enjoy the following liberties, in greater measure than those of other realms:

Article 41. In the greater part of Aragon, the peasant who works the land may depart from his lord's estate if he is ill-treated, provided he surrenders his tenancy and pays any debts justly owed. No lord may bind a peasant to the soil against his will by force alone.

Article 42. Exception: In certain territories, particularly in Catalonia, the remença custom prevails, wherein peasants are bound to the land by ancient usage. The fueros of Aragon do not override the particular customs of Catalonia in this matter.

Article 43. No freeman of Aragon may be enslaved, save that Moors and infidels taken in just war may be held as captives according to the laws of Christendom.

Article 44. Any serf or bondsman who dwells in a chartered city for a year and a day without his lord reclaiming him shall be deemed free.

Title II: Of Justice for Commons

Article 45. The common folk shall have access to justice in the Justicia's courts as well as in royal and municipal courts. The Manifestación and Firma de Derecho are available to all freemen, not only to nobles.

Article 46. No man may be condemned without trial, nor punished beyond what the law provides for his offense.

BOOK VI: OF THE CORTES

Title I: Of Its Composition

Article 47. The Cortes of Aragon is the assembly of the realm, wherein all estates are represented: the clergy (brazo eclesiástico), the high nobility (brazo de ricos hombres), the lesser nobility (brazo de caballeros e infanzones), and the cities (brazo de universidades).

Article 48. The King may summon the Cortes at his pleasure, but must summon it at least once every two years, and whenever great matters touching the realm require deliberation.

Article 49. The Cortes shall meet in Zaragoza unless necessity requires another location, and proper notice must be given to all who have the right to attend.

Title II: Of Its Powers

Article 50. No new tax, levy, subsidy, or imposition may be laid upon the people of Aragon without the consent of the Cortes. The King may request; only the Cortes may grant.

Article 51. The consent of all four estates is required for any grant of taxation. If any single estate refuses, the tax may not be levied.

Article 52. No new law may be enacted nor existing law amended without the consent of the Cortes. The King proposes; the Cortes disposes.

Article 53. The Cortes may present grievances (greuges) to the King, and the King must hear them and provide remedy before the Cortes votes upon his requests.

Article 54. The Cortes may petition the King for redress of wrongs, and the King should give just answer, though he is not bound to grant every petition.

Title III: Of Procedure

Article 55. Each estate shall deliberate separately upon matters before the Cortes, and each shall have one vote. Unanimity among the estates is required for taxation and legislation.

Article 56. The proceedings of the Cortes shall be recorded by notaries and preserved in the archives of the realm.

BOOK VII: OF THE SEPARATE REALMS

Title I: Of the Distinction of Kingdoms

Article 57. The Crown of Aragon encompasses divers realms: the Kingdom of Aragon, the Principality of Catalonia, and the Kingdom of Valencia, together with such other territories as may be united to the crown. Each realm retains its own laws, customs, fueros, and liberties.

Article 58. The King of Aragon is also Count of Barcelona and King of Valencia. He owes separate oaths to each realm and must observe the particular laws of each.

Article 59. A law enacted by the Cortes of Aragon has no force in Catalonia unless the Corts of Catalonia separately approves it, and likewise for Valencia and any other realm.

Article 60. The King may not transfer revenues from one realm to another without the consent of the realm from which the revenues come.

Article 61. Offices in each realm shall be held by natives of that realm. A Castilian may not hold office in Aragon, nor an Aragonese in Catalonia, save by special dispensation of the appropriate Cortes.

Title II: Of Union Under One Crown

Article 62. Though the realms are separate in law, they are united in the person of the King, and shall render mutual aid in time of war and necessity.

Article 63. The King may summon a General Cortes of all realms for matters touching the common defense, but each realm's representatives retain their separate voting and their separate fueros.

BOOK VIII: OF AMENDMENTS AND INTERPRETATION

Article 64. These fueros may be amended only by consent of the King and all four estates of the Cortes, with the Justicia certifying that the amendment violates no fundamental liberty of the realm.

Article 65. In all cases of doubt, the fueros shall be interpreted in favor of liberty and against the expansion of royal power, for the fueros were made to protect the people from tyranny, not to arm the tyrant against the people.

Article 66. These fueros bind the King and all his successors forever. No King may claim ignorance of them, for they are published and known. No King may claim exception from them, for the oath binds without reservation.

Quod principi placuit, legis habet vigorem—what pleases the prince has the force of law—is the maxim of tyrants. In Aragon, the maxim is otherwise:

Quod lex statuit, regi placere debet. What the law establishes, the king must accept.

CLOSING

Datum et actum in the City of Zaragoza, in the presence of the Cortes, in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-seven, for the instruction of Don Juan, by the grace of God King of Castile and León, claimant to the Crown of Aragon.

May God preserve the fueros.
May God preserve the realm.
May God preserve the king who keeps his oath.

Finis.

[Certified true copy by the Office of the Justicia of Aragon]

[Seal]

laws.title: Fueros de Aragon: Additions
laws.summary: Supplementary articles to the Fueros extending Aragonese constitutional protections to newly incorporated territories, addressing the legal status of Mudéjar and Jewish communities, and clarifying commercial regulations for cross-border trade with Castile and the Mediterranean ports.
laws.full_text:
FUEROS DE ARAGÓN
Additiones Novae — New Books Added by the Cortes of Zaragoza
November 1437

In Nomine Domini. Amen.

These additions to the ancient Fueros of Aragon are enacted by the consent of His Majesty Don Juan, King of Aragon, Count of Barcelona, King of Valencia, and the four estates of the realm assembled in Cortes at Zaragoza, in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-seven.

Let it be known that these provisions do not abridge, diminish, or alter the ancient liberties of the realm, but rather strengthen and clarify them for the benefit of all who dwell under the protection of Aragonese law.

BOOK IX: OF THE CENTRAL REGISTRY OF PRIVILEGES
De Registro Privilegiorum

PREAMBLE

Whereas the privileges, liberties, fueros, and grants of the Kingdom of Aragon have accumulated over centuries in divers chests, archives, monasteries, and strongboxes throughout the realm;

Whereas this dispersal has led to confusion, contradiction, litigation, and the diminishment of rights that should be protected;

Whereas no king can swear to uphold that which he does not know, nor defend that which lies hidden from his sight;

Whereas the noble houses of Aragon have expressed their desire for clarity, certainty, and the permanent protection of their ancient rights;

Therefore, by the consent of all estates, we establish the Central Registry of Privileges, to be maintained in perpetuity for the protection of Aragonese liberties.

Title I: Establishment of the Registry

Article 1. There shall be established in the Kingdom of Aragon a Central Registry of Privileges (Registrum Centrale Privilegiorum), wherein all fueros, privileges, liberties, grants, immunities, and customary rights may be recorded and preserved.

Article 2. The Registry shall be maintained by the Office of the Justicia of Aragon, in secure archives within the city of Zaragoza, protected from fire, flood, theft, and all manner of destruction.

Article 3. The Justicia shall appoint such clerks, scribes, notaries, and archivists as are necessary to maintain the Registry, all of whom shall be natives of the realms of the Crown of Aragon and shall swear oaths of faithful service.

Article 4. The Registry shall be accessible to all who have legitimate interest in consulting it. Any freeman of Aragon may request certified copies of registered privileges upon payment of reasonable fees established by the Justicia's office.

Title II: The Effect of Registration

Article 5. A privilege once registered in the Central Registry becomes unassailable (inexpugnabile). No king, no court, no authority temporal or spiritual may challenge, abridge, diminish, or revoke a registered privilege, save only by the free consent of the holder thereof.

Article 6. Registration transforms a privilege from a claim that may be disputed into a right that cannot be disputed. The act of registration is the act of permanent confirmation.

Article 7. This protection extends to all successors of the registering party. A privilege registered by a father protects his sons, his grandsons, and all who inherit his rights in perpetuity.

Article 8. No future king of Aragon may alter, suspend, or circumvent the protections of this Title. Any decree, order, or act purporting to challenge a registered privilege is void ab initio and shall be declared so by the Justicia.

Title III: The Transition Period

Article 9. For a period of twenty-five years from the promulgation of this Book—that is, until the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and sixty-two—all privileges not yet registered shall retain their current validity and force.

Article 10. During the transition period, no house shall be penalized, disadvantaged, or prejudiced for declining to register its privileges, for delay in registration, or for difficulty in locating ancient documents.

Article 11. Houses are encouraged but not compelled to register during the transition period. Registration is voluntary, and the benefits of registration are offered as inducement, not the penalties of non-registration as coercion.

Article 12. After the expiration of the transition period, the following provisions shall apply:

(a) Registered privileges take precedence over unregistered privileges in any dispute or conflict between them;

(b) Unregistered privileges remain valid but are subject to the same uncertainties, disputes, and litigation that prevail under the current system;

(c) No unregistered privilege shall be deemed void solely by reason of non-registration, but neither shall it enjoy the unassailable protection afforded to registered privileges.

Title IV: Registration of Verbal and Customary Privileges

Article 13. Many privileges in the Kingdom of Aragon exist not in written form but in custom, tradition, and the memory of generations. Such privileges are no less valid for their lack of parchment.

Article 14. A house wishing to register a verbal or customary privilege may petition the Justicia for recognition. The petition shall include:

(a) A description of the privilege claimed;

(b) Evidence of its exercise over time, including the testimony of witnesses, the acknowledgment of neighbors, or other proof of long usage;

(c) Any documents, however informal, that reference the privilege.

Article 15. The Justicia's office shall examine such petitions and, if satisfied that the privilege has been genuinely exercised by custom, shall reduce it to writing and enter it in the Registry.

Article 16. A customary privilege once registered enjoys the same unassailable protection as a privilege derived from ancient charter. The act of registration makes real in law what was real in practice.

Article 17. The Justicia may require additional evidence, conduct inquiries, or hear testimony before approving the registration of customary privileges. This process shall be conducted fairly, without favor to great houses over lesser ones.

Title V: Later-Discovered Privileges

Article 18. It may occur that a privilege, long thought lost, is discovered after another conflicting privilege has been registered. In such cases, the following rules apply:

Article 19. A later-discovered privilege may still be registered in the Central Registry, provided it meets the requirements for registration and is not fraudulent.

Article 20. However, when a later-discovered privilege conflicts with an earlier-registered privilege, the earlier-registered privilege takes precedence. Priority of registration establishes priority of right in cases of conflict.

Article 21. This rule exists to prevent fraud and to protect those who registered in good faith. A house that discovers an ancient document purporting to grant rights already confirmed to another house cannot use that discovery to overturn settled expectations.

Article 22. In cases where the conflict is partial rather than total, the Justicia may seek to harmonize the privileges, preserving what can be preserved for both parties. Complete displacement of a registered privilege by a later discovery is not permitted.

Title VI: The Noble Oversight Committee

Article 23. To ensure the fair and impartial administration of the Registry, there shall be established a Committee of Oversight (Comitatus Custodiae), composed of three nobles of the realm.

Article 24. The members of the Committee shall be appointed by the Cortes, one from each of the noble estates: one from the ricos hombres, one from the caballeros, and one from the infanzones.

Article 25. Committee members shall serve terms of five years, rotating such that the composition changes gradually rather than all at once. No member may serve consecutive terms.

Article 26. The Committee shall have the following powers and duties:

(a) To review any decision of the Justicia's office regarding the registration or rejection of privileges;

(b) To hear appeals from houses dissatisfied with the handling of their registration;

(c) To investigate complaints of unfair treatment, favoritism, or corruption in the Registry's administration;

(d) To report annually to the Cortes on the state of the Registry.

Article 27. No privilege may be rejected for registration without the Committee's review and concurrence. The Justicia may approve registrations alone, but rejections require Committee confirmation.

Article 28. The Crown shall have no representative on the Committee. This is an Aragonese institution, maintained by Aragonese officers, overseen by Aragonese nobles, protecting Aragonese rights. Royal interference in the Committee's work is forbidden.

Title VII: The Independence of the Justicia

Article 29. The Office of the Justicia of Aragon, as guardian of the Registry and of the fueros themselves, must remain independent of royal influence.

Article 30. The King may not appoint, remove, direct, or discipline the Justicia or any officer of the Justicia's court in matters touching the Registry or the interpretation of the fueros.

Article 31. Any reforms to the Office of the Justicia—whether to strengthen its independence, expand its staff, improve its procedures, or otherwise alter its functioning—must originate from the noble estate and be approved by the Cortes. The Crown may not initiate such reforms.

Article 32. This provision exists because the King swears to uphold the fueros; he cannot also control the office that interprets and protects them. The guardian must be independent of the guarded.

Article 33. The King acknowledges that he cannot defend fueros he does not know exist. The Registry serves the Crown by making known what must be defended. But knowledge does not confer control; the King learns what he must uphold, not what he may challenge.

CLOSING OF BOOK IX

Let this Registry stand as a monument to Aragonese liberty. Let it protect the rights of the great and the small, the ancient houses and the new. Let it bring clarity where there was confusion, certainty where there was doubt, and peace where there was conflict.

And let any king who violates these provisions know that he breaks not merely a law, but a sacred compact with his people—and that an oath broken by one party binds not the other.

BOOK X: OF THE SACRED TITHE AND THE DEFENSE OF CHRISTENDOM
De Decimis Sacris et Defensione Christianitatis

PREAMBLE

Whereas the Holy Father Pope Innocent III granted to the kings of Spain the tercias reales—the royal third of the tithe—for the purpose of funding the sacred war against the enemies of Christ;

Whereas the Reconquista in Iberia is now complete, praised be God, but the enemies of Christ press ever closer to the heart of Christendom in the East;

Whereas Constantinople, the ancient seat of the Roman Empire and the guardian of Eastern Christianity, stands in mortal peril from the Ottoman Turk;

Whereas the clergy of Aragon, assembled in this Cortes, have acknowledged that the defense of Christendom is as sacred a cause today as it was when the tercias were first granted;

Whereas clarity is needed regarding the rights and obligations of Crown and Church in this matter;

Therefore, by the consent of the ecclesiastical estate and the Crown, we establish the following provisions.

Title I: The Right to the Tercias

Article 1. The Crown of Aragon affirms its right to the tercias reales—the royal third of the tithe—as granted by apostolic authority for the defense of the faith.

Article 2. This right shall be confirmed by petition to the Holy See, requesting clarification that the original grant remains in force for the defense of Christendom against the Ottoman threat, as it was in force for the defense against the Moorish threat.

Article 3. The Archbishop of Zaragoza, speaking for the clergy of Aragon, shall co-sign this petition, affirming the Church's support for the clarification.

Article 4. Until Rome has ruled, the existing arrangements regarding the tercias shall continue without alteration. This Book establishes principles for the future, not demands for the present.

Title II: Dedication to the Crusade

Article 5. The tercias collected under the authority of this Book shall be dedicated exclusively to the defense of Christendom against its enemies. This is a sacred trust, not a general revenue.

Article 6. A separate accounting shall be maintained for all tercias revenues, distinct from the ordinary treasury of the Crown. This accounting shall be called the Arca Sacra Cruciatae—the Sacred Treasury of the Crusade.

Article 7. Expenditures from the Sacred Treasury shall be limited to:

(a) The maintenance of armies and fleets engaged in the defense of Christian lands against infidel assault;

(b) The fortification of cities, harbors, and strongpoints essential to that defense;

(c) The support of Christian populations living under threat of conquest;

(d) The ransom of Christian captives held by infidel powers;

(e) Such other purposes as directly serve the defense of Christendom, as certified by the Archbishop of Zaragoza or his delegate.

Article 8. The tercias may not be used for wars between Christian princes, for the personal enrichment of the Crown, for the payment of ordinary government expenses, or for any purpose unconnected with the sacred cause for which they were granted.

Title III: Collection and Oversight

Article 9. The collection of tithes shall remain in the hands of Church officials, as is proper for sacred revenues. The Crown shall not replace ecclesiastical collectors with royal officers.

Article 10. However, the Crown may appoint auditors to work alongside Church collectors, verifying that the tercias are honestly calculated, properly separated, and faithfully remitted to the Sacred Treasury.

Article 11. These auditors shall be men of good character, preferably with ecclesiastical training or connections, who understand both the sacred nature of the tithe and the practical necessities of accurate accounting.

Article 12. The auditors shall have no authority to collect, only to observe and verify. They shall report discrepancies to both the Crown and the relevant bishop, who shall work together to resolve any irregularities.

Article 13. The Archbishop of Zaragoza, or a delegate appointed by him, shall have the right to inspect the Sacred Treasury's accounts at any time, ensuring that the revenues are spent only for their dedicated purpose.

Title IV: The Crown's Obligations

Article 14. In exchange for the Church's support regarding the tercias, the Crown acknowledges and affirms the following obligations:

Article 15. The Crown shall build and maintain churches in the lands recovered from infidel occupation in the East, providing for the spiritual needs of Christian settlers and the conversion of willing souls.

Article 16. The Crown shall build and maintain churches in the new lands discovered along the African coast and beyond, bringing the light of Christ to peoples who have never known His name.

Article 17. The Crown shall support the missionary endeavors of the religious orders, particularly those engaged in preaching to infidels and the ransoming of captives.

Article 18. The Crown shall defend the liberties of the Church in all its dominions, neither encroaching upon ecclesiastical jurisdiction nor permitting others to do so.

Article 19. These obligations are binding upon the King and all his successors. They are the price of the Church's support, and they shall be honored in perpetuity.

CLOSING OF BOOK X

Let the wealth of the faithful serve the defense of the faith. Let the tithe given to God return to God's purpose—the protection of His people against those who would destroy them. Let Crown and Church stand together in this sacred cause, each fulfilling its proper role, neither encroaching upon the other.

And let any king who diverts these sacred revenues to profane purposes know that he sins not only against the law, but against God Himself—and that such sin brings consequences both temporal and eternal.

BOOK XI: OF VOLUNTARY MUSTER FOR THE HOLY WAR
De Convocatione Voluntaria pro Bello Sacro

PREAMBLE

Whereas the Ottoman Turk threatens the destruction of Christian civilization in the East;

Whereas the Emperor of the Romans has called upon all Christian princes for aid in the defense of Constantinople and the restoration of lands stolen by the infidel;

Whereas His Majesty Don Juan, King of Aragon, holds also the title of Defensor Romaniae, charged by God and the Emperor with the coordination of the Western response to this threat;

Whereas the nobility of Aragon has expressed interest in participating in this sacred enterprise, but according to their ancient liberties rather than by royal compulsion;

Therefore, by the consent of all estates, we establish the following provisions for voluntary muster in the defense of Christendom.

Title I: The Principle of Voluntary Service

Article 1. No noble of Aragon shall be compelled to serve in the war against the Ottoman. The fueros protect the liberty of the nobility, and that liberty includes the freedom to choose one's wars.

Article 2. However, the Crown offers to all nobles of Aragon the opportunity to serve—and with that service, the opportunity to earn glory, titles, and estates in the lands to be recovered from infidel occupation.

Article 3. This is not a demand disguised as an offer. Nobles who decline to participate shall suffer no penalty, no disfavor, no diminishment of their rights or standing. They simply shall not share in the rewards reserved for those who risk blood and treasure in the sacred cause.

Article 4. The choice belongs to each noble house. Some will choose glory; some will choose safety. Both choices are lawful under the fueros.

Title II: The Mustering System

Article 5. For the purpose of organizing Aragonese participation in the Eastern war, mustering points shall be established within the realms of the Crown of Aragon.

Article 6. Each mustering point shall be overseen by a marshal (marescallus), who shall be a native of the realm in which the mustering point is located. Castilian marshals shall not command Aragonese musters; the fueros require that offices be held by natives of the realm.

Article 7. The marshals shall be appointed by the Crown from among nobles who have demonstrated military competence and administrative capability. The Cortes may advise on appointments, though final authority rests with the Crown.

Article 8. At each muster, the following shall be recorded:

(a) The name of each noble house contributing forces;

(b) The number and type of troops contributed;

(c) The equipment and readiness of those troops;

(d) Whether the noble claimant serves personally or sends forces under a deputy.

Article 9. These records shall be maintained with the same care as the Registry of Privileges, for they determine the claims of each house to the rewards of service.

Title III: Unified Command

Article 10. Those who present forces at muster agree to serve under unified command for the duration of the campaign. This is the price of participation.

Article 11. The purpose of unified command is not to diminish noble dignity, but to ensure victory. An army with a dozen independent captains, each pursuing his own glory, is not an army—it is a mob. The Ottoman has destroyed such forces before. He shall not be given the opportunity to do so again.

Article 12. Unified command means:

(a) Obedience to the orders of designated commanders in matters of strategy and tactics;

(b) Coordination with other contingents, whether Aragonese, Castilian, or from other Christian realms;

(c) Discipline in camp, on march, and in battle;

(d) Acceptance that individual glory is subordinate to collective victory.

Article 13. Nobles who cannot accept these conditions should not muster. There is no shame in remaining home; there is great shame in joining an army and then undermining its cohesion through disobedience or pride.

Title IV: The Constitution of Contributions and Claims

Article 14. The rewards for service shall be calculated according to the Constitutio de Contributionibus et Claimis, proclaimed at Constantinople in the year 1434 by His Majesty Don Juan and the Emperor John VIII Palaiologos.

Article 15. The key provisions of that Constitution, applicable to Aragonese participants, are as follows:

Article 16. Contribution Strength is calculated thus:

Contribution Strength = (Weighted Troop Value × Claim Multiplier) + Personal Service Bonus

Article 17. Troop Values:

| Troop Type | Minimum Equipment | Value |
|------------|-------------------|-------|
| Infantry | Spear, shield, helmet, padded jack or better | ×1 |
| Light Cavalry | Horse, lance or javelin, sword, helmet, leather or mail | ×3 |
| Heavy Cavalry / Knight | Warhorse, lance, sword, full mail or plate, shield | ×5 |

Article 18. Naval Values:

| Vessel Type | Requirements | Value |
|-------------|--------------|-------|
| War Galley | Fully crewed, armed marines, combat ready | 100 |
| Transport Galley | Crew present, fewer than 20 marines | 40 |
| Armed Merchant | Armed crew, defensible | 30 |
| Small Coastal Vessel | Armed, seaworthy | 10 |

Article 19. Claim Multiplier:

| Claim Type | Multiplier |
|------------|------------|
| Ancient/legitimate claim (predating 1204 or granted by legitimate Roman Emperor) | ×3 |
| No ancient claim, or claim derived from Latin Empire (1204-1261) | ×1 |

Article 20. Personal Service Bonus:

| Condition | Bonus |
|-----------|-------|
| Noble claimant fights personally | +20 |
| Noble claimant does not fight personally | +0 |

Note: "Fights personally" means present in the field for the campaign, bearing arms, subject to the same dangers as his men.

Title V: Titles and Estates

Article 21. The contribution system determines precedence in the granting of titles and estates in reconquered territories.

Article 22. Minimum thresholds for titles:

| Title | Minimum Contribution Strength |
|-------|------------------------------|
| Minor estate / village lordship | 25 |
| Prokathemenos (district administrator) | 50 |
| Kephale (provincial governor) | 100 |
| Doux (Duke / military governor) | 200 |
| Megas Doux or equivalent | 400 |

Article 23. These thresholds are guidelines. The Emperor and the Defensor Romaniae may adjust based on strategic necessity and the availability of territories.

Article 24. Claims accumulate across multiple years of service. A house that contributes modestly but consistently may eventually outrank a house that contributed greatly once and then withdrew.

Article 25. Sacrifice is honored. A house that loses all its men in faithful service retains full credit for that year's contribution. Losses suffered in battle do not reduce recorded contribution.

Title VI: Special Provisions for Aragon

Article 26. Certain provisions are specific to Aragonese participation:

Article 27. Aragonese forces shall muster at Aragonese mustering points, under Aragonese marshals, before joining the combined host. This preserves Aragonese identity and ensures compliance with the fueros.

Article 28. Aragonese nobles with ancient claims in the East—whether from the Catalan Company's time or earlier—may present those claims to the Tribunal established under the Constitution. Claims derived from the Latin Empire of 1204 are void, but legitimate earlier claims receive the ×3 multiplier.

Article 29. The language of command for Aragonese contingents shall be Catalan or Aragonese, as appropriate. Interpreters shall be provided for coordination with contingents speaking other tongues.

Article 30. Aragonese laws regarding the treatment of prisoners, the division of plunder, and the conduct of war shall be honored within Aragonese contingents, except where they conflict with the requirements of unified command or the laws of Christendom regarding just war.

CLOSING OF BOOK XI

Let those who seek glory find it in the defense of Christendom. Let those who seek estates earn them with blood and courage. Let those who prefer safety remain home without shame, for not all men are called to every war.

But let no man say he was not offered the opportunity. The door stands open. The path to honor is clear. Those who walk it will be remembered; those who do not will be forgotten.

Deus Vult.

FINAL ATTESTATION

These three Books—the Ninth, Tenth, and Eleventh—are hereby added to the Fueros de Aragón by the consent of His Majesty Don Juan, King of Aragon, Count of Barcelona, King of Valencia, and the four estates of the realm assembled in Cortes at Zaragoza.

They shall have the same force and dignity as the ancient fueros, and shall be interpreted according to the same principles: in favor of liberty, in protection of ancient rights, and against the expansion of arbitrary power.

Datum et actum in the City of Zaragoza, in the presence of the Cortes, in the year of Our Lord one thousand four hundred and thirty-seven.

Sealed by:

His Majesty Don Juan II
King of Aragon, Count of Barcelona, King of Valencia, King of Castile and León, Defensor Romaniae

Don Martín Díez de Aux
Justicia of Aragon

Don Dalmau de Mur
Archbishop of Zaragoza, speaking for the Ecclesiastical Estate

Don Lope Ximénez de Urrea
Speaking for the Estate of Ricos Hombres

Don Juan de Híjar
Speaking for the Estate of Caballeros

Don Berenguer de Montcada
Speaking for the Estate of the Cities

Finis

May God preserve the fueros.
May God preserve the realm.
May God preserve the king who keeps his oath.
May God grant victory to those who fight in His name.

laws.title: Combined Fleet Assessment of 1438
laws.summary: Strategic assessment of all naval forces available to the Crown across Castilian, Aragonese, and allied fleets, cataloguing vessel types, combat readiness, crew complements, and operational capacity for the planned eastern Mediterranean campaigns.

COMBINED FLEET ASSESSMENT

Fleet Status, Projections, and Strategic Capacity

January 1438 --- Toledo

Prepared by Diego de Daza, Royal Administrator, with Captain Fernán de
Vargas and Isaac de Baeza

Supersedes: Royal Naval Development Plan (April 1435)

PART I: STRATEGIC OVERVIEW

This assessment consolidates the naval resources of all kingdoms under
His Majesty Juan II's authority: Castile, Aragon (with Sicily and
Sardinia), Naples, and the Byzantine Empire, together with the
Portuguese fleet available through the Maritime Union of 1435. It
replaces the original Castilian naval development plan with a
comprehensive view of combined Christian naval power.

Primary Strategic Objectives

1. Defense of Constantinople: Maintain sufficient naval presence to
prevent Ottoman blockade and secure supply lines through the
Dardanelles.

2. Military Projection: Capacity to deploy 25,000-35,000 soldiers
from Iberia and Italy to the Eastern Mediterranean in a single campaign
season.

3. Settler Transport: Continue annual convoys supporting
Constantinople's population growth (target: 15,000-20,000 settlers
annually).

4. Naval Superiority: Maintain qualitative and quantitative
advantage over the Ottoman Imperial Fleet through 1445 and beyond.

PART II: CURRENT FLEET STATUS (January 1438)

A. Kingdom of Castile --- Royal Fleet

Status: 92% of April 1435 projections achieved. Losses to storms (2
naos) and one carrack in extended refit.

  Vessel Type    Projected   Actual   Notes

  Carracks           20              18           1 in refit (Esperanza), 1
                                                  lost

  Naos               25              22           2 lost to storm (Santa
                                                  Clara, San Bartolomé)

  War Galleys        13              13           On target

  Fishing/Utility    36              33           Minor shortfall

  Patrol Craft       14              14           On target

  TOTAL              108             100          92% of projection

B. Kingdom of Castile --- Military Orders Fleet

Status: Exceeded projections. The Orders invested heavily from their own
revenues.

PART IV: OTTOMAN FLEET COMPARISON

Galata, Rhodes correspondents). Sultan Murad II has invested seriously
in naval expansion since the Tenedos truce (1435).

(weeks vs. months).

settler convoys, no trade protection). Troops packed tightly for short

PART VI: CONSTANTINOPLE BASING CAPACITY

The Golden Horn provides one of the finest natural harbors in the
world---7.5 kilometers long, calm waters, no tides. The chain across the
mouth prevents enemy entry. However, basing a fleet requires more than
anchorage: wharves, warehouses, repair facilities, crew housing, and
supply infrastructure.

Current Capacity

Warships supportable with existing facilities: 30-40

The Neorion shipyard (three functional slipways) can service 4-6 vessels
at a time. Additional ships can anchor in the harbor but cannot be
maintained properly. Crew capacity: approximately 8,000-10,000 men
through winter. Constantinople's current population (\~85,000) can
absorb this garrison.

Approved Expansion Program

Investment: 80,000 florins over 3-5 years

Target capacity: 80 warships with full support

  ----------------------------------- ----------------- -----------------
  Improvement                     Cost            Timeline
                                      (florins)       

  Dredge silted harbors (Neorion,     15,000            1438-1439
  Prosphorion)

  Expand Neorion (2 additional        12,000            1439-1440
  slipways)                                             

  Naval warehouses (rope, canvas,     10,000            1438-1439
  tar, timber)                                          

  Crew barracks and facilities        8,000             1439-1441

  Reserve fund and contingency        10,000            Ongoing

  TOTAL                               80,000            1438-1443
  ----------------------------------- ----------------- -----------------

Strategic Implications

With 80-warship basing capacity at Constantinople, His Majesty can
station the combined fleet directly at the point of conflict. This
negates the Ottoman geographic advantage: our ships would be based where
the fighting occurs, not scattered across three seas requiring months to
concentrate.

Supply lines remain dependent on passage through the Dardanelles. While
the truce holds, convoys can resupply the Constantinople base. In
wartime, control of the Straits becomes essential.

PART VII: FLEET PROJECTIONS (1438-1443)

Combined Fleet Growth

  Year   Castile   Orders   Aragon   Naples   Constple   TOTAL

  1438       100           29           37           6            2              174

  1443       166           45           47           26           21             305

Note: Portuguese fleet (\~32 vessels) not included in projections as
growth depends on Prince Henry's exploration priorities. Approximately
12 vessels available for emergency summons throughout period.

Warship Growth (Combat Vessels Only)

  1441        34-36             110-115           \~150

  1442        38-40             120-125           \~165

  1443        42-44             130-135           \~180
  ----------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------------

SUMMARY

The combined Christian fleet under His Majesty's authority currently
numbers approximately 206 vessels, including 105 warships (22 carracks,
80+ war galleys). This provides numerical superiority over the Ottoman
fleet (\~85 vessels) and qualitative superiority through Western carrack
technology.

By 1443---two years before the Tenedos truce expires---the fleet will
grow to over 300 vessels with 180 warships, capable of deploying 35,000
soldiers to the Eastern Mediterranean in a single campaign season.

The approved Constantinople expansion (80,000 florins) will create
basing capacity for 80 warships, allowing concentration of forces at the
strategic center rather than scattered across three seas.

The fleet is built for His Majesty's purposes: the defense of
Constantinople, the projection of Christian power, and---when the time
comes---the defeat of the Ottoman Empire.

APPROVED BY ROYAL AUTHORITY

Juan II of Castile, León, Aragon, Sicily, Naples

Defensor Romaniae

Toledo, January 1438

KINGDOM OF CASTILE

Comprehensive Economic Development Plan

1434 --- 1440

Updated Summer 1438

Prepared by Diego de Daza, Chief Financial Administrator Under the
Authority of His Majesty King Juan II

I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Crown's economic development program, initiated in summer 1434, has
achieved exceptional results. The comprehensive assessment roll of 80
(Excellent) indicates that industries are performing at approximately
130% of original projections.

Key achievements include: paper mills generating 7,000 florins annually
(projected 5,000); the Ghent textile consortium producing 5,000 florins
annually with superior crimson dye techniques; Bilbao arms workshops
delivering 640 soldier's kits per year; and the wool breeding program
showing 15-20% finer clip quality, on pace to match English wool by
1445.

This document consolidates all existing initiatives, documents their
current status, and outlines the new investments approved for
1438-1440, totaling 56,400 florins in one-time expenditures and 10,800
florins in new annual costs.

II\. CROWN-OWNED INDUSTRIES

These industries are directly owned and operated by the Crown, with
revenues flowing to the royal treasury.

A. Paper Mills (Segovia & Toledo)

Status: EXCEPTIONAL SUCCESS \| Original Roll: 88 \| Performance:
140% of projections

  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------
  Metric             Detail

  Investment (1435)      10,000 florins total

  Annual Revenue (1438)  7,000 florins (projected 5,000)

  Combined Production    \~900 reams/year

  Apprentices Trained    14 Castilians (Martín de Ávila shows exceptional
                         talent)
  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------

The Two Mills:

-   Segovia Mill (Wilhelm Hartmann, German): 600 reams/year
    functional paper for correspondence, legal documents, ledgers

-   Toledo Mill (Marco da Pescia, Italian): 300 reams/year fine
    paper for royal documents, books, papal orders

Future Development: Third mill under consideration with
all-Castilian staff led by Martín de Ávila. Potential specialization in
navigational charts and maps.

B. Wool Breeding Program (Segovia/Extremadura)

Status: ON TRACK \| Original Roll: 42 \| Performance: Adequate,
meeting timeline

The Crown maintains royal breeding flocks with 16 smuggled English rams
(6 Ryelands, 5 Cotswolds, 5 Lincolns) crossed with 640 selected Merino
ewes.

-   Spring 1438 Results: First crossbred clip harvested showing
    15-20% finer fiber than baseline Merino

-   Projection: On pace to match English wool quality by 1445

-   Strategic Impact: Will enable domestic production of fine cloth
    rivaling Flemish quality

III\. CROWN-SUBSIDIZED INDUSTRIES

These industries are privately operated by foreign masters and their
consortiums, receiving Crown subsidies in exchange for knowledge
transfer and strategic production.

A. Textile Workshop --- Ghent Consortium (Segovia)

Status: EXCEPTIONAL SUCCESS \| Original Roll: 87 \| Performance:
143% of projections

  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------
  Metric             Detail

  Investment (1435)      5,500 florins (workshop 4,000 + housing 1,000 +
                         supplies 500)

  Annual Subsidy         500 florins (guaranteed purchases)

  Revenue (1438)         5,000 florins (projected 3,500)

  Apprentices            14 Castilians trained
  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------

The Ghent Masters:

-   Gillis de Coninck: Master weaver, leads consortium

-   Arnout van Steenbergen: Fulling and finishing specialist

-   Mathijs Coppens: Dyer --- has achieved superior crimson
    technique

Key Achievement: Complete cloth-making capability established.
Castile can now process wool from raw fiber to finished fabric
domestically.

Consortium Request (APPROVED): Permission to bring families
permanently to Castile. Hidalgía to be granted upon five years of
service. This cements their loyalty and ensures techniques remain in
Castile.

B. Arms & Armor Workshop --- Steinmann Consortium (Bilbao)

Status: STRONG SUCCESS \| Original Roll: 74 \| Performance:
107-128% of projections

  Annual Subsidy         3,500 florins (retainer 1,500 + guaranteed
                         purchases 2,000)

  Production (1438)      640 soldier's kits/year (projected 500-600)

  Reputation             "Bilbao steel" requested by name throughout
                         Mediterranean
  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------

The Augsburg Masters:

-   Heinrich Steinmann: Lead armorer --- "weapons for soldiers, not
    for display"

-   Brother-in-law: Blade-smith

-   Konrad Fels: Mail-maker

CRITICAL CONCERN: Heinrich Steinmann is age 57, hands beginning to
stiffen. Has requested a second master from Nuremberg for succession
planning. APPROVED --- recruitment authorized.

C. Glass Workshop --- Barbarigo (Burgos)

Status: STRONG SUCCESS --- NO LONGER SECRET \| Original Roll: 85 \|
Performance: 133% of projections

  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------
  Metric             Detail

  Investment (1434)      7,300 florins (smuggling 500 + workshop 6,000 +
                         housing 800)

  Annual Subsidy         1,200 florins (retainer 800 + security 400)

  Revenue (1438)         2,000 florins (projected 1,500)

  Quality                Cristallo equals Venetian work

  Apprentices            4 Castilians trained; 2 now produce credible
                         cristallo
  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------

The Master: Alessandro Barbarigo --- genuine Murano master of 19
years' experience, defected after Venice "disappeared" his son.

Status Change (Summer 1438): By royal decree, Barbarigo is no longer
hidden. He operates openly under Crown protection. The knowledge has
taken root in Castile --- secrecy no longer serves strategic purpose.

Venice Protocol: A diplomatic gift (500-800 florins of Castilian
goods) will be sent to Venice acknowledging their position but asserting
that Barbarigo is a free man in Castile. Royal charter declares any harm
to him an offense against the Crown.

IV\. TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES (ENHANCED)

A. Granada Silk Industry

Status: FULLY RECOVERED \| Pre-war capacity restored

-   All silk thread now woven into cloth domestically (previously 1/3
    sold raw to Genoese)

-   50 additional silk looms operational

-   Muslim craftsmen protected under amān, working productively

-   Additional Revenue: +3,500 florins annually from value capture

B. Córdoba Leather Industry

Status: EXPANDING \| Investment: 3,000 florins (1434)

-   Sumac plantations now maturing (3-5 year cycle completing)

-   New tannery facility outside Córdoba city operational

-   Guadamecí workshops established in Toledo and Seville

-   Additional Revenue: +3,000 florins annually

C. Seville Fishing Fleet

Status: EXPANDED \| Investment: 2,700 florins (1434)

-   10 Crown vessels leased to fishermen (ownership transfers after 20
    years)

-   Atlantic fishing routes established toward Canary Islands

-   Additional Revenue: +2,000 florins annually + 210 florins lease
    payments

D. Cannon Foundry (Seville)

Status: EXPANDING WITH CHALLENGES \| Expansion Roll: 23
(difficulties)

  ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
  Metric              1436                1438

  Production              8-10 guns/year          18-22 guns/year

  Skilled Workers         12                      24

  Furnaces                1                       2 (1 temperamental)
  ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------

Problems Identified: Second furnace has inconsistent heat causing
casting cracks. Bronze supply occasionally disrupted. Two apprentices
poached by Aragonese foundries.

Additional Investment (APPROVED): 6,000 florins one-time (master
founder recruitment 2,500 + domestic bronze supply 3,000 + apprentice
retention 500). Target: 30 guns/year by late 1439.

V. PROBLEM INDUSTRIES

A. Málaga Ceramics --- Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar

Status: CRITICAL --- KNOWLEDGE WILL BE LOST

Ibrahim al-Fakhkhar (age 77) is the sole surviving master of Málaga's
golden lusterware technique. His son Ahmad was killed defending the
Puerta de Granada during the conquest. His grandson Yusef fled to Fez.

Interventions Attempted:

1.  Personal letter from King Juan expressing grief and commissioning
    work (Roll 11 --- suspicious distance)

2.  Princess Catalina sent to Málaga to listen and ask why his art
    matters (Roll 37 --- crack in wall)

Ibrahim's Message: "Tell your king that beauty does not die with
the man who makes it. It dies when no one remembers why it mattered."

Catalina's Outcome: Ibrahim permitted the visit. He showed his
workshop but explained nothing. When leaving, he said: "You may come
again. If you wish."

Royal Decision: Ibrahim has made his choice. The Crown will honor
it. Future contact will be to honor his craft and legacy, not to
convince. When he passes, his art passes with him. This will be mourned
as something beautiful lost to the world.

VI\. NEW INVESTMENTS APPROVED (SUMMER 1438)

The following initiatives have been approved by His Majesty for
immediate implementation:

A. Textile Industry Grand Expansion

With the wool breeding program showing results and the Ghent
consortium's exceptional performance, Castile will dramatically expand
its textile capacity.

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Component                         One-Time     Annual

  Second workshop complex (Segovia)     6,000 fl         ---

  Additional 100 looms                  4,500 fl         ---

  Family relocation (12 families)       2,400 fl         ---

  Training facility                     2,000 fl         ---

  Dyeing expansion (Coppens crimson)    1,500 fl         ---

  Warehouse for wool storage            1,200 fl         ---

  Additional wages and retainers        ---              2,500 fl

  Materials and maintenance             ---              1,500 fl

  SUBTOTAL                          17,600 fl    4,000 fl
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

Strategic Vision: By 1445, Castile will have capacity to weave all
domestically-produced wool into cloth. No more exporting raw wool to
Flanders. Castile becomes a cloth exporter.

B. Naval Supplies Development

Current shipbuilding program strains existing capacity for rope, tar,
sailcloth, and timber. These investments reduce foreign dependence.

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Initiative                        One-Time     Annual

  Rope-walk expansion (Galicia)         3,000 fl         800 fl

  Tar kilns (Asturias)                  2,500 fl         600 fl

  Sailcloth workshop (Bilbao)           4,000 fl         1,000 fl

  Timber roads (Cantabria)              5,000 fl         ---

  SUBTOTAL                          14,500 fl    2,400 fl

C. Granada Mining Engineers

German mining engineers from Saxony and Tyrol have developed superior
extraction techniques. Investment pays for itself many times over.

  Recruitment of Saxon engineers (2-3)  4,000 fl         ---

Potential Return: If German techniques increase yield by 20%,

best investment available.

D. Printing Press Initiative

A revolutionary technology is emerging in Germany --- movable metal type
for printing books. This pairs perfectly with our paper mills and could
establish Castile as a center of innovation.

-   Phase 1 (1438-1439): Intelligence gathering --- agents to Mainz,
    Strasbourg to identify masters

-   Phase 2: Recruitment via German contacts (same network that
    found Steinmann)

-   Phase 3: Workshop establishment in Toledo near fine paper mill

Investment Authorized: 3,000 florins for recruitment efforts. Full
workshop investment (5,000-7,000 florins) approved upon successful

E. Steinmann Succession & Other Initiatives

  gift

VII\. FINANCIAL SUMMARY

A. New Investments Summary (1438)

  TOTAL BENEFIT                             \~27,000
  --------------------------------------------- -------------------------

Note: Infrastructure program concludes in 1438. From 1439, annual

Approved by Royal Authority

Juan II of Castile
