laws.title: Granada Silver Mining Operation
laws.summary: Establishes crown-directed silver mining operations in the Sierra Nevada and surrounding regions of the former Emirate, defining extraction rights, labor recruitment from resettled communities, revenue distribution between the crown and local administrators, and environmental provisions for the mining districts.
laws.full_text:
GRANADA SILVER MINING OPERATION

Comprehensive Administrative Charter

1438 --- 1443

Prepared by Diego de Daza, Chief Financial Administrator

Under the Authority of His Majesty King Juan II

I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

In the year of Our Lord 1438, silver deposits of extraordinary richness
were discovered near Lanteira in the Sierra Nevada mountains of Granada.
The discovery, secured by Don García López de Padilla, Governor of
Granada, represents a transformative blessing for the Crown of Castile.

The Crown has established an innovative mining system wherein the Crown
provides security, infrastructure, and refining facilities while
independent miners extract ore in exchange for thirty percent of the
yield. This model harnesses private enterprise while ensuring Crown
control of the critical bottleneck: the refineries that transform raw
ore into precious metal.

Initial operations in Q4 1438 generated 43,428 florins net revenue
from a single refinery operating at capacity for approximately six
weeks. Projections indicate annual net revenues of 250,000 to 300,000
florins by 1440---representing a 20-25% increase in total Crown
revenues.

A second refinery has been authorized for construction, with completion
targeted for summer 1439. Additionally, a Royal Mint will be established
in Toledo to convert the Crown's silver holdings into currency,
completing the chain from ore extraction to circulating coinage.

II\. THE DISCOVERY

A. Origin

The silver deposits were discovered by chance when a Moorish shepherd
reported unusual stones to local authorities. Don García López de
Padilla, recognizing the potential significance, immediately secured the
area and commissioned expert assessment.

Genoese mining assessors confirmed deposits of exceptional quality. The
ore body extends throughout the Lanteira district of the Sierra Nevada,
with veins reaching depths that suggest decades of productive
extraction.

B. Ore Quality

The Lanteira silver achieves 97% purity after refining---exceptional
by any standard, and possibly the finest in all Christendom. Master
Refiner Heinrich von Steinberg, with thirty-one years of experience in
the Freiberg mines of Saxony, declared upon examination:

"In thirty-one years, I have never seen ore like this."

The German ore requires three passes through the cupellation process;
Lanteira ore requires only two. The silver separates more cleanly,
producing metal of superior quality with reduced processing costs.

III\. THE MINING MODEL

A. The 70/30 Split

The Crown has established an innovative model that harnesses private
enterprise while maintaining fiscal control. The principle is simple:
ore is worthless until refined. By controlling the refineries, the
Crown controls the silver---regardless of who extracts it from the
ground.

Division of Yield:

-   Crown Share: 70% of all refined silver

-   Miner Share: 30% of all refined silver, paid directly upon
    processing

Crown Responsibilities:

-   Security forces (1,000 men under a Crown Marshall)

-   Road construction and maintenance

-   Refinery construction and operation

-   Administrative apparatus (registration, tribunals, inspectors)

-   Equipment rental for mining groups

Miner Responsibilities:

-   Extraction of ore

-   Transport of ore to refineries

-   Tools and personal supplies (available for rental)

-   Risk of finding productive veins

B. Equipment Rental System

Rather than providing loans to starting miners---which creates complex
debtor relationships---the Crown provides equipment rental. Mining
groups may lease tools, carts, and supplies for modest weekly fees. If a
group fails to find productive ore, they return the equipment and owe
nothing. This avoids the moral complexity of debt collection while
ensuring miners have access to necessary tools.

C. Miner Organization Requirements

All mining groups must comply with the following requirements:

1.  Registration: Every mining group must register with Crown
    administrators before commencing operations

2.  Leadership: Each group must have a designated registered leader
    responsible for the group's conduct

3.  Profit Distribution: Equal distribution of profits among group
    members is required; exploitation of workers is prohibited

4.  Defined Claims: Mining groups operate within defined claim areas
    assigned by Crown administrators

5.  Compliance: All groups must comply with tribunal rulings and
    Crown regulations

D. Dispute Resolution

A tribunal of three judges, rotating monthly, settles all disputes
regarding claims, ore weights, payments, and conduct. The tribunal's
authority is absolute within its jurisdiction. Harsh penalties apply for
theft, violence, and fraud. During the first month of operations, the
tribunal settled fourteen disputes; by month's end, this had dropped to
two or three---demonstrating that clear, consistent enforcement
establishes order rapidly.

IV\. KEY PERSONNEL

A. Master Refiner: Heinrich von Steinberg

  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------
  Age                53 years

  Origin             Freiberg, Saxony

  Experience         31 years; former Obersteiger of Himmelfahrt
                         mine; directed refining for Elector of Saxony

  Salary             400 florins per year, plus housing

  Bonus              0.5% of yield improvements attributable to his
                         methods

  Authority          Complete authority over all refining operations,
                         answerable only to the Crown
  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------

Team Composition:

-   12 journeymen from Saxony

-   2 masters of the pattinson process (silver-lead separation producing
    exceptional purity)

-   Personal library of metallurgical texts not available outside Saxony

-   Specialized tools and instruments of his own design

-   Expertise in ventilation systems preventing lung-sickness

B. Governor of Granada: Don García López de Padilla

Don García provides overall administrative oversight of the mining
district. He discovered and secured the deposits, recruited initial
labor, and coordinates with von Steinberg on operational matters. His
authority extends to maintaining order, enforcing Crown regulations, and
ensuring smooth integration of mining activities with broader Granadan
administration.

C. Additional Saxon Recruitment (Authorized)

Von Steinberg has requested additional journeymen from Saxony---8 to 10
men---to staff the second refinery. Recruitment cost: approximately
2,000 florins for travel and relocation. This request has been
approved.

V. INFRASTRUCTURE

A. Security

-   Force Strength: 1,000 men under a Crown Marshall

-   Fortifications: Key access points secured; construction
    completed 1438

-   Purpose: Maintain order, protect ore transport, prevent
    smuggling, enforce tribunal rulings

B. Roads

Roads capable of bearing heavy ore carts were completed by July
1438---ahead of schedule. The construction employed laborers from
Granada's population, providing honest wages and productive employment
to men who might otherwise have turned to banditry. The road network
connects mining areas to the central refinery.

C. Refineries

First Refinery (Operational August 1438):

-   Location selected by von Steinberg for proper drainage, water
    access, ventilation, and defensibility

-   Furnaces designed to von Steinberg's specifications

-   Operating at full capacity since October 1438

-   Ore carts now queue at gates---demand exceeds capacity

Second Refinery (APPROVED --- Target: Summer 1439):

-   Location: Two leagues north of first refinery, site identified by
    von Steinberg

-   Construction cost: 15,000 --- 18,000 florins

-   Will double processing capacity

-   Additional Saxon journeymen to staff (recruitment authorized)

VI\. 1438 OPERATIONS AND RESULTS

A. Timeline

  ------------------ ----------------------------------------------------
  Period         Milestone

  Spring 1438        Von Steinberg's party arrives from Saxony

  July 1438          Roads completed

  August 1438        First refinery operational; call for miners issued

  September 1438     2,000+ miners registered; tribunal established; 14
                     disputes settled first week

  October 1438       First ore carts arrive; refining begins; 97% purity
                     confirmed

  November 1438      Full capacity reached; ore carts queuing; second
                     refinery requested

  December 1438      Q4 accounts presented: 43,428 florins net revenue
  ------------------ ----------------------------------------------------

B. Q4 1438 Financial Results

  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------
  Item                                    Amount (Florins)

  Gross Crown Share (70% of yield)            \~62,000

  Less: Operating Costs                       (\~18,500)

  NET REVENUE TO CROWN                    43,428
  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------

Note: This represents approximately six weeks of refinery operations
at capacity from a single facility. The revenue from Q4 alone exceeds
the construction cost of the second refinery.

VII\. ROYAL MINT ESTABLISHMENT

To complete the chain from ore extraction to circulating currency, His
Majesty has authorized the establishment of a Royal Mint in Toledo.
The mint will convert the Crown's silver (and future African gold) into
standardized coinage.

A. Establishment Costs

  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------
  Component                               Cost (Florins)

  Secure facility (Toledo, near Alcázar)      8,000 --- 12,000

  Dies, presses, furnaces, scales, testing    4,000 --- 6,000
  equipment                                   

  Recruitment of master minters (Germany or   3,000 --- 5,000
  Italy)                                      

  Initial security arrangements               1,500 --- 2,000

  TOTAL ESTABLISHMENT                     16,500 --- 25,000
  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------

B. Annual Operating Costs

  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------
  Component                               Annual Cost (Florins)

  Master minter and senior staff (3-4 men)    800 --- 1,200

  Journeymen and workers (15-20 men)          1,500 --- 2,000

  Security detail                             600 --- 800

  Materials, maintenance, fuel                1,000 --- 1,500

  TOTAL ANNUAL                            3,900 --- 5,500
  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------

C. Seigniorage Revenue

A well-run mint producing 200,000 florins equivalent of currency
annually generates 4,000 to 8,000 florins in seigniorage
profit---the difference between face value and production cost. With the
Crown controlling its own silver supply at 97% purity (purchased at no
market cost), this margin increases considerably.

Net Effect: The mint is expected to be revenue-neutral or slightly
profitable even before considering the strategic value of controlling
currency production.

D. Timeline and Initial Production

-   Recruitment letters: Dispatched December 1438

-   Master minter arrival: Expected Spring 1439

-   Facility construction: Concurrent with recruitment

-   Mint operational: Late Summer or Autumn 1439

-   Initial production: Existing Castilian denominations (doblas in
    gold, reales in silver)

Note: The facility is designed for both gold and silver coinage. When
His Majesty determines the time is appropriate for new imperial
denominations, the dies can be changed within a day.

VIII\. FIVE-YEAR PROJECTIONS (1439-1443)

A. Mining Revenue Projections

  ------------ ---------------- ------------ ----------------- ---------------------
  Year     Refineries   Miners   Gross (70%)   Net Revenue

  1438 (Q4)    1                2,000+       \~62,000          43,428

  1439         2                3,500+       260,000-315,000   180,000-220,000

  1440         2                5,000+       360,000-430,000   250,000-300,000

  1441         2-3              6,000+       400,000-470,000   280,000-330,000

  1442         3                7,000+       430,000-500,000   300,000-350,000

  1443         3                8,000+       460,000-530,000   320,000-370,000
  ------------ ---------------- ------------ ----------------- ---------------------

B. Assumptions and Variables

Projections assume:

1.  Continued ore quality at current levels

2.  Steady growth in mining population as word spreads

3.  Second refinery operational by Summer 1439

4.  Potential third refinery by 1441 if demand warrants

5.  Operating costs remaining approximately 30% of gross Crown share

6.  No major disruptions (war, plague, geological problems)

Variables that could affect projections:

-   Upside: Veins prove even richer than assessed; Saxon engineers
    improve extraction efficiency; additional deposits discovered

-   Downside: Veins deplete faster than expected; labor disputes
    disrupt operations; Ottoman conflict affects security

C. Capital Investment Schedule

  ----------- --------------------------------------------- ----------------------
  Year    Investment                                Cost (fl)

  1438        Roads, first refinery, fortifications,        \~40,000
              initial setup                                 

  1439        Second refinery construction                  15,000-18,000

  1439        Additional Saxon journeymen recruitment       \~2,000

  1439        Royal Mint establishment (Toledo)             16,500-25,000

  1441        Third refinery (if warranted)                 \~18,000

  TOTAL   All capital investments 1438-1443         \~95,000-105,000
  ----------- --------------------------------------------- ----------------------

Return on Investment: Total capital investment of approximately
100,000 florins will be recovered within the first five to six months of
1439 operations. Thereafter, all net revenue represents pure gain to the
Crown.

D. Cumulative Five-Year Summary

  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------
  Metric                                  Amount (Florins)

  Total Capital Investment (1438-1443)        \~100,000

  Total Net Revenue (1438-1443, conservative) \~1,175,000

  Total Net Revenue (1438-1443, optimistic)   \~1,415,000

  FIVE-YEAR NET GAIN (conservative)       \~1,075,000

  FIVE-YEAR NET GAIN (optimistic)         \~1,315,000
  ------------------------------------------- ---------------------------

IX\. STRATEGIC SIGNIFICANCE

The Granada silver operation represents a transformation of the Crown's
financial position. At projected maturity (1440 onwards), the mining
operation alone will contribute 250,000 to 350,000 florins
annually---an increase of 20-30% over pre-discovery Crown
revenues.

This revenue enables:

-   Naval Expansion: Accelerated shipbuilding programs without
    straining other revenue sources

-   Military Readiness: Maintained standing forces and improved
    equipment without additional taxation

-   Constantinople Investment: Continued support for the eastern
    settlement program

-   Infrastructure Development: Roads, ports, and facilities across
    the realm

-   Industrial Investment: Continued development of textile, arms,
    and other industries

-   Currency Stability: A Crown-controlled mint producing
    standardized coinage

Perhaps most significantly, the silver provides the Crown with
strategic independence. Major initiatives need no longer depend on
loans from Italian bankers, grants from the Cortes, or special levies
that breed resentment. The Crown can act according to its judgment,
funded by its own resources.

Approved by Royal Authority

Juan II of Castile

Toledo, Winter 1438

Prepared by Diego de Daza

Chief Financial Administrator

laws.title: Great Patronage Program
laws.summary: Royal patronage program funding scholarly, artistic, and architectural projects across the realm, establishing stipends for university scholars, commissions for cathedral construction, support for manuscript copying and translation, and the development of a court culture befitting an imperial monarchy.
laws.full_text:
THE GREAT PATRONAGE

A Program for the Beautification of the Realm

1438 --- 1442

With Perpetual Continuation Thereafter

Prepared by Diego de Daza, Chief Financial Administrator

ROYAL DECLARATION

"Art is not only beautiful, it is also functional. A great painting
either teaches or commemorates a great occasion. A great sculpture might
inspire the soul to Christian morals. There should always be a POINT to
art. A beautiful painting of just a landscape could be a vision of the
kingdom of heaven, the world as it should be, something to fight for.

I will start a great art patronage program. From this day on, the Crown
will make the lands beautiful, so the life of everyone might be a little
bit more uplifted, a bit more happy.

The rich and the poor, we are all equal before God. We are not equal in
this world, but a beautiful song lifts the spirit as much for a king as
it does for a beggar."

--- His Majesty King Juan II, Summer 1438

I. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

His Majesty has committed 400,000 florins over four years (100,000
florins annually from 1438-1442) to transform Castile from a kingdom of
warriors into a kingdom of beauty. Following this initial period, a
permanent annual budget of 80,000 florins will sustain the arts in
perpetuity.

The program encompasses seven major categories:

1.  The Royal Chapel of Sound --- A church built for acoustics, open
    to all

2.  The Bridges of Saints --- Statues adorning the great crossings
    of the realm

3.  The Toledo Approaches --- Beautiful roads, shrines, and
    monuments welcoming visitors

4.  The Cathedral Works --- Granada new-built, Seville accelerated,
    Burgos crowned

5.  The Altarpiece Program --- Sacred art for churches throughout
    the realm

6.  Public Monuments --- Fountains, statues, and beauty in common
    spaces

7.  Recruitment and Training --- Foreign masters, Castilian students
    abroad, workshops

II\. FOUR-YEAR BUDGET OVERVIEW

  ------------------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- -------------
  Category              Year 1    Year 2    Year 3    Year 4

  Royal Chapel of Sound     25,000        20,000        8,000         5,000

  Bridges of Saints         3,000         4,000         3,500         2,500

  Toledo Approaches         8,000         10,000        6,000         4,000

  Cathedral Works           20,000        25,000        30,000        30,000

  Altarpiece Program        8,000         12,000        15,000        18,000

  Public Monuments          6,000         9,000         12,000        12,000

  Recruitment & Training    25,000        15,000        15,000        18,000

  Contingency &             5,000         5,000         10,500        10,500
  Administration                                                      

  ANNUAL TOTAL          100,000   100,000   100,000   100,000
  ------------------------- ------------- ------------- ------------- -------------

Four-Year Total: 400,000 florins

III\. THE ROYAL CHAPEL OF SOUND

Purpose: A church built for acoustics, where music rises to heaven
as it was meant to. Open to all---rich and poor alike---because a
beautiful song lifts the spirit as much for a king as for a beggar.

Location: Toledo, near the Puente de San Martín, so that pilgrims
crossing the bridge of saints may enter directly into sacred sound.

A. The Building

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Component                         Year         Cost (fl)

  Architect recruitment (Italy)         1                2,000

  Site preparation and foundations      1                5,000

  Main construction (walls, vaulting    1-2              25,000
  for acoustics)                                         

  Interior finishing (carved choir      2-3              8,000
  stalls, altar)                                         

  Great organ (Flemish or German        2-3              4,000
  master)                                                

  SUBTOTAL: Building                                 44,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

B. The Musical Institution

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Component                         Year         Cost (fl)

  Maestro de Capilla recruitment        1                1,500
  (Burgundy/Italy)                                       

  Choir establishment (30 voices: boys  1                3,000
  and men)                                               

  Instruments (viols, shawms, sackbuts, 1-2              2,500
  portative organs)                                      

  Music copying and library             1-2              1,000
  establishment                                          

  Boy choir school (housing, education) 1-4              6,000

  SUBTOTAL: Musical Institution                      14,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

C. Ongoing Operations (from Year 3)

Once established, the Royal Chapel requires approximately 5,000
florins annually for:

-   Maestro de Capilla salary: 300 florins/year

-   Adult singers (12-15 men): 1,200 florins/year

-   Boy choir maintenance and education: 1,500 florins/year

-   Instrumentalists (6-8 men): 800 florins/year

-   Music copying, instrument maintenance: 400 florins/year

-   Building maintenance: 800 florins/year

TOTAL ROYAL CHAPEL (4 Years): 58,000 florins

IV\. THE BRIDGES OF SAINTS

Purpose: Every person entering the great cities of Castile crosses a
bridge. Saints watching over travelers bless their journeys and declare
that this is a Christian kingdom of beauty, not merely soldiers who won
a war.

A. Bridge Projects by Location

  --------------------- ----------- ------------- ---------- ------------ --------------
  Bridge            City    Statues   Year   Cost       Material
                                                             (fl)       

  Puente de San Martín  Toledo      12            1-2        2,400        Marble

  Puente de Alcántara   Toledo      8             2          1,600        Marble

  Puente Romano         Córdoba     16            2-3        2,400        Limestone

  Puente Romano         Salamanca   10            3          1,500        Limestone

  Puente de Piedra      Zamora      8             3-4        1,200        Limestone

  Puente Mayor          Burgos      8             4          1,200        Limestone

  Installation &        Various     ---           1-4        2,700        ---
  pedestals                                                               

  TOTAL                         62                   13,000   
  --------------------- ----------- ------------- ---------- ------------ --------------

Saints to be depicted: The Twelve Apostles, the Four Evangelists,
Saints James (Santiago), Isidore of Seville, Ferdinand III (recently
canonized), the Virgin Mary, and local patron saints as appropriate to
each city.

V. THE TOLEDO APPROACHES

Purpose: The experience of entering Toledo should begin a mile
before the city walls. Paved roads, planted trees, wayside shrines---a
sequence of beauty that prepares the soul for what awaits within.

A. Road Improvements

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Component                         Year         Cost (fl)

  Western approach paving (1 mile to    1-2              4,000
  San Martín)                                            

  Eastern approach paving (1 mile to    2-3              4,000
  Alcántara)                                             

  Tree planting (cypresses, olive       1-2              1,500
  trees)                                                 

  Wayside shrines (12 total, 6 per      1-3              3,600
  approach)                                              

  Rest stations with fountains (4       2-3              4,000
  total)                                                 

  Welcome monuments at approach         3-4              3,000
  entrances (2)                                          

  Clearance of hovels and unsightly     1                2,000
  structures                                             

  Relocation assistance for displaced   1                3,000
  residents                                              

  Ongoing maintenance fund              3-4              2,900

  TOTAL TOLEDO APPROACHES                            28,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

VI\. THE CATHEDRAL WORKS

Purpose: The great cathedrals declare the faith of a kingdom.
Granada requires a cathedral worthy of the conquest. Seville's vast
project deserves royal support. Burgos awaits the crowning of its
spires.

A. Granada Cathedral (New Construction)

The converted mosque serves its purpose, but Granada deserves a
purpose-built cathedral---a monument to the completion of the
Reconquista. This is a generational project; the four-year budget begins
the work.

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Phase                             Year         Crown
                                                         Contribution

  Architect competition and selection   1-2              3,000

  Site preparation and foundations      2-3              15,000

  Initial construction (walls begin     3-4              30,000
  rising)                                                

  4-Year Total (Granada)                             48,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

Note: Complete construction will require 30-50 years and contributions
from Church revenues, noble donors, and ongoing Crown support. The
four-year budget establishes the foundation; the perpetual budget
continues the work.

B. Seville Cathedral (Acceleration)

Construction began in 1401 on the site of the former Almohad mosque.
When complete, it will be the largest Gothic cathedral in the world.
Royal contributions will accelerate the work.

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Contribution                      Year         Amount (fl)

  Annual royal contribution             1-4              5,000/year

  4-Year Total (Seville)                             20,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

C. Burgos Cathedral (Spire Completion)

The spires of Burgos Cathedral were planned by the original French
masters but never completed. Royal patronage will finally crown this
ancient seat of Castilian Christianity.

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Work                              Year         Amount (fl)

  Master mason recruitment (German      1                2,000
  Gothic specialist)                                     

  Spire construction contribution       2-4              25,000

  4-Year Total (Burgos)                              27,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

D. Toledo Cathedral (Enhancement)

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Work                              Year         Amount (fl)

  Chapel beautification and new         1-2              5,000
  altarpiece                                             

  Cloister enhancement                  3-4              5,000

  4-Year Total (Toledo)                              10,000
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

TOTAL CATHEDRAL WORKS (4 Years): 105,000 florins

VII\. THE ALTARPIECE PROGRAM

Purpose: Sacred art in every church---the Bible of the poor. Those
who cannot read may learn the stories of Christ and the saints through
images. A shepherd in Extremadura and a fisherman in Galicia should both
see beauty when they pray.

A. Program Structure

Altarpieces will be commissioned in three tiers based on church size and
prominence:

-   Grand Altarpieces (cathedrals, major churches): 800-1,500
    florins each. Multiple panels, gold leaf, finest pigments, master
    painters.

-   Standard Altarpieces (parish churches, urban areas): 200-500
    florins each. Skilled journeyman work, good quality materials.

-   Simple Altarpieces (village churches, rural chapels): 50-150
    florins each. Apprentice work under master supervision, basic but
    dignified.

B. Four-Year Rollout

  ----------- --------------- ----------- -------------- ------------ ------------
  Year    Focus         Grand   Standard   Simple   Budget
              Region                                                

  1           Toledo &        2           10             20           8,000
              environs                                                

  2           Seville,        3           15             30           12,000
              Burgos,                                                 
              Valladolid                                              

  3           Córdoba,        3           20             40           15,000
              Granada,                                                
              Segovia                                                 

  4           Provincial      4           25             60           18,000
              expansion                                               

  Total                   12      70         150      53,000
  ----------- --------------- ----------- -------------- ------------ ------------

Four-Year Output: 232 altarpieces placed in churches across Castile,
bringing sacred art to hundreds of thousands of faithful.

VIII\. PUBLIC MONUMENTS

Purpose: Beauty in common spaces---fountains in market squares,
statues at city gates, carved reliefs commemorating great events. Art
that speaks to everyone who passes, declaring that Castile is civilized,
heir to Rome and Greece.

A. Categories of Work

  -------------------------- --------------- --------------- --------------
  Type                   Unit Cost   4-Year Qty  Total

  Grand fountains (major     2,000-3,000     4               10,000
  plazas)                                                    

  Simple fountains (market   400-800         15              9,000
  squares)                                                   

  Gate statues (city         150-300         30              6,000
  entrances)                                                 

  Commemorative reliefs      500-1,000       8               6,000

  Market cross monuments     200-400         25              8,000

  TOTAL PUBLIC MONUMENTS                                 39,000
  -------------------------- --------------- --------------- --------------

IX\. RECRUITMENT AND TRAINING

Purpose: A tradition of art cannot be purchased; it must be grown.
We must import masters to teach, send our talented young abroad to
learn, and establish workshops where Castilian apprentices train until
they surpass their teachers.

A. Foreign Master Recruitment

  -------------------------- ------------------- --------------- -----------------
  Specialty              Origin          Number      Recruitment
                                                                 Cost

  Painters (panel, fresco)   Italy/Flanders      4-6             12,000

  Sculptors (stone, wood)    Italy/Germany       3-4             8,000

  Architects                 Italy               2-3             6,000

  Illuminators               Flanders/Burgundy   2               3,000

  Organ builders             Germany/Flanders    1-2             2,500

  Subtotal Recruitment                       12-17       31,500
  -------------------------- ------------------- --------------- -----------------

B. Castilian Students Abroad

Talented young Castilians---identified through guild recommendations,
Church schools, and noble households---will be sent to study in
Florence, Rome, Bruges, and other centers of artistic excellence.

  ----------------------------------- ------------------- -----------------
  Program                         Students/Year   Annual Cost

  Painting students (Florence, Rome)  6-8                 2,400

  Sculpture students (Florence, Rome) 4-6                 1,800

  Architecture students (Rome)        2-3                 900

  Music students (Burgundy)           3-4                 1,200

  Annual Subtotal                 15-21           6,300

  Four-Year Total (Students)                          25,200
  ----------------------------------- ------------------- -----------------

C. Workshop Establishment

  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------
  Facility                          Year         Cost

  Royal Painting Workshop (Toledo)      1-2              4,000

  Royal Sculpture Workshop (Toledo)     2-3              3,500

  Royal Academy of Arts (Year 4)        4                8,800

  Subtotal Workshops                                 16,300
  ------------------------------------- ---------------- ----------------

TOTAL RECRUITMENT & TRAINING (4 Years): 73,000 florins

X. PERPETUAL BUDGET (FROM YEAR 5)

Following the initial four-year investment, the Great Patronage
continues with a permanent annual budget of 80,000 florins. This
ensures artists can build lives in Castile knowing their work will
continue.

  --------------------------------------------- -------------------------
  Category                                  Annual Budget

  Royal Chapel operations                       5,000

  Cathedral works continuation (Granada,        25,000
  others)                                       

  Altarpiece program continuation               15,000

  Public monuments expansion                    10,000

  Training & student stipends                   8,000

  Royal Academy of Arts operations              6,000

  Master retainers and salaries                 6,000

  Maintenance of completed works                3,000

  Contingency and administration                2,000

  PERPETUAL ANNUAL TOTAL                    80,000
  --------------------------------------------- -------------------------

Approved by Royal Authority

Juan II of Castile

Toledo, Summer 1438

Prepared by Diego de Daza

Chief Financial Administrator

"From this day on, the Crown will make the lands beautiful, so the
life of everyone might be a little bit more uplifted, a bit more
happy."

laws.title: Imperial Population Census of 1438
laws.summary: Comprehensive population census across all territories of the Crown including Castile, Aragon, Naples, Sicily, and Constantinople, recording household counts, occupational data, tax capacity, and military-age males to inform revenue projections and mobilization planning.
laws.full_text:
Census of Christian Realms

Prepared for His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León, Defensor
Romaniae

Summer 1438

Introduction

This census provides estimates of population across the realms under
Your Majesty's influence or protection, compiled from tax records,
ecclesiastical surveys, and administrative reports. The figures reflect
conditions as of Summer 1438, accounting for the effects of the Black
Death's lingering impact, the Reconquista's completion, and ongoing
settlement programs.

Population recovery from the great mortality of 1348-1350 continues
throughout Christendom. The Iberian peninsula lost an estimated sixty
percent of its inhabitants during that calamity, and recovery has been
gradual. Your Majesty's economic development programs and the
settlement of Constantinople have accelerated growth in key regions.

Part I: The Iberian Peninsula

Crown of Castile

The Crown of Castile remains the most populous realm in Iberia,
encompassing Old Castile, New Castile, León, Galicia, Asturias,
Extremadura, Andalusia, and the newly conquered Emirate of Granada.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Region                      Population   Notes
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Old Castile (Burgos, Segovia,   650,000          Core heartland, stable
  Ávila, Valladolid)                               growth

  New Castile (Toledo, Madrid,    480,000          Economic development
  Cuenca)                                          zone

  León and Zamora                 320,000          Traditional settlement

  Galicia                         380,000          Maritime population

  Asturias and Cantabria          120,000          Mountain communities

  Extremadura                     180,000          Frontier zone, Military
                                                   Orders

  Andalusia (Seville, Córdoba,    520,000          Fertile lands, trade
  Jaén)                                            centers

  Murcia                          90,000           Border region

  Basque Provinces (Vizcaya,      140,000          Iron industry,
  Guipúzcoa)                                       seafaring

  Granada (formerly Nasrid        185,000          Muslim majority; silver
  Emirate)                                         discovery

  CASTILE TOTAL               3,065,000    
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Granada Note: The conquest of 1433 disrupted population patterns
significantly. Many Muslims fled to North Africa, while Christian
settlers from northern Castile have begun arriving. The discovery of the
Lanteira silver deposits is attracting additional migration. The Muslim
population remains approximately 140,000, with 45,000 Christians
(including new settlers and Mozarabs).

Crown of Aragon

The Crown of Aragon comprises the Kingdom of Aragon proper, the
Principality of Catalonia, the Kingdom of Valencia, and the Balearic
Islands. King Alfonso V currently campaigns in Italy.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Region                      Population   Notes
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Kingdom of Aragon               200,000          Mountainous; fueros
                                                   tradition

  Principality of Catalonia       260,000          Barcelona \~35,000;
                                                   commerce

  Kingdom of Valencia             210,000          Significant Mudéjar
                                                   population

  Balearic Islands (Mallorca,     45,000           Maritime trade
  Menorca, Ibiza)                                  

  ARAGON TOTAL                715,000      
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Kingdom of Portugal

Portugal under King Duarte I maintains close alliance with Castile
through the Maritime Accord. The kingdom focuses increasingly on
Atlantic exploration and African trade.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Region                      Population   Notes
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Entre-Douro-e-Minho             240,000          Densest settlement

  Trás-os-Montes and Beira        180,000          Interior highlands

  Estremadura and Lisbon          220,000          Lisbon \~40,000; royal
                                                   capital

  Alentejo                        120,000          Grain-producing plains

  PORTUGAL TOTAL              810,000

Kingdom of Navarre

The small mountain kingdom remains under the House of Évreux with close
ties to France. Its strategic position astride the Pyrenean passes gives
it importance beyond its population.

  Kingdom of Navarre                      95,000           2.0%

  IBERIAN TOTAL                       4,685,000    100%
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Part II: Italian Territories

Kingdom of Naples

The Kingdom of Naples (Kingdom of Sicily citra Pharum) encompasses
southern Italy from the Papal States to Calabria. King Alfonso V claimed
the throne in 1442 following Queen Giovanna II's death in 1435, though
his position remains contested by René of Anjou.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Region                      Population   Notes
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Terra di Lavoro (incl. Naples   320,000          Naples \~80,000;
  city)                                            capital

  Principato (Salerno region)     140,000          Amalfi coast

  Apulia                          240,000          Grain-producing; ports

  Calabria                        180,000          Greek communities
                                                   remain

  Abruzzo and Molise              150,000          Mountain regions

  Basilicata                      70,000           Interior highlands

  NAPLES TOTAL                1,100,000    
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Kingdom of Sicily (Island)

The island of Sicily (Kingdom of Sicily ultra Pharum) has been under
Aragonese rule since 1282. The Black Death struck severely here, and
population has yet to recover fully. The island serves as a granary for
the Mediterranean and a strategic naval base.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Region                      Population   Notes
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Val di Mazara (western)         180,000          Palermo \~25,000

  Val Demone (northeastern)       150,000          Messina \~20,000

  Val di Noto (southeastern)      120,000          Catania, Syracuse

  SICILY TOTAL                450,000      
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Part III: Constantinople and the Eastern Territories

Imperial City of Constantinople

Constantinople has experienced remarkable recovery under the
Apokatastasis settlement program. When Your Majesty assumed the title of
Defensor Romaniae in 1434, the city held barely 40,000 souls within
walls built for half a million. The extraordinary success of the
settlement campaign (witnessed by Divine Providence) has transformed the
demographic picture.

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Population Category         Estimate    Notes
  ------------------------------- --------------- -----------------------
  Greek Orthodox (native)         38,000          Original inhabitants

  Latin Settlers (Iberian)        28,000          Military Orders,
                                                  families

  Latin Settlers (Italian)        12,000          Venice, Genoa, other
                                                  cities

  Military Garrison               4,000           Military Orders +
                                                  auxiliaries

  Jews and Others                 3,000           Various communities

  CONSTANTINOPLE TOTAL        85,000      Growing rapidly
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Settlement Program Impact: The 1434 settlement campaign yielded
extraordinary results. Over 5,000 Latin settlers arrived in the first
two years alone. The Military Orders have established permanent
commanderies, and entire extended families have relocated from Iberia.
Greeks and Latins are beginning to intermarry, and the Apokatastasis has
transformed from decree to lived reality. The Sultan has noted the
city's recovery with concern.

Remaining Byzantine Territories

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Territory                   Population   Notes
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Despotate of the Morea          80,000           Constantine Palaiologos

  Thracian Villages (Byzantine)   5,000            Near Constantinople

  BYZANTINE TOTAL             170,000      Including
                                                   Constantinople
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Part IV: Overseas Territories and Outposts

Atlantic Islands and African Coast

Portuguese exploration continues to establish outposts along the African
coast, while settlement of the Atlantic islands progresses. Castile
maintains interest in the Canary Islands.

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Territory                   Population   Status
  ------------------------------- ---------------- -----------------------
  Ceuta (Portuguese)              2,500            Garrison and settlers
                                                   (1415)

  Madeira (Portuguese)            1,200            Active colonization

  Porto Santo (Portuguese)        400              First Atlantic
                                                   settlement

  Azores (Portuguese)             600              Settlement beginning

  Canary Islands (various)        \~80,000         Native Guanche +
                                                   settlers

  African Coast Outposts          500              Trading posts,
                                                   transient

  OVERSEAS TOTAL              \~85,000     Mostly Canary natives
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Part V: Grand Summary

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Realm/Territory                 Population    Relationship to
                                                        Crown
  ----------------------------------- ----------------- ------------------
  Crown of Castile                    3,065,000         Direct rule

  Crown of Aragon                     715,000           Allied (Alfonso V)

  Kingdom of Portugal                 810,000           Allied (Duarte I)

  Kingdom of Navarre                  95,000            Independent

  Kingdom of Naples                   1,100,000         Alfonso V (heir
                                                        presumptive)

  Kingdom of Sicily (island)          450,000           Aragonese (Alfonso
                                                        V)

  Byzantine Territories               170,000           Protected
                                                        (Defensor)

  Overseas Territories                85,000            Various

  TOTAL ALL TERRITORIES           6,490,000     
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Of this total: Approximately 3,065,000 souls (47%) are under Your
Majesty's direct rule in Castile. An additional 1,635,000 (25%) are
under allied Aragonese rule in Aragon, Naples, and Sicily. Some 810,000
(12.5%) are under allied Portuguese rule. The remaining 980,000 (15%)
are in various states of independence, protection, or transition.

Part VI: Five-Year Population Projections (1438-1443)

Population growth in this era averages 0.5-1.0% annually under favorable
conditions, though this varies considerably by region. Active settlement
programs, economic development, and stable governance can accelerate
growth, while war, plague, or famine cause sharp declines. The following
projections assume continued peace and current development policies.

  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Territory         1438     1439     1440     1442     1443
  --------------------- ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------ ------------
  Crown of Castile      3,065K       3,096K       3,127K       3,190K       3,222K

  --- Granada alone     185K         192K         200K         215K         225K

  Crown of Aragon       715K         719K         723K         730K         734K

  Portugal              810K         818K         826K         843K         851K

  Navarre               95K          95.5K        96K          97K          97.5K

  Naples                1,100K       1,106K       1,111K       1,122K       1,128K

  Sicily                450K         452K         454K         459K         461K

  Constantinople        85K          95K          105K         125K         135K

  Byzantine Other       85K          86K          87K          89K          90K

  TOTAL             6,490K   6,568K   6,629K   6,755K   6,719K
  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Key Growth Factors:

Granada: The silver discovery at Lanteira is attracting miners and
their families. Continued Christian settlement from northern Castile.
Growth rate approximately 3-4% annually---the highest in Iberia.

Constantinople: Active settlement program continues drawing Iberian
and Italian families. Military Orders expanding presence. Growth rate
approximately 10-12% annually through migration---extraordinary but
dependent on continued Ottoman truce.

Portugal: Atlantic exploration providing outlet for population
pressure. Growth steady at approximately 1% annually.

Risk Factors: Plague recurrence remains the greatest threat---any
outbreak could reverse years of growth. The Ottoman truce expires in
1445; warfare would devastate Constantinople's recovery. Aragonese
involvement in Italian conflicts could affect Naples and Sicily
populations through military losses and economic disruption.

Conclusion

By 1443, should current trends continue, the population of territories
under Your Majesty's direct rule, alliance, or protection may approach
6.7 to 6.8 million souls. Castile alone should exceed 3.2 million.
Constantinople, if the settlement program maintains its momentum, could
reach 130,000-140,000---approaching a third of its ancient glory.

The completion of the Reconquista in 1433 was not merely a military
triumph but a demographic foundation. The fertile lands of Granada, now
augmented by silver wealth, will draw settlers for generations. The
Apokatastasis represents a similar foundation for the East---the
beginning of a new Latin-Greek civilization in the heart of the ancient
Roman world.

Prepared by the Office of Royal Administration under the direction of
Don Diego de Daza.

Submitted to His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León, Defensor
Romaniae, in the Year of Our Lord 1438.

laws.title: Imperial Muster Plan of 1438
laws.summary: Mobilization plan for assembling military forces across all Crown territories for the planned eastern crusade, specifying troop quotas by region, assembly points, supply chains, equipment standards, and the command structure for an integrated multi-kingdom army.
laws.full_text:
IMPERIAL MUSTER PLAN

Ordo Convocationis Imperialis

Summer 1438

Issued by Royal Decree of Juan II, King of Castile, León, Aragon,
Naples, and Sicily, Defensor Romaniae

I. PURPOSE AND SCOPE

This document establishes the operational framework for the Second
Imperial Muster, to be conducted across all territories under the Crown
during Summer 1438. The muster serves three purposes:

1.  To test and refine the voluntary muster system established in 1437

2.  To train officers and men in coordinated movement and field
    operations

3.  To build unity across territories through shared experience and
    celebration

The First Muster (1437) produced an extraordinary response of 12,437
men across all territories. This second muster will test whether these
forces can execute coordinated operations under unified command.

II\. COMMAND STRUCTURE

Central Administration

-   Don Álvaro de Luna --- Head of Imperial Administration

-   Diego de Daza --- Chief Administrator, reporting standards and
    logistics

-   Sir Thomas Beaumont --- War Academy coordination, officer
    deployment

Royal Participation

His Majesty King Juan II will personally command the Toledo muster,
marching with the troops to Arévalo and commanding the cavalry during
field exercises. Prince Fernando, Prince of Asturias (age 4) and
Princess Catalina (age 6) will accompany the King, demonstrating the
Trastámara commitment to shared service.

Academy Officers

All graduates of the Royal Military Academy (43 officers) plus current
senior cadets (22) will be deployed across the fifteen exercises. Each
endpoint will receive 3-4 academy-trained personnel serving as either
commanders or observers. Officers will submit written assessments of
each exercise within fourteen days of completion.

III\. OPERATIONAL CONCEPT

Phase One: Assembly

Men assemble at designated mustering points. Officers conduct roll call
and organize units into march formations. Destination is revealed only
after assembly is complete---testing officers' ability to lead under
uncertainty.

Phase Two: March

Each muster conducts a 3-5 day march to its assigned destination. Routes
are chosen to present varied terrain challenges: river crossings,
mountain passes, forced marches, and night movements as appropriate.
Local commanders bear full responsibility for march discipline, supply,
and timing.

Phase Three: Combination

Where possible, two musters converge at a single destination. Men from
different regions meet, learn to form combined units, and recognize
themselves as part of a unified imperial force rather than separate
regional levies.

Phase Four: Field Exercises

Upon arrival at the destination, forces assemble immediately into battle
formations. Standardized drills are conducted:

1.  Infantry Defensive Formation --- Units form defensive square or
    line on command

2.  Ranged Volley --- Crossbow and archer formations advance and
    loose at marked targets

3.  Cavalry Maneuver --- Mounted units execute flanking movement on
    signal

4.  Artillery Demonstration --- Where available, field cannon fired
    2-3 times (supervised by academy officers)

Phase Five: Celebration

Following successful completion of exercises, the Crown provides a feast
for all participants. Food and drink are purchased locally at fair
prices, stimulating the regional economy. The muster concludes with men
departing in good spirits, having accomplished something meaningful
together.

IV\. MUSTERING POINTS AND DESTINATIONS

Kingdom of Castile

  Point

                                                  crossing

                                                  plateau

                                                  valley

                                   miles\\      overland        
  ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

then overland march.

                                                 discipline

Crown of Aragon

  Point

V. CROWN EXPENDITURES

Feast Provisions by Endpoint

All food and drink to be purchased locally at fair market prices. Crown
agents shall pay promptly and in full, ensuring the muster brings
prosperity to host communities.

  ------------------ -------------- ---------------- ------------- --------------
