  Palencia (Castile) \~2,300        3,450 fl         500 fl        3,950 fl

  Córdoba (Castile)  \~2,400        3,600 fl         500 fl        4,100 fl

  Loja (Granada)     \~1,700        2,550 fl         350 fl        2,900 fl

  Guadix (Granada)   \~500          750 fl           150 fl        900 fl

  Lérida (Aragon)    \~1,700        2,550 fl         350 fl        2,900 fl

  Tortosa (Aragon)   \~2,400        3,600 fl         500 fl        4,100 fl

  Benevento (Naples) \~2,100        3,150 fl         450 fl        3,600 fl

  Messina (Sicily)   \~800          1,200 fl         200 fl        1,400 fl

  Selymbria          \~800          1,200 fl         200 fl        1,400 fl
  (Constantinople)                                                 

  TOTAL          \~18,400   27,600 fl    3,950 fl  31,550 fl
  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Calculation basis: 1.5 florins per man for food and drink; damage
reserve of \~20% of food costs.

Additional Expenditures

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Item                                 Notes       Cost
  ---------------------------------------- --------------- --------------
  Artillery transport and powder           10 exercises    3,000 fl

  Target construction and materials        All endpoints   800 fl

  Academy officer travel and expenses      65 officers     1,300 fl

  Messenger network and coordination       All territories 600 fl

  Sea transport (Cartagena contingent)     \~600 men       1,500 fl

  Contingency reserve (10%)                Unforeseen      3,900 fl

  ADDITIONAL SUBTOTAL                                  11,100 fl
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Total Crown Expenditure

  ------------------------------------------------ ----------------------
  Feast provisions and damages                     31,550 florins

  Additional expenditures                          11,100 florins

  TOTAL MUSTER EXPENDITURE                     42,650 florins
  ------------------------------------------------ ----------------------

Note: This expenditure represents an investment in imperial unity
and military readiness. The cost per man (\~2.3 florins) is modest
compared to the value of a trained, coordinated force that answers a
single command across five territories.

VI\. ADMINISTRATIVE STANDARDS

Official Language

Latin shall serve as the administrative language for all
inter-territorial communications. All reports, orders, and official
correspondence between territories and the central administration in
Toledo shall be composed in Latin. Local administration may continue in
vernacular languages as appropriate.

Officer Rotation

Crown marshalls and tax assessors shall be rotated between territories
every three to five years, where language competency permits. This
rotation prevents the development of local loyalties that might conflict
with imperial interests and ensures administrators maintain perspective
on the whole rather than their assigned region alone.

Reporting Standards

All territorial administrators shall submit reports in standardized
format, enabling comparison across the empire:

1.  Quarterly Reports: Revenues, expenses, notable events

2.  Annual Reviews: Comprehensive territorial assessment

3.  Muster Reports: Within 14 days of exercise completion

Given at Toledo, in the Month of January, Anno Domini 1438

JUAN II

Rex Castellae et Legionis, Aragonum, Neapolis et Siciliae

Defensor Romaniae

laws.title: African Trade Enterprise 1439-1444
laws.summary: Five-year commercial venture plan for establishing Castilian trade posts along the North African coast and expanding south toward the gold and spice routes, defining investment structures, naval escort requirements, diplomatic protocols with local rulers, and profit-sharing arrangements.
laws.full_text:
African Trade Enterprise

Five-Year Assessment: 1439-1444

Prepared for His Majesty King Juan II by Don Álvaro de Luna

Executive Summary

The African Trade Enterprise, initiated in 1439 following the Treaty of
Timbuktu, has established a functioning trade route between Castilian
ports and the Mali Empire via the Senegal River. While infrastructure
development fell below initial projections, the venture has achieved
viability and demonstrates significant potential for future expansion.

By 1444, the Crown is receiving approximately 1,000 pounds of gold
annually, valued at 16,000 florins. Total gold received over the
five-year period amounts to approximately 6,250 pounds, representing
gross revenue of 100,000 florins.

I. Salt Production Expansion

The salt production program was implemented across two primary sites:
the expansion of existing works at Trapani, Sicily, and the construction
of new facilities along the Andalusian coast near Cádiz.

Production Results

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Location               Target (quintales) Achieved
                                                    (quintales)
  -------------------------- ---------------------- ---------------------
  Trapani, Sicily            20,000                 20,000

  Cádiz, Andalusia           20,000                 18,000-20,000

  TOTAL ADDITIONAL       40,000             38,000-40,000
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Assessment: Program met expectations. Trapani expansion completed
1442 under Maestro Giacomo Ferrante. Cádiz works operational mid-1443
under Don Rodrigo de Ponce. Salt quality excellent at both sites.

Salt Production Investment

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Expense Category                      Amount (florins)
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Trapani expansion (pans, walls, quays)    15,000

  Cádiz construction (new works)            30,000

  TOTAL INFRASTRUCTURE                  45,000

  Annual operating costs (ongoing)          13,000/year
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Note: Salt works are leased to operators (Ferrante in Sicily, Ponce
family in Cádiz). Crown receives fixed rents plus guaranteed purchase
rights at set prices. Operating costs borne by lessees; Crown pays only
for salt purchased for African trade.

II\. Trade Route Infrastructure

Infrastructure development encountered significant challenges,
particularly from tropical diseases affecting garrison troops and
difficulties establishing intermediate outposts. Results fell below
projections.

Outposts Established

  ------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Location          Status               Function
  --------------------- ------------------------ -------------------------
  Canary Islands        Fully operational        Primary waypoint,
                                                 resupply

  Arguin Island         Operational (limited)    Intermediate resupply

  São João da Ribeira   Expanded, operational    Primary trading post

  Second coastal site   ABANDONED                Local hostility, disease
  ------------------------------------------------------------------------

Naval Assets Dedicated to African Trade

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Category                        Details
  ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
  Caravels operational                4-5 vessels

  Cargo capacity per caravel          50-60 tons (\~100,000-120,000 lbs)

  Voyages achievable per year         5-8 round trips

  Voyage duration (round trip)        2-3 months

  Annual salt transport capacity      500,000-800,000 lbs
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Infrastructure Investment

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Expense Category                      Amount (florins)
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Caravel construction/procurement (5       17,500
  vessels)                                  

  São João da Ribeira expansion             8,000

  Arguin Island outpost                     5,000

  Abandoned coastal outpost (lost)          4,000

  Garrison troops and supplies (5 years)    12,000

  Portuguese pilot fees and consultation    3,500

  TOTAL INFRASTRUCTURE                  50,000
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Assessment: Below expectations. Disease losses severe; one outpost
abandoned. Infrastructure constrains trade volume. Recommendation:
continued investment in outpost development and additional caravels
required to achieve full potential.

III\. Gold Trade Results

Despite infrastructure limitations, gold trade has achieved viability.
The Treaty of Timbuktu secured preferential treatment from Mansa Mahmud
II, and Ambassador Musa Keita facilitated productive relationships with
Malian merchants.

Annual Gold Receipts

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Year          Gold (lbs)    Value           Voyages
                                      (florins)       
  ----------------- ----------------- ----------------- -----------------
  1440              350               5,600             3

  1441              550               8,800             4

  1442              750               12,000            5

  1443              900               14,400            6

  1444              1,000             16,000            7

  TOTAL         3,550         56,800        25
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Note: Initial expedition (1437-1439) returned 600 lbs gold separately.
Five-year program total including initial haul: approximately 4,150
lbs.

Trade Goods Exchanged

Exports to Mali:

-   Salt (primary): \~500,000-600,000 lbs shipped annually by 1444

-   Chain mail armor (gifts to Mansa): 50 sets over 5 years

-   Toledo steel weapons (gifts): 200 swords, 100 spear-points

-   Horses (gifts and trade): 35 horses delivered (high mortality en
    route)

Imports from Mali:

-   Gold bullion (primary): 1,000 lbs annually by 1444

-   Ivory: \~2,000 lbs annually

-   Malagueta pepper: \~500 lbs annually

-   Manuscripts and scholarly works (gifts from Mansa)

IV\. Royal Mint Operations

African gold is transported to the Royal Mint at Toledo for processing
into currency. The mint became fully operational in Autumn 1439.

Gold Processing and Coinage

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Measure                         Value (by 1444)
  ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
  Gold bullion received annually      1,000 lbs (453 kg)

  Gold purity (African gold)          \~22 carat (91.7% pure)

  Doblas minted annually              \~32,000 doblas

  Face value of coinage               16,000 florins equivalent

  Seigniorage (Crown profit on        \~800 florins/year (5%)
  minting)                            
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Note: The dobla castellana weighs approximately 4.6 grams. One pound of
gold (453g) yields approximately 98 doblas. Each dobla is worth
approximately 0.5 florins. Crown retains seigniorage plus any premium
achieved on gold sales to merchants.

V. Financial Summary (1439-1444)

Total Investment

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Category                              Amount (florins)
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Salt production infrastructure            45,000

  Trade route infrastructure                50,000

  Initial expedition (1437-1439)            40,000

  Diplomatic gifts (weapons, horses, armor) 15,000

  TOTAL CAPITAL INVESTMENT              150,000
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Revenue and Returns

  -----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Revenue Source                        Amount (florins)
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Gold trade (5 years cumulative)           56,800

  Initial expedition gold (600 lbs)         9,600

  Ivory and pepper sales                    8,000

  Seigniorage from minting                  2,500

  TOTAL REVENUE (5 years)               76,900
  -----------------------------------------------------------------------

Net Position and Projections

Five-Year Net Position (1439-1444): -73,100 florins (investment
phase)

Annual Revenue by 1444: \~18,000 florins (gold + ivory +
seigniorage)

Annual Operating Costs: \~8,000 florins (crews, garrison,
maintenance)

Annual Net Profit (from 1445): \~10,000 florins

Break-Even Point: Approximately 1452 at current rates; earlier if
infrastructure expanded

VI\. Strategic Assessment

The African Trade Enterprise has achieved its primary objective:
establishing a viable alternative route for African gold that bypasses
the Maghrebi-controlled trans-Saharan caravans. While infrastructure
limitations constrain current volumes, the venture demonstrates clear
potential for expansion.

Strengths:

-   Treaty of Timbuktu provides exceptional diplomatic foundation

-   Salt production capacity far exceeds current trade route capacity

-   Malian merchants actively prefer Castilian salt over desert caravans

-   Direct Crown control eliminates intermediary margins

Weaknesses:

-   Insufficient caravels limit voyage frequency

-   Disease continues to claim garrison troops

-   Only one intermediate outpost operational

-   Dependence on Portuguese pilots and expertise

Recommendations:

-   Commission 3-4 additional caravels (est. cost: 14,000 florins)

-   Establish second intermediate outpost with better site selection

-   Implement seasonal garrison rotation to reduce disease losses

-   Train Castilian pilots to reduce Portuguese dependence

-   Consider horse breeding program in Canaries to reduce transport
    mortality

Prepared and submitted this day,

Don Álvaro de Luna

Constable of Castile

Toledo, Spring 1444

laws.title: Madrid Imperial Capital Plan
laws.summary: Master plan for transforming Madrid into the imperial capital of the expanded Crown, including construction of a new royal palace, administrative quarter, university, cathedral expansion, road improvements, water infrastructure, and residential districts to accommodate the growing bureaucracy.
laws.full_text:
PLAN FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF

MADRID

IMPERIAL CAPITAL OF THE CROWNS

A Ten-Year Program of Construction

Commissioned by His Most Christian Majesty

JUAN II

King of Castile, León, Aragon, Naples, and Sicily

Defensor Romaniae

Anno Domini MCDXXXIX

Prepared by the Royal Architects:

Maestro Lorenzo de Palencia --- Master of Castilian Construction

Maestro Giorgio di Montepulciano --- Master of Italian Design

Maestro Willem van der Berg --- Master of Practical Engineering

PART I: THE VISION

Purpose and Intent

His Majesty King Juan II, having united under his sovereign authority
the Crowns of Castile, León, Aragon, Naples, and Sicily, and bearing the
sacred title of Defensor Romaniae as protector of Constantinople and the
Christian East, requires a capital befitting the dignity and scope of
this unprecedented realm.

The ancient city of Toledo, though venerable in history and hallowed by
tradition, is constrained by its terrain and cannot accommodate the
administrative, ceremonial, and symbolic requirements of an empire
spanning from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean. Therefore, His Majesty
has determined to construct a new capital at Madrid, transforming a
modest town into the seat of Christian imperium.

The Iota Concept

The city shall embody the symbol of His Majesty's reign: the Greek
letter Iota (Ι), first letter of Ioannes, the royal name rendered in the
tongue of the Eastern Empire. As the Chi-Rho proclaimed Constantine's
devotion to Christ, so shall the Iota proclaim the unity of the
Christian realms under Juan's protection.

The city plan follows the form of the Iota: a great central avenue
running north to south---the vertical stroke---intersected by three
great plazas representing the horizontal bars of the letter. The city
rises from north to south, so that all who enter ascend toward the
throne, the cathedral, and the great Iota Monument that crowns the
whole.

Urban Design Principles

The city shall be built according to the principles of the città
ideale---the ideal city---as conceived by the masters of Florence and
Rome. Streets shall radiate with purpose. Buildings shall stand in
proportion to one another. Light and air shall flow freely. The chaos of
medieval growth shall give way to rational order.

Yet this order serves humanity, not mere geometry. Public fountains
shall ensure no citizen walks more than five minutes for clean water.
Sewers beneath the streets shall carry waste away. Paved roads shall
banish mud and disease. Heated buildings shall make winter bearable.
Madrid shall be not merely beautiful, but livable---a gift to its people
as much as a monument to its king.

PART II: THE BUILDINGS

1. The Palace of Light (Palacio de la Luz)

Total Cost: 180,000 florins --- Construction: Years 1-6

The royal palace shall be built in the new Italian style, emphasizing
light, air, and harmony rather than defensive fortification. The age of
Moorish raids has passed; the palace need not be a fortress. Instead, it
shall awe visitors with beauty and proclaim the confidence of a secure
and prosperous realm.

Principal Chambers:

• The Throne Room: A great hall of one hundred feet in length, with
coffered ceiling rising thirty feet. Windows on three sides flood the
space with light. The throne stands on a raised dais at the southern
end, so that all who approach walk toward the light.

• The Council of Realms Chamber: Adjacent to the throne room, connected
by a grand archway. A round chamber with domed ceiling, embodying the
principle of equality among the five realms. Five great windows face the
cardinal directions and the heavens, representing Castile, Aragon,
Naples, Sicily, and Constantinople united under God.

• Administrative Wings: East and west wings extending from the main
structure, housing the Royal Treasury offices, Crown Marshalls'
chambers, tax assessors, the Royal Secretariat, diplomatic meeting
rooms, and archives. Capacity for fifty officials working simultaneously
in each wing.

• Royal Apartments: A private wing at the rear, overlooking gardens
descending toward the Manzanares. Connected to the seat of power by a
single corridor, allowing His Majesty to move from private father to
public king in thirty paces.

2. The Cortes Building (Casa de las Cortes)

Total Cost: 85,000 florins --- Construction: Years 2-5

A single great building organized so each estate maintains dignity and
privacy, arranged around a central courtyard.

The Three Wings:

• The Clerical Wing: Seating for sixty members---bishops, abbots, and
cathedral chapters. An attached chapel for prayer before sessions.

• The Noble Wing: Seating for one hundred members---the great houses and
lesser nobility. Decorated with the arms of every lineage represented.

• The Commons Wing: Seating for ninety members---representatives of the
cities. Simpler decoration, but no less dignified in proportion and
light.

• The Great Hall: A semicircular chamber where all three estates gather
for opening ceremonies, royal addresses, and final votes. Rising tiers
focus on a central podium. Acoustics designed so a speaker can be heard
in every seat without shouting. Total capacity: 250 members plus
observers in gallery.

3. The Royal Chapel (Capilla Real)

Total Cost: 45,000 florins --- Construction: Years 1-3

A jewel box for prayer---small but perfect. Seating for one hundred: the
royal family, household, and honored guests. Every surface shall sing
with meaning.

Walls of white marble inlaid with gold. A great altarpiece depicting the
Reconquista and the defense of Constantinople. Windows of colored glass
telling the story of salvation. A choir loft for the singers recruited
through the Great Patronage Program. This chapel shall be complete
within three years, providing a place of worship long before the great
cathedral rises.

4. The Cathedral of Madrid

Total Cost: 400,000 florins over 25-30 years (100,000 in first decade)

The great work of generations. A cathedral to rival Burgos, Toledo, and
Seville---perhaps to surpass them all.

Specifications:

• Length: 400 feet from western doors to eastern apse

• Width: 150 feet across the transepts

• Height: Central tower rising 300 feet, visible from twenty miles

• Capacity: 5,000 worshippers

Construction shall proceed in stages: foundations and lower walls in the
first decade; nave and aisles in the second; transepts and choir in the
third; towers and ornamentation thereafter. From the first year, a
consecrated space shall exist for worship. The people of Madrid shall
see their cathedral rising around them, stone by stone, year by year---a
living testament to faith.

5. The Iota Monument (La Torre del Iota)

Total Cost: 120,000 florins --- Construction: Years 2-9

The heart of everything. The symbol made stone. Rising at the highest
point of the city, visible from every quarter and from miles beyond.

The Pedestal Base:

• A massive square structure, 100 feet on each side, 60 feet tall

• Built of white limestone reinforced with iron

• Four grand staircases, one on each face

• Interior chambers for guards, storage, and maintenance

• Summit platform with views across the entire city

The Iota Tower:

• Rising from the pedestal center, an additional 140 feet (200 feet
total from street)

• Rectangular cross-section: 30 feet by 15 feet---unmistakably the
vertical stroke

• Three observation galleries at the horizontal bars of the Iota:

--- Lowest gallery (80 feet): Views of the city

--- Middle gallery (130 feet): Views of the countryside

--- Highest gallery (180 feet): Views to the Guadarrama and Toledo

• Internal spiral staircase of 400 steps

• Great golden cross surmounting the pinnacle: Faith above empire, God
above king

6. The Citadel and Barracks

Total Cost: 90,000 florins --- Construction: Years 1-5

A fortress within the city, south of the cathedral on a slight rise.
Star-shaped walls in the modern style, angled to deflect cannon fire.
The city itself remains open, but the citadel provides refuge should
Madrid ever face threat.

Facilities:

• Barracks for 2,000 soldiers

• Armories and stables

• Independent water supply from deep wells

• Stores sufficient for six months' siege

• Royal Treasury Vaults beneath the citadel, carved into bedrock:
multiple chambers with iron doors, each requiring separate keys held by
different officials

7. Infrastructure

Total Cost: 180,000 florins --- Construction: Years 1-10

The invisible work that makes a city function---more important than any
monument.

Water System:

• Aqueduct from the Guadarrama foothills, fifteen miles distant

• Twelve public fountains along the Via Iota and major plazas

• No citizen shall walk more than five minutes for clean water

Sanitation:

• Underground sewers carrying waste to the Manzanares downstream

• All major buildings connected from initial construction

Streets:

• Via Iota: Sixty feet wide, paved in stone, lined with trees

• Major streets paved in stone; secondary streets in compacted gravel

• Oil lamps at major intersections, maintained by city watch

Heating:

• Hypocaust system for all major buildings

• Warm floors throughout winter in palace, Cortes, and public buildings

8. The Royal Residence (Casa del Rey)

Total Cost: 50,000 florins --- Construction: Years 3-6

A private home within the palace grounds but separate from the Palace of
Light. Connected by covered walkway, yet maintaining its own gardens,
entrance, and peace. A place for family, for children, for the private
life of the sovereign.

Private apartments for the King and Queen. Nurseries and schoolrooms for
the royal children. Gardens with fruit trees, fountains, and space for
play. A private chapel for family devotions. Quarters for personal
servants and the shadow guard.

9. The Hall of the Faithful

Total Cost: 20,000 florins --- Construction: Years 4-6

A chapel connected to the citadel, dedicated to those who sacrificed for
others---the shield against the dark, the sword protecting the innocent.
The names of those who died defending Constantinople inscribed upon its
walls. Soldiers and knights shall pass through this hall on their way to
duty, reminded daily of what they serve and why sacrifice has meaning.

10. The Royal Baths (Baños Reales)

Total Cost: 30,000 florins --- Construction: Years 5-8

Public baths in the Roman style, heated year-round by the hypocaust
system. One facility for men, one for women, one for the royal
household. The Moors understood the value of public bathing; this wisdom
shall not be abandoned simply because it came from infidels.
Cleanliness, health, and a gift to the common people.

11. The Commercial Exchange (Lonja)

Total Cost: 30,000 florins --- Construction: Years 6-9

A grand building in the lower plaza where merchants and bankers conduct
business under one roof. The crown builds it; merchants pay fees to use
it. Space reserved nearby for banking houses---the Medici, the Genoese,
the Venetians, the Fuggers---who will establish branches in the imperial
capital. The Lonja shall become self-sustaining within a few years of
completion.

12. Treasury Vaults

Total Cost: 15,000 florins --- Construction: Years 2-4

Beneath the citadel, vaults carved deep into bedrock to house His
Majesty's treasury---currently exceeding 1,200,000 florins and growing
annually. Multiple chambers with iron doors. Each door requiring
separate keys held by different officials. Walls of stone so thick no
tool could breach them in less than a week. Designed against fire,
flood, and treachery.

Financial Sustainability

The Granada silver mines alone produce 250,000 florins annually. The
entire Madrid project, spread over ten years, consumes on average
134,500 florins per year---approximately half of this single revenue
stream. Combined revenues from all realms exceed 500,000 florins
annually.

Therefore, even during peak construction years, the Royal Treasury will
continue to grow. By the time Madrid is complete in 1449, the treasury
will be larger than it is today, not smaller. This project is not merely
affordable---it is sustainable without strain upon the realm's finances
or its people.

PART IV: ADMINISTRATION

Project Governance

The construction of Madrid shall be overseen by a Royal Construction
Council comprising:

• Maestro Lorenzo de Palencia --- Chief Architect, responsible for
overall construction

• Maestro Giorgio di Montepulciano --- Design Architect, responsible for
aesthetic vision

• Maestro Willem van der Berg --- Chief Engineer, responsible for
infrastructure

• A representative of the Royal Treasury, responsible for disbursements

• A representative of the Crown Marshall, responsible for security

This council shall meet monthly to review progress, resolve disputes,
and adjust plans as necessary. Quarterly reports shall be submitted to
His Majesty.

Labor and Materials

Construction will require:

• 2,000-3,000 laborers at peak activity (Years 3-5)

• Master craftsmen recruited from across Castile, Aragon, Italy, and
Flanders

• Stone quarried from the Guadarrama mountains

• Timber from the forests of Old Castile

• Iron from the Basque country

• Glass from Venetian workshops

• Marble imported from Italy for the finest works

Labor camps shall be established near the construction site, with
provisions for housing, feeding, and caring for workers. Fair wages
shall be paid promptly. The construction of Madrid shall demonstrate
Christian justice as well as Christian ambition.

Future Growth

This plan establishes the bones of Madrid---the principal buildings, the
infrastructure, the monuments. But a city is more than its great works.
Space has been reserved for:

• Noble townhouses along streets near the palace

• Merchant residences and guild halls in the commercial district

• Common housing in surrounding quarters

• Banking houses near the Lonja

• Churches and convents as the population requires

• Schools, hospitals, and charitable institutions

Private construction shall follow crown-established standards: maximum
heights, minimum street widths, required connection to sewers, approved
materials. Madrid shall grow according to plan, not accident. Within
twenty years, a city of 50,000. Within fifty years, perhaps 100,000. The
infrastructure we build now shall support generations of growth.

CONCLUSION

This plan represents the labor of three architects and the vision of a
king. It proposes to build, within ten years, a capital worthy of an
empire---a city that proclaims the unity of five crowns, the triumph of
Christian faith, and the dawn of a new age.

The cost is great but sustainable. The labor is immense but achievable.
The vision is bold but grounded in the practical realities of stone,
water, and human effort.

When complete, Madrid will stand as testament to what can be
accomplished when resources, will, and faith align. The Iota will rise
above the plains of Castile, visible for miles, declaring to all who see
it: here is the heart of Christian empire. Here is the seat of Juan,
Defensor Romaniae. Here is the capital of the crowns.

--- FINIS ---

laws.summary: Banking agreement between the Crown and the House of Medici establishing credit facilities, currency exchange services, loan terms for military campaigns, and the Medici bank's role as financial agent for Castilian commercial operations across the Italian peninsula and eastern Mediterranean.
laws.full_text:
[CONVENTIO BANCARIA]

Agreement Between the Crown and the House of Medici

Florence, the Twenty-Eighth Day of July, in the Year of Our Lord 1439

[BE IT KNOWN TO ALL] that this agreement is made between
His Most Catholic Majesty Juan II, by the Grace of God King of
Castile, León, Granada, Aragon, Naples, and Sicily, Defensor Romaniae,
hereinafter referred to as "the Crown", and Cosimo di Giovanni
de' Medici, principal of the Banco dei Medici of Florence,
hereinafter referred to as "the Bank".

WHEREAS the Crown and the Bank, recognizing the mutual benefit of
cooperation between sovereign authority and financial enterprise, and
acknowledging that each institution serves purposes distinct yet
complementary, do hereby establish the following terms of association:

[ARTICLE I: THE GUARANTEED DEPOSIT]

The Crown shall maintain with the Bank a deposit of three hundred
thousand florins (300,000 fl.), to be held as guaranteed working
capital for a period of no less than ten years from the date of this
agreement.

This deposit may be liquidated at a maximum rate of thirty thousand
florins (30,000 fl.) per annum. The Crown agrees not to demand
withdrawal exceeding this amount in any calendar year, thereby providing
the Bank with stable capital for its lending operations.

In consideration of this guaranteed capital, the Bank shall pay to the
Crown interest at the rate of four percent (4%) per annum, amounting
to twelve thousand florins (12,000 fl.) annually, payable in quarterly
installments to the Crown's designated treasury.

[ARTICLE II: ADDITIONAL DEPOSITS AND WITHDRAWALS]

Any funds held by the Bank on behalf of the Crown in excess of the
guaranteed deposit of three hundred thousand florins shall be
transferred to the Crown's central treasury in Toledo or Madrid on a
quarterly basis, unless otherwise directed by the Crown's
treasurer.

For withdrawals exceeding fifty thousand florins (50,000 fl.) in any
single transaction, the Crown shall provide the Bank with notice of
thirty (30) days to allow for proper management of liquidity.

[ARTICLE III: TRANSACTION FEES]

For all transfers and transactions conducted within the Crown's
territories---including but not limited to Castile, Granada, Aragon,
Naples, and Sicily---the Bank shall charge a cambium of two percent
(2%).

For transfers to territories outside the Crown's direct
sovereignty---including France, England, the German states, and the
Italian republics---the Bank shall charge three percent (3%),
reflecting the additional complexity and risk of such operations.

For transactions involving Constantinople, the rate of three percent
(3%) shall apply until such time as the Bank establishes a permanent
branch there. After three years of stable operations, this rate shall be
subject to renegotiation.

[ARTICLE IV: THE IOTA CURRENCY]

The Crown has minted a new coin, designated the Iota (Ι), weighted
precisely to the Florentine florin standard and interchangeable
therewith in all commercial transactions.

When disbursing funds to subjects of the Crown within the Crown's
territories---including but not limited to soldiers, suppliers, and
creditors---the Bank shall pay in Iota coin where practical and
available. This requirement applies solely to payments to the Crown's
own subjects and does not extend to the Bank's other clients or
operations.

In consideration of this obligation, the Crown hereby guarantees by
royal charter that the Iota shall maintain its present weight and purity
for the duration of this agreement. The Crown shall not debase,
diminish, or alter the standard of the Iota without providing the Bank
one year's notice and renegotiating terms as necessary.

[ARTICLE V: BANKING PRESENCE]

The Bank currently maintains branches in Naples and Barcelona,
with correspondent arrangements in Valencia. For as long as the Bank
provides transaction services within the Crown's territories under the
terms described herein, the Crown shall maintain the guaranteed deposit
as specified in Article I.

The Bank agrees to consider in good faith the establishment of a branch
in Constantinople, recognizing the strategic importance of the
Crown's eastern possessions and the commercial opportunities therein.

[ARTICLE VI: FUTURE CONSIDERATIONS]

The Crown has expressed intention to develop systems integrating harbour
transactions with banking services, whereby merchants may conduct trade
and remit duties through letters of credit rather than physical
transport of coin. The Bank expresses interest in participating in such
systems should they be enacted with the support of the relevant trading
guilds.

Such future arrangements shall be the subject of separate negotiation
and agreement, and nothing in this document commits either party to
specific terms not yet determined.

[ARTICLE VII: INDEPENDENCE AND NEUTRALITY]

Both parties acknowledge that the Bank serves clients throughout
Christendom and that its reputation for independence and neutrality is
essential to its function. Nothing in this agreement shall be construed
to make the Bank an instrument of the Crown's policy or to compromise
the Bank's ability to serve other clients.

Likewise, the Crown retains full sovereignty over its financial affairs
and may establish additional banking relationships or its own financial
institutions as it sees fit, without prejudice to the terms herein
agreed.

[IN WITNESS WHEREOF], the parties have set their hands
and seals on the date first written above.

+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
| \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\   | \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\   |
| _\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ | _\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ |
|                                   |                                   |
| JUAN II                       | COSIMO DE' MEDICI            |
|                                   |                                   |
| King of Castile, León, Granada,   | Principal of the Banco dei Medici |
|                                   |                                   |
| Aragon, Naples, and Sicily        | of Florence                       |
|                                   |                                   |
| Defensor Romaniae               |                                   |
+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+

[WITNESSES:]

Ser Giovanni di Niccolò Benci, Notary of Florence

Don Álvaro de Luna, Constable of Castile

Ilarione de' Bardi, Manager of the Medici Bank of Rome

laws.full_text:
ORDINATIO MARESCALLORUM CORONAE

Ordinance of the Crown Marshalls

Proclaimed at Toledo, Anno Domini 1439

PREAMBLE

JUAN, by the Grace of God, King of Castile and León, of Aragon, of
Naples and Sicily, Defender of Romania, to all lords temporal and
spiritual, to all officers of the Crown, and to all faithful subjects of
Our realms, greeting and grace.

WHEREAS the collection of lawful revenues is essential to the defence of
Christendom, the administration of justice, and the welfare of Our
peoples; and WHEREAS certain difficulties have arisen in the execution
of this sacred duty; We do hereby ordain and establish the following
procedures for the governance of Our Crown Marshalls and the protection
of Our tax assessors.

PART I: THE THREE-STRIKE PROCEDURE

Article 1: Definition of a Strike

A strike shall be recorded against any lord, vassal, or landholder when
any of the following occurs:

> (a) Failure to provide requested documentation within a reasonable
> timeframe as determined by the assessor;
>
> (b) Deliberate obstruction, delay, or deception in the assessment
> process;
>
> (c) Refusal to permit access to accounts, properties, or records
> required for assessment;
>
> (d) Any threat, intimidation, or hostile act directed at a Crown
> assessor or marshall, whether explicit or implicit;
>
> (e) Non-payment of assessed obligations without valid dispute or
> arrangement.

Article 2: Recording and Accumulation

All strikes shall be recorded in the central registry maintained by the
Royal Treasury at Toledo. Strikes accumulate against each household
regardless of which specific assessor or marshall filed the report.
Records shall be maintained in perpetuity and may be cited in any future
proceedings.

Article 3: Consequence of Three Strikes

Upon the recording of a third strike against any lord, the Crown
Marshall delivering the third demand shall simultaneously issue a Royal
Summons requiring the lord to present himself before the Crown at Toledo
within a timeframe determined by the marshall based upon the lord's
circumstances, distance from the capital, and any legitimate impediments
to travel.

PART II: THE ROYAL SUMMONS

Article 4: Nature of the Summons

The Royal Summons is not a punishment but an opportunity. The summoned
lord shall appear before the King or his designated representative to
explain the circumstances of his non-compliance, present any evidence in
his defence, and negotiate a resolution to outstanding obligations.

Article 5: Timeframe and Escort

The Crown Marshall shall set a reasonable timeframe for appearance,
taking into account distance, weather, health, and other legitimate
factors. The marshall may, at his discretion, offer to accompany the
lord to Toledo as a royal escort. This offer is both a courtesy and a
means of ensuring compliance.

Article 6: Valid Excuses for Non-Appearance

Only an Act of God may excuse failure to appear within the appointed
timeframe. This includes severe illness certified by a physician,
natural disasters preventing travel, or other circumstances clearly
beyond human control. Mere inconvenience, pressing business, or personal
preference shall not constitute valid excuse.

Article 7: Failure to Appear

Should any lord fail to appear before the Crown within the appointed
timeframe without valid excuse, notification shall be sent
immediately to the King himself. Such failure shall be considered
an act of rebellion against the Crown. The King reserves the right to
dispatch military force to compel obedience and, if necessary, to strip
titles and privileges from the rebellious lord as an example to others.

PART III: PROTECTION OF ASSESSORS

Article 8: The Tiered Escort System

Crown assessors shall be provided with armed escort according to the
following tiers:

  ---------------------- ------------------------ ------------------------
  Assessment Type    Guards Required      Examples

  Routine                None required            City merchants,
                                                  cooperative minor
                                                  landholders

  Noble Estate (First    Two guards               Initial assessments at
  Visit)                                          any noble estate

  Difficult or Disputed  Four guards              Known troublesome lords,
                                                  second/third visits
                                                  after disputes, previous
                                                  threats
  ---------------------- ------------------------ ------------------------

The assessor shall have discretion to request escort based upon his
knowledge of circumstances, and may request additional guards if
conditions warrant.

Article 9: Purpose of Guards

The guards serve three purposes: first, to protect the physical safety
of the assessor; second, to serve as witnesses to any threats,
obstruction, or misconduct; third, to demonstrate that the Crown watches
over its servants and takes their welfare seriously. The presence of
royal guards transforms any threat from a private matter into an offence
against the Crown itself.

Article 10: Threats as Strikes

Any threat or act of intimidation against an assessor, whether explicit
or implicit, shall be recorded as a strike under Article 1(d) of this
Ordinance. The marshall shall review the assessor's account, interview
the guards who were present, and determine whether the conduct warrants
recording. Implicit threats---such as displays of armed force,
references to danger, or confinement of assessors---shall be treated
with the same gravity as explicit verbal threats.

PART IV: EXPANSION OF CROWN SOLDIERS

Article 11: Authorized Strength

The Crown Soldiers shall be expanded from their present strength of one
hundred fifty men to a total strength of two hundred men. This
expansion shall be accomplished through immediate recruitment of fifty
additional soldiers of proven character and martial skill.

Article 12: Garrison Rotation

To maintain morale and readiness, the duty of escorting assessors shall
be rotated among all four garrisons---Toledo, Segovia, Burgos, and
Valladolid. Each garrison shall take escort duty for a period of two
months before returning to regular garrison duties while another
garrison assumes the responsibility. This rotation ensures that all
soldiers experience varied service and that no garrison grows stale from
unchanging routine.

Article 13: Garrison Assignments

  ----------------------- --------------- --------------------------------
  Garrison            Strength    Primary Duties

  Toledo (Alcázar)        50 men          Royal family, treasury,
                                          archives, Cortes security

  Segovia (Alcázar)       45 men          Secondary treasury, royal mint,
                                          state prisoners

  Burgos                  45 men          Northern gateway, royal
                                          apartments, regional presence

  Valladolid              40 men          Royal chancery archives, land
                                          records

  Reserve/Transit         20 men          Leave, recovery, escort
                                          rotation, special duties
  ----------------------- --------------- --------------------------------

PART V: ITINERANT MARSHALLS

Article 14: Establishment

There shall be appointed three Itinerant Marshalls (Marescalli
Itinerantes), knights of exceptional virtue, wisdom, and judgment, who
shall travel freely throughout the realms seeking out injustice,
investigating complaints, and representing royal authority in places
where regular marshalls cannot easily reach.

Article 15: Authority and Duties

The Itinerant Marshalls shall possess the same authority as regular
Crown Marshalls, with the additional power to initiate investigations on
their own initiative when they encounter evidence of wrongdoing. They
shall not be assigned to fixed districts but shall move as duty
requires---one in the north, one in the south, one moving between the
eastern territories as circumstances demand.

Article 16: Qualifications

Candidates for Itinerant Marshall must possess: knightly rank and proven
martial virtue; wisdom and sound judgment demonstrated through years of
service; the ability to work alone, far from support, for extended
periods; literacy in Latin and at least one vernacular tongue; and
unimpeachable loyalty to the Crown and the Faith. The Military Orders of
Calatrava, Santiago, and Alcántara, as well as the Dominican Order,
shall be consulted for suitable candidates.

Article 17: Reporting

The Itinerant Marshalls shall report directly to the Crown. When they
encounter matters requiring urgent attention, they shall send word
immediately to Toledo. They shall carry the same signet ring as all
Crown Marshalls, marking them as servants of the King with authority to
act in his name.

PART VI: PROCLAMATION AND EFFECT

Article 18: Announcement at Cortes

This Ordinance shall be formally proclaimed at the next meeting of the
Cortes, that all lords temporal and spiritual may understand their
obligations and the procedures by which the Crown shall enforce
compliance. All Crown Marshalls available shall be assembled at the
Cortes to meet with the nobles and demonstrate that these officers are
men of wisdom and mercy as well as authority.

Article 19: Effective Date

This Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its proclamation at
the Cortes. All strikes previously recorded shall count toward the
three-strike threshold established herein.

Article 20: Supremacy

This Ordinance supersedes all previous instructions regarding the
conduct of Crown Marshalls and tax assessors. Where any conflict exists
between this Ordinance and prior practice, this Ordinance shall govern.

--- ✠ ---

Given at Toledo, in the Month of May, Anno Domini 1439

JUAN II

Rex Castellae et Legionis, Aragonum, Neapolis et Siciliae

Defensor Romaniae

laws.title: Ordinatio Consilii Regentiae Castellae
laws.summary: Establishes the Regency Council of Castile to govern in the king's absence during the eastern campaign, defining the council's composition, powers, limitations, succession protocols, and the mechanism for royal authority to be delegated without being diminished.
laws.full_text:
Ordinatio Consilii Regentiae Castellae

Decree Establishing the Regency Council of Castile

--- ✠ ---

In the name of God Almighty, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Amen.

Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile, León, Aragon, Naples, and
Sicily, Defender of the Faith and Protector of Christendom, to all who
read this decree, greeting and grace.

--- ✠ ---

Preamble

Whereas the burdens of our office require our presence in distant
lands for the defense of Christendom;

Whereas the governance of our realm of Castile must continue in our
absence with wisdom and justice;

Whereas the concentration of such governance in a single hand has
proven neither prudent nor in keeping with the ancient customs of our
realm;

We do hereby establish, by our royal authority and with the counsel of
our faithful subjects, a Council of Regency for the governance of
Castile during such times as we are absent from the realm.

Article I: Composition

The Council of Regency shall consist of three members, each representing
one of the estates of the realm:

> Firstly, one member elected by the noble estate of the Cortes, from
> among their number;
>
> Secondly, one member elected by the estate of the commons of the
> Cortes, from among their number;
>
> Thirdly, one member elected by the ecclesiastical estate of the
> Cortes, from among their number.

Each estate shall determine its own representative by such method as
that estate sees fit, provided that the selection is made during a
lawfully assembled session of the Cortes.

Article II: Authority

The Council of Regency shall exercise the governance of Castile in the
King's absence, with authority to:

> Firstly, maintain the peace and administer justice throughout the
> realm;
>
> Secondly, collect and disburse the ordinary revenues of the Crown
> according to established law and custom;
>
> Thirdly, correspond with foreign powers on routine matters not
> touching upon war, alliance, or the succession;
>
> Fourthly, make such appointments to minor offices as the
> administration of the realm requires;
>
> Fifthly, execute such other duties as the proper governance of the
> realm demands.

Article III: Limitations

The Council of Regency shall NOT, without the express written consent of
the King, undertake any of the following:

> Firstly, declare war or conclude peace with any foreign power;
>
> Secondly, negotiate treaties of alliance or marriage touching upon
> the royal house;
>
> Thirdly, alter the laws or customs of the realm;
>
> Fourthly, levy extraordinary taxation beyond that already approved
> by the Cortes;
>
> Fifthly, make appointments to the great offices of state;
>
> Sixthly, alienate any lands, castles, or revenues belonging to the
> Crown;
>
> Seventhly, pardon crimes of treason, heresy, or lèse-majesté.

Article IV: Obedience to the Crown

The Council of Regency serves at the pleasure of the King and Queen. Its
members are bound to obey all commands issued by the King, or by the
Queen acting in the King's name. No act of the Council may contradict a
direct royal instruction. The King retains the authority to overrule,
modify, or annul any decision of the Council at any time, for any
reason, without explanation.

The Queen, when present in Castile, shall be kept informed of all
significant matters before the Council and may attend its deliberations
at her pleasure. Her counsel shall be sought on all matters touching
upon the royal household, the succession, or the welfare of the royal
children.

Article V: Term and Election

Each member of the Council of Regency shall serve until the next lawful
assembly of the Cortes, at which time all three positions shall be
subject to election anew. No presumption of continuity shall attach to
any member; each Cortes shall make its selections freely, whether to
retain the current member or to select another.

The first election under this decree shall take place at the next
assembly of the Cortes following the promulgation of this decree.

Article VI: Vacancy

Should any member of the Council die, become incapacitated, or be
removed by royal command during their term, the remaining members shall
continue to exercise the Council's authority until the relevant estate
can select a replacement. Such selection may be made by the assembled
heads of that estate in Toledo, without requiring a full session of the
Cortes, provided that at least seven members of the estate concur in the
selection.

Article VII: Accountability

The Council of Regency shall maintain full and accurate records of all
decisions, expenditures, and correspondence undertaken in the King's
name. These records shall be made available to the King upon his return,
or at any time upon royal request. Any member found to have acted
contrary to royal instruction, to have exceeded the Council's
authority, or to have enriched himself through his office, shall be
subject to removal and such further punishment as the King sees fit.

--- ✠ ---

Seal and Promulgation

Given at Toledo, in the Month of November, Anno Domini 1439

Let this decree be read in every cathedral, published in every market,
and recorded in every archive of our realm, that none may claim
ignorance of its provisions.

JUAN II

Rex Castellae et Legionis, Aragonum, Neapolis et Siciliae

Defensor Romaniae

laws.title: Ordo Belli Orientalis
laws.summary: Comprehensive operational plan for the eastern crusade campaign, detailing the order of battle, embarkation schedule, naval convoy routes, land campaign objectives in Anatolia and the Balkans, supply logistics, allied force coordination, and contingency plans for Ottoman counter-offensives.
laws.full_text:
ORDO BELLI ORIENTALIS

The Plan for the Eastern War

Issued by Royal Decree of Juan II, King of Castile, León, Aragon,
Naples, and Sicily, Defensor Romaniae

November 1439

PART I: PURPOSE AND STRATEGIC CONCEPT

This document establishes the comprehensive plan for equipping,
training, and deploying the Royal Army for the Eastern Crusade,
scheduled for Spring 1441. The campaign will join Polish and Hungarian
allies in a coordinated offensive against the Ottoman Empire, with the
strategic objective of breaking Ottoman power in the Balkans and
securing the approaches to Constantinople.

The plan introduces revolutionary tactical doctrine combining three
innovations that together invert every traditional Ottoman battlefield
advantage:

1. Aggressive Artillery Deployment: Rapid positioning of superior
Castilian guns to deny Ottomans time to construct fieldworks, forcing
them to attack prepared Christian positions rather than defending their
own.

2. War Wagon Fortress (Wagenburg): Hussite-style reinforced wagons
forming a mobile defensive core that breaks cavalry charges and provides
shelter for infantry and artillery crews.

3. Pike Infantry Formations: Swiss-style disciplined pike blocks
that can hold against Janissary pressure while cavalry waits for the
decisive moment.

PART II: EQUIPMENT PROGRAM

A. Milanese Arms Procurement

A Crown agent shall be dispatched to Milan this winter with authority to
contract for quality infantry equipment. The order emphasizes uniformity
and craftsmanship over maximum quantity. All armor shall bear the Iota
symbol (Ι), marking it as Crown property.

  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Item                                  Cost (Florins)

  7,000 infantry kits (brigandine, sallet,  98,000
  sword, spear, dagger)                     

  Shipping (Genoa to Cartagena/Seville)     10,000

  Agent expenses, inspection, contingencies 7,000

  SUBTOTAL: MILANESE ORDER                  115,000
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------

B. Domestic Production (Bilbao)

Master Heinrich Steinmann's consortium will produce approximately 800
kits by autumn 1440, added to 1,700 currently in royal stores. Total
domestic contribution: 2,500 kits. Existing subsidy of 3,500 florins
annually continues; no additional cost.

C. Self-Equipped Men (Hombres de Armas Propias)

Men who arrive at muster with their own acceptable equipment shall
receive an honor bonus and the title Hombre de Armas Propias (Man of
His Own Arms). This title shall be recorded in muster rolls and
announced publicly at the Toledo assembly.

  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Category                              Bonus (Florins)

  Infantry with acceptable personal         5
  equipment                                 

  Cavalry with acceptable personal          10
  equipment                                 
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------

Estimated 7,500 self-equipped men receiving bonuses: 45,000 florins

D. Equipment Repair Stations

Men whose personal equipment fails inspection but is repairable shall
have opportunity to improve their gear at Crown-funded repair stations.
Smiths from Bilbao's trained apprentices shall staff these stations with
portable forges and replacement parts.

  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Location                              Cost (Florins)

  Toledo (main muster point)                3,000

  Regional stations (Burgos, Seville,       2,000
  Córdoba)                                  

  SUBTOTAL: REPAIR PROGRAM                  5,000
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------

E. Equipment Possession Rules

All equipment issued from Crown stores bearing the Iota mark remains
Crown property on permanent loan. Upon death, discharge, or desertion,
equipment returns to royal armories. Sale of Iota-marked equipment
constitutes theft of Crown property.

Self-equipped men retain ownership of their personal arms. The honor
bonus compensates their investment without creating resentment toward
those receiving Crown equipment.

PART III: WAR WAGON PROGRAM

A. Castilian Training Wagons

Fifty reinforced war wagons shall be constructed in Castile during
winter 1439-40 for training purposes during the 1440 muster. These
wagons will be distributed across regional muster points to familiarize
officers and men with wagenburg tactics. They shall remain in Castile
for kingdom defense after the expeditionary force departs.

  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Item                                  Cost (Florins)

  50 war wagons (heavy oak, iron            2,000
  reinforcement, gunports, chains)          

  Construction locations: Burgos,           ---
  Valladolid, Toledo                        
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------

B. Eastern Theater Wagons

Four hundred war wagons shall be acquired in the East through purchase
from Hungarian craftsmen or local construction supervised by officers
trained in wagenburg doctrine. János Hunyadi's expertise shall be sought
for both officer instruction and wagon specifications.

  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------
  Item                                  Estimated Cost

  400 war wagons (Hungarian construction or 16,000--20,000
  purchase)                                 

  Officer training with Hunyadi's forces    2,000

  SUBTOTAL: EASTERN WAGONS                  18,000--22,000
  ----------------------------------------- -----------------------------

PART IV: ARMY COMPOSITION

The expeditionary force of 29,000 men shall be organized as follows:

  ---------------------------------- ------------- -----------------------
  Force Component                Men       Role

  Wagenburg Crews                    7,200         Crossbow, handgun,
                                                   polearm

  Artillery Crews                    1,000         Bombards and field
                                                   pieces

  Pike Infantry                      8,500         Main battle line

  Crossbowmen/Handgunners (field)    3,500         Ranged support

  Sword-and-Buckler (Rodeleros)      2,500         Flank defense, gap
                                                   exploitation

  Heavy Cavalry                      2,800         Decisive charge

  Light Cavalry (Jinetes)            2,500         Scouting, screening

  Command, Signals, Support          1,000         Officers, surgeons,
                                                   logistics

  TOTAL                              29,000    
  ---------------------------------- ------------- -----------------------

Tactical Deployment

Center: The wagenburg (400 wagons, 7,200 men) forms an impenetrable
defensive core. Artillery positions at corners and along the perimeter.
Pike infantry deploys behind or beside the wagenburg, ready to advance
or hold.

Flanks: Field crossbowmen and rodeleros protect the pike formations'
flanks. Light cavalry screens against Ottoman probing attacks.

Reserve: Heavy cavalry held behind the wagenburg, waiting for the
decisive moment when Ottoman forces are disordered by artillery and pike
resistance.

PART V: TRAINING PROGRAM (1440 MUSTER)

A. Regional Muster Points

Each regional muster point shall have war wagons and trained officers
present. Men shall begin familiarization with wagenburg formations
immediately upon arrival.

B. Infantry Training Requirements

Pike Drill: Formation fighting with eighteen-foot pikes. Standing
shoulder to shoulder. Lowering pikes in unison. Responding to horn and
drum signals. Trusting neighboring men to hold.

Wagenburg Training: Entering and exiting wagons. Reloading behind
wagon boards. Defending gaps between linked wagons. Chain and hook
handling for linking and unlinking.

Combined Arms: Artillery crews and infantry practicing together.
Deployment timing. Communication between gun positions and infantry
formations.

C. Artillery Training

Cannon crews shall practice rapid deployment throughout 1440. Exercises
shall test how quickly guns can be positioned and begin firing at marked
targets. Combined deployments with infantry shall establish coordination
doctrine.

D. Cavalry Discipline (CRITICAL)

Ottoman tactics rely on feigned retreat to draw Christian cavalry away
from infantry support. Castilian jinetes must be trained to resist this
instinct.

Signal Drills: Horns, flags, and drums shall control cavalry
movement. No pursuit without explicit signal. Return signals shall be
practiced until instinctive.

Trap Exercises: Mock engagements where "retreating" forces are
actually traps. Men who pursue without orders shall face harsh
consequences in training---flogging if necessary---rather than death in
battle.

Discipline Principle: Better to flog a dozen jinetes in training
than lose a thousand because they could not resist chasing a feigned
retreat.

E. March to Toledo

After regional training, the entire army shall march to Toledo for final
assembly. There, His Majesty shall review all forces, select the best
troops for the expedition, and conduct final combined exercises.
Equipment inspection and upgrades shall be completed before selection.

PART VI: ARTILLERY PRE-DEPLOYMENT

All artillery pieces intended for the Eastern campaign shall be shipped
to Constantinople in autumn 1440. This ensures that when the main army
sails in spring 1441, every ship carries fighting men rather than heavy
guns.

Heavy Bombards: 40--50 guns shipped autumn 1440

Field Pieces: 15--20 guns shipped autumn 1440

Powder and Shot: Sufficient supplies for extended campaign, stored
at Constantinople

PART VII: COMPLETE FINANCIAL SUMMARY

  --------------------------------------------- -------------------------
  Program                                   Cost (Florins)

  EQUIPMENT PROGRAM                         

  Milanese Order (7,000 kits + shipping +       115,000
  expenses)                                     

  Self-Equipment Bonuses (\~7,500 men)          45,000

  Repair Stations (Toledo + regional)           5,000

  Equipment Subtotal                            165,000

  WAR WAGON PROGRAM                         

  Castilian Training Wagons (50 wagons)         2,000

  Eastern Theater Wagons (400 wagons,           20,000
  estimated)                                    

  Wagon Subtotal                                22,000

  TRAINING AND PREPARATION                  

  Hunyadi Officer Training Mission              2,000

  Pike Procurement (thousands of 18-foot ash    4,000
  shafts)                                       

  1440 Muster Exercises (estimated, per 1438    45,000
  model)                                        

  Training Subtotal                             51,000

  TOTAL PROGRAM COST                        238,000
  --------------------------------------------- -------------------------

Treasury Impact

Current Treasury (November 1439): 1,350,738 florins

Program Cost: 238,000 florins

Percentage of Treasury: 17.6%

Assessment: Sustainable. The treasury can bear this expenditure
while maintaining reserves for other commitments and contingencies.

PART VIII: IMPLEMENTATION TIMELINE

  ------------------ ----------------------------------------------------
  Date           Action

  December 1439      Agent departs for Milan with contract authority

  December 1439      Wagon construction begins in Castile (Burgos,
                     Valladolid, Toledo)

  December 1439      Pike procurement begins (ash shafts from northern
                     forests)

  January 1440       Milanese workshops begin production

  January 1440       Officers dispatched to Hungary to train with Hunyadi

  Spring 1440        Tétouan campaign (amphibious rehearsal)

  Summer 1440        Grand muster with wagon training at regional points

  Summer 1440        Artillery-infantry combined exercises

  Late Summer 1440   March to Toledo for final assembly and selection

  September 1440     Milanese equipment arrives; distribution and fitting

  Autumn 1440        Artillery ships to Constantinople

  Winter 1440-41     Eastern wagon construction/procurement

  Spring 1441        Expeditionary force sails for Constantinople
  ------------------ ----------------------------------------------------

CONCLUSION

This plan represents the most comprehensive military preparation in the
history of Castile. It combines proven innovations---Hussite wagon
tactics, Swiss pike discipline, and Castilian artillery
superiority---into a doctrine designed specifically to defeat Ottoman
battlefield advantages. The cost is substantial but sustainable. The
training is demanding but achievable. The objective is nothing less than
breaking Ottoman power in the Balkans and securing Christendom's eastern
frontier.

By the grace of God and the discipline of Christian arms, we shall
prevail.

Prepared by:

Diego de Daza, Chief Administrator

Sir Thomas Beaumont, Commander, Royal Military Academy

Captain Fernán de Vargas, Tactical Advisor

Approved by:

Juan II, King of Castile, León, Aragon, Naples, and Sicily, Defensor
Romaniae
